Non-Road Sediment Sources

Streambank erosion occurs in undisturbed drainages as a part of natural channel geomorphic
processes. Streambank erosion can be accelerated by management activities, for example cattle
trampling on grazing allotments. Along several planning-area streams, bank trampling was
evaluated by Helena National Forest hydrology crews during the summers of 2008-2010 using
the Region 1 Bank Alteration Protocol (Enk et al. 2005). Several reaches were observed to be
impacted by bank trampling (data available in the project record). Although this information is
now somewhat dated, the allotments surveyed are generally operating in the same manner and
trampled streambanks are likely a continuing source of sediment to area streams. The Lake
Helena TMDL estimated that anthropogenic streambank erosion accounted for 11 percent and
16 percent of the total sediment loading in Tenmile Creek and Sevenmile Creek, respectively (US
EPA, 2006). The Little Blackfoot TMDL reports that streambank erosion makes up 18 percent of
the annual sediment load in the drainage (MT DEQ and US EPA 2011). However, much of the
sediment generated from eroding streambanks in both TMDL planning areas comes from
agricultural areas downstream of the forest boundary (US EPA, 2006; MT DEQ and US EPA,
HYDROLOGY - 162

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

2011). There is also likely, accelerated streambank erosion along other streams within the
planning area due to past mining activities and cattle grazing.
Other sources of sediment in planning area streams include natural watershed erosion, erosion
from timber harvest activities on private and federal land and abandoned mining lands (see
cumulative effects discussion). Aside from natural erosion, these sources likely contribute less
sediment than erosion from roads, based on estimates made in the Lake Helena assessment and
other area TMDL reports (US EPA 2006; Montana DEQ 2004; MT DEQ and US EPA 2011).

Non-Sediment Impairments

A common impairment of stream water quality in the study area is elevated metals from past
mining activities. For example, an adit failure in the Tramway Creek drainage delivered elevated
metals loads to the Little Blackfoot River for several weeks during the winter of 2008-2009
(metals contamination in the flow from this adit has greatly diminished since the adit failure).
Another vector for metals transport to streams is contaminated roads, where mine waste rock
was used in road construction (e.g. Rimini Road along Tenmile Creek). Many of the streams in
the planning area do not fully meet designated beneficial uses as a result of metals impairments
(MT DEQ, 2014).

Water Yield

Water yield in most if not all of the drainages in the planning area will likely be measurably
greater than baseline conditions as a result of widespread tree mortality from insect infestation,
in concert with other activities that have removed large numbers of trees from the watersheds
(e.g. green-tree timber harvest) over the past few decades. Baseline conditions are defined to
be the expected water yield given a natural extent of forest cover throughout a watershed. In
practice, the concept of a static baseline water yield is of limited value, as forest cover in
undisturbed watersheds is generally in a state of flux based on several factors, including fire and
insect-induced mortality.

Water yield would not be meaningfully affected by a decision under any alternative of the
Divide Travel Plan, as it would designate only open and closed routes. Even if the plan facilitates
the eventual stabilization or removal of roads from the landscape and recovery of forest on
former road beds, the area of trees gained would be insignificant with respect to basin water
yield at the 6th-HUC scale. Decommissioning several hydraulically connected roads in a
watershed might alter the flow regime marginally, as efficient vectors of runoff (roads) are
removed from the landscape, although this too would be difficult to measure.

Riparian Conditions

Riparian areas include zones at the interface of land and water and are important ecological
niches on the landscape of the analysis area. The condition of riparian areas within the travel
planning area varies widely. Within grazing allotments, riparian areas are generally impacted by
cattle grazing and trampling. Several stream riparian areas were evaluated by Helena National
Forest hydrologic technicians using an abbreviated Proper Functioning Condition (PFC) protocol
(Prichard 1998) during the 2008 to 2010 field seasons (Table 58). Although this dataset is four to
six years old at this time, allotment management has not changed substantially. Thus, riparian
conditions are likely similar to what was observed during the survey years. The PFC approach
specifies field review by an interdisciplinary team of resource specialists, because this dataset
was not collected by such a team, the results presented in
HYDROLOGY - 163

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Table 58 is preliminary. The PFC methodology qualitatively evaluates riparian area vegetation,
channel and floodplain characteristics to arrive at an estimate of how well the riparian area
functions in dissipating flow energy and maintaining floodplain stability during larger flood
events. Past mining, livestock and native ungulate grazing, browsing and trampling and other
land use activities can all negatively impact riparian area form and function. Streams outside of
grazing allotments and legacy mining areas have in the past generally been rated as properly
functioning.

There are many non-riparian wetlands in the travel planning area, however their extent has not
been quantitatively described and their condition is largely unknown. Professional observation
within allotments has shown that wetlands in some locations see degradation from trampling
and grazing. Impacts from recreational activities (camping and campfires, off highway vehicle
use, etc.) have also been observed in non-riparian wetlands.

Hydrology, Environmental Consequences
Effects Common to All Alternatives

Road maintenance and improvements unrelated to this decision, but carried out as part of
routine operations or as part of future projects, would generally reduce sediment delivery from
system routes to streams for a period of years following the work. However, maintenance
backlogs continue to leave many system roads in need of improvement.

Effects Common to All Action Alternatives
The action alternatives would each designate Helena National Forest system routes. Roads or
trails not designated system routes would by default be considered unauthorized routes and
would be closed to motorized use and available for decommissioning in future projects.
Unauthorized routes have been surveyed in some, but not all areas within the planning area and
have been observed in some areas to negatively impact water quality and riparian form and
function. Alternative 1 does not identify unauthorized routes as available for decommissioning.
Thus, implementation of Alternatives 2, 3, 4 or 5 would likely result in somewhat improved
water quality and riparian conditions within the planning area. This conclusion is based on the
assumption that unauthorized routes that impact water quality or riparian conditions would be
decommissioned as watershed improvement projects in the first few years following the
decision. However, the potential unauthorized route decommissioning would not be mandated
by the decision and therefore cannot be considered a direct or indirect effect of the decision.

Alternative 1, No Action
Direct, Indirect and Cumulative Effects
Under alternative 1, no new management actions are proposed. If no new actions are
undertaken, no new management-related water resource impacts would occur. Past and
ongoing management activities, such as road use, OHV use, mining and livestock grazing would
continue to affect water resources. No new additions to watershed-scale cumulative effects
would be predicted, because no new management activities are proposed with alternative 1.

HYDROLOGY - 165

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Irreversible and Irretrievable Commitments
An irretrievable commitment represents a temporary loss of a resource, which can be replaced
over time. An irreversible commitment represents a total loss of a resource, which cannot be
replaced. An irretrievable commitment of alternative 1 would be continued sediment delivery to
streams from the existing road network and continued impact to riparian areas traversed by
roads. There are no irreversible commitments from this alternative.

Alternatives 2, 3, 4, 5
Direct and Indirect Effects
Direct and indirect effects of the four action alternatives are essentially the same and are
therefore presented together. Direct and indirect effects of the action alternatives are also
similar to those of the no-action alternative, in that no new construction is proposed and no
system roads are specified for decommissioning. New construction and decommissioning would
be left to subsequent analysis. However, implementation of all the action alternatives would set
the stage for decommissioning of any unauthorized routes. As stated above, the impacts of
unauthorized routes on water resources in the planning area have not been fully quantified, but
are likely to be considerable.
An additional indirect benefit of the action alternatives to water resources in the planning area
lies in their designation of routes. By placing all routes in the planning area into one of several
categories, the four action alternatives provide the framework for future projects to
decommission or stabilize roads. Any route designated as closed to wheeled motorized vehicles
yearlong could be decommissioned in a separate, subsequent NEPA analysis. The routes that fit
this definition include routes with the designated map code of 01-Res (Closed), 06-Res (oversnow vehicles only), MT-01-Res (trail closed to motorized vehicles) and NS-01-Res (non-system
routes). All of the action alternatives have more miles of roads in these categories that are
within the buffers specified by INFISH because Alternatives 2, 3, 4 and 5 incorporate and close
routes that are currently unclassified. Similarly, roads in these categories under the action
alternatives have a higher number of stream crossings than do those under the no action
alternative, again because of the incorporation of miles that are currently unclassified.
Each of the action alternatives also incorporates a number of miles of currently unclassified
roads that would be designated as open, at least seasonally. Most of these routes are currently
on the landscape and are receiving motorized use. Under the action alternatives, these newly
incorporated routes would add to the Helena National Forest travel system at most 1.1 miles of
open roads within INFISH buffers and three open stream crossings (Table 59 and Table 60). Of
the eight roads that would be added to the system with alternative 5, FSR# 123-001 has the
greatest impact on water resources. This road, in the Ontario Creek drainage, parallels Ontario
Creek for 0.6 miles within the INFISH buffer. The route also has two culvert stream crossings
over tributaries to Ontario Creek and accesses a ford on FSR# 123-A1 (an open route that
connects FSR# 123-001 to FSR# 123). However, FSR# 123-001 provides an alternate route to
FSR# 4104-A1 and closing FSR# 4104-A1 to wheeled-motorized traffic would allow the closure
and stabilization of five stream crossings, including two problematic fords and close an
equivalent distance (0.6 miles) within the INFISH buffer. A route-by-route description for all
proposed unclassified routes is provided in the project record. Although the action alternatives
would incorporate up to 1.1 miles of road within INFISH buffers and three stream crossings, only
the action alternatives provide a mechanism by which to eventually decommission or stabilize
HYDROLOGY - 166

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

stream adjacent roads and unneeded stream crossings, a potential benefit to water quality and
riparian condition.
The potential for road decommissioning does not constitute a direct or indirect effect resulting
from the travel planning decision, but it should be considered a benefit. Additionally, the de
facto recognition of all unauthorized, non-system routes as illegal and available for
decommissioning is an indirect effect of all four action alternatives; in that the full benefit to
watershed values would not be realized until the routes were decommissioned, this decision
would not specify the decommissioning of these routes.

With respect to water quality, the primary difference among the four action alternatives is in the
total number of road/stream crossings and miles of road within INFISH buffers (a 300-foot
buffer distance for fish-bearing and 150-foot buffer for non-fish-bearing streams) available for
future decommissioning or stabilization (Table 60 and Table 61). However, because no road
decommissioning would occur as a direct result of this decision, these differences are generally
not pertinent to direct or indirect effects of the alternatives. There would likely be some indirect
benefit to watershed conditions in the effective closure of roads to motorized use, in that over
time these roadbeds could be expected to revegetate and stabilize. However, without
decompaction and recontouring, restoration of subsurface flow-path connectivity and soil
productivity would not be realized until decades into the future. In any case, the differences do
give alternative 5 the greatest potential for future work that would benefit watershed values.

An additional difference between the four action alternatives occurs with the dispersed camping
rule. As described in chapter 2 of the FEIS, alternatives 2, 3 and 4 would permit off-road
wheeled motorized use within 300 feet of a road or trail for dispersed camping. Alternative 4
would also permit off-road vehicle use within 300 feet of roads for all legal recreational
activities. However, alternative 5 would permit wheeled motorized vehicle travel up to 30 foot
from water and 70 foot from a designated route while still allowing for many of the historic
dispersed campsites, greater than 70 feet from the road to remain. For all action alternatives,
wheeled motorized vehicle travel for camping opportunities would be allowed within the
specified distance of designated system routes, including roads and trails (unless signed
otherwise or specifically closed) as long as:
•
•
•
•

No new permanent routes are created by this activity,
No damage to existing vegetation, soil, or water resource occurs,
Travel off-route does not cross streams and
Travel off-route does not traverse riparian or wet areas.

Dispersed recreation sites currently exist and are heavily used within the planning area.
Implementation of any of the action alternatives would provide for the monitoring and
enforcement of the provisions for resource protection and would ensure that adverse impacts
are minimized. This component is particularly important to the quality of water resources
HYDROLOGY - 169

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

because many dispersed sites are located adjacent to or provide access to waterbodies and lack
the design features found at developed sites to mitigate negative impacts of use. As a result, the
impacts of dispersed recreation use on soils, water quality and riparian resources can be greater
than impacts at developed sites. It is difficult to quantify the positive impact that restrictions for
dispersed recreation would have on water quality and riparian condition; however positive
effects would be realized with the removal of sediment sources and re-establishment of riparian
vegetation in areas previously accessible to dispersed camping. Alternative 5 would provide the
most potential benefits and resource protection, in that this alternative reduces the number of
heavily used dispersed recreation sites in sensitive riparian areas. With the implementation of
the action alternatives, monitoring of dispersed sites and enforcement of the Motorized Vehicle
Use Map (MVUM) established by this decision should help to prevent additional degradation of
water quality and riparian areas by minimizing the negative effects of off-road travel.

Implementing any action alternative for this project could require a programmatic Helena

measurably impact water resources. Although managing seasonal closures would decrease
traffic levels during certain months, it would not directly eliminate the potential for sediment
delivery to streams from adjacent roads or road/stream crossings.

Irreversible and Irretrievable Commitments
Irretrievable commitments of the action alternatives would include continued sediment delivery
to streams from the existing road network and continued impacts to riparian areas traversed by
roads. There are no irreversible commitments from this alternative.

HYDROLOGY - 173

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Cumulative Effects
In addition to the impacts of roads on water quality, riparian condition and stream form and
function, several past and present federal and non-federal activities have affected and continue
to affect water quality, water yield and riparian health in the cumulative effects analysis area.
Past timber harvest has likely caused temporary increases in water yield and sediment delivery,
though these effects generally attenuate over time. In the past, mining has contributed metals
and sediment to stream channels in the watersheds. In some cases, ongoing mining activity
continues to be a chronic source of sediment to streams and of riparian degradation. Old mine
workings can also pose chronic or episodic water quality problems to forest streams, as in the
Tramway Creek (Little Blackfoot) adit plug failure of November 2008. Past pulses of elevated
sediment (e.g. from timber harvest or mining) can remain stored in stream channels (banks,
bed, floodplain) for many years following deposition. Continued grazing in riparian areas and
cattle trailing along streams within grazing allotments would likely continue to contribute
elevated sediment levels to streams in watersheds with grazing allotments. Road work
completed in recent years should reduce erosion and sediment delivery from certain projectarea roads (appendix B). Thus, some past and ongoing activities have been and continue to
generate elevated sediment delivery, whereas other activities will reduce sediment delivery.
This decision would not directly result in measurable additions to or reductions from cumulative
watershed effects.
In planning area watersheds, water yield most likely has been and would continue to be affected
by large-scale tree mortality. Large-scale loss of live trees reduces the volume of water removed
from a watershed by transpiration. Increases in water yield could result in higher peak flows
than would otherwise occur; higher flows have the potential to increase streambank and bed
scour. As discussed above, none of the alternatives would meaningfully affect water yield.
Extensive tree mortality could also potentially affect stream temperature in streams that cross
the affected stands through multiple mechanisms. For instance, whereas reduced shade may
result in an increase in stream temperature, increased base flow resulting from decreased
transpiration could have the opposite effect. Regardless, understory vegetation is generally
unaffected by insect mortality and would continue to provide shade to streams. Furthermore,
understory and riparian vegetation exposed to increased levels of sunlight (due to loss of
overstory canopy) can expand and provide additional shade (Gravelle & Link 2007). None of the
alternatives would measurably influence stream temperature.
Reasonably foreseeable federal and non-federal activities that could affect water quality, water
yield and riparian health in the cumulative effects analysis area include future timber harvest,
fuels-reduction projects, small-scale mining or failure of old mines, continued livestock impacts,
roads and fire. Foreseeable timber harvest and fuels reduction activities in the analysis area (e.g.
Telegraph Vegetation Project, Tenmile-South Helena Project) on the national forest are not
likely to substantially affect water quality or riparian area viability, assuming compliance with
the streamside management zone (SMZ) law and strict adherence to the Montana Department
of Natural Resources and Conservation (DNRC) forestry best management practices (Montana
DNRC 2008). Timber sale road improvements (e.g. Telegraph, Tenmile projects) would be
expected to reduce sediment delivery from project area roads through implementation of road
best management practices. The road impacts on water quality, as outlined in the Affected
Environment section of this report, would not change as a direct result of any of the action
alternatives. However, the action alternatives lay the groundwork for future road stabilization
and decommissioning, which if implemented would reduce sediment delivery from forest roads.
HYDROLOGY - 174

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Other activities that would serve to reduce sediment delivery to streams in project watersheds
would likely be implemented periodically in the future within the cumulative effects analysis
area. Such activities include watershed improvement projects, culvert upgrades and effectively
implemented allotment management plan (AMP) revisions, among others.

Conclusions
Alternative 1, No Action
Currently, many streams do not fully support all beneficial uses within several of the planningarea 6th-HUC watersheds. In some of these impaired streams, beneficial uses are compromised
due at least in part to land use activities off of the Helena National Forest. Under the no action
alternative, full attainment of all beneficial uses would still not be met in planning-area
watersheds. Existing activities (e.g. forest roads) on the Helena National Forest portions of these
watersheds might in some cases not meet the state requirement that “all reasonable land, soil
and water conservation practices have been applied” (ARM 17.30.602) to minimize pollution,
although effects of forest roads and other management practices in place before April 1993 are
exempt from this standard (MCA 75-5-317). This exemption notwithstanding, many of these
roads could be considered to “cause excessive water pollution” (HNF Forest Plan, II/25) and
should thus be “corrected where feasible” (ibid.), or stand in violation of the Forest Plan. Road
maintenance can and should continue in the planning area under this alternative and would
address some chronic sediment sources on the existing road network. However, future road
decommissioning in the planning area would be greatly facilitated by a travel management
decision and would allow for work to restore areas that under existing conditions are chronic
sources of sediment. With these matters considered, alternative 1 would hold the least promise
of the alternatives for future work to reduce the impact of the Forest’s road network on water
quality and riparian conditions.

Alternatives 2, 3, 4, 5
The action alternatives are similar to alternative 1 in that the open-or-closed constraint of this
decision would not specifically provide for actions that would alleviate current water quality
problems in the planning area. Thus, the remarks above under Conclusions—Alternative 1 also
apply to alternatives 2 through 5, with the important exceptions that the action alternatives
would provide the framework for future system road decommissioning.
From the standpoint of protecting watershed values and reducing impacts of the Helena
National Forest travel system on water quality, a travel planning decision that contained specific
road closure measures would be more desirable than one that offered only open-or-closed
prescriptions. Therefore, Helena National Forest hydrology specialists recommend that NEPA
analyses for future decommissioning begin immediately upon finalizing the Divide Travel Plan
Decision, so that routes closed by this decision can be decommissioned as soon as funding
becomes available. Furthermore, many routes that are known sediment sources to streams on
the Montana list of water-quality-limited segments (WQLS) would remain open under all action
alternatives. All action alternatives would also include re-opening of some routes that are
currently closed year-round. However, a road opened by this decision may or may not become a
greater source of sediment, depending on level of use, maintenance, improvements and other
factors. Nevertheless, with respect to water resources, it is recommended that open roads
hydraulically connected to streams should receive improved maintenance, as funding allows; to

HYDROLOGY - 175

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

move towards meeting the sediment reductions recommended in the Little Blackfoot and Lake
Helena TMDL documents.
The action alternatives would realize a net reduction in open-road stream crossings, open-road
miles within INFISH buffers and overall road density. The decision would be a positive step
toward route decommissioning and stabilization, which would result in reduction of sediment
delivery to streams throughout the project area. Thus, any of the action alternatives are
preferable to the no action alternative. Alternative 5 makes the most progress in addressing
road related watershed concerns, but each of the action alternatives would move toward Forest
Plan consistency on the maintenance of acceptable water quality in streams on the Helena
National Forest. The implementation of this plan would also move the Forest toward meeting
the Lake Helena and Little Blackfoot TMDL sediment reduction goals.

Forest Plan Consistency

Although several water bodies in the planning area are not currently meeting state water quality
standards (i.e. several streams are on the Montana 303(d) list of WQLS), the no-action
alternative is in compliance with water-related Forest Plan standards. The proposed travel plan,
under any of the action alternatives, does not specify any activities that would directly result in
the degradation of water quality in the planning area. In this sense, the travel plan is in
compliance with the Forest Plan standard requiring that a project resulting in water pollution be
modified or discontinued (see Regulatory Framework above). The Divide Travel Plan is also
consistent with the Forest Plan standard requiring that BMPs are employed in projects to
minimize non-point-source pollution, in that the decreased number of open routes would allow
limited road improvement funds to be concentrated on fewer roads, potentially decreasing the
maintenance backlog. Additionally, unauthorized routes would be available to be stabilized or
removed from the landscape, which would move the Forest Service towards meeting State
water quality recommendations. While this decision would not directly specify road
improvements or decommissioning, its route designations set the stage for this work.

FISHERIES
Regulatory Framework
1976 National Forest Management Act

Under the National Forest Management Act of 1976 (NFMA), the Forest Service is charged with
maintaining the viability of all existing native and desired non-native vertebrate species in a
planning area. A forest plan must identify management indicator species (MIS) that serve as
proxies for fulfilling this NFMA viability requirement. Westslope cutthroat trout (WCT) is the
fisheries management indicator species on the Helena National Forest. The regulations (36 CFR
219.9) impose a standard by requiring habitat objectives to be established for maintaining
viability of management indicator species throughout a planning area.

Endangered Species Act (Act) of 1973

The Endangered Species Act of 1973 (section 2) is designed to protect imperiled species, which
are officially listed as endangered or threatened, from extinction as a “consequence of economic
growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation.” The stated
purpose of the Endangered Species Act is to provide a means to protect listed species and
FISHERIES - 176

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

“conserve the ecosystems upon which they depend.” Bull trout are listed as a threatened fish
species under the ESA and occur west of the Continental Divide on the Helena National Forest
within the Upper Clark Fork and Blackfoot River sub-basins.
Section 7(a)(2) of the Act states each Federal agency shall, in consultation with the Secretaries
of Interior and Commerce (Secretary), insure that any action they authorize, fund, or carry out is
not likely to jeopardize the continued existence of a listed species or result in the destruction or
adverse modification of designated critical habitat. This section of the Act defines the
consultation process, which is further developed in regulations promulgated at 50 CFR §402.
Section 7(a)(1) of the Act makes clear that all Federal agencies should participate in the
conservation and recovery of listed threatened and endangered species. It directs all other
Federal agencies to utilize their authorities in furtherance of the purposes of the Act by carrying
out programs for the conservation of species listed pursuant to the Act. Under this provision,
Federal agencies often enter into partnerships with the Fish and Wildlife Service for
implementing and funding conservation agreements, management plans and recovery plans
developed for listed species.
Pertinent also to this project is road management guidance in the biological opinion (BO) on
Forest Plans (USDI 1998, pgs 23, 24, 71-73, 82, 89, 90, 94, 95, 100) that emphasize commitments
to implement existing standards in INFISH for ESA listed fish. Specific INFISH standards RF-2, RF3 and RF-4 will be a priority as discussed under the Helena National Forest Plan. From a
dispersed and developed recreation aspect, standard RM-2 (pg 9) specifies where adjustment
measures such as education, use limitations, traffic control devices and/or specific site closures
fail to meet Riparian Management Objectives and avoid adverse effects to native fish habitat,
eliminate the practice or occupancy. The 1998 biological opinion (pg 89) emphasizes given the
negative impact of roads on aquatic species and a habitat, moving forward on the development
of comprehensive plans addressing road system related effects is extremely important to bull
trout conservation.

Helena National Forest Plan

Direction for fisheries management under the Helena National Forest Plan (USDA 1986)
emphasizes maintenance or enhancement of cold-water habitat and water quality to meet the
needs of fisheries (Forest Plan pages II-1 and II-4). The general forestwide standard (pg II-22)
states: “Maintain quality water and habitat for fish by coordinating activities and by direct
habitat improvement.” The analysis will also identify opportunities, if any exist, for mitigating
adverse effects on water related beneficial uses.

For road management (pgs II-31 to II-32), the Plan states that unacceptable damage to soils,
watershed, fish, wildlife, or historical/archaeological sites will be mitigated by road restrictions
or other road management actions as necessary. Forest specialists representing soils and
watershed shall provide input to the road maintenance planning process to verify standards,
identify rehabilitation needs and designate roads which should be permanently closed for
resource protection. Road standard #3 (pg II-30) provides where forest specialists representing
soils, watershed and fisheries shall identify potential soil erosion, water quality and fisheries
problems and provide input, including project design features or mitigation measures, to the
development of road design standards.
In riparian areas, page II-35 of the Forest Plan specifies that wet meadows and wet areas are
closed to OHV use. Construction of roads will avoid stream course encroachment and
FISHERIES - 177

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

channelization, including the avoidance of all riparian areas except to cross them. In addition,
the Plan states the Forest will provide for vegetative cover adjacent to streams to serve as a
filter strip for sediment and maintain optimum water temperatures, as well as provide large
debris for long-term instream fish cover and pooling. For stream crossings, Plan standards call
for stream crossing structure design that allows free water flow and fish passage. Additionally,
the Plan requires riparian areas are to be managed compatible with dependent wildlife species.
The Forest Plan (USDA 1986) was amended on August 30, 1995 to incorporate the INFISH (USDA
Forest Service 1995). This interim strategy was designed to provide additional protection for
existing populations of native trout, especially bull trout, outside the range of anadromous
(moving from ocean to fresh water to spawn) fish, on 22 National Forests in the Pacific
Northwest, Northern and Intermountain Regions throughout the Columbia River Basin including
the Helena National Forest. This strategy, therefore, applies to riparian habitats for only those
watersheds west of the Continental Divide in the Divide Travel Planning area. INFISH
established riparian management objectives (RMOs) and riparian habitat conservation areas
(RHCAs) including project and site-specific standards and guidelines for drainages west of the
Divide in the interior Columbia River. INFISH standards pertinent to this project include road
standards RF-2, RF-3 and RF-4. RF-3c requires closing, stabilizing, or obliterating roads not
needed for future management activities and prioritizing these actions based on
current/potential damage to inland native fish in priority watersheds.

Forest Service Manual

The Forest Service Manual (FSM) contains legal authorities, policies, instructions and guidance
needed in the proper management of aquatic resources. Where other resource activities have
potential to impact fish habitat, FSM 2634 provides for integrating prescriptions during project
planning to help meet fisheries habitat objectives and to mitigate adverse impacts of resource
management activities. After a half-century of rigorous research, fine sediment originating from
a broad array of human activities has been singled out as the principal factor in the degradation
of stream fisheries (Waters 1995, pg 79). Water quality management shall recognize sediment
as the major non-point pollutant from Forest Service lands and establish guidelines and
procedures for preventing unacceptable resource impacts from introduced sediment (FSM
2542.02).
In addition, FSM 2672.1 imposes a strict standard for treatment of sensitive species. The Forest
Service designates westslope cutthroat trout (WCT) on the Regional Forester’s Sensitive Species
(RFSS) list and therefore, confers special attention in WCT management to ensure their viability
and preclude trends toward endangerment that would result in warranting listing under the
Endangered Species Act. A biological evaluation (BE) is required to be completed to display the
effects of the selected alternative.

Assumptions
This analysis draws upon the following assumptions:
•
•

Research confirms roads have the greatest effect of all forest management practices on
erosion and sedimentation (Megahan and King 2004).
The stream road proximity indicator (high risk roads less than 300 feet of a stream)
provides a reasonable approximation of the hydrologic connectivity (sedimentation) and
physical alterations on streams.

FISHERIES - 178

Environmental Impact Statement

•
•

•

•

•

•

•
•

•

Divide Travel Plan

The road-stream intersections indicator provides a reasonable estimate of stream
crossings that act as sediment delivery sites and fragment aquatic habitats.
Road-stream intersections and roads within 300 feet of a stream (high risk roads)
respond most predictably and reliably to the action alternatives as a barometer of
potential change.
An important effect to salmonid fish and habitat relates to increased sediment delivery
and deposition due to high risk roads and stream route intersections. (USDA FS 1998;
USDA FS 1999, pgs 143-145, 179-180)
Excess sediment delivery and deposition in stream channels is an important source of
mortality to trout (Chapman 1988, Waters 1995). Other variables (temperature,
dissolved oxygen, food, cover and angler harvest) are outside the scope of this analysis
as the project focuses on designating routes open for motorized vehicle use and gating
select routes identified for administrative closure.
Critical channel reaches (core sampling reaches) within a watershed generally represent
an estimate of sediment effects on spawning habitat for the watershed as a whole.
(Stowell et al., 1983)
For the purposes of this analysis, roads defined as “closed” include all those with the
following restriction codes: 01, 06, NS-01, MT-01-Res, NM and NOMTR. The “06”
restricted roads would be closed year-round to motorized use except where
snowmobiles would be allowed due to surrounding lands available for over-snow use.
All high risk roads, whether open or closed in this travel analysis can be considered for
future obliteration/recontour projects to protect soil, watershed and fish resources.
It is assumed that over-snow travel with snowmobiles presents no sediment risk to
streams except at stream ford crossings.
Sediment risk associated with winter travel increases on high risk road segments when
wheeled vehicles needed to accommodate both motorized (snowmobile) and nonmotorized recreationists travel these routes during periods of winter/springtime thaws.
The erosion and rutting hazard on roads becomes high under rapidly warming weather
conditions (e.g chinook winds) increasing the potential for road top materials to enter
the surface water system. (Burroughs & King 1989; Kennedy 1997; Walch 2008)
The closure of existing open roads tends to decrease road surface erosion and sediment
delivery to the surface water system over the long-term due to passive revegetation of
the road prism.

Information Used
Information on fish populations within the Divide Travel Planning area was drawn from updated
GIS fishery spatial layers and associated linked data. Geographic information systems spatial
layers were derived from a variety of sources including past and ongoing fisheries electrofishing
surveys conducted by Forest Service and Fish, Wildlife and Parks fisheries personnel over the
past 30 years, WCT sub-basin updates in 2009, WCT biological evaluations, past NEPA fisheries
reports and bull trout biological assessments in consultation with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife
Service (USFWS). Additionally, information specific to bull trout watersheds came from
watershed baselines for the Little Blackfoot River portion of the Upper Clark Fork bull trout
Section 7 Watershed (USDA 2000) including any updates to those baselines for consultation with
the USFWS.

FISHERIES - 179

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Relevant to measures used to evaluate effects of roads on fisheries resources, GIS road and
stream GIS coverages helped to estimate the number of stream/road intersections (culverts,
bridges, fords) and miles of high risk roads (those inside INFISH buffers). In lieu of complete
field data across portions or entire areas encompassed by twenty-six (26) NRCS 6th field HUCs,
the transportation and stream coverages were attributed in GIS as an aid to project ongoing and
potential effects on fish habitat for the various alternatives. A roads database for the Divide
Travel Planning area was the basis for monitoring any changes in measures used to evaluate
potential effects on fish habitat.
Information to help characterize fish habitat conditions in the planning area was drawn from
past sediment and riparian monitoring data, cursory fish habitat condition surveys, fish species
and distribution surveys, road sediment surveys and culvert assessments on the Helena National
Forest. All resource information was collected by Forest Service fisheries and hydrology
personnel for over the past 28 years. Other sources included previous analysis specific to the
Little Blackfoot River and Tenmile Creek drainages, the Divide Landscape Analysis, stream permit
applications and westslope cutthroat trout and bull trout biological evaluations. Watershed
baselines for the Little Blackfoot River portion of the Upper Clark bull trout Section 7 Watershed
(USDA 2000) including updates to the various sub-watershed documents were also used.
Field data from road sediment inventories and culvert inventories/assessments since 2008 in
sub-watersheds south of Highway 12 in the project area are mostly complete and on-going.
These surveys will provide a baseline comparison for the indicators and observed effects on the
ground within this analysis area. Road surveys within the Divide Travel Plan area north of
Highway 12 are ongoing and will be strategically conducted to address the highest risk areas for
listed species and their habitat.

Methodology and Scientific Accuracy
This report follows procedures outlined in Report FS-683, Roads Analysis: Informing Decisions
about the National Forest Transportation System (USDA Forest Service, 1999) customized to
local situations. The effects section takes the broad scale forestwide roads analysis down to the
finer sub-watershed scale (6th field hydrologic unit code (HUC)) specific to the Divide Travel Plan
area. Key road related issues identified are: stream substrate conditions, road proximity to
streams and stream crossings/intersections. Two measures determined most useful at
quantifying these important road/fish habitat interactions were: 1) high risk roads (roads within
INFISH buffers) and 2) stream/road intersections (crossings).
These two measures, used to evaluate effects, were chosen with an understanding about how
the mechanisms impact fish habitat (sediment, channel alterations and habitat fragmentation)
are tied specifically to high risk roads and stream crossings. Therefore, the road and stream
coverages were attributed in GIS for all sub-watersheds encompassed by the project area. This
GIS based analysis systematically examined the motorized transportation system aimed at the
two measures in evaluating potential effects on fish habitat. Determining miles of high risk road
involved buffering the stream coverage by a 300-foot distance each side of streams for fishbearing habitat and 150-foot distance for non-fish-bearing streams consistent with INFISH
riparian habitat conservation areas (buffers), then clipping out all road segments within these
buffers as a reasonable approximation of the length of high risk roads in each sub-watershed.
Stream/road intersection points were produced by intersecting the road and stream layers and
placing the intersection nodes into point coverage for each sub-watershed.

FISHERIES - 180

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Streams delineated on topographic maps may, however, under represent actual streams;
conversely crenulated contour coverages may over represent streams depending on the rules
applied and individual crenulation (USDAFS 1999, pgs 140 and 180). The accuracy of the
indicators in this analysis is probably moderate at best. Past analyses in the North Belts Travel
Plan found that comparing GIS based stream/road intersections with actual on-the-ground
measurements amongst four arterial routes indicated the GIS coverages over represented the
amount of stream/road intersections by approximately 30 percent. Conversely, field checking
stream/road intersections for the Cabin Gulch Vegetation Treatment project found that GISbased stream/road intersections were under represented up to 45 percent of the actual number
of intersections in East Cabin Gulch, yet GIS coverages over represented this indicator 21
percent in the North Fork Deep Creek drainage. Therefore, this analysis likely provides a
reasonable approximation of relative differences between the alternatives. Ground truthing can
provide accurate data as it relates to actual miles of high risk roads and number of stream/road
intersections in a watershed. Portions of the analysis area have been ground-truthed and this
monitoring is ongoing.
To separate the differences amongst alternatives since there is no ground disturbance or
physical changes planned to the transportation system under this “open/closed” roads
administrative decision, a risk/benefit assessment was performed for each road segment by subwatershed. The benefits of closing currently open segments of road to motorized use yearround is based on the premise that erosion and sedimentation are reduced as a function of
passive re-vegetation and lack of motorized disturbance over closed roadbeds in the long-term.
Additionally, permanently closing roads sets the stage for future road treatment opportunities
that fully restore slopes and drainages impacted by roads to contour over the long-term.
Conversely, the consequence of opening currently closed segments of road to motorized use
relates to the potential to destabilize the road bed and inhibit re-vegetation over the long-term.
Additionally, access decisions to open closed roads have implications for the extent and nature
of recreational use and subsequent effects on fish habitat (Clark and Gibbons 1991, pg 476).

Fisheries, Affected Environment
Introduction
This section is organized under two major subsections: fish populations and fish habitat. The
first discusses the current known distribution and status of fish populations in the Divide Travel
Plan area including discussions about non-native and native fish species that occupy project area
streams. The second subsection gives an overview of stream habitat conditions and trends as
influenced by past and ongoing land-use activities that can affect fish populations.

Analysis Area
The Divide Travel Planning area encompasses twenty-six (26) National Resource Conservation
Service (NRCS) 6th field HUCs, commonly referred to as sub-watersheds. Four sub-watersheds
are dropped from the fisheries analysis area since there are no fish populations and/or roads
occurring in the portion of these sub-watersheds encompassed by the planning area. Therefore,
22 sub-watersheds - seven east of the Continental Divide and 15 west of the Divide are
considered for potential effects to fisheries resources in this travel planning decision.
Natural processes and landuse activities unique at the sub-watershed scale influence local fish
habitats independently of other sub-watershed units. Logically the geographic unit of
preference is delineated at the sub-watershed (6th-field HUC) scale as the range for examining
FISHERIES - 181

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

direct/indirect and cumulative effects in the fisheries analysis area. It is possible, however, for
water quality in a sub-watershed to be influenced by activities in another sub-watershed located
upstream from it.

Fish Populations in Planning Area
Trout species occupy approximately 140.7 miles of stream in the planning area. Other fish
species found in the planning area include longnose suckers and sculpins. Appendix A of the
fisheries specialist report shows maps that display the current known distribution of native and
non-native salmonid trout in the Divide Travel Plan area respectively.
In the Upper Missouri sub-basin side of the Divide Travel Plan area non-native trout occupy
approximately 27.7 miles (96 percent) of fish habitat while native WCT (90+ percent pure)
occupy about 1.6 miles (5.5 percent) of available fish habitat. In the Upper Clark Fork sub-basin
side of the planning area, non-native trout occupy about 73.1 miles (65.3 percent) of fishbearing habitat while native WCT (those populations 90+ percent pure included those untested)
occupy about 109.7 miles (98 percent) of fish habitat. Although rare, bull trout, a native char
listed as “threatened” under the Endangered Species Act, had occupied about 20.9 miles (18.7
percent) of fish habitat in the Upper Clark Fork sub-basin side of the planning area; however,
recent electrofishing surveys conducted from 2000 to 2010 suggest these numbers are
questionable. The Little Blackfoot River local bull trout population is believed nearly extinct
based on extensive sampling efforts by Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks surveys in 2007 and
2008 and sampling by Forest Service fishery personnel in 2010 (USDA 2013, pgs 69-71).
The Divide Travel Plan area straddles both east and west sides of the Continental Divide and
includes six fish-bearing sub-watersheds in the Upper Missouri 4th field HUC (sub-basin) and 15
fish-bearing sub-watersheds in the Upper Clark Fork 4th field HUC. Table 64 lists six subwatersheds east of the Divide having streams supporting a fishery. One of the seven eastside
watersheds having no fish populations on forest is Lower Tenmile Creek and is therefore not
listed in Table 64.
Table 65 outlines the 15 sub-watersheds west of the Divide having fish-bearing streams.
A summary of key aspects of known fish populations in the planning area is provided below in
two separate tables. Table 64 summarizes aspects of fish populations found in the Upper
Missouri sub-basin (east) side of the project area and Table 65 summarizes aspects of fish
populations for the Upper Clark Fork sub-basin (west) side of the project area.
