In summary, there are approximately 329 stream/road intersections and 125.2 miles of high risk
roads in the planning area under Forest Service jurisdiction. Currently about 34 percent (112) of
the Forest Service stream crossings and 23 percent (29.24 miles) of Forest Service high risk roads
are closed to wheeled motorized use in the planning area. Indirect effects associated with the
transportation system relate specifically to access opportunities for concentrated recreational
uses along the stream-valley corridor as well as disturbance associated with the presence of
high risk ford crossings. There are nine undeveloped Forest Service dispersed campsites along
the Little Blackfoot River and seven fords in TES fish habitat; six fords occur west of the Divide
and one ford occurs east of the Divide in Skelly Gulch. The importance of Skelly Gulch is it is one
of very few streams that support a core conservation (100 percent genetically pure) population
FISHERIES - 210

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

of westslope cutthroat trout east of the Continental Divide in Montana. As a general reference
point, under pristine or unmanaged conditions the measurement indicators evaluated and
summarized under Table 69 would zero out for this exercise.
Table 66, Table 67 and Table 69 provide clear evidence how the current existing transportation
system in the planning area is the primary contributor for accelerated erosion and sediment
loading, altered channel morphology and fragmented fish habitat and populations in most subwatersheds in the Divide Travel Plan area. A screening of 6th field HUCs in the Divide area shows
that Upper Tenmile Creek, Telegraph Creek and Upper Dog Creek appear the most heavily
impacted sub-watersheds as a function of the transportation network. Those HUCs
experiencing additional risks from dispersed campsites and high risk fords include Little
Blackfoot River-Hat Creek, Little Blackfoot River-Larabee Gulch and Ontario Creek. This
represents a departure from optimum salmonid habitat compared to unmanaged/pristine
conditions and an ongoing effect of the transportation system discussed further under the
cumulative effects discussion below.
Amongst westslope cutthroat trout sub-watersheds east of the Continental Divide, Skelly Gulch
and Greenhorn Creek are most at risk from the transportation system. The Greenhorn Creek
westslope cutthroat trout population may have already become extinct based on 2010 to 2012
electrofishing surveys by Forest Service and Montana Department Fish Wildlife and Parks
fisheries crews. For westslope cutthroat trout sub-watersheds west of the Divide, those most at
risk from roads support isolated (resident) westslope cutthroat trout populations. These include
Snowshoe Creek, Carpenter Creek and North Trout Creek. The remaining westslope cutthroat
trout fishery west of the Divide appears mostly to be a connected network of fish habitat
(metapopulation) with a fluvial component occurring in Dog Creek and the Little Blackfoot River
upstream from Elliston. For bull trout habitat in the planning area, Dog Creek downstream of
the Forest boundary and the mainstem Little Blackfoot River and Ontario Creek remain at high
risk as a function of the primary and secondary indicators outlined in Table 69.

Population Viability
Westslope cutthroat trout are the fish management indicator species of concern for the Helena
National Forest that represent a measure of the effects of management activities on habitat
with the objective of ensuring population viability (Forest Plan pg II-17).
A formal population viability analysis is restricted to the use of quantitative modeling that
estimates risk of extinction over a specified time period, typically 100 years (Ralls et al. 2002, pgs
522-523). These mathematical exercises can be expensive requiring comprehensive data about
many factors influencing probability of extinction for a population. Moreover, there are no
consensus guidelines on when and how population viability analysis should be applied (Ralls et
al 2002, pg 521) and insufficient data to build an appropriate model has proven not feasible to
this situation. In practice, agency biologists must assess whether a proposed action will increase
the likelihood of loss of viability or lead to a trend toward federal listing of a sensitive species
from more limited information and resources.
This viability analysis focuses on westslope cutthroat trout and relies on a recommended
alternative method of risk assessment based on viability models by Ruggiero et al. (1994) that
center on criteria established by Rieman et al. (1993). More detailed physical and biological
effects upon sensitive westslope cutthroat trout and listed bull trout are reserved for two
separate framework documents, a biological evaluation for westslope cutthroat trout and a
biological assessment for bull trout.
FISHERIES - 211

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Briefly, these more in depth biological analyses borrow from concepts presented in Ruggiero et
al. (1994) in conjunction with criteria established by Rieman et al. (1993) such that an analysis of
population viability is fundamentally about birth, death, immigration and emigration rates and
how environmental factors affect these rates over time (Ruggiero et al. 1994, pg 366). Select
habitat attributes considered significant to fish and sensitive to land management disturbances
were reviewed in Overton et al. (1995, pg 1). Research has shown how increasing and
decreasing levels of sediment in trout reproductive habitat is the common denominator
affecting trout embryo and fry survival rates negatively and positively (Waters 1995).
Once fine sediments increase beyond average natural levels in trout spawning habitat (typically
28 to 30 percent on Helena National Forest streams), the reproductive quality of that habitat
diminishes proportionately resulting in corresponding declines in fry production. Risk of
increasing the amount of fine sediments in fish spawning habitat rises in drainages as the
amount of high risk roads and stream/road intersections increases.
In reference to the indicators in Table 69, direct and indirect effects to sensitive westslope
cutthroat trout and listed bull trout (and other salmonids) vary amongst the 6th field HUCs as a
function of changes in the amount of open stream/road intersections and miles of high risk road
open in a sub-watershed. Generally, the risk for negative effects to salmonid embryo/fry
production including growth and survival increases when more crossings and high risk roads
become open and vice versa. Exceptions to this rule can occur whenever key crossings or high
risk roads occur in TES habitat that do not change in spite of a net increase/decrease of
crossings or roads in other non-fish-bearing streams within the same HUC or sub-watershed.
Details how these effects indicators relate to the effects specific to each 6th field HUC are
reserved for the biological evaluation and biological assessment for the selected alternative. A
qualitative overview for the Divide Travel Plan area concerning road effects upon listed bull
trout, sensitive westslope cutthroat trout and western pearlshell mussel common to all
alternatives is provided below in Table 70.

impossible to measure exactly and the science of watershed management has not produced the
tools or techniques to allow managers the capability to quantify cumulative effects with
precision and accuracy. Natural ecosystems exhibit wide variation, complexities and
uncertainties that result in generalized expressions of combined effects.

Divide Travel Plan

Although measuring the effects of any project in the context of past and ongoing actions cannot
be predicted or measured precisely, it is commonly accepted in watershed practice that the
streambed is the ultimate integrator of land-use activities including natural processes unique to
a given drainage. The common denominator of various land-use actions affecting fish habitat is
excess sediment in the streambed beyond natural background levels (Meehan 1991, pg 5-6).
Hence, baseline conditions and the cumulative effect of proposed actions are best measured in
the streambed where sediment accrues in critical reaches. Fine sediment in salmonid spawning
gravels is the accepted indicator of current habitat conditions and trends on the Helena National
Forest.
Helena National Forest fish biologists rely on critical (response) reaches for sampling fine
sediments in spawning habitat using McNeil substrate core sampling methodologies (Platts et al.
1983, pgs 17-20; Bunte and Abt 2001, pgs 30-31 and 203-205). Critical reaches are
representative stream segments that reflect changes in fish habitat as a function of altered
sediment yields upstream of the reach of interest (Stowell et al. 1983). This approach is applied
as a practical means to assess existing (baseline) conditions of salmonid spawning habitat from a
host of land-use activities, particularly roads. It is also useful to help monitor trends in the
quality of salmonid spawning habitat in response to disturbance activities in a drainage.
Reference sediment levels for the Helena National Forest gathered in the 1980s to 2000s relied
on McNeil core data from unmanaged drainages or undisturbed portions of drainages on the
Helena National Forest. It was found that 30 percent fines represented a plausible mean
reference value of fine sediment levels in salmonid spawning habitat and ± 9.9 percent about
the mean is assumed to be a reasonable measure of natural variation for fisheries management
goals based on data collected from Helena National Forest streams matching Lake Helena 303(d)
listed streams. This would equate to fine sediment levels within the range of approximately 20
to 40 percent at most sites in unmanaged drainages.
McNeil core data was obtained from four streams in unmanaged tributaries in the planning
area. Two streams, No Grass Creek and Bison Creek, lie within the Electric Peak roadless area.
The other two are unnamed tributaries that lie outside roadless areas but have no roads or
vehicle crossings upstream from the sampled reach. Average sediment levels for these streams
measured 28.9 percent, 36.9 percent, 31.4 percent and 30.2 percent respectively with a
weighted average of the means for all four streams at 31.9 percent. For this analysis, 30 percent
and 31.9 percent are used as benchmarks to judge the degree of cumulative effects on area
streams using ± 9.9 percent either side of the mean as a reasonable measure of natural variation
for salmonid spawning habitat.

Reasonably Foreseeable Future Actions
Reasonably foreseeable projects or programs considered for review were drawn from the
master list provided (see appendix B). Foreseeable actions are discussed qualitatively in terms
of how they might influence trends in sedimentation and subsequently, salmonid spawning
habitat.
The Telegraph Creek Mountain Pine Beetle (MPB) Salvage project involves the removal of
mountain pine beetle infested stands of mostly lodgepole pine trees on about 8,000 acres of
land within the Telegraph Creek, Ontario Creek and Mike Renig 6th field HUCs. This also includes
a pre-commercial thinning component. There may be accelerated erosion and sediment
delivery into downstream fisheries habitat from high risk roads proposed for log hauling and
access to and from treatment units. Each large-scale vegetation treatment project has a road
FISHERIES - 215

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

improvement package with mitigation and design measures intended to sequester sediment as
an important resource protection measure of the project. With implementation of the road
improvement component, the risk of accelerating sediment delivery into streams within the
three sub-drainages is predicted to be low. There would be high risk for short-term sediment
increases during initial road improvement stages as specified segments of high risk roads would
be subject to temporary ground disturbance in preparation for hauling logs.
An important element common to all alternatives has been added to the Telegraph Creek
Mountain Pine Beetle Salvage project. This would involve the replacement of the large ford on
the Little Blackfoot River Figure 3 associated with road # 4100 with a bridge. This would
markedly mitigate the ongoing impacts from the current large ford by reducing sediment
delivery to surface waters and eliminating direct instream disturbance from wheeled motorized
use in TES fish habitat. In addition, there would be permanent removal of the bridge upstream
of the ford associated with road # 123 (Ontario Creek Road), including removal of all road fill
(and two overflow pipes) that bisects the Little Blackfoot River floodplain. This would return an
area of the Little Blackfoot River floodplain back to natural functioning condition. Access to
Ontario Creek would be via a new road segment that branches off from road # 4100 on the east
side of the Little Blackfoot River and connects back to road # 123 avoiding the Little Blackfoot
and Ontario Creek floodplains.
On the Upper Missouri River sub-basin side of the planning area, the Tenmile Road
Improvement project would likely reduce sediment levels in Tenmile Creek. This project
involves re-aligning several road segments, replacing three bridges and paving about six miles of
county road # 695 from Hwy 12 to the community of Rimini. Therefore, this project would likely
risk delivering some fine sediment into nearby Tenmile Creek in the short-term because it
parallels Tenmile Creek up to the Rimini townsite and involves some instream work associated
with replacing three bridges. Ground disturbance activities associated with the project would
increase sediment risk until paving and re-vegetation of disturbed areas is complete. In the
long-term, there would be some decreases in the amount of road sediment into nearby Tenmile
Creek due to the paving of this road. This may be offset somewhat by county winter sanding
operations expected for this route.
Road drainage repairs are planned on roads 136 (Ophir Cr), 314 (Elliston Cr to Spotted Dog Cr),
335 (Sweeney Cr), 571 (Dog/Hope Cr), 708 (Snowshoe Cr), 1805 (Austin Cr) and 1855 (upper Dog
Cr). A total of about 54 miles of road would be re-bladed/reshaped with approximately 286
drain dips installed and 12 cattle guards cleaned of silt. One new 18 inch diameter CMP culvert
is proposed at an existing crossing. These improvements would likely risk short-term sediment
increases to fish habitat from initial disturbance of the road bed. There would be a long-term
sediment reduction from the road bed with these drainage improvements in Upper Dog,
Snowshoe Creek, Ophir Creek, Greenhorn Creek and the Little Blackfoot River-Elliston 6th field
HUCs.

Effects Common to All Alternatives

The physical presence of the transportation system as it relates to high risk road segments and
associated stream crossings and dispersed campsites outlined in Table 69 remain on the
landscape as an ongoing (cumulative) effect regardless of any decision to administratively close
or open roads. No alternative under this decision would directly eliminate or relocate the
physical presence of those features from stream corridors as the Divide Travel Plan Decision
includes only open or closed designations. Therefore, sediment delivery from high risk roads
FISHERIES - 216

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

remains a common element in all alternatives simply due to where and how certain road
segments are hydrologically connected to the stream system. Additionally, large volumes of
sediment held in storage as roadfills associated with some culverts remain at risk of being
unleashed downstream into fish habitat. Where stream crossings and roads encroach on
streams there would continue to be alterations of channel morphology and disruption to
floodplain processes resulting in less pool frequency, less bank cover, reduced spawning gravels,
higher energy gradients and partially fragmented fish habitat.
A reasonably foreseeable federal action common amongst all alternatives is additional review of
roads to determine which segments on both open and closed roads are having adverse effects
to inland native fish habitat prerequisite to developing a plan to minimize those effects. Such
future federal action would move the Forest closer in meeting the intent of the Conservation
Strategy for Bull Trout in Western Montana by cataloging road sediment sources and identifying
opportunities to reduce sediment delivery.

Effects Common to All Action Alternatives

Each action alternative has the common element to either close or open a pre-determined
amount of high risk roads and associated crossings and to place seasonal restrictions on some
routes in the planning area. This would directly affect the nature and extent of motorized
recreational use in riparian corridors and indirectly affect fish habitat (Clark and Gibbons 1991,
pg 476). Opening high risk routes that are currently closed would potentially accelerate
sedimentation and disturb fish habitat while closing high risk routes would have the reverse
effect.

On the other hand, closing most high risk roads and associated crossings would likely result in
road surfaces becoming passively re-vegetated over the long-term, thereby reducing sediment
runoff into the stream system. Roads proposed for closure would also improve opportunities
for future road obliteration and removal of crossings under an implementation plan that would
help restore watershed function and fish habitat.
Under action alternatives 2 through 4, the proposed 300 foot language for the planning area
would allow wheeled motorized travel off designated routes up to 300 feet with some
restrictions intended to mitigate potential resource damage. Unless signed, wheeled motorized
travel would be allowed within 300 feet of designated routes as long as:
•
•
•
•

No new permanent routes are created;
No damage to existing vegetation, soils or water resource occurs;
Travel off-route does not cross streams; and
Travel off-route does not traverse riparian or wet areas.

Without clearly defined designated routes to dispersed campsites, however, there is potential
for the creation of new user-created routes and dispersed camps at public user’s discretion.
Under alternative 5, dispersed camping and associated parking would be more limited to 70 feet
or less from the edge of a designated route using the same restrictions (above) under the 300
foot language for action alternatives 2 through 4. In addition, vehicle travel would be limited no
closer than 30 feet from streams or other bodies of water. Consequently, the potential for
creation of additional user-created routes and dispersed campsites that could risk damage to
streams at public users’ discretion becomes substantially reduced or minimized under
alternative 5. Clearly defined restrictions in this sense would help reduce confusion amongst
FISHERIES - 217

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

users how far is acceptable to travel off designated routes and what constitutes damage to
vegetation, soils, or water resources.

Alternative 1, No Action
Direct and Indirect Effects
The no action alternative has the direct effect of maintaining the status quo in terms of open
high risk roads and stream crossings in the planning area see Table 66 and Table 67. Currently
there are 125.2 miles of high risk Forest Service roads and 329 stream crossings in the planning
area. Approximately 77 percent of the Forest Service high risk roads and 66 percent of Forest
Service stream crossings would remain open to wheeled motorized use. The indirect effect of
no action would be continued risk for accelerated sediment delivery into the surface water
system and sediment accrual into fish habitat over natural background levels due to roads.
Dispersed recreational campsites associated with the Forest Service transportation system in
the planning area south of Hwy 12 totaled 46 in 2005. Nine of these dispersed campsites are
located adjacent to streams: eight are on the Little Blackfoot River and one is on Ontario Creek.
Surveys found these nine dispersed campsites inhibit attainment of riparian management
objectives under INFISH. Lacking measures to address concentrated recreation use at each of
these sites, the direct effect of the no action alternative would be continued concentrated
recreation use at these nine campsites that indirectly generates observable impacts see Table
68 to stream-riparian habitat at these dispersed campsites.
Seven unimproved fords on TES fish habitat associated with the existing transportation system
would also remain under this alternative. Six fords are currently open and one closed to
motorized vehicle use. Four fords (three are open) occur in documented bull trout habitat and
the other three open fords occur on sensitive westslope cutthroat trout streams. The direct
effect of no action would be to maintain the status quo of leaving open six fords to recurring
wheeled vehicle traffic. The indirect effect would be ongoing motorized vehicle disturbance to
the channel at open fords, which exacerbates sediment delivery and risks direct mortality to the
embryonic and fry life stages of bull trout and/or westslope cutthroat trout at those crossings.

Irreversible and Irretrievable Commitments
There would be no irreversible commitment or permanent loss of future options in regards to
the existing road system. Under no action there is always the possibility for any road, closed or
open, that is adversely affecting water quality, stream function, TES fish habitat or public safety,
to be removed or relocated so that stream processes can be restored that would benefit water
quality and fish populations. This would occur under a separate NEPA analysis.
There would be an irretrievable (temporary) commitment of resources in the matter of ongoing
road sediment delivery to fish-bearing habitat due to some road locations resulting in a direct
surface flow path (hydrologic connection) to planning area streams. Approximately 17.4
percent of the entire transportation system consists of Forest Service high risk roads, including
associated Forest Service stream/road intersections that can cause an irretrievable commitment
or temporary reduction in fish habitat quality restorable by eliminating or relocating those
particular roads. High risk roads when left untreated would continue being an ongoing
cumulative effect that diminishes the fish production capabilities of fish habitat within the
project area.

FISHERIES - 218

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Culverts present an ongoing risk for releases of substantial stores of sediment in the form of
roadfills at culvert crossings including potential barriers to fish migration. Culverts that either
have not been removed or upgraded with bridges or aquatic organisms passage-compliant
structures designed to pass 100-year floods impose an irretrievable commitment upon streamriparian dependent fisheries.

Cumulative Effects
Past, present and reasonably foreseeable future actions applicable to Divide Travel Plan project
sub-watersheds are addressed in appendix B. The transportation system in the project area was
excluded from this list as it is addressed in detail here and in the background discussion for fish
habitat under the fisheries affected environment section above.
Table 66 and Table 67 of the affected environment section provide a quantitative overview of
all the stream/road intersections and miles of high risk roads for the various 6th field HUCs (subwatersheds) of the planning area. Each table treats these two indicators of effect by addressing
them as either open or closed status per sub-watershed.
There is a total of about 719 miles of road in the planning area including National Forest System
routes and routes under other ownership. About 165 miles are considered high risk roads that
pose a risk for chronic excessive sediment delivery to the surface water system, fragment
stream habitat and/or alter stream-floodplain functions. The Forest Service maintains
jurisdiction on about 125.2 miles of the high risk roads and 29.24 miles (23 percent) of these are
closed under the no action alternative. Non- Forest Service roads account for the remaining
39.5 miles of high risk roads; these roads represent an ongoing cumulative effect to the surface
water system in the planning area outside Forest Service management.
There are also currently 439 stream/road intersections (crossings) in the planning area. The
Forest Service has jurisdiction on about 329 crossings and 112 Forest Service crossings (33
percent) are closed under the no action alternative. Stream crossings are principal access sites
for road sediment into the stream system. Due to their presence in the various planning area
drainages, chronic road sediment delivery and physical alteration of stream habitat would
remain an ongoing cumulative effect on fisheries habitat in the planning area.
Additionally, Forest Service dispersed recreation campsites and fords open to public access
contribute to ongoing cumulative effects under this alternative. Nine dispersed campsites are
directly adjacent to TES fish habitat and six open fords occur on TES fishery streams that risk
chronic disturbance of the streambed from direct motorized wheeled vehicle use and
potentially direct mortality of incubating trout eggs and fry. A seventh ford located in Ontario
Creek is currently closed to wheeled motorized traffic.
In non-fish-bearing streams, a ford occurs on an unnamed tributary to the Little Blackfoot River
above Kading campground. This ford does not directly risk mortality to salmonid embryos and
fry, but provides an avenue for chronic sediment delivery into inland native fish habitat in
nearby Little Blackfoot River.
An important project common amongst all alternatives is currently under consideration for
funding to help improve access needs prerequisite to the foreseeable Telegraph Creek Mountain
Pine Beetle Salvage project. This project would replace the large ford on the Little Blackfoot
River with a bridge associated with road # 4100 (Negro Mountain Road). Consequently, there
would be the permanent removal of 0.1 mile of high risk road and three other stream crossings
in TES fish habitat. There would also be foreseeable future direction under a biological opinion
FISHERIES - 219

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

for bull trout to determine which segments of roads are having adverse effects to inland native
fish habitat prerequisite to developing a plan to eliminate or minimize those impacts.

Forest Plan Consistency

Numerous road segments and crossings that have risks to inland native fish and fish habitat are
quantified under Table 66 and Table 67 and would continue to remain open under the no action
alternative. Even with future reviews on roads having adverse effects to streams to help
determine what actions are needed to avoid adverse effects on native fish and habitat, the no
action alternative results in the slowest pace in meeting the Forest Plan INFISH amendment for
avoiding adverse effects on fisheries. This is because no action closes no roads and crossings
that are impacting fish habitat as a tool considered very effective at removing sediment sources
in the long-term.

A reasonably foreseeable federal action under this alternative (and other action alternatives) is
additional review of roads to determine which segments on both open and closed roads are
having adverse effects to inland native fish habitat prerequisite to developing a plan to minimize
those impacts. This future federal action moves the Forest closer in meeting the intent of
avoiding adverse effects to inland native fish and fish habitat.

Alternative 2
Direct and Indirect Effects
Alternative 2 would have the direct effect of closing a net additional 5.89 miles (4.7 percent) of
Forest Service high risk roads to motorized wheeled vehicle use from the current status. Table
72 summarizes the changes in the miles of open high risk roads for each 6th field HUC in the
planning area. Ten sub-watersheds would experience a reduction in open high risk roads;
therefore, these same sub-watersheds would potentially experience varying reductions in longterm road sediment delivery as an indirect effect of closing some segments of high risk roads. In
addition, there would likely be increased opportunities to obliterate roadbeds to restore natural
drainage and stream habitat especially in those drainages that would experience half-a-mile or
more of high risk roads being closed. Nine sub-watersheds would experience no change from
the current miles of open high risk roads so the indirect effect for these drainages (see Table 72)
reflects the no action alternative in terms of road sediment delivery risk. The 0.02 mile of road
in the Little Blackfoot-Hat 6th HUC for this exercise is not likely a sediment risk based on its short
distance and upper location in the INFISH zone and lack of crossings. The small number may
also relate to GIS mapping inconsistencies
Four sub-watersheds west of the Divide would undergo a net increase in open high risk roads
from their current levels as a direct effect of this alternative (see Table 72). These include
Ontario Creek, Mike Renig Gulch and the Elliston sub-watershed portion of the Little Blackfoot
River drainage. The Hat Creek sub-watershed portion of the Little Blackfoot River drainage also
experiences some minor increase in open high risk roads; however, the 0.02 miles as show in
the table probably relate more to a GIS mapping error so this sub-watershed likely experiences
no change from the current open status of high risk roads. The increased miles of open high risk
roads are a mainly a result of proposals to open closed road # 4104-A1 in Ontario Creek; road #
1856 in the Mike Renig drainage; and roads 314-A1 and 314-E1 in Elliston Creek.
The indirect effect of opening these high risk roads to wheeled motorized use relates to
increasing risk of sediment production and delivery to streams that can impact trout
FISHERIES - 220

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

reproduction. Road traffic is recognized to increase production of road sediment ranging from
two to 30 times the sediment production compared to roads without traffic (Luce and Black
2001, pg 1). Surface rutting resulting from repeat traffic was reported to increase sediment
production 200 to 500 percent in contrast to unrutted roads (Burroughs and King 1989, pg 1;
Kennedy 1997). Foltz (1999, pg 3) reported 96 percent to 99 percent of the sediment generated
from road surfaces of high to marginal aggregate surface quality was less than 6 millimeters in
diameter. A major concern for fisheries management is the accrual of excess sediment less than
6.4 millimeters in size into salmonid spawning and rearing habitat. Waters (1995, pgs 86-109)
provides an overview of research on sediment that show most reductions in egg-embryo success
result when sediment particles of 0.83 millimeters and smaller occur in redds in proportions of
about 15 percent or higher. Fry mortality increases as larger sediment particles (3 to 6
millimeters in size) increase in overlying strata.

Alternative 2 also has the direct effect of closing six more stream crossings to motorized

summarizes the changes in the amount of open stream route intersections for each subwatershed. Ten sub-watersheds would experience no change in the current open status of
stream crossings so the indirect effect in these drainages reflects the no action alternative in
terms of sediment risk and opportunity in improving drainage. Seven sub-watersheds would

the potential for variable reductions in long-term road sediment delivery in these drainages with

Five sub-watersheds (one east of the Divide and four west of the Divide) would experience
increases in crossings open to wheeled motorized vehicle use from their current levels as a
direct effect of this alternative (see Table 73). These include Middle Tenmile Creek (east of the
Divide), Ontario Creek, Telegraph Creek, Mike Renig Gulch and the Elliston sub-watershed
portion of the Little Blackfoot River drainage. The additional open crossings are the result of
proposals to open closed road # 4104-A1/A2 in Ontario Creek; road #1856 in the Mike Renig
drainage; and roads 314-A1 and 314-E1 in Elliston Creek. East of the Divide two stream
crossings that would be opened to wheeled motorized vehicle use are associated with opening
road # 335-A in Sweeney Creek to wheeled motorized traffic.
The indirect effects of opening these closed crossings to wheeled motorized use relates to
increased risk for sediment production and delivery to streams including establishment of new
dispersed camps in the riparian area.

Effects of Alternative 2 Specific to Occupied Bull Trout Habitat and Westslope
Cutthroat Trout Habitat:
Seven fords are located on streams supporting westslope cutthroat trout and four of these
occur in habitat that also supports listed bull trout. A direct effect of alternative 2 would be the
closing of all four fords in bull trout occupied habitat to wheeled motorized traffic. One ford
(non-system road 123-013) would be permanently closed and three other fords (roads 4100,
227-D1, 4104-A1/A2) temporarily closed until a bridge or other bottomless aquatic organism
passage (AOP) compliant structure would be installed under a mitigation plan that protects
native aquatic species. This therefore helps reduce risk for direct mortality to the early life
history stages of bull trout and westslope cutthroat trout in Ontario Creek and the Little
Blackfoot River. In upper Ontario Creek the ford (road 4104-A1/A2) in bull trout habitat is
currently closed but would be opened seasonally (from May 16th to October 14th) under this
alternative. To protect instream habitat and early life stages of native trout, this ford would
remain closed until a bridge or other bottomless structure could be installed in its place. Risk for
direct mortality to bull trout in the Little Blackfoot River or Ontario Creek is considered to be
very low currently due to their extremely low numbers as observed and documented in the
latest electrofishing surveys between 2008 and 2012 by Forest Service and Montana Fish,
Wildlife and Parks fisheries crews.
The balance of open fords on fish-bearing streams occurs in westslope cutthroat trout habitat in
Skelly Gulch east of the Divide (road 1853-A1), Sawmill Gulch (road 4005) and an unnamed
tributary to Ontario Creek (road 495-D1). Because of its high importance to westslope cutthroat
trout conservation east of the Divide, the ford (and its associated high risk road) on Skelly Gulch
would be closed. The direct effect therefore would be the elimination of wheeled motorized
traffic in westslope cutthroat trout habitat in upper Skelly Gulch, which is documented as
spawning habitat for that population. The indirect effect would be the reduction of chronic
sediment delivery into westslope cutthroat trout habitat and the protection of incubating
westslope cutthroat trout embryo and fry from direct mortality due to wheeled motorized
traffic through the stream at ford crossing. In Sawmill Gulch and the unnamed Ontario
tributary, proposed mitigation to protect westslope cutthroat trout would be to close the
crossings until an approved aquatic organism passage compliant structure sized to pass 100-year
flood flows could be installed. This would have the indirect effect of protecting westslope
cutthroat trout from potential direct mortality from wheeled motorized traffic through the
creek bed.

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Four dispersed campsites accessed by non-system road 123-013 would be closed as a direct
effect of closing road 123-013 under this alternative. This would eliminate concentrated
recreation activity along 0.25 miles of the Little Blackfoot River associated with the dispersed
campsites and have the indirect effect of passive re-vegetation on disturbed ground along this
segment of the Little Blackfoot River.
Three sub-watersheds that have a net increase of both high risk roads and stream crossings
open in TES fish habitat are Ontario Creek, Mike Renig Gulch and Little Blackfoot River-Elliston.
However, in the Little Blackfoot River-Larabee, road 227-E1, which extends about 0.9 mile
beyond Kading campground, would remain open to wheeled motorized vehicles seasonally from
May 15th to October 14th. Approximately 0.6 miles of high risk road, one ford crossing on a
fishless tributary and two high risk dispersed campsites associated with the road would be open.
Keeping this route open would have a direct effect for potential adverse effects on inland native
fish habitat.
In the Little Blackfoot-Elliston HUC, the direct effect of this alternative would be opening over
one mile of high risk road including two crossings on Elliston Creek and indirectly increasing the
risk for sediment delivery into westslope cutthroat trout habitat. In Telegraph Creek, opening
roads 1857-D1 and 1857-D2 to wheeled motorized use would have the direct effect of allowing
wheeled motorized use on currently closed segments of road having three stream crossings.
The indirect effect of this decision relates to increased risk for sediment delivery into westslope
cutthroat trout habitat in Booth Gulch.
With these exceptions, the overall direct effect on westslope cutthroat trout drainages in the
planning area would be the elimination of wheeled motorized traffic travel on 1.02 miles of high
risk road in westslope cutthroat trout habitat east of the Divide and approximately 5.23 miles of
high risk road in westslope cutthroat trout drainages west of the Divide. The westslope
cutthroat trout drainage east of the Divide that would benefit is Skelly Gulch where
approximately one mile of high risk road and an active ford would be closed as a direct effect of
this alternative. Greenhorn Creek is doubtful whether it still supports any westslope cutthroat
trout based on extensive surveys by Forest Service and Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks
fisheries crews in 2009 to 2012. This drainage would experience the direct effect of having 2.8
miles of high risk road including seven more stream crossings closed to wheeled motorized
traffic. The indirect effect of these closures on fish habitat in the planning area is the long-term
trend of reduced sedimentation into the surface water system for ten sub-watersheds that
support fish populations; six of these support westslope cutthroat trout.

Effects of Alternative 2 Specific to Western Pearlshell Mussel Habitat
Western pearlshell mussels do not occur in the Little Blackfoot River or its tributaries in the
planning area. Additionally, with the exception of Tenmile Creek (east of the Divide) below the
confluence of Walker Creek, no stream reaches have been designated as predicted western
pearlshell habitat based on surveys by Stagliano (2010). The Divide Travel Plan area therefore is
not likely to impact western pearlshell mussels or habitat in or downstream of the project area
west of the Divide.
In the fisheries analysis, increased excess sedimentation was discussed as an environmental
stressor most probable to adversely affect salmonids from open roads and crossings. Increased
sedimentation is also one of the stressors of concern to western pearlshell mussels (Box and
Mossa 1999). Research has found that eliminating ongoing vehicular disturbance on existing
roads reduces the amount of sediment delivered to streams from those routes. Sediment yields
FISHERIES - 224

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

from the project area transportation system are unlikely to increase because there would be no
increases in the amount of high risk roads and crossings open to wheeled motorized vehicle use
in the Upper Tenmile 6th HUC. The single crossing in Middle Tenmile Creek opened under this
alternative is remotely located from predicted pearlshell mussel habitat in lower Tenmile Creek
and lacks connectivity to lower stream reaches of Tenmile Creek.

Irreversible and Irretrievable Commitments
There would be no irreversible commitment or permanent loss of future options in regards to
the existing road system under alternative 2. There is always the possibility for any Forest
Service road, closed or open, that is adversely affecting water quality, stream function, TES fish
habitat or public safety, to be removed or relocated so that stream processes can be restored
that benefit water quality and fish habitat. This would occur on a separate NEPA analysis.
There would be an irretrievable (temporary) commitment of resources in the matter of ongoing
road sediment delivery to fish-bearing habitat due to some road locations resulting in a direct
surface flow path (hydrologic connection) to planning area streams. Approximately 17.4
percent of the entire transportation system consists of Forest Service high risk roads including
associated Forest Service stream/road intersections that can cause an irretrievable commitment
or temporary loss of fish habitat quality restorable by eliminating or relocating those particular
roads or applying some other adjustment measures on the roads. High risk roads when left
untreated would continue being an ongoing cumulative effect that decreases the overall fishproduction capabilities of fish habitat within the project area.
Under-designed culverts present an ongoing risk for releases of substantial stores of sediment in
the form of roadfills at culvert crossings and potential barriers to fish migration. Culverts at risk
that have not been removed or upgraded with aquatic organism passage -compliant ones
designed to pass 100-year floods impose an irretrievable commitment upon stream-riparian
dependent fisheries.

Cumulative Effects
Past, present and reasonably foreseeable future non-road actions applicable to the Divide Travel
Plan project area are addressed in appendix B. The transportation system was not included in
that list as it is addressed in detail in this report. Table 72 and Table 73 in the affected
environment section provide a quantitative overview of all stream/road intersections and miles
of high risk roads in each 6th field HUC as an ongoing effect from the transportation system in
the Divide Travel Plan area. Both tables further refine the two road measures by outlining the
amounts currently open versus closed for each sub-watershed.
There are approximately 719 miles of road in the planning area including National Forest System
(NFS) routes and routes under other ownership. About 165 miles are considered high risk roads
that pose a risk for chronic excessive sediment delivery to the surface water system, fragment
stream habitat and/or alter stream-floodplain functions. The Forest Service maintains
jurisdiction on about 125.2 miles of high risk roads and 95.96 miles are currently open (29.24
miles closed). Under alternative 2, about 90.07 miles of high risk Forest Service roads would
remain open and the other 35.13 miles (29.24 miles currently closed plus 5.89 proposed miles)
or 28 percent would be closed to wheeled motorized vehicle use. Non- Forest Service roads
account for 39.5 miles of high risk roads; these roads represent an ongoing cumulative effect to
the surface water system in the planning area outside of Forest Service management.
There are also currently 439 stream/road intersections (crossings) in the planning area. The
Forest Service has jurisdiction on 329 crossings and 217 crossings are currently open (112
FISHERIES - 225

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

closed). Alternative 2 would result in 211 crossings remaining open to motorized use and the
other 118 (112 currently closed plus 6 proposed) crossings or 35.9 percent would be closed to
wheeled motorized vehicle use. Because stream crossings are principal access sites for road
sediment into the stream system and localized physical alteration of stream habitat, their
presence in the various planning area drainages would remain an ongoing cumulative impact on
fish habitat in the planning area. Closing six crossings under this alternative represents less than
2 percent of the total stream crossings in the planning area with potential for permanent
removal.
Additionally, nine Forest Service dispersed campsites are directly adjacent TES fish habitat, but
wheeled motorized access to four of these campsites would close under this alternative. The
other five dispersed campsites would remain open to public users with risk for ongoing adverse
effects to TES fish habitat without effective adjustment measures to meet riparian management
objectives in riparian habitat conservation areas. Six open fords on TES fish streams would
experience permanent or temporary closures to reduce exacerbating sediment delivery to fish
habitat and risk of direct mortality to westslope cutthroat trout and bull trout. A seventh ford
currently closed in Ontario Creek would remain closed to wheeled motorized traffic until a
bridge or other bottomless structure replaces it under an implementation plan. The physical
presence of these fords would continue as a risk for chronic sediment delivery to TES fish habitat
until measures under an implementation plan could replace the fords or rehabilitate crossings
proposed for closure in this alternative.
In non-fish-bearing streams, the ford on an unnamed tributary to the Little Blackfoot River
above Kading campground remains open so would continue to be a source of chronic sediment
delivery into inland native fish habitat in nearby Little Blackfoot River. However, there would be
no risk for direct fish mortality from motorized vehicle traffic through this ford crossing.
An important project common amongst all alternatives is currently under consideration for
funding to help improve access needs prerequisite to the foreseeable Telegraph Creek Mountain
Pine Beetle Salvage project. This project would replace the large ford on the Little Blackfoot
River with a bridge associated with road # 4100 (Negro Mountain Road). Consequently, there
would be the permanent removal of 0.1 mile of high risk road and three other stream crossings
in TES fish habitat. There would also be foreseeable future direction under a biological opinion
for bull trout to determine which segments of roads are having adverse effects to inland native
fish habitat prerequisite to developing a plan to eliminate or minimize those impacts.

Forest Plan Consistency

Numerous roads and crossings that have risks to inland native fish and fish habitat were
quantified under Table 66 and Table 67, which would continue to remain open under
alternative 2. Alternative 2 would, however, result in closing a net 5.89 miles of Forest Service
high risk roads including six stream crossings that are having some adverse effects on native
fishes and fish habitat. Hence, this alternative would incrementally move the Forest forward in
helping meet the intent of the Forest Plan amendment compared to the no action alternative.
There is some tradeoff in that a few currently closed roads and crossings would be opened to
wheeled motorized use under this alternative potentially increasing risk for adverse effects to
native fishes and fish habitat. To maintain consistency with the Forest Plan, an element
common to all action alternatives is that opened fords on TES fish habitat would be closed to
wheeled motorized vehicles until appropriate mitigation measures are in place that minimize or
FISHERIES - 226

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

eliminate ongoing adverse effects from high risk roads and wheeled motorized use through
fords.
Additionally, a reasonably foreseeable federal action under this alternative (and other
alternatives) is further review of roads to confirm which segments on both open and closed
motorized routes are having adverse effects to inland native fish habitat. This would be
required particularly west of the Divide in order to develop a plan to minimize or eliminate
those effects from roads. This future federal action helps meet the intent of INFISH
amendments by identifying specific roads and needed actions to avoid adverse effects to inland
native fish and fish habitat.

Alternative 3
Direct and Indirect Effects
Alternative 3 would have the direct effect of closing an additional 21.17 miles (16.9 percent) of
Forest Service high risk roads currently open to motorized wheeled vehicle use in the planning
area. Table 74 summarizes the changes in the amount of open high risk roads for each 6th field
HUC. Fourteen sub-watersheds would experience reductions in miles of open high risk roads;
therefore, an indirect effect for these sub-watersheds would be the potential for long-term
reductions in sediment delivery to streams in these drainages with increased opportunities to
obliterate roadbeds to help restore natural drainage and stream habitat. Eight sub-watersheds
would experience no change in the miles of high risk roads currently open to motorized traffic
so the indirect effect for those drainages reflects the no action option in terms of sediment
delivery and opportunities for watershed restoration. The 0.05 mile of road in the Little
Blackfoot-Elliston 6th HUC is not likely a sediment risk based on its short length and upper
location in the INFISH zone and lack of crossings. This sub-watershed is therefore judged having
virtually no change in its open high risk roads.
Alternative 3 would also have the direct effect of closing 46 more Forest Service stream/road
intersections (crossings) to wheeled motorized vehicle use in the planning area from the current
status (alternative 1). Table 75 summarizes the changes in the amount of open crossings by
sub-watershed. Thirteen drainages would realize a reduction in open stream crossings to
wheeled motorized vehicle use with an indirect effect for potential long-term decreases in
sediment delivery and increased opportunities at removing culverts that restore natural
drainage and stream habitat. Nine sub-watersheds would experience no change in the current
open status of stream crossings; the indirect effect in these drainages reflects the no action
alternative in terms of sediment risk and opportunity at restoring drainage. Unlike the other
action alternatives, no drainages in the planning area would experience any increase in open
high risk roads or stream crossings.

In effect, Alternative 3 closes over 15 miles more high risk roads and 40 more crossings to
wheeled motorized vehicle traffic compared to alternative 2. Therefore, compared to
alternative 2 it has the potential to amplify reductions in sediment production and delivery to
streams in sub-watersheds showing net reductions in these indicators. There would also be
more opportunity to obliterate and restore drainage than alternative 2. Research has
demonstrated how minimizing or eliminating motorized use over roads and crossings
substantially reduces road sediment delivery to streams (Luce and Black 2001, pg 1; Burroughs
and King 1989, pg 1; Kennedy 1997; Foltz 1999). Waters (1995, pgs 86-109) provides an
overview of research on sediment that show most reductions in egg-embryo success result
when sediment particles of 0.83 millimeter and smaller occur in redds in proportions of about
FISHERIES - 229

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

15 percent or higher and fry mortality increases as larger sediment particles (3 to 6 millimeters
in size) collect in the overlying strata. Alternative 3 would help minimize long-term sediment
delivery to fish habitat in the planning area because this option provides for the second highest
miles of high risk roads and stream crossings (after alternative 5) that could potentially be
obliterated or removed respectively to restore natural drainage and eliminate sources of chronic
sediment delivery in 14 sub-watersheds.

Effects of Alternative 3 Specific to Occupied Bull Trout Habitat and Westslope
Cutthroat Trout Habitat:
The overall direct effect on westslope cutthroat trout drainages in the planning area would be
the elimination of wheeled motorized traffic travel on about one mile of high risk road in one
westslope cutthroat trout drainage east of the Divide and approximately 12.95 miles of high risk
roads in eight westslope cutthroat trout drainages west of the Divide. Skelly Gulch is the
westslope cutthroat trout drainage on the east side that would benefit from closing
approximately 0.4 miles of hydrologically connected road and an active ford in westslope
cutthroat trout habitat. Another east-side drainage, Greenhorn Creek, is doubtful whether it
still supports any westslope cutthroat trout based on the latest findings by Forest Service and
Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks fisheries crews in 2009 to 2012. This drainage would
experience approximately 2.8 miles of high risk roads and seven stream crossings being closed
to wheeled motorized traffic. The indirect effect on westslope cutthroat trout habitat in the
planning area translates to a long-term trend of reduced sedimentation into the surface water
system in 14 sub-watersheds that support fish populations; nine of these support westslope
cutthroat trout.
Other direct effects from alternative 3 relate to fords and dispersed campsites tied to existing
open high risk roads. Under this alternative four fords (roads 4100, 227-D1, 4104-A1/A2, 123013) in documented bull trout habitat would be closed to wheeled motorized vehicle use. This
would eliminate risk for direct mortality to the early life history stages of bull trout and
westslope cutthroat trout in Ontario Creek and the Little Blackfoot River from wheeled
motorized vehicle traffic through fords. In addition, a ford crossing (road 227-E1) on a fishless
tributary above Kading campground would be closed permanently. In upper Ontario Creek the
ford (road 4104-A2) in bull trout habitat is currently closed and would remain permanently
closed. Therefore, the risk for direct mortality to bull trout and westslope cutthroat trout in the
Little Blackfoot River and Ontario Creek as a function of wheeled motorized traffic through fords
would be discountable under this alternative. Due to extremely low numbers of bull trout
observed and documented in the latest Forest Service and Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks
electrofishing surveys from 2008 to 2012, risk of mortality to bull trout from wheeled motorized
vehicle traffic in the Little Blackfoot River and Ontario Creek is considered to be very low.
Three other open fords occur in westslope cutthroat trout habitat and each are located in Skelly
Gulch east of the Divide (road 1853-A1) and in Sawmill Gulch (road 4005) and an unnamed
tributary to Ontario Creek (road 495-D1) west of the Divide. As discussed above, a ford (and its
associated high risk road) on Skelly Gulch would be permanently closed having the direct effect
of eliminating wheeled motorized traffic through westslope cutthroat trout habitat including a
hydrologically connected segment of road 1853-A1. The indirect effect would be the
minimization of chronic road sediment delivery into westslope cutthroat trout habitat and
protection of incubating westslope cutthroat trout embryos and fry at risk from wheeled
motorized traffic through the streambed. In Sawmill Gulch and the unnamed Ontario tributary,
proposed mitigation to protect westslope cutthroat trout would be the temporary closing of the
FISHERIES - 230

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

two fords until an approved aquatic organism passage compliant structure sized to pass 100year flood flows could be installed. This would have the indirect effect of preventing potential
direct mortality of westslope cutthroat trout fry and eggs and reduce sedimentation from direct
wheeled motorized traffic through the creek bed.
Four dispersed campsites all accessed by non-system road 123-013 and two other dispersed
campsites accessed by road 227-E1 (the extension beyond Kading campground) would be closed
as a direct effect of closing these roads. Alternative 3 would also close the Larabee ford and the
large ford on road 4100 including 1.4 miles of road 4100. The direct effect would be the
cessation of the concentrated recreation activity along the banks of the Little Blackfoot River
next to these six dispersed campsites and an indirect effect of passive re-vegetation on
disturbed ground adjacent the Little Blackfoot River. Projects to fully accomplish road and
crossing closures would follow in a separate implementation plan for this planning area.

Effects of Alternative 3 Specific to Western Pearlshell Mussel Habitat
Effects of alternative 3 on western pearlshell mussels or habitat match those under alternative 2
based on the rationale that discusses potential affects to western pearlshell mussels.

Irreversible and Irretrievable Commitments
There would be no irreversible commitment or permanent loss of future options in regards to
the existing road system under alternative 3. There is always the possibility for any Forest
Service road, closed or open, that is adversely affecting water quality, stream function, TES fish
habitat or public safety, to be removed or relocated so that stream processes can be restored
benefiting water quality and fish habitat. This would occur under a separate NEPA analysis.
There would be an irretrievable (temporary) commitment of resources in the matter of ongoing
road sediment delivery to fish-bearing habitat due to some road locations resulting in a direct
surface flow path (hydrologic connection) to planning area streams. Approximately 17.4
percent of the entire transportation system consists of Forest Service high risk roads including
associated Forest Service stream/road intersections that can cause an irretrievable commitment
or temporary loss of fish habitat quality restorable by eliminating or relocating those particular
roads or applying some other adjustment measures on the roads that protect and restore
aquatic habitats. High risk roads where left untreated would continue being an ongoing
cumulative effect that decreases the overall fish-production capabilities of fish habitat within
the planning area.
Under-designed culverts present an ongoing risk for releases of substantial stores of sediment in
the form of roadfills at culvert crossings and they pose potential barriers to fish migration.
Culverts at risk that have not been removed or upgraded with aquatic organism passage
compliant ones designed to pass 100-year floods present an irretrievable commitment upon
stream-riparian dependent fisheries.

Cumulative Effects
Past, present and reasonably foreseeable future non-road actions applicable to the Divide Travel
Plan area are addressed in appendix B. The transportation system was not included in the list in
appendix B as it is addressed in detail within this report. Table 66 and Table 67 in the affected
environment section provide a quantitative overview of all stream/road intersections and miles
of high risk roads in each 6th field HUC as a measure of ongoing effects related to the
transportation system in the Divide Travel Plan area. Both tables refine the two road measures
by outlining the amounts currently open versus closed for each sub-watershed.
FISHERIES - 231

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

There are 719 miles of road in the planning area including NFS routes and routes under other
ownership. About 165 miles are considered high risk roads that present a risk for chronic excess
sediment delivery to the surface water system, fragment stream habitat and/or alter streamfloodplain functions. The Forest Service maintains jurisdiction over 125.2 miles of high risk
roads and 95.96 miles are currently open (29.24 miles closed). Under action alternative 3, about
74.79 miles of high risk Forest Service roads would remain open and the other 50.41 miles
(29.24 miles currently closed plus 21.17 proposed miles) or 40.2 percent would be closed to
wheeled motorized vehicle use. Non- Forest Service roads account for 39.5 miles of high risk
roads in the planning area; these roads represent an ongoing cumulative effect to the surface
water system in the planning area.
There are in addition some 439 stream/road intersections (crossings) throughout the planning
area. The Forest Service has jurisdiction on 329 crossings and 217 crossings are currently open
(112 are closed). Alternative 3 would result in 171 crossings remaining open to motorized use
and the other 158 (112 currently closed plus 46 proposed closed) or 48 percent would be closed
to wheeled motorized vehicle use. Because stream crossings are principal access sites for road
sediment into the stream system with localized physical alteration of stream habitat, their
presence in the various planning area drainages would remain an ongoing cumulative impact on
fish habitat in the planning area. Closing 46 crossings under this alternative represents about
10.5 percent of the total stream crossings in the planning area with potential for permanent
removal. Permanent removal of closed crossings and mitigating open crossings would
substantially reduce ongoing adverse effects on fish habitat under an implementation plan that
would follow this decision.
Additionally, nine, Forest Service, dispersed campsites associated with high risk roads are
directly adjacent TES fish habitat and six of these would close under this alternative. These sites
are predicted to trend toward pre-disturbance conditions. The other three dispersed recreation
campsites would remain open to public users with likely adverse effects to TES fish habitat
without effective adjustment measures to meet riparian management objectives in riparian
habitat conservation areas.
Six currently open fords on TES fish streams would experience permanent or temporary closures
that reduce risk of direct mortality to early life stages of westslope cutthroat trout and bull
trout. A seventh ford located in Ontario Creek would remain closed as is to wheeled motorized
traffic. The physical presence of these fords would remain an ongoing risk for sediment delivery
to TES fish habitat until measures under an implementation plan would replace fords with
bottomless structures on roads planned to be open or rehabilitate those proposed for closure in
this alternative. In non-fish-bearing streams, a ford on an unnamed tributary to the Little
Blackfoot River above Kading campground would be closed to wheeled motorized vehicle traffic
favoring a long-term trend for eliminating or minimizing road sediment delivery into inland
native fish habitat downstream from the ford.
An important project common amongst all alternatives is currently under consideration for
funding to help improve access needs prerequisite to the foreseeable Telegraph Creek Mountain
Pine Beetle Salvage project. This project would replace the large ford on the Little Blackfoot
River with a bridge associated with road # 4100 (Negro Mountain Road). Consequently, there
would be the permanent removal of 0.1 mile of high risk road and three other stream crossings
in TES fish habitat. There would also be foreseeable future direction under a biological opinion
for bull trout to determine which segments of roads are having adverse effects to inland native
fish habitat prerequisite to developing a plan to eliminate or minimize those impacts.

Forest Plan Consistency

Roads and crossings having risk to inland native fish and fish habitat were quantified under
Table 66 and Table 67. Under alternative 3, approximately 21.17 added miles Forest Service
high risk roads and 46 Forest Service stream crossings having risk upon native fish and habitat
would be closed. This alternative leaves the least amount of high risk roads and crossings open
that may have adverse effects to native fishes and fish habitat after alternative 5 and therefore,
moves the project area forward at the next most rapid pace for fully meeting the intent of the
INFISH amendments. To help maintain consistency with the Forest Plan, an element common
amongst action alternatives is that opened fords in TES fish habitat would be closed to wheeled
motorized vehicles until appropriate mitigation measures are in place to minimize or eliminate
ongoing adverse effects from high risk roads and wheeled motorized use through fords.
Additionally, a reasonably foreseeable federal action under this alternative (and other action
alternatives) is further review of roads to confirm what segments on both open and closed
motorized routes are having adverse effects on inland native fish habitat. This would be
required particularly west of the Divide to develop a plan to minimize or eliminate those road
effects. This future federal action helps to meet the intent of INFISH amendments by identifying
specific roads and needed actions to avoid adverse road effects to inland native fish and fish
habitat.

Alternative 4
Direct and Indirect Effects
Alternative 4 would have the direct effect of closing an additional 17.82 miles (14.2 percent) of
Forest Service high risk roads currently open to motorized wheeled vehicle use in the planning
area. Table 76 summarizes changes in the miles of open high risk roads for each 6th field HUC.
Fifteen sub-watersheds would experience various reductions in miles of open high risk roads;
therefore an indirect effect for those sub-watersheds is the potential for long-term reductions in
road sediment delivery in these drainages with increased opportunities to obliterate roadbeds
to help restore natural drainage and stream habitat. Six sub-watersheds would experience no
change in the miles of high risk roads currently open to motorized traffic so the indirect effect in
these drainages reflects the no action option in terms of sediment delivery and opportunities for
watershed restoration. The 0.05 mile of road in the Little Blackfoot-Elliston 6th HUC is an
unlikely sediment risk based on its short length and upper location in the INFISH zone and lack
of any crossings. This sub-watershed is therefore considered having virtually no substantive
change from existing conditions.
Alternative 4 also has the direct effect of closing 37 more Forest Service stream crossings to
motorized wheeled motorized vehicle use in the planning area compared with alternative 1.
Table 77 summarizes the changes in amount of open stream crossings in each sub-watershed.
Thirteen drainages would realize a reduction in open stream crossings to wheeled motorized
vehicle traffic with an indirect effect for potential reductions in long-term sediment delivery and
increased opportunities at removing culverts to help restore natural drainage and stream
habitat. Eight sub-watersheds would experience no change in the current numbers of open
stream crossings to motorized vehicle traffic so the indirect effect in these drainages reflects the
no action alternative in terms of sediment risk and opportunity at restoring drainages.

Effects of Alternative 4 Specific to Occupied Bull Trout Habitat and Westslope
Cutthroat Trout Habitat:
The overall direct effect on westslope cutthroat trout drainages in the planning area would be
elimination of wheeled motorized traffic on about one mile of high risk road in one westslope
cutthroat trout drainage east of the Divide and approximately 10.52 miles of high risk road in
nine westslope cutthroat trout drainages west of the Divide. Skelly Gulch is the westslope
cutthroat trout drainage on the east side that would benefit from closing 0.4 miles of
hydrologically connected road and an active ford in westslope cutthroat trout habitat. Another
east-side drainage, Greenhorn Creek, is unlikely to support westslope cutthroat trout any longer
based on the latest findings by Forest Service and Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks fisheries
crews in 2009 to 2012. This drainage would experience the direct effect of having 2.8 miles of
high risk road and seven stream crossings closed to wheeled motorized traffic. The indirect
effect on westslope cutthroat trout habitat in the planning area translates to the long-term
trend of reduced sedimentation into the surface water system for 15 sub-watersheds that
support fish populations; ten of these support westslope cutthroat trout.
Other direct effects from alternative 4 relate to fords and dispersed campsites tied to current
open high risk roads. Under alternative 4, one ford (road 123-013) would be permanently
closed and three other fords (roads 4100, 227-D1, 4104-A1A2) temporary closed. All are located
in documented bull trout and westslope cutthroat trout habitat. Therefore, risks for direct
mortality upon the early life history stages of bull trout and westslope cutthroat trout in Ontario
Creek and the Little Blackfoot River from wheeled motorized vehicle traffic through fords is
minimized or eliminated. Due to extremely low numbers of bull trout observed and
documented in the latest Forest Service and Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks electrofishing
surveys between 2008 and 2012, risk of mortality to bull trout from wheeled motorized vehicle
traffic in the Little Blackfoot River or Ontario Creek is considered very low.
Ontario Creek (west of the Divide) is the only drainage that would experience a net increase in
opening high risk roads and crossings from their current closed status under this alternative.
Approximately 0.8 miles of high risk road would be opened to wheeled motorized vehicle use as
a result of a proposal to open road # 4104-A1/A2 for a loop experience. Ontario Creek would, in
addition, experience an increase of five stream crossings as open to wheeled motorized vehicle
use from current levels (see Table 77). Opening these stream crossings includes a ford on
Ontario Creek as a result of the proposal to open closed roads 4104-A1/A2 and 495-A3. The
indirect effect of opening these closed crossings to wheeled motorized use would be an
increased risk of sediment delivery into Ontario Creek and direct mortality of bull trout and
westslope cutthroat trout early life stages at the ford crossing. To protect TES fish and habitat
from wheeled vehicle disturbance at ford crossings, those crossings would be temporarily closed
until a bridge or other aquatic organism passage compliant bottomless structure could be
installed under a mitigation plan to protect water quality and native fish species. This resource
protective measure greatly reduces risk of direct mortality to the early life history stages of bull
trout and westslope cutthroat trout in Ontario Creek.
Three other open fords occur in westslope cutthroat trout habitat and are located in Skelly
Gulch east of the Divide (road 1853-A1), in Sawmill Gulch (road 4005) and an unnamed tributary
to Ontario Creek (road 495-D1) west of the Divide. As discussed above, a ford (and its
associated high risk road) on Skelly Gulch would be closed having the direct effect of eliminating
wheeled motorized traffic through westslope cutthroat trout habitat including the hydrologically
connected segment of road 1853-A1. The indirect effect would be minimization of chronic road
FISHERIES - 236

Divide Travel Plan

sediment delivery into westslope cutthroat trout habitat and protection of incubating westslope
cutthroat trout embryos and fry at risk from wheeled motorized disturbance through the
streambed. In Sawmill Gulch and the unnamed Ontario tributary, proposed mitigation to
protect westslope cutthroat trout would be in the form of temporary closing both fords until an

Four dispersed campsites accessed by non-system road 123-013 and two other dispersed
campsites accessed by road 227-E1 would be closed as a direct effect from closing these roads.
The direct effect would be the cessation of concentrated recreation activity along the banks of
the Little Blackfoot River associated with these six dispersed campsites. An indirect effect would
be the passive re-vegetation and reduced sedimentation at each dispersed campsite along the
Little Blackfoot River.
Alternatives 3 and 4 differ from alternatives 1 and 2 with regard to the existing open road 227E1, which extends beyond Kading campground 0.9 miles. This extension road would be
permanently closed to wheeled motorized vehicles under alternatives 4 and 3. Consequently,
approximately 0.6 miles of high risk road including one ford crossing and two high risk dispersed
campsites associated with this road would all close. The indirect effect translates to reduced
risk for chronic sedimentation and streambank alteration on inland native fish habitat in the
Little Blackfoot River.

Culverts at risk that have not been removed or upgraded with aquatic organism passage
compliant ones designed to pass 100-year floods present an irretrievable commitment upon

direction under a biological opinion for bull trout to confirm what segments of roads are having
adverse effects to inland native fish habitat prerequisite to developing a plan to eliminate or
minimize those impacts.

Forest Plan Consistency

Table 66 and Table 67 quantify the amount of roads and crossings having risk to inland native
fish and fish habitat. Under alternative 4, approximately 17.82 miles of Forest Service high risk
roads and 37 stream crossings in the planning area having risk to native fish and fish habitat
would be closed. Therefore, this alternative is less aggressive than alternatives 3 and 5 at
moving the planning area toward consistency with INFISH amendments to the Forest Plan.
Alternative 4 would move the planning area forward to help meet the intent of the INFISH
amendments more aggressively than action alternative 2. To help maintain consistency with the
Forest Plan, an element common amongst action alternatives is that opened fords in TES fish
habitat would be closed to wheeled motorized vehicles until appropriate mitigation measures
are in place to minimize or eliminate ongoing adverse effects from high risk roads and wheeled
motorized use through fords.
Additionally, a reasonably foreseeable federal action under this and other action alternatives
would be further review of roads to confirm what segments on both open and closed motorized
routes are having adverse effects to inland native fish habitat. This would be required
particularly west of the Divide to develop a plan to minimize or eliminate road effects on
streams. This future federal action helps to meet the intent of INFISH by identifying specific
roads and needed actions to avoid adverse road effects to inland native fish and fish habitat.

Direct and Indirect Effects
Alternative 5 would have the direct effect of closing an additional 29.23 miles (23.3 percent) of
Forest Service high risk roads currently open to motorized wheeled vehicle use in the planning
area. Table 78 summarizes the changes in the miles of open high risk roads for each 6th field
HUC. Eighteen sub-watersheds would experience various reductions in miles of open high risk
roads; therefore, an indirect effect for these sub-watersheds would be the potential for
substantial reductions in long-term road sediment delivery to streams with maximum
opportunities to obliterate roadbeds to help restore natural drainage and stream habitat. Two
sub-watersheds would experience no change in the miles of high risk roads currently open to
motorized traffic so the indirect effect in these drainages reflects the no action option in terms
of road sediment delivery and opportunities for watershed restoration as it applies to road
obliteration.
Alternative 5 also has the direct effect of closing 67 more Forest Service stream crossings to
wheeled motorized vehicle use in the planning area from the current levels (alternative 1).
Table 79 summarizes these changes for each sub-watershed. Fifteen drainages undergo various
