Effects of Alternative 5 Specific to Occupied Bull Trout Habitat and Westslope
Cutthroat Trout Habitat:
The overall direct effect on westslope cutthroat trout drainages in the planning area would be
elimination of wheeled motorized traffic on at least one mile of high risk road in one westslope
cutthroat trout drainage east of the Divide (Skelly Gulch) and approximately 19.29 miles of high
risk road throughout twelve westslope cutthroat trout drainages west of the Divide. In Skelly
Gulch approximately 0.4 miles of hydrologically connected road and an open ford would be
closed as a direct effect of this alternative. Although Greenhorn Creek remains questionable in
terms of westslope cutthroat trout present based on the latest findings by Forest Service and
Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks fisheries crews, this drainage would experience the direct
effect of closing 3.28 miles of high risk road including eight stream crossings to wheeled
motorized traffic. The indirect effect of all road closures on fish habitat relates to the long-term
trend of reduced sedimentation into the surface water system of 18 sub-watersheds that
support fish populations in the planning area; 13 of these support westslope cutthroat trout.
With few exceptions, alternative 5 surpasses alternative 3 overall regarding improving trends on
TES habitat from proposals that close high risk roads and crossings in the planning area.
Other direct effects under alternative 5 relate to fords and dispersed campsites associated with
current open high risk roads. This alternative would have the effect of closing four fords (roads
4100, 227-D1, 4104-A1/A2, 123-013) to wheeled motorized vehicle use in documented bull
trout habitat. The ford (road 4104-A2) in upper Ontario Creek is currently closed and would
remain so under this alternative. Additionally, a ford on a fishless tributary above Kading
campground would become permanently closed in conjunction with closing road 227-E1, which
includes a 0.6 mile segment of high risk road. The indirect effect is predicted reduction in
sediment delivery at this ford. Therefore, risk for direct mortality to bull trout and westslope
cutthroat trout in Ontario Creek and the Little Blackfoot River as a function of wheeled
motorized traffic through fords becomes discountable. Due to extremely low numbers of bull
trout observed and documented in the latest Forest Service and Montana Fish, Wildlife and
Parks electrofishing surveys between 2008 and 2012, risk of mortality to bull trout from
wheeled motorized vehicle traffic in the Little Blackfoot River or Ontario Creek is considered to
be very low.
Three other open fords are in westslope cutthroat trout habitat. One is located in Skelly Gulch
east of the Divide (road 1853-A1) and two others are in Sawmill Gulch (road 4005) and an
unnamed tributary to Ontario Creek (road 495-D1) west of the Divide. As discussed above, a
ford including its associated high risk road on Skelly Gulch would be closed having the direct
effect of eliminating wheeled motorized traffic through westslope cutthroat trout habitat
including the hydrologically connected segment of road 1853-A1. The indirect effect would be
minimization of chronic road sediment delivery into westslope cutthroat trout habitat and
protection of incubating westslope cutthroat trout embryos and fry potentially at risk of direct
mortality related to wheeled motorized traffic through the streambed. Two fords west of the
Divide in Sawmill Gulch and the unnamed Ontario tributary would have proposed mitigation to
protect westslope cutthroat trout by temporarily closing the fords until an approved aquatic
organism passage compliant structure sized to pass 100-year flood flows could replace the
existing fords. That would have the indirect effect of preventing potential direct mortality of
westslope cutthroat trout fry and eggs and reducing sedimentation from wheeled motorized
traffic through the creek bed and crossing approaches.

Four dispersed campsites accessed by non-system road 123-013 and two dispersed campsites
accessed by road 227-E1 would be closed as a direct effect of closing those roads. This has the
additional direct effect of eliminating concentrated recreation activity along the banks of the
Little Blackfoot River in association with these six dispersed campsites with the indirect effect of
passive re-vegetation and reduced sedimentation in the long-term at each of these dispersed
campsites next to the Little Blackfoot River.
Modifications proposed under alternative 5 serve as tradeoffs for maximizing the miles of high
risk roads and stream crossings proposed closed compared to all the other alternatives. West of
the Divide these changes indirectly affect Elliston Creek, Ontario Creek and Telegraph Creek
headwater tributaries. East of the Divide these changes indirectly affect streams only in the Iron
Horse sub-watershed.
A direct effect of this alternative would be the addition of 0.13 miles of high risk road including a
stream crossing opened to wheeled motorized vehicle use in Elliston Creek (see Table 78 and
Table 79) as a result of adding motorized trail #1871-001 to the system of designated routes
open for wheeled motorized vehicle use. The indirect effect of opening this road segment for
wheeled motorized use relate primarily to increasing the risk for road sediment production and
delivery into westslope cutthroat trout habitat in Elliston Creek including risk for direct mortality
to westslope cutthroat trout embryo and fry at the new stream crossing in Elliston Creek
without mitigation to replace the ford with a bottomless pipe structure.
For Ontario Creek, maintaining closure of roads 4104-A1 and A2 and instead adding route 123001 as a seasonal motorized trail results in a net reduction of only 0.05 miles of high risk road
and three less stream crossings open to wheeled motorized use. Other proposed road closures
in Ontario Creek increases the amount of high risk road that would be closed overall in this
drainage to 0.37 miles; therefore, there is potential to decrease road sediment delivery in the
long-term in westslope cutthroat trout and bull trout habitat. The closure of the ford associated
with road 4104-A2 is offset by opening a new ford associated with opening route 123-001 to
seasonal motorized trail use. To protect early life stages of TES fish at this ford, it would remain
closed until the proper aquatic organism passage compliant structure designed to pass 100-year
flood flows could be installed.
In Telegraph Creek the direct effect is a net total of 2.38 miles of high risk road being closed and
potentially a long-term reduction in road sediment delivery into westslope cutthroat trout
habitat as an indirect effect under this alternative. However, there would be no net reduction in
open stream crossings compared to alternatives 3 and 4 even with this amount of high risk
roads proposed for closure (see Table 79). This is primarily due to opening routes 1857 and
1859, including some ancillary routes, on the southwest side of the Telegraph drainage to
provide additional opportunity for seasonal motorized trail use. Four stream crossings closed
under the action alternatives 3 and 4 remain closed under this alternative; however, the
proposed seasonal motorized trail system under this alternative would bisect four other
headwater tributaries cancelling out crossing closures elsewhere in this drainage. These
crossings do not occur in fish-bearing streams and do not occur on fords so there would be no
risk of direct mortality to trout at these crossings.
On the east side of the Divide the Iron Horse Creek 6th HUC would likely experience increases in
sediment delivery as a function of opening an additional 0.49 miles of high risk road primarily in
Lost Horse Creek. However, no conservation populations of westslope cutthroat trout occur in
that creek and there would be no changes in amount of open stream crossings.

Effects of Alternative 5 Specific to Western Pearlshell Mussel Habitat
Effects of alternative 5 on western pearlshell mussels or habitat are the same as under
alternative 2 based on rationale that discusses potential affects to western pearlshell mussels.

Irreversible and Irretrievable Commitments
There is no irreversible commitment (permanent loss) of future options in regards to the road
system under alternative 5. The possibility remains for any Forest Service road, closed or
opened, that is adversely affecting water quality, stream function, TES fish habitat or public
safety to be removed or relocated under a separate decision so that stream processes can be
restored that benefit water quality and fish populations.
There would be an irretrievable (temporary) commitment of resources related to ongoing road
sediment delivery to fish habitat under this alternative due to some road locations having a
direct surface flow path (hydrologic connection) to project area streams. Approximately 17.4
percent of the entire transportation system consists of Forest Service high risk roads including
associated Forest Service stream/road intersections that can cause an irretrievable commitment
or temporary loss of fish habitat quality restorable by eliminating, relocating, or applying some
other project design features on those roads to restore and protect aquatic habitat. High risk
roads where left untreated represent an ongoing cumulative effect that decreases the overall
fish production capabilities of fish habitat within the planning area.
Under-designed culverts present an ongoing risk for releases of substantial stores of sediment in
the form of roadfills at culvert crossings and they pose potential barriers to fish migration.
Culverts at risk that have not been removed or upgraded with aquatic organism passage
compliant ones designed to pass 100-year floods present an irretrievable commitment upon
stream-riparian dependent fisheries.

Cumulative Effects
Past, present and reasonably foreseeable future non-road actions applicable to the Divide Travel
Plan area are addressed in appendix B. The transportation system was not included in the list in
appendix B as it is addressed in detail within this report. Table 66 and Table 67 under the
affected environment section provide a quantitative overview of all stream/road intersections
and miles of high risk roads in each 6th field HUC as a measure of ongoing effects related to the
transportation system in the Divide Travel Plan area. Both the tables refine the two road
measures by outlining the totals currently open versus closed by 6th field HUC.
There are approximately 719 miles of roads in the planning area including NFS routes and routes
under other ownership. About 165 miles are considered high risk roads that risk chronic
excessive road sediment delivery to the surface water system, fragment stream habitat and/or
alter stream-floodplain functions. The Forest Service maintains jurisdiction over 125.2 miles of
high risk roads and about 95.96 miles are currently open to wheeled motorized vehicle use (the
other 29.24 miles are currently closed).
Under alternative 5, about 66.73 miles of high risk Forest Service roads would remain open and
58.47 miles (29.24 miles currently closed plus 29.23 proposed miles) or 46.7 percent would be
closed to wheeled motorized vehicle use. Non- Forest Service roads account for 39.5 miles of
the high risk roads in the planning area; these roads represent an ongoing cumulative effect to
the surface water system and fish habitat in the planning area.
There are also 439 stream/road intersections throughout the planning area and the Forest
Service has jurisdiction over 329 crossings. Currently 217 Forest Service crossings are currently
FISHERIES - 244

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

open (112 are closed). Alternative 5 would result in 150 crossings remaining open to wheeled
motorized use and the other 179 (112 currently closed plus 67 proposed closed) or 54.4 percent
would be closed to wheeled motorized vehicle use. Because stream crossings are principal
access sites for road sediment with localized physical alterations of stream habitat, their
presence in planning area drainages would constitute an ongoing cumulative impact on fish
habitat. Closing 67 crossings under this alternative represents 15.3 percent of the total stream
crossings in the planning area with potential for permanent removal. Alternative 5 provides the
highest measure to close crossings with the prospect to remove more than 50 percent of the
crossings in the planning area. In conjunction with mitigation applied to the remaining open
crossings, this alternative has the potential to reduce or minimize ongoing effects on fish habitat
the most amongst alternatives under an implementation plan that could follow this decision.
Additionally, nine Forest Service dispersed campsites associated with high risk roads are directly
adjacent TES fish habitat and six of these would close under this alternative. Therefore,
activities associated with concentrated recreation use next to TES fish habitat at six campsites
would cease. Subsequently, disturbance to riparian vegetation, streambank disturbance and
compacted soils at these sites are predicted to trend toward pre-disturbance conditions in the
long-term. Three other dispersed recreation campsites would remain open to public users
having some risk to adversely affect TES fish habitat without effective adjustment measures to
meet riparian management objectives in riparian habitat conservation areas.
Six fords currently open on TES fish streams would experience permanent or temporary closures
that would minimize or eliminate risk of direct mortality to early life stages of westslope
cutthroat trout and bull trout. A seventh ford located in Ontario Creek would remain closed to
wheeled motorized vehicle disturbance. The physical presence of these fords, however, remain
an ongoing risk for sediment delivery to TES fish habitat until measures under an
implementation plan would result in replacing temporarily closed fords with bottomless
structures or rehabilitate crossings proposed to be closed under this alternative. In non-fishbearing streams, the ford on the Little Blackfoot River unnamed tributary above Kading
campground would be permanently closed to wheeled motorized vehicle traffic subsequently
leading to a long-term trend of eliminating or minimizing road sediment delivery downstream
into native fish habitat from this site.
One potential project related to this project is under consideration which would improve access
needs prerequisite to the foreseeable Telegraph Creek Mountain Pine Beetle Salvage project.
This project would replace the large ford on the Little Blackfoot River with a bridge associated
with road # 4100 (Negro Mountain road) in conjunction with rerouting a portion of road # 123
(Ontario Cr road). Consequently, there would be the permanent removal of 0.1 mile of high risk
road from the Little Blackfoot floodplain and three other stream crossings in TES fish habitat.
There would also be foreseeable future direction under a biological opinion for bull trout to
determine which segments of roads are having adverse effects to inland native fish habitat
prerequisite to developing a plan to eliminate or minimize those impacts.

roads and 67 stream crossings potentially at risk to native fish and fish habitat in the planning
area. This alternative leaves the least amount of roads and stream crossings open that pose risk
for adverse effects to native fishes and fish habitat. For instance, alternative 5 closes up to 54

percent of road/stream crossings and 46.7 percent of all high risk roads in the planning area.
Therefore, it moves the travel planning area toward consistency with INFISH amendments to the

Additionally, a reasonably foreseeable federal action under this and other alternatives would be

Conclusions

The transportation system in the Divide Travel Plan area consists of approximately 719 miles of
roads that extend throughout portions of 22 sub-watersheds on the Helena Ranger District. The
project area extends to both sides of the Continental Divide. The majority of planning area
roads is under Forest Service jurisdiction while the remaining roads are on lands of other
ownership. This report examines only the Forest Service roads as various segments are
proposed to be designated closed to wheeled motorized vehicle use while a few others would
be designated opened compared to baseline conditions (no action).

Another element of the Divide Travel Plan relates to over-snow travel typically for motorized
winter recreation. Motorized over-snow traffic would also realize some area and route changes
compared to baseline conditions in the planning area. Because ground conditions for this type
of recreation or travel activity are frozen and covered with snow, motorized over-snow travel is
assumed having minimal or no sediment risk to streams. Therefore, this component of travel
planning was essentially dismissed from consideration as a potential adverse effect or risk to
streams and fish habitat.
The planning area supports over 140 miles of fish-bearing streams throughout 21 of 22 subwatersheds. Not all sub-watersheds lie entirely within the planning area. The fish assemblage
consists of a mix of native and non-native species. Non-native brook trout and rainbow trout
account for 96 percent of the fishery in the upper Missouri River side of the planning area and
non-native brown trout and brook trout comprise about 65 percent of the fishery in the Upper
Clark Fork River basin side of the planning area. Native salmonids include westslope cutthroat
trout both sides of the Divide and bull trout occur only west of the Divide in the planning area.
Other native fish present in the planning area include mountain whitefish, longnose suckers and
sculpins. Westslope cutthroat trout are designated a Regional Forester’s Sensitive Species listed
and are the fish management indicator species on the Helena National Forest. Bull trout are
listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) of 1973. The western pearlshell
mussel was added to the aquatic sensitive species list in June 2011 and they are therefore
considered for potential effects from this project.
Evidence from all studies, reviews and bibliographies on effects of sedimentation constitutes a
strong indictment how anthropogenic sediment exceeding natural background levels is a
stressor to the biological integrity and productivity of clean freshwater streams. Roads have
FISHERIES - 246

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

been documented to produce the most sediment and stream alteration among all forest landuse activities. The major threat upon benthic invertebrates is the smothering of physical habitat
by sediment deposition on the streambed. To trout, the threat from chronic excess sediment is
to their reproductive success and loss of rearing habitat. Most roads in the planning area,
however, are located far enough away from the stream network so that they do not pose such
risks. Therefore, this report separates out only Forest Service roads that parallel and bisect
streams. The focus for this analysis is on roads within INFISH buffers (as they pertain west of the
Divide) but extended both sides of the Divide for consistency and referred in this report as high
risk roads. Two measures used in discerning and quantifying the road/stream relationship are
high risk roads (those within INFISH buffers) and road/stream intersections (crossings).
Currently there are approximately 125.2 miles of high risk roads and 329 stream crossings under
Forest Service jurisdiction throughout the planning area. Under existing conditions, there are
about 29.24 miles (23 percent) of the high risk roads and 112 (34 percent) stream crossings
currently closed to wheeled motorized vehicle travel. Closing high risk roads has the direct
effect of eliminating motorized vehicle traffic (and road maintenance) on the roadbed and
indirectly allows exposed road surfaces to passively re-vegetate and accumulate duff, thus,
reducing sedimentation. Closing roads additionally sets the stage for potential future road
obliteration or storage opportunities as a tool to help restore watersheds and fish habitat.
Four action alternatives, with few exceptions, would close additional high risk roads and
associated stream crossings in the planning area to wheeled motorized vehicle use. The
administrative action of closing open roads and stream crossings helps to reduce their impacts
on water quality and fish habitat by permanently discontinuing wheeled vehicle disturbance
over the roadbed. The five alternatives for the Divide Travel Plan each have different levels of
high risk road and crossing closures and those differences are quantified respectively in Figure 4
and Figure 5 below.

Figure 4: Chart comparing miles high risk roads open and closed by alternative.

FISHERIES - 247

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Figure 5: Chart comparing number stream crossings open and closed by alternative.

The general forestwide standard for fisheries is met in the action alternatives via close
coordination with fisheries staff throughout the entire planning process as specified in the
Forest Plan (pg II-22). No alternative involves road construction or reconstruction so standards
for instream activities or structures do not apply, except under cumulative effects activities
where all work in streams has been closely coordinated with fisheries staff and the state Fish,
Wildlife and Parks department to ensure spawning habitats remain accessible and are not
adversely affected by sediment and channel alteration. Road maintenance is covered in
accordance with direction provided in the Transportation System Maintenance Handbook and
special measures provided under the 1999 Programmatic Biological Assessment for Road
Maintenance (MT Bull Trout Level 1 Team).
The no action alternative (existing condition) would maintain the current level of 95.96 miles of
high risk roads and 217 stream crossings open for wheeled motorized vehicle travel while 29.24
miles and 112 crossings would remain closed. This meets general forestwide standards by
means of coordinating with forest fisheries staff throughout the planning process and there are
no proposals for road construction or reconstruction so standards for instream activities or
structures do not apply. No action, however, would fall short of INFISH standards RF-2c and RF3c because there would be no effort to move the transportation system forward to avoid the
ongoing impacts associated with the existing road network such as closing additional high risk
roads in inland native fish habitat.
Alternative 2 moves the planning area toward consistency with the INFISH amendment the least
amongst all action alternatives by closing 5.89 miles (4.7 percent) of high risk Forest Service
roads and six more stream crossings relative to existing conditions in the planning area. Only
1.21 miles of the proposed closures occur west of the Divide. The INFISH standards RF-2c and
RF-3c are met by development of this Travel Management Plan and distinguishing those roads
on the transportation system in need for closing, stabilizing or other future mitigation activities
that help to avoid adverse impacts to inland native fish. Two fords located directly in occupied
TES fish habitat would be closed permanently under this alternative and the five other fords
closed temporarily until those fords are replaced with aquatic organism passage compliant
structures sized for 100-year flood flows. Additionally, this alternative would close wheeled
FISHERIES - 248

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

motorized access to four (of nine) dispersed recreation campsites currently having ongoing
adverse impacts on native fish habitat, including documented bull trout habitat, adjacent to
those campsites. Recreation management standards RM-1 and RM-2 would be met for four
campsites having adverse effects on native fish habitat since they would be closed while the
other five high risk campsites are identified for future adjustments to avoid adverse effects on
fish habitat under a separate NEPA analysis. This alternative therefore helps eliminate risk of
direct mortality on TES fish and reduce habitat disturbance from fords and dispersed camping
activity.
Alternative 3 would move the planning area toward consistency with the INFISH amendment to
the Forest Plan aggressively because it would close 21.27 miles (16.9 percent) of high risk Forest
Service roads and 46 more stream crossings relative to existing conditions in the planning area.
This amounts to the most closures after alternative 5. INFISH standards RF-2c and RF-3c are
met by development of this Travel Management Plan and distinguishing which roads on the
transportation system are in need for closing, stabilizing or other future mitigation activities that
help to avoid adverse impacts to inland native fish. Five fords located directly in occupied TES
fish habitat would be permanently closed under this alternative and two others would be
temporarily closed till replaced with aquatic organism passage compliant structures sized for
100 year flood flows. Additionally, this alternative would close wheeled motorized access to six
(of nine) dispersed recreation campsites having adverse impacts on native fish habitat, including
documented bull trout habitat, adjacent to those campsites. Recreation management standards
RM-1 and RM-2 would be met for six campsites having ongoing impacts on native fish habitat
since they would be closed. The other three high risk campsites are identified under this
analysis for future adjustments to avoid adverse effects on fish habitat under a separate NEPA
analysis. Thus, this alternative would be highly effective at eliminating risk of direct mortality on
TES fish and reducing habitat disturbance from fords and dispersed camping activity in the
planning area.
Alternative 4 would also move the planning area toward consistency with the INFISH
amendment very aggressively because it results in the closure of 17.82 miles (14.2 percent) of
high risk Forest Service roads and 37 more stream crossings relative to existing conditions in the
planning area. This amounts to more closures than alternative 2, but fewer than alternatives 3
and 5. The INFISH standards RF-2c and RF-3c are met by development of this Travel
Management Plan and distinguishing which roads on the transportation system are in need for
closing, stabilizing or other future mitigation activities that help to avoid adverse impacts to
inland native fish. Two fords located directly in occupied TES fish habitat would be closed
permanently under this alternative and the five other fords closed temporarily till replaced with
aquatic organism passage compliant structures sized for 100-year flood flows. Additionally, this
alternative would close wheeled motorized access to six (of nine) dispersed recreation
campsites having adverse impacts on native fish habitat, including documented bull trout
habitat, adjacent to those campsites. Recreation management standards RM-1 and RM-2 would
be met for six campsites having ongoing impacts on native fish habitat since they would be
closed. The other three high risk campsites are identified under this analysis for future
adjustments to avoid adverse effects on fish habitat under a separate NEPA analysis. This
alternative would also be effective at eliminating risk of direct mortality on TES fish and reducing
habitat disturbance from fords and dispersed camping activity in the planning area. Compared
to alternative 3, this alternative would open a closed route (road 4104-A1/A2) in upper Ontario
Creek and result in replacing an existing ford with a bridge on Ontario Creek as opposed to
permanently closing the crossing under alternative 3.
FISHERIES - 249

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Alternative 5 would move the planning area toward consistency with the Inland Native Fish
Strategy (INFISH) amendment to the Forest Plan most aggressively of all the alternatives
because it would close 29.23 miles (23.3 percent) of high risk Forest Service roads and 67 more
stream crossings relative to existing conditions in the planning area. This amounts to the most
closures of high risk roads amongst all alternatives. INFISH standards RF-2c and RF-3c are met
by development of this Travel Management Plan and distinguishing which roads on the
transportation system are in need for closing, stabilizing, or other future mitigation activities
that help avoid adverse impacts to inland native fish. Five fords located directly in occupied TES
fish habitat would be permanently closed under this alternative and two others would be
temporarily closed until they could be replaced with aquatic organism passage compliant
structures sized for 100-year flood flows. Additionally, this alternative would close wheeled
motorized access to six (of nine) dispersed recreation campsites having adverse impacts on
native fish habitat, including documented bull trout habitat, adjacent to those campsites.
Recreation management standards RM-1 and RM-2 would be met for six campsites having
ongoing impacts on native fish habitat since they would be closed. The other three high risk
campsites are identified under this analysis for future adjustments to avoid adverse effects on
fish habitat under a separate NEPA analysis. This alternative and alternative 3 would be most
effective at eliminating risk of direct mortality on TES fish and reducing habitat disturbance from
fords and dispersed camping activity in the planning area.
As evidenced by the magnitude and extent of high risk roads and crossings in the planning area,
the Forest Service road system presents a high degree of risk for adverse effects on inland native
fish and fish habitat in the planning area without meaningful measures to minimize those risks.
Stream crossings and high risk road segments under other ownerships (see Table 66 and Table
67) represent road use activity considered an ongoing cumulative effect outside current Forest
Service control. A Biological Evaluation/Assessment is needed to satisfy requirements of the
Forest Service Manual (FSM) at FSM 2672.4 to review Forest Service actions for possible effects
to listed, proposed or sensitive species. To that end, projected effects to the federally listed bull
trout, the sensitive westslope cutthroat trout and sensitive western pearlshell mussel have been
summarized in Table 80 below. A biological evaluation for sensitive westslope cutthroat trout
and western pearlshell mussel will be completed for the preferred alternative. Because of
adverse baseline conditions to listed bull trout habitat, formal consultation via a bull trout
assessment will be prepared and submitted to the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service.

Summary of Determinations for Alternative 5

Alternative 5 (the preferred alternative) will have both beneficial and adverse effects on bull
trout. Background sedimentation will still occur under all the alternatives due to the remaining
high risk roads left open in the analysis area. This will continue to have adverse effects on bull
trout into the foreseeable future. However, bull trout will experience the immediate and longterm beneficial effects of closures to high risk roads, crossings and associated recreation sites
resulting in a reduction of sediment delivery to their habitat.
The actions in alternative 5 may impact individual westslope cutthroat trout by continuing to
have some sediment delivery into their habitat by the remaining open roads. However, this will
not likely cause an impact to the westslope cutthroat trout population in the analysis area and
therefore will not result in a trend for listing. Westslope cutthroat trout will also experience the
immediate and long-term beneficial effects of closures to high risk roads, crossings and
associated recreation sites resulting in a reduction of sediment delivery to their habitat.
Westslope cutthroat trout will not be affected because of the location of their occurrences and
predicted habitat will not be affected through the actions in alternative 5.

WILDLIFE
Introduction
The Divide landscape of the Helena National Forest (HNF) supports a diverse assemblage of
wildlife populations typical of most National Forests in the northern Rockies. While the
landscape encompasses numerous blocks of habitat in which human presence is fleeting and
slight, roads and trails have been a prevalent feature of this landscape since the mid-late 19th
century. Motorized routes concentrate human activity and harbor the potential to influence
wildlife species and their habitats in a variety of ways. Wildlife response to roads can be highly
variable depending on the inherent reaction of the species to human influences; the character,
severity and longevity of the road impacts; the habitat context; the time of year; and so on.
The Divide Travel Plan is proposing a number of changes to the current road and motor trail
system in the Divide landscape. The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) for the
Travel Plan presents 4 alternative scenarios for travel management in addition to the existing
condition:
•

•
•

•

•

Alternative 1 would retain the existing condition, with 439 miles of Forest, County and
private roads; 35 miles of trails available to public use via wheeled motor vehicles during
all or part of the year (16 miles of which are currently unauthorized); and 418 miles of
snowmobile routes.
Alternative 2 would support approximately 433 miles of open Forest, County and
private access roads; 36 miles of motor trails; and 394 miles of snowmobile routes.
Alternative 3 would put more emphasis on non-motorized routes and would support
approximately 394 miles of open Forest, County and private access roads; no authorized
motor trails; and 416 miles of snowmobile routes.
Alternative 4 is a modified version of Alternative 3, with 403 miles of open Forest,
County and private access roads; 4 miles of authorized motor trails; and 404 miles of
snowmobile routes.
Alternative 5, while designed to provide a variety of motorized loop trails, eliminates
numerous parallel and dead-end roads and closes several other routes in an effort to
WILDLIFE - 251

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

enhance big game security. It would provide 284 miles of open Forest, County and
private access roads; 64 miles of authorized motor trails; and 403 miles of snowmobile
routes
The above mileages include 118 miles of County and private access roads open to the public
within National Forest administrative boundaries. These roads are open under all alternatives.
The Travel Plan deals with Helena National Forest lands in the Divide landscape of the Helena
Ranger District. Not included are the Clancy-Unionville implementation area in the
southeastern part of the landscape and most of the Little Prickly Pear drainage in the northern
end, both of which have been covered by earlier travel planning efforts (Sound Wood Salvage
Project, 1998; Clancy-Unionville Vegetation Manipulation and Travel Management Project,
2003;). This report describes the current environment for terrestrial wildlife in the Divide
landscape with an emphasis on the influence of the existing road and motor trail network. It
then examines the expected response of wildlife communities to each of the 5 proposed
alternatives. The following components are addressed:
General Habitat—including Old-Growth Forest
•
Riparian Habitats
•
Connectivity – Habitat Fragmentation, Movement Corridors and Linkage Zones
•
Snags and Woody Debris
•
Migratory landbirds and Shorebirds
•
Big Game Species
•
Threatened, Endangered and Sensitive (TES) species
•
Forest Plan Management Indicator Species (MIS)
I have abbreviated analysis of species, groups of species and habitat components for which the
probability of a meaningful effect is very low. This includes some species and habitat elements
that figure prominently in assessments of timber harvest and prescribed burning projects, but
will suffer few, if any, direct effects from the kind of travel management proposed here. The
northern goshawk, for example, may suffer significant loss of nesting habitat from
unconstrained timber harvest, but is unlikely to be affected in any meaningful way by Divide
Travel Plan proposals. These species and components are addressed, but not at length.
Quantitative analysis is reserved for species and habitat elements that may be influenced in
measurable ways by implementation of any of the alternatives proposed by this travel planning
effort. In some cases, detailed discussion of indicator species (such as elk) serves as a surrogate
for other potentially affected species (such as mule deer and moose) that are addressed in less
detail.
•

REGULATORY FRAMEWORK
National Forest Management Act

The Forest Service is charged with maintaining the viability of all existing native and desired nonnative vertebrate species in a planning area under the National Forest Management Act of 1976
(NFMA) (36 CFR 219.19). A forest plan must identify “management indicator species” (MIS) that
serve as proxies for fulfilling this NFMA viability requirement [see Helena Forest Plan (1986)
page II/17]. The regulations impose a standard by requiring development of habitat objectives
for maintaining viability of MIS throughout a planning area. In this report, an assessment of
Forest Plan management indicator species (MIS) can be found in the “Affected Environment”
WILDLIFE - 252

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

and “Environmental Consequences” sections. A further discussion of population viability of MIS
is provided in Appendix E.

Forest Service Manual

The Forest Service Manual (FSM) provides direction for the management of terrestrial resources.
FSM 2630 provides overall objectives for maintaining and improving wildlife habitat. Section
2670 establishes objectives and procedures for managing and protecting threatened,
endangered and sensitive species. This latter section directs that the Forest Sevice prepare a
biological evaluation for any of its activities that may affect threatened, endangered, proposed,
or sensitive species. In this report, the assessment of threatened and sensitive species in the
“Affected Environment” and “Environmental Consequences” sections serves as the Biological
Evaluation for species known to be present in the Travel Plan Area. A summary of the
evaluation for all species on the Helena NF can be found in Appendix F.

Helena Forest Plan
The Helena Forest Plan (HFP), developed in the early 1980s and released in 1986, sets the
framework for management of wildlife species. Forestwide standards and guidelines for wildlife
are identified on pages II/17 – II/21. In addition, the standards incorporate more detailed
direction for elk and grizzly bears in Appendices C, D and E. The standards and guidelines are
applied to all alternatives in the following analysis as appropriate.

Endangered Species Act

The Endangered Species Act (ESA) of 1973 requires all Federal agencies to review all projects to
ensure that the action is not likely to jeopardize continued existence of any proposed,
threatened, or endangered species. This is documented in a biological assessment for those
listed or proposed species present in the project area. In cases where the assessment
determines that a proposed action may affect a listed or proposed species, the ESA requires
consultation with and concurrence from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) before a
decision can be signed. A Biological Assessment for the 2 threatened terrestrial wildlife species
in the Divide Travel Plan Area will be prepared as a separate document, once the Record of
Decision for the project has been developed. [The Biological Evaluation of threatened,
endangered and sensitive (TES) species is a requirement of Forest Service policy and is included
within this report.]

National Environmental Policy Act

The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 requires that all environmental analyses consider
a full range of reasonable alternatives to the proposed action, alternatives that address the
significant issues and meet the purpose and need for the proposed action. As the Divide Travel
Plan has evolved over the past few years, the number of alternatives has expanded from three
to five. The Wildlife Specialist Report presents an in-depth review of the potential effects of
each of these alternatives on the wildlife environment. These findings are then presented in
much the same form and detail in the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) and will be used to
shape the final decision presented in the Record of Decision.

Migratory Bird Memorandum of Understanding

In December 2008, the Forest Service and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) signed a
“Memorandum of Understanding” to promote the conservation of migratory birds (USFS and
WILDLIFE - 253

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

USDI 2008). Section D(3) of the Memorandum obliges the Forest Service, within its NEPA
process, to “evaluate the effects of agency action on migratory birds, focusing first on species of
management concern along with their priority habitats and key risk factors”. A discussion of
migratory birds of conservation concern in the Travel Plan Area and an assessment as to the
potential effects of Travel Plan alternatives on these species is included in the “Affected
Environment” and “Environmental Consequences” sections of this report.

Table 81, on the following pages, summarizes the assumptions, methodologies and basic

information used in the analysis of different alternatives [40 CFR 1502.15]. More detailed
information as to the construction and application of habitat models for threatened,
endangered and sensitive species and for management indicator species (including elk) is
included in the Project File. More complete discussion of the resource issues introduced here
comes in following sections.

ASSUMPTIONS AND INFORMATION USED

METHODOLOGIES AND SCIENTIFIC ACCURACY

Information on wildlife and wildlife habitat in the Divide
Travel Plan Area has been extracted from 20 years of field
survey work throughout the Divide landscape (1992-2012).
Some of this information is summarized in the Divide
Landscape Analysis (HNF 1996) and in environmental
analyses conducted for a variety of projects across the
landscape since 1992 [HRD/ HNF files]. I have also employed
recent modeling and mapwork by HNF GIS specialists.
This section focuses on direct effects of roads on forest and
grassland/shrubland habitat (habitat loss, fragmentation,
edge effects). Effects on riparian and wetland sites are
addressed in the section on “Riparian Habitat”. Edge effects
are described for roads but not for trails. This derives from
the observation that most trails on the HNF are narrow
tracks that produce little, if any measurable edge. That is,
trails in forest habitat run under the canopy rather than
scouring out a contrasting corridor through the surrounding
habitat. As a result, edge effects associated with these
narrow travelways are assumed to be negligible.
Information used to model old-growth is described in the
documentation file created by HNF GIS specialists [Project
File]. Modeling is based on sampling for the timber stand
data layer (part of the Master Vegetation Layer). Effects
generated by roads in old growth forest are assumed to be
similar to those that occur in forested habitat in general.
Information used to assess effects on riparian habitat is
based on data summarized in the Fisheries and Watershed
Specialist Report and analyses conducted by HNF GIS
specialists. We assume that these assessments are sufficient
to indicate effects on these focal habitat sites that are
important not only to species of special concern (such as
western toads) but to a wide variety of wildlife.
The size and distribution of habitat patches away from the

Because wildlife species composition in any given area is
primarily a product of available habitats, most wildlife is
discussed at the “coarse filter” scale. That is, we assume that
broad groups of similar vegetation will support similar arrays of
wildlife species and levels of biodiversity (absent specific
limitingfactors generated by human interference or natural
factors). Likewise, we assume that roads in each of these broad
vegetation types will affect associated wildlife communities in
similar ways. In some cases, individual species and their specific
habitat needs are discussed, especially in the case of uncommon
species dependent on particular habitat components for which
data is available. This is a “fine filter” approach. Effects on
general habitat are discussed in terms of habitat loss,
fragmentation and edge effects.

WILDLIFE - 255

Direct effects of roads are discussed briefly with regard to
fragmentation, habitat loss (particularly with regard to snags)
and edge effects. These data are not quantified.

Methodologies for assessing effects of motorized use within the
300 foot riparian zone (Riparian habitat conservation Areas) are
described in the Fisheries and Watershed reports. This analysis
reports miles of open road expected in these riparian areas
under different alternatives.

influence of open roads is used as a general indicator for
comparing differences among alternatives. I made use of
previous modeling efforts for portions of the Divide
landscape (Walker and Craighead 1997; Olimb and
Williamson 2006) to assess the general status of habitat
connectivity in the Travel Plan Area and then looked at
changes in non-motorized patch size in specific areas where
alternatives differed from one another to come up with a
relative indicator. I assume that the fewer and larger the
unroaded patches, the better the connectivity (the less the
fragmentation). Better connectivity may be partially a
function of lower road density alone, but primarily it reflects
patterns of open road dispersion (regardless of density) that
allow ample blocks of wildlife habitat to function free from
road influences.

connectivity among alternatives are from (1) a model developed
by Walker and Craighead (1997) and expanded upon by Olimb
and Williamson (2006) and (2) the FS Region-1 Connectivity
Protocol. The 2 habitat models focus on the needs of animals
needing the largest corridors (grizzly bears, mountain lions, elk)
and employ habitat suitability, habitat complexity and
weighted road density as key parameters. The Region-1 Protocol
calculates the size and distribution of unroaded patches at least
½ mile from open roads, since research on several species
(including elk and grizzly bears) indicates that ½ mile provides an
adequate buffer.
This assessment focuses on size and distribution of areas free
from vehicle use. All unroaded and non-motorized patches
larger than 1,500 acres are tallied and changes between
alternatives calculated. This gives a general sense of relative
differences between alternatives and of the potential
effectiveness of the Continental Divide “linkage zone” or
“corridor” for larger wildland species. Effectiveness of the
linkage varies by species depending on their habitat needs,
behavioral traits and reaction to humans. Lynx and marten, for
example, prefer continuously forested environment, while
grizzly bears and elk are best served by a mosaic of forest and
non-forest.
Since no new roads will be constructed under any alternative, I
assume no direct effects from habitat loss. The methodology
used to analyze indirect effects on snags and logs is described in
“Analysis Methodology for Effects of Roads on Snags and Logs”
in Appendix A. Indirect effects on snags and logs related to
“edge” created by road prisms remaining on the landscape are
described in the General Habitat section.

Elk herd units (EHUs) were delineated by Helena National
Forest (HNF) and Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks (MFWP)
biologists in 2003 and modified in 2007 and 2011. Herd units
extend 1.5 mi beyond HNF boundaries, which we assume
accounts for the area used by most elk that regularly move
on and off the Forest in winter. Assessment of the impacts
of roads on elk are based on the road attribute layers for
each alternative.
With the exception of one herd unit(Greenhorn EHU),
Summer range is assumed to be synonymous with the entire
herd unit (though this is often an overestimation). Hiding
cover, which underlies the Forest Plan standard for elk
summer range quality, is based on modeling by HNF GIS
analysts (USFS 2009). We use the MT Fish, Wildlife and Parks
definition of hiding cover, which assumes that forest crown
closure of 40% or more is an indicator of hiding cover.
To delineate Forest Plan winter range, I used maps
developed for the HNF Oil and Gas Leasing EIS (1995). I
chose this delineation after comparing plots of several
thousand winter elk locations (from MFWP aerial surveys and
radio-telemetry) to 3 available winter range maps, ”Forest
Plan” (1981-86),“Oil and Gas” (1995) and MFWP (19992010). The “Oil and Gas” map covered 96% of winter elk
locations within herd units. I used the more broadly defined
MFWP winter ranges when discussing elk habitat use and
movement patterns beyond the HNF.

Methodologies used to determine direct and indirect effects on
elk include the following:
Summer Habitat Effectiveness (Christensen et al. 1993) is based
on open road density within each elk herd unit (including
private roads) between May 16 and Sept. 30. Road locations and
vehicle use patterns have been verified on the ground to the
extent possible.
Modeling of hiding cover (for Forest Plan compliance) provides a
reasonably accurate estimate of percent cover over broad areas,
but it is not useful for drawing local, site-specific conclusions as
to elk habitat use. Crown closure, estimated from satellite
imagery, served as a surogate for measuring hiding cover
directly on the ground (as per HFP, p. II/18).
Effects of travel management on winter range are based on
open road and snowmobile trail patterns on “HNF Oil and Gas
EIS winter range” within HNF boundaries and on “MFWP winter
range” in the 1.5 mile herd unit extension beyond those
boundaries. Assessment of snowmobile use comes from the
most recent Forest snowmobile trail maps and verification from
discussion with local snowmobile groups that regularly use the
trail system.
Elk vulnerability during the hunting season is based on the
percentage of fall home range occupied by effective elk security
areas. Security areas are delineated via methodology developed
by Hillis et al. (1991) and modified for “eastside” environments.

Security is calculated for the portion of an elk herd unit within
HNF administrative boundaries. The goal is for 50% of each herd
unit to be maintained as elk security areas. Herd units below
50% security are considered to be in compliance with the Forest
Plan security standard as long as % security does not decline (as
a result of management activity). The assumption is that
security is adequate as long as MFWP population objectives for
elk are being met in local hunting districts, or in those portions
of the distict subject to influence by the herd unit. Smaller nonmotorized areas (250-999 acres) recognized as security areas in
previous analyses are classified as “intermittent refuge areas”.
The need to maintain the integrity of these areas is recognized
but their acreage is not calculated as part of % security for herd
units.

Threatened and Endangered Species
Canada Lynx

The Northern Rockies Lynx Management Direction (NRLMD)
(USFS 2007b) provides the background information,
standards, guidelines and general management underpinning
for dealing with lynx. While this direction addresses all
National Forest lands in the northern Rockies, I assume that
our local survey work and habitat modeling are sufficient to
allow us to tweak aspects of it to provide a better fit for the
Divide landscape. Potential lynx habitat and suitable
snowshoe hare habitat have been modeled by HNF GIS
personnel using a combination of data from the timber stand
management record system (TSMRS) (field-based stand data)
and V-Map satellite imagery (USFS 2009). Road and
snowmobile use are derived from GIS processes that tally
miles of these routes in suitable lynx habitat in LAUs

WILDLIFE - 258

Area-wide distribution of potential lynx and snowshoe hare
habitat has been modeled and mapped by HNF GIS personnel,
using criterea from the NRLMD. Field-based information for
validating habitat modeling efforts has come from a variety of
sources, including general wildlife surveys that have made note
of habitat components useful to lynx throughout the landscape
since the 1990s, lynx denning and foraging habitat surveys in
the Tenmile drainage in 2003 and on-going Forestwide field
surveys of potential snowshoe hare habitat conducted according
to Regional protocols. The relative effects of snowmobiles are
inferred from the miles of snowmobile trail in lynx habitat in
different alternatives.

collected DNA samples using established protocols since 2006 in

I assume, based on NRLMD guidance, that the effects of open
roads and snowmobile routes in lynx habitat are imposed
more by the access they provide competing carnivores and
trappers than by the general presence of humans on these
routes. Much of the background information for interpreting
results of field surveys and modeled habitat data has come
from the Lynx Science Report (USFS 1999), the Lynx
Conservation Assessment and Strategy (Ruediger et al. 2000),
The Scientific Basis for Conserving Forest Carnivores (USFS
1994) and recent fieldwork conducted in western Montana
by several research workers.
Basic guidance for grizzly bear management comes from the
Grizzly Bear Recovery Plan (1993) and the Interagency Grizzly
Bear Committee (IGBC) Guidelines (1986) and the Grizzly Bear
Management Plan for Western Montana (MFWP 2006).
Application of this direction is modified by ongoing research,
the slow expansion of occupied grizzly range southward
across the HNF and the development of updated
management documents.
The entire Travel Plan Area lies within the Grizzly Bear
“Distribution Zone”, the area south of Northern Continental
Divide Ecosystem (NCDE) Grizzly Bear Recovery Zone in
which grizzlies are known to be present. The original
Distribution Zone designated in 2005 was based on the
pattern of grizzly sightings to that point and was limited to
the area north of Mullan Pass. In 2013, however, based on
field observation accumulated from a variety of sources, the
Distribution Zone was expanded to cover the rest of the
landscape down to the Beaverhead-Deerlodge NF boundary.
Grizzly bear numbers throughout the landscape are assumed
to be very low and as a result, environmental assessments in
recent years have applied management guidelines for IGBC
Management Situation #5, which I assume is appropriate in

the MacDonald Pass area and parts of the Little Blackfoot and
Tenmile drainages (Gehman et al. 2007-2010). DNA from hair
and scat samples have been analyzed by the USFS Rocky Mtn
Research Station (Missoula) to identify species and individuals
(Pilgrim 2007-2010). We have made use also of track survey
transects run regularly by MFWP along the Divide for several
years, as well as fortuitous observations by a number of
individuals.

open roads. These patterns are shown separately for the
original Distribution Zone north of Mullan Pass and the newly
expanded Zone south of there. .
Information on distribution of grizzly bears and suitable habitat
components across the Divide landscape has been derived from
wildlife surveys by HNF biologists since the early 1990s, data
from MFWP and observations by field-going personnel and
Forest-users. Observations of bears have been ranked as to
credibilty and the information applied accordingly. Criteria
outlined in the Grizzly Bear Recovery Plan and the IGBC
Guidelines were served as the basis for analysis. We do not
have enough systematic observations by trained personnel to
allow us to estimate population numbers for the Divide
landscape or to determine if individuals are resident or
transient.

Sensitive Species
Northern Rocky
Mountain Gray Wolf

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) and MFWP biologists
have provided information on the status of wolves in the
Divide landscape regularly since the early 1990s. Much of
this data has been documented in Montana Wolf Program
Weekly Reports and Rocky Mtn Wolf Recovery Annual

come from field observations by HNF biologists, HNF field
crews, local residents and other Forest users. More recently,
we have garnered data from tracking surveys by Wild Things
Unlimited (Bozeman, MT). Because of the small number of
wolves in the Divide landscape at any one time, their
relatively high profile and the intense scrutiny given them by
monitoring agencies, I assume that we have a more complete
picture of local wolf populations than of any other wildlife
group in the landscape.

Wolverine

Information and assumptions used to analyze effects on
wolverine are documented in Hillis and Kennedy (2003) and
center around natal denning habitat. Since wolverines are
most vulnerable to disturbance at these sites in late winter
and early spring, I assume that the primary source of human
disturbance will come from snowmobiles.
Wolverines are often associated with large blocks of
unroaded country with minimal human presence and I
assume that these habitat zones are important to wolverine
population viability. Assessment of unroaded habitat has
employed information from elk security area analysis, grizzly
bear habitat analysis and corridor/linkage zone analysis,
each of which measures the size and arrangement of
unroaded habitat blocks in a different way. The rationale for

WILDLIFE - 260

The HNF used no specific methodology, only general field
surveys. Wild Things Unlimited has located wolves using specific
tracking and sample gathering protocols, although their efforts
are focused on forest carnivores rather than wolves.
Information on the whereabouts of wolves, wolf dens and
rendezvous sites has come mostly from fieldwork by the USFWS
and more recently, by MFWP. These efforts have included aerial
and ground-based radio telemetry. In determining effects, we
made use of local information from USFWS, MFWP and research
as identified in “References Cited”. Constant monitoring of the
small local wolf population (by MFWP) results in periodic
population estimates that are precise and accurate. Statewide
wolf counts, however, tend to underestimate the total
population, given its size and distribution: Recent Gray Wolf
Annual Reports by MFWP (2010-2012) discuss methodologies
employed to get at the actual size and configuration of the wolf
population.
Impacts to wolverine natal denning habitat typically come from
snowmobile activity (Hillis and Kennedy 2003). As the current
Regional habitat model has not identified any wolverine denning
habitat in the Divide landscape, I’ve approached this parameter
qualitatively. Fieldwork suggested areas that might provide
viable denning sites and the potential for snowmobile presence
was then inferred from Travel Plan alternative maps and the
Helena RD Snowmobile Trail map (2003). The most robust field
data on wolverines in the landscape comes from winter tracking
surveys by Wild Things Unlimited coupled with DNA analysis by
the USFS Rocky Mtn Research Station. Other field observations
come from MFWP biologists, HNF field workers, local residents,
recreationists and trappers. Since the needs of wolverines with
regard to unroaded habitat are murky, such habitat blocks were

Analysis of the fisher is based primarily on literature review.
Habitat has been modeled by the HNF GIS shop (USFS 2009)

With few recent fires in the Divide landscape, no blackbacked woodpecker surveys have been conducted. I assume,

The only methodology employed was to compute open road
miles in modeled fisher habitat (via GIS) and then calculate
acres within the 600 ft wide road corridor from which firewood
cutters could remove large snags and logs potentially useful to
fishers. The results are useful primarily as a relative measure to
compare alternatives. Systematic winter tracking surveys (Wild
Things Unlimited, 2006-2012) have regularly detected lynx and
wolverines in the central part of the Divide landscape, but have
found no sign of fishers. Likewise, a grid of hair-snag survey
stations in 2008 detected no fishers in the landscape. Reports of
fishers in this area have been fortuitous and rare and have not
been sufficient to allow an estimation of population numbers.

corridors have implications for black-backed woodpeckers, low
though their numbers may be. The methodology used to
determine these effects is described in the section on Snags and
Woody Debris.
While the survey and analysis methods used to characterize the
dead tree resource in well-defined, accessible road corridors
have generated estimates with a high degree of precision and
accuracy, the ongoing bark-beetle outbreak has produced a
moving target in terms of snag density and dispersion at any
given time. We can say, however, that numbers of large dead
trees are increasing significantly thoughout Divide road corridors
and the Travel Plan area as a whole.
No field surveys targeting black-backed woodpeckers have been
conducted in the Divide landscape, but they have been reported
in the MacDonald Pass burn (from 2009).

Given the high mortality of mature pine trees in the current bark

Hairy woodpecker habitat modeling is based on Region-1
protocols. A summary of how these protocols were applied
to HNF habitats can be found “Criteria for Wildlife Models
HNF” (USFS 2009). See also “Snags and Woody Debris”,

Information as to distribution, population density and habitat
use by hairy woodpeckers in the Divide landscape comes
from wildlfe field surveys and fortuitous observations since
1992 [HNF wildlife files]. Northern Region Landbird Surveys
have also provided data.
Based on this information, I assume that hairy woodpeckers
are very versatile as to the kinds of habitats they use and
that the Region-1 model, while delineating optimal
habitat,substantially underestimates total suitable habitat.
So, I have presented results both for (1) R-1 modeled habitat
(which is based, at least in part, on Hutto 1995) and for (2) an
expanded complex of mature forest habitat regardless of
stand density and evidence of dead trees. I base this latter
delineation on the assumption that all mature forest stands

designed to locate active nests. Nest sites are then mapped and
monitored. Once clusters of nests indicating the centers of
goshawk home ranges have been identified, it is possible to
identify additional potential goshawk ranges throughout the
landscape and survey in those areas. Field monitoring is
continuing, in particular, to document changes in goshawk home
range use patterns resulting from the mountain pine beetle
epidemic.
A tally of open road miles in goshawk nesting and foraging
habitat (and associated road corridor acreage) provides as a
mechanism for comparing potential indirect effects of snag
removal by firewood cutters under different alternatives.
Potential disturbance of existing nest stands from opening up of
currently closed roads under some alternatives provides an
additional means of comparison.
Given the high mortality of mature pine trees in the current bark
beetle epidemic, all mature stands with a ponderosa or
lodgepole pine component now support significantly more snags
than when HNF habitat models were last run. These
developments, combined with a habitat model that presents a
relatively narrow definition of hairy woodpecker habitat (which I
refer to as “optimal” nesting habitat), result in an underestimate
of habitat useful to these birds in the Travel Plan Area.
The key components that characterize optimal nesting habitat
are snag-rich mature forest stands (overstory trees >10 inches
dbh) of sparse-to-intermediate density (<50% canopy closure).
In the Divide landscape, this results in the delineation of
considerably less habitat than hairy woodpeckers have been
observed to use. So, I have also looked at mature forest habitat
in general as a suitable environment for hairy woodpeckers
(though not all of it may be nesting habitat). This includes all
stands classified as mature forest (dbh >7 inches) regardless of
density or evidence of dead trees.

Site-Specific Assessments
Local Effects in Key
Areas

Local areas addressed in this section were chosen based on
the extent to which they were treated differently under the 3
alternatives, their importance to the wildlife resource and in
some cases, the level of controversy they generated. I
assumed that by focusing on site-specific issues in these
particular localities, the implications of implementing each
alternative and the differences between alternatives, could
be clarified.
Data used to define the status of these areas with regard to
open road miles, local road densities and snowmobile area
closures were derived from the HNF Visitor Map, Divide
Travel Plan alternative maps and HNF “B-maps” (USGS
1:24,000 scale maps with the HNF road and trail system
superimposed).
More qualitative information on local wildlife resources and
their response to different road/trail scenarios was drawn
primarily from HNF wildlife field surveys (1992-2012), with
supplementary information coming from MFWP surveys and
mapping efforts, USFWS fieldwork and the HNF Roads
Analysis (2001-2004).

WILDLIFE - 265

The boundaries of local areas (for purposes of calculating road
densities) were defined by a combination of topographic
features and the reach of the local road system at issue. In a
number of cases, I drew boundaries along section lines. Road
miles were measured with an engineers’ compass and areas
determinied via dot grid: No GIS technology was applied, but
the precision and accuracy of the more primitive methodology
employed here can be assumed to be in the same range as
standard GIS estimates for areas of this magnitude.
Aside from these measurements, the bulk of the assessment is
based on more qualitative information dealing with local wildlife
associations, habitat configurations and expected responses to
the proposed scanarios presented by different alternatives.

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Affected Environment
Introduction
The Divide Travel Plan Area covers all but the southeastern corner (the Clancy-Unionville unit)
and the northern tip (Little Prickly Pear drainage) of the Divide landscape and encompasses a
wide range of wildlife habitats and wildlife species associations. Not all of these habitats and
species groups are affected by Forest travel management in ways that are measurable or
meaningful (in terms of individual species behavior, survivorship, or productivity). As a result,
not all of the wildlife parameters (species, habitats, habitat components) tallied in the following
table are analyzed and discussed in the body of the report that follows, though they may receive
some mention.
Parameters not carried forward in the report are those for which there are either no anticipated
impacts associated with alternatives or for which the impacts are addressed via analysis of a
surrogate species [the elk analysis, for example, provides a basis for inferring primary impacts
on white-tailed deer and moose]. As summarized in the previous section, the information
presented in this analysis comes from survey and observation in the field, accumulated
professional experience, discussion with other professionals and field-going personnel,
examination of scientific literature, GIS modeling analyses and conservation strategies and
recovery plans.

Table 82 identifies relevant wildlife parameters, the degree to which they have been analyzed
and the rationale for the level of analysis. Analysis categories include (1) detailed effects
assessment, (2) coverage under analyses for other parameters, (3) assessment of existing
condition only, or (4) summary in the Wildlife Analysis Approach Table (appendix A of the
wildlife specialist report).
