Only three of the six herd units currently comply with the standard for big game security (having
plotted out below the curve shown in Figure 22). Two of these (Jericho and Spotted Dog-Little
Blackfoot) support notably more hiding cover than the other 4 units. The third herd unit in
compliance (Black Mountain-Brooklyn Bridge) has moderate hiding cover, but it has the lowest
open road density of any herd unit in the landscape (with the Lazyman Inventoried Roadless
Area occupying more than half the unit). Failure of a herd unit to comply with the standard is
associated with vaious combinations of insufficient hiding cover (Quartz), high open road
density (Little Prickly Pear-Ophir), or both (Greenhorn). While open road density can be quickly
reduced by closing roads, an increase in hiding cover is the product of long, slow natural
processes that cannot be manipulated in the short term. In the meantime, hiding cover across
WILDLIFE - 302

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

the landscape is decreasing further as trees killed in the mountain pine beetle outbreak
continue to fall across much of the Travel Plan Area.
While the relationship between open road density and hiding cover can be informative, it does
not account for the spatial arrangement and size of unroaded patches, topography as a
mediator of hunter access, the distribution of forage and other factors that influence the ability
of elk to survive the hunting season. Forest stands that do not meet the definition of hiding
cover may prove to be secure areas for elk where local conditions of topography, remoteness
and environmental barriers impede hunter access. Conversely, blocks of hiding cover situated in
roaded country may be highly insecure. Hiding cover has a role to play but it is not synonymous
with security (Lyon and Canfield 1991; Unsworth and Kuck 1991; Lyon and Christensen 1992;
Christensen et al. 1993).
When the Helena Forest Plan was fashioned in the early 1980’s, the total elk population on the
Forest was estimated to be around 5,000 (4,900 elk in 1981) (HFP, p. V/5). Goals, objectives and
standards for big game in the Plan were designed, among other things, to provide enough
habitat on the National Forest to support 6,400 elk by 2000, in support of MFWP goals for
harvestable elk (HFP, p. V/5). Recent MFWP aerial survey data (2014) indicate that at least
11,350 elk inhabit the nine hunting districts that have major overlap with the Helena NF. This
total does not include elk on seven other hunting districts with relatively small overlap of Helena
NF lands. While some of the elk in the overlapping hunting districts spend all or part of their
time on non Forest land or on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge and Lewis and Clark NFs, a significant
number of them, well in excess of 6,400, are part of the Helena NF population.
Although elk populations in the Divide landscape have increased substantially since the 1980’s
and have been at or above MFWP population goals for several years, as well as exceeding
Helena NF population goals, big game standard 4a continues to indicate that elk security is substandard in half of the local herd units and barely above standard in the others. As such, the
index has been an imprecise and often uninformative guide to the state of elk security over the
past 25 plus years [see discussion in “Forest Plan Programmatic Amendment for Big Game
Security for the Divide Travel Plan”].

The Concept of Elk Security Areas

Since the release of the Helena Forest Plan in 1986, field research in the northern Rockies and
Pacific Northwest has led to the concept of “elk security areas” as a basis for assessing elk
vulnerability to hunting. The degree to which elk are able to survive the fall hunt is seen, in
large part, as a function of the size and pattern of habitat blocks, amply forested in most cases,
to which hunter access is limited and in which elk have consistent, unencumbered access to
basic resources. Hillis and others (1991) developed an analysis procedure (generally referred to
as the “Hillis method”) based on the availability of large non-linear blocks of habitat (greater
than or equal to 250 acres) ½ mile from open roads. The intent was that at least 30 percent of
the “hunting season home range” within a “standardized habitat analysis unit” be held in
security areas (Hillis et al., p. 39). This particular set of parameters was designed for denselyforested western Montana elk habitat and the Hillis team recommended that, particularly for
areas further east where forest cover was more limited, security requirements be evaluated on
a site-specific basis and the guidelines adjusted so that results made biological sense in a local
setting (Hillis et al. 1991, p. 40; Christensen et al. 1993, p. 5).

WILDLIFE - 303

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Forest Plan Amendment for Big Game Security

Under a Forest Plan amendment proposed for the Divide Travel Plan and applicable to future
projects in the Divide landscape, a “security area” approach would replace the current “hiding
cover/open road density index” as the Forest Plan standard for gauging the vulnerability of elk
to hunting [see “Forest Plan Programmatic Amendment for Big Game Security for the Divide
Travel Plan”]. The amendment derives from the Hillis methodology (1991), but it includes
modifications designed for “eastside” Forest environments in general and the Divide landscape
in particular. The specifics of the amendment come in part from guidelines worked out by
biologists from the Forest Service and Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks (MFWP) and
summarized in “U.S. Forest Service and Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks
Collaborative Overview and Recommendations for Elk Habitat Management on the Custer,
Gallatin, Helena and Lewis and Clark National Forests” (USFS and MFWP 2013). Other details
emerged from a series of meetings focused on big game management for the Divide Travel Plan:
Participants included Helena NF and MFWP biologists, as well as local interest groups (2013 to
2014).

The new standard [Forest Plan Programmatic Amendment] is based on three basic statements,
clarified by a series of definitionss, guidelines, goal statements and site-specific data for Divide
elk herd units. The standard reads as follows:
Road management will be implemented to maintain or improve big game security and
hunting opportunity.
•
Road management will also be implemented to maintain or improve big game
intermittent refuge areas [discussed below].
•
The standard applies only to the National Forest System lands within those portions of
an elk herd unit that are within the Helena Ranger District, Helena National Forest
administrative boundary.
Public motorized use will be managed during the hunting season (September 1 to December 1)
to maintain elk security at levels specified for each of the six Divide elk herd units under each
alternative proposed for the Divide Travel Plan. These baseline security levels are shown in
Table 109 and Table 110 in the “Environmental Consequences” section of this report. Security is
defined in terms of the percentage of an elk herd unit occupied by non-motorized security areas
[Table 109].
•

The goal of the standard is to maintain or improve elk security in herd units where
security/refuge areas occupy less than 50 percent of the unit and to keep it above 50 percent in
herd units that have achieved that level. Any decrease in percent security in herd units that are
under 50 percent, would represent non-compliance with the standard. Herd units would remain
in compliance as long as their security percentages hold steady or increase. The 50 percent
security area level (considerably higher than the 30 percent recommended by the Hillis group) is
based on what has been deemed desireable and achievable in the Blackfoot landscape just to
the north [Blackfoot Non-Winter Travel Plan FEIS, 2014]. For the sake of consistency, the 50
percent goal has been applied to the Divide landscape as well, although we recognize that, given
the entrenched nature of the State, County and Forest road system in the landscape west of
Helena, this percentage is unachievable on all but perhaps two of the six Divide herd units. The
fact that herd units are below 50 percent security does not mean that they are out of
compliance with the standard.

WILDLIFE - 304

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

The figures in Table 109 represent the baseline security levels that need to be maintained or
improved in order for herd units to continue complying with the standard under any given
alternative. Currently, percentages in a majority of herd units are low [Table 89; Table 109,
Alternative 1]: But they represent security levels that have been allowing MFWP to meet its elk
population objectives in local hunting districts, or in those portions of the districts associated
with Divide landscape herd units [Table 92 and Table 93]. The inference is that, although
percentages are well below 50 percent, the current arrangement of security and refuge areas is,
for the time being, operating effectively.

Delineating Elk Security in the Divide Landscape

In delineating elk security areas, we have relied on guidelines recently developed by MFWP and
Helena NF biologists (USFS and MFWP 2013) with additional input from interested local groups
and individuals. These criteria and the elk security areas that arise from them in the Divide
landscape are summarized in the proposed Forest Plan Programmatic Amendment for Big Game
Security [following report].
While distance from open motor routes is the essential parameter used to define the
boundaries of elk security areas, a number of other components come into play in determining
what that distance should be and how large the area needs to be in order to provide effective
security. Hillis et al. (1991) identified deficient forest cover as a potential problem for “eastside”
Forests in Montana. Other factors that can diminish the integrity of a security area include:

small size (in the 250 acre range),
•
narrow or irregular shape (excessive edge and access opportunity),
•
gentle terrain (which encourages hunters to probe further into the area),
•
scarcity of physical barriers (such as cliffs, talus, broad streams, bogs, deadfall)
•
limited elevational range (which limits elk use to only part of the hunting season),
•
forest structure that is open or highly fragmented,
•
few interior foraging areas (which forces elk to leave the security area to find food),
•
isolation from other security areas (no credible travel corridors between areas),
•
an interior network of closed roads and trails (providing walking lanes for hunters),
•
proximity to local population centers (which generally leads to high hunting pressure),
•
multiple entry points (trailheads, roadside pullouts, parking areas).
Factors that increase the effectiveness of security areas are the converse of those listed above:
large size, plentiful forest cover, minimal trails and old roadways, rugged terrain, heavy deadfall
and so on.
•

In developing the guidelines, we recognized that all of these factors may influence the ability of
an area to hold elk through the hunting season; but we felt that the key component was size.
Accordingly, rather than adjust individual security area boundaries to account for a multiplicity
of factors, we simply set the minimum size of a bona fide “elk security area” at 1,000 acres,
considerably larger than the 250 acre minimum recommended by Hillis et al. for “westside”
Forests. This is an adjustment for “eastside” cover conditions and it also conforms to the 1,000acre security area minimum recently established for the Blackfoot Non-Winter Travel Plan Area
on the Lincoln Ranger District just to the north (USFS 2014).
A number of smaller habitat blocks (between 250 and 1,000 acres) that have been classified as
security areas in past analyses are now designated as “intermittent refuge areas”. While most
WILDLIFE - 305

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

of these areas are probably too small to hold elk securely throughout the hunting season, they
serve as temporary refuges for hunted animals and in parts of the Divide landscape, they
represent the only escape areas available [see Figure 23]. While their acreages are not added
into the security area total for a given elk herd unit, they have been mapped and noted as areas
that need to be managed for elk security.
We calculate elk security on a herd unit basis [see “Elk Herd Units” in the following section].
Herd units along the Helena NF boundary have been drawn to extend 1.5 mile out onto nonForest land. But, in delineating security areas, we do so only for the area within Helena NF
administrative boundaries (see USFS and MFWP 2013). This is where MFWP and the Helena NF
would like to retain elk in the hunting season: public land open to all hunters (where the Forest
Service has management control and the ability to close roads). By excluding from the security
calculation those portions of the herd units that lie outside the Forest boundary, we have
omitted security provided by private lands on which public hunting is barred and on which elk
have been learning to seek refuge with increasing frequency. MFWP and the Helena NF feel
that relying on these sanctuaries for security is undesirable since it decreases public hunting
opportunity. In addition, the status of private lands can be in flux over the long-term,
depending on landowner decisions that may have little consideration for the welfare of elk. So,
while I have accounted for the role that these lands play in influencing elk security on the
National Forest as a cumulative effect, I have not analyzed it as a direct effect on Helena NF
land.
Elk security areas are now delineated as habitat blocks of at least 1,000 acres [250 acres for
intermittent refuge areas] with borders ½ mile from roads and motor trails open during the big
game hunting season. Security area boundaries have also been pulled back ½ mile from private
land holdings that support active roads somewhere on the property. This has eliminated some
areas that had previously been delineated as security areas and it has reduced the size of others.
At the recommendation of MFWP, the hunting season was defined to include both the general
rifle and archery seasons, thus occupying most of the period between September 1 and
December 1 [USFS and MFWP 2013, p. 13]. Open routes in this period were determined via the
road and trail attribute layers in the Helena NF GIS data base and security area boundaries
drawn accordingly. Resulting areas are shown in Figure 23.

The Role of Forest Cover

While the new Forest Plan Programmatic Amendment does not require that elk security areas
provide a particular level of hiding cover, it does recognize forest cover as an important
component of security and includes a set of guidelines for managing cover on fall elk ranges
[following report]. The guidelines focus on maintaining cover where it exists within security
areas and in travel lanes between them. Where cover is not available, the guidelines emphasize
managing for its recruitment. Abundant cover is most valuable in areas known to be frequented
by elk: saddles, low divides, drainage-heads, riparian/ wetland sites and the upper third of
slopes in large drainages. These objectives do not apply to areas where hiding cover has not
been abundant historically because of intrinsic environmental conditions (primarily in dry
grasslands and shrublands and in dry Douglas-fir and ponderosa pine forests).

The guidelines also recognize that forest cover that is not dense enough or tall enough to
provide classic hiding cover may still provide concealment in certain circumstances or otherwise
allow animals to elude hunters. In this analysis, I refer to three levels of forest cover:

WILDLIFE - 306

Environmental Impact Statement

•
•

•

Divide Travel Plan

“hiding cover” provided by conifers capable of hiding 90 percent of a standing elk or
deer at 200 feet, the standard definition from the Forest Plan;
“screening cover” provided by conifers and other vegetation that afford longer sight
distances than hiding cover but that can obstruct a clear view toward standing or
moving animals;
“concealment cover” provided by small conifers, shrubs, boulders, or coarse woody
debris that can hide calves/fawns and bedded adults (and may serve to impede hunter
movement).

The Role of Off-Forest Lands in Providing Elk Security

Another factor contributing to elk security is land ownership pattern. In recent years, more elk
have been finding fall refuge on large blocks of private land off the National Forest. This occurs
when ranchers or other owners of large parcels near the Forest prohibit or restrict public
hunting. In parts of the Divide landscape, elk have been quick to identify the security value of
these private lands. A recent study by MFWP concluded that, given the choice, elk prefer
unhunted sanctuaries on private lands to traditional security areas on public land (MFWP 2011c;
Proffitt et al. 2010, 2013) (see also Burcham et al. 1999). The immediate impetus to move to
private land prior to or early in the hunting season may be driven by inadequate security and an
overabundance of hunters and motorized recreationists on public lands. Later in the season,
because most private refuges are located at lower elevation, it may be generated by
accumulating snow and declining forage availability in the mountains. It may also be a function
of elk instinctively returning to historic valley ranges as lands become available for them to do
so.
Regardless of the reasons, these private sanctuaries are acting as valley and foothills “security
areas” that augment security (as defined by Hillis et al.) on public land. With private land,
however, hunter access is often completely precluded rather than simply made more difficult by
walking distance and terrain as with National Forest security areas [see discussion of the
Deerlodge and Granite Butte EMUs in the Montana Elk Management Plan (MFWP 2004, p. 187203)]. Hunting opportunity is thus diminished. On the other hand, given the checkerboard
pattern of public and private land ownership in the valleys, groups of elk sometimes drift into
unprotected areas where they are vulnerable to being surrounded and indiscriminantly shot by
opportunistic hunters in vehicles. For these reasons, wildlife managers see the accumulation of
elk in the valleys during the hunting season as problematic.

As seen in Table 89, only one herd unit, Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot, approaches the 30 percent
security acreage threshold proposed by Hillis et al. (1991). Even when intermittent refuge areas
are added in, percentages of all herd units remain well below the idealized 50 percent goal set
for the Blackfoot and Divide landscapes. Strategic road closures can bring some percentages up
appreciably, but this is not feasible in some herd units. These percentages represent the
baseline condition that allow each of these herd units to comply with the amended elk security
standard at the present time (alternative 1). As long as the acreages and perc entages do not
decline, the herd units remain in compliance.
It should be noted that although some of the herd units have very low on-Forest security levels,
elk are able to compensate in most cases by taking advantage of private lands where public
hunting is not allowed or where access is difficult. The relationship between these security area
percentages and the status of local elk populations will be discussed in following sections.

Elk Herd Units
To analyze the effects of Helena NF actions on elk, we have partitioned the Divide landscape
into six elk herd units (EHUs) [Figure 23 and Figure 27]. Elk herd units include all lands within
Helena NF boundaries, public and private and adjacent land out to 1.5 miles beyond the
boundary (mostly private holdings, but some BLM and State land) [see Figure 27, following].
This extension delineates an off-Forest area used by elk that remain dependent on the National
Forest throughout the winter (often returning to the Forest to bed after foraging in off-Forest
grasslands) [see appendix D of the wildlife specialist report]. The delineation eliminates areas
occupied by elk that move well away from the Forest for the duration of the winter. The only
area excluded from 1.5 mile extension occurs along the northeast edge of the Black Mountain–
Brooklyn Bridge EHU where the off-Forest zone extends into the City of Helena, an area
inhabited by deer, but not elk. EHUs are used to calculate compliance with Forest Plan big game
standards 2, 3 and 4a (HFP, pp. II/17-18).
Current EHUs in the Divide landscape were delineated in 2003 by Helena NF and MFWP
biologists and modified in 2007, 2008 and 2011. Three modifications were made: (1) the
addition of the 1.5 mile zone beyond the Forest boundary to better represent the influence of
Forest management on wintering elk; (2) extension of the Greenhorn EHU boundary well
beyond the 1.5 mile limit to reflect known movements of MFWP radio-collared elk and (3) the
merging of the Spotted Dog and Little Blackfoot herd units into a single unit to better reflect
how elk groups intermingle in that area in summer and fall.

WILDLIFE - 311

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Herd units are designed to encompass areas occupied by relatively cohesive groups of elk on the
National Forest. The delineations are imperfect, however, for a number of reasons: (1) herd
units are mapped as discrete areas, whereas elk herd home ranges often overlap; (2) mapped
herd unit boundaries are fixed, whereas elk ranges on the ground may be fluid from one year to
another; (3) some groups of elk within a herd may occupy one mapped herd unit in summer and
another in winter; (4) the delineation of what constitutes a unified “elk herd”, “herd unit” or
“herd group” is often difficult to pin down and mapped herd units may differ in size and pattern
depending on the idiosyncrasies of the mapper and the quality of the field data; (5) yearlong elk
ranges often run well beyond National Forest boundaries and for purposes of analyzing the
impacts of Forest management, herd unit boundaries need to be cut off at some point near the
Forest boundary, often well short of where elk may actually go in some winters.
Given these circumstances, a case can be made for using terms such as “elk analysis unit” or “elk
analysis area” to identify the fixed, discrete areas that the Helena NF has mapped out for
purposes of assessing elk habitat and reserving the term “elk herd unit” to describe the dynamic
groupings of elk that management agency biologists have identified through long-term field
observation. For the time being, however, in order to maintain a certain consistency, I will
continue to apply the term “elk herd units” to these Helena NF elk assessment areas.
In the Divide landscape, most EHU boundaries have been drawn along primary drainage
bottoms so that the EHUs encompass cohesive summer ranges at higher elevation. Before
2003, most herd unit boundaries had followed major ridgelines, thus splitting the areas used by
elk herd groups in summer. In winter, elk that have spent the summer in a given herd unit on
the National Forest may diverge onto two or more non-Forest winter ranges, where they mingle
with elk that have summered on other herd units (G. Joslin, pers. comm. 2003). Summer range
centered units thus seemed a more accurate characterization of elk activity on Helena NF
ground.
Current herd units in the Divide landscape are quite large compared to those used prior to 2003
and those in use on several other Forests in Region 1. Pre-2003 Divide herd units were the size
of timber compartments, roughly 4,000 to 12,000 acres, whereas present-day Divide units range
from around 35,000 acres to 87,000 acres (Table 88). This brings them into line with herd units
in the Elkhorn and Big Belt landscapes. These units may encompass the ranges of two or more
smaller elk “herd groups”. Because the movements of these smaller groups on summer and
transitional ranges may be difficult to map with any consistency from year to year (without radio
telemetry data), the larger, stable units make more sense for habitat analysis.
The Travel Plan Area takes in parts of six elk herd units in the Divide landscape: The Plan Area
does not include the 1.5 mile extension beyond Helena NF boundaries or National Forest land
covered by previous travel planning efforts. These include the Clancy-Unionville area (much of
the Quartz and Black Mountain – Brooklyn Bridge EHUs) and most of the upper Little Prickly
Pear drainage (half of the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU). Forest Plan compliance, however, is
calculated for entire elk herd units, not just on the portions that fall within the Travel Plan Area.
In Table 90, “Total Acres in EHU” includes all public and private land within administrative
boundaries of the Helena NF plus the 1.5 mile extension onto non-Forest land. The category
“EHU Acres within Helena NF Administrative Boundaries” is larger than “Total Acres of Helena
NF land within EHU” due to non-Forest inholdings inside the administrative boundary. The
arrangement of elk herd units in the Divide landscape is shown on the map in Figure 23, which

LITTLE PRICKLY PEAR–OPHIR Elk Herd Unit
The Little Prickly Pear–Ophir Creek EHU straddles the Continental Divide south of the Helena/
Lincoln RD boundary. It covers the upper reaches of the Little Prickly Pear Creek watershed east
of the Divide and the headwaters of the greater Dog Creek and Ophir Creek drainages west of
the Divide. Prior to 2003, the Helena NF recognized two herd units in this area (“Ophir” west of
the Divide and “Little Prickly Pear” east of it). Regular movement of elk across the Divide in
summer and fall, led MFWP to suggest merging the two units in 2003. The resulting Ophir–Little
Prickly Pear EHU is now the largest in the Divide landscape at 87,022 acres. About 37,300 acres
(43 percent) of the EHU are in private or other non-Forest ownership.
Much of the northern half of the unit (mostly east of the Divide) is in unroaded country that
abuts the Nevada Creek Roadless area on the Lincoln District to the northwest. As a result, elk
security in this half of the unit is good. Hunters are aware of the high fall elk density in this
roadless country and a substantial number of them push into the area on foot or horseback
during both the bow and rifle seasons and with a certain degree of success. This is the kind of
area that MFWP feels is producing a “high-quality hunting experience”. Security west of the
Divide (the southern half of the herd unit), however, is impaired. Open roads are ubiquitous,
particularly in the Dog Creek drainage and there are no unroaded habitat patches large enough
to qualify even as intermittent refuge areas. Shortly after the start of the rifle season, elk in this
area retreat to a limited number of small enclaves, the largest being in unroaded country south
and west of Black Mountain. Overall, 23 percent of the area within Helena NF boundaries in the
Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU is occupied by effective elk security areas (Table 89, Table 91). Elk
do make use of a number of smaller unroaded enclaves for temporary refuge, in particular, in
forested sites around Esmeralda Hill, LaSalle Gulch, Cellar and Ogilve Gulches and Spring Gulch.
Summer habitat effectiveness (based on open road/ motor trail density) shows a similar pattern:
very high in the Little Prickly Pear watershed east of the Divide, considerably lower west of the
Divide. Overall habitat effectiveness for the entire EHU (including the 1.5 mile off-Forest
extension) is 54 percent, above the recommended minimum of 50 percent. The non-motorized
portion of the Little Prickly Pear watershed is particularly effective as summer habitat. One of
the only “large” burns to have occurred in the Divide landscape in the past few decades is
located here in Beartrap Gulch and the South Fork of Little Prickly Pear Creek. It dates from the
1960s and while it retains few snags, it provides excellent summer foraging opportunities for
WILDLIFE - 313

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

elk. Mule Deer, black bears and grizzly bears also make use of the burn in summer. GIS
modeling estimates that 60 percent of the EHU provides hiding cover (Table 91).
Bona-fide winter range [see the Helena NF Oil and Gas Leasing EIS (USFS, USFWS 1995)] is
limited to the northern end of the EHU around Cayuse Ridge and Ogilve Gulch and to private
ranchlands in the broad valleys of Little Prickly Pear Creek and its tributaries to the east. Elk
utilize the Helena NF portion of the “winter range” primarily as transitional range in spring and
fall but may remain through part of the winter if snow conditions allow.

GREENHORN Elk Herd Unit
The Greenhorn EHU lies astride the Continental Divide. Roughly 80 percent of it is on the east
side of the Divide in the upper Tenmile and Silver Creek drainages. The west side is drained by
tributaries of Dog Creek. The EHU encompasses MacDonald, Priest and Mullan Passes, all
primary cross-over corridors for big game animals and humans. Although the EHU occupies
56,314 acres, approximately 36,400 acres (65 percent) are in private or other non-Forest
ownership. The acreage of National Forest land in this EHU is the smallest in the Divide
landscape. The extensive off-Forest acreage is a function of the eastern EHU boundary being
extended well beyond the normal 1.5 mile limit, based on MFWP radio-telemetry data from the
1990s [see Figure 27]. This data is not available for other herd units.
Most of the National Forest portion of the unit is at high elevation along the Divide and serves
as elk transitional range (mostly spring) and to a lesser extent as summer range. Although
summer habitat effectiveness, as indicated by open road density, is acceptable (55 percent),
elevated levels of human activity associated with the three passes (each with a primary road
running through) and widespread livestock grazing dilute summer use potential in some areas.
The unit supports broad grasslands along the Divide and down the west slope [Figure 10] and
elk graze through these areas conspicuously in spring before human use begin to escalate and
cattle arrive. GIS modeling estimates that hiding cover occupies about 56 percent of EHU
summer range. Summer range in this herd unit covers only about 54 percent of the unit,
another derivative of MFWP radio-telemetry data. Hiding cover on the unit as a whole is only 41
percent (Table 88, Table 91).
Effective elk security areas (greater than or equal to 1,000 acres) occupy only about seven
percent of the area within Helena NF boundaries, with the unroaded areas concentrated
between Greenhorn and Sweeney Creeks, around Greenhorn Mountain and in the upper Little
Porcupine drainage. Smaller, less effective security enclaves are situated in upper Greenhorn
Creek, upper Blue Cloud Creek, Rich Spur Gulch and around Priest Pass, among other sites. The
lower elevation segments of the herd unit east of the Divide between Sweeney and Greenhorn
Creeks provide some winter range, but most winter use occurs off the Forest on both sides of
the Divide.

SPOTTED DOG–LITTLE BLACKFOOT Elk Herd Unit
The Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot EHU is a complex unit. It is situated west of the Continental
Divide in the upper Little Blackfoot watershed and occupies a large area between Telegraph
Creek to the east and the Helena NF boundary area to the west. It includes the headwaters of
the Little Blackfoot River (the Electric Peak Roadless Area), which covers about 28,000 acres in
the southern part of the unit [Figure 12]. The herd unit was formed in 2011 by merging two
smaller units (the Spotted Dog and Little Blackfoot EHUs) because of the tendency of elk herd

WILDLIFE - 314

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

groups to move between the two areas in summer and fall. It is now the second largest herd
unit in the Divide landscape with 82,314 acres of public and private land.
Currently, 31 percent of the herd unit is in non-Forest ownership. About 5,750 acres are in
private inholdings on the National Forest and another 20,075 acres in private and State
ownership in the 1.5 mile extension beyond the Forest boundary (most of it private). The
western part of the herd unit extends into the 38,000 acre Spotted Dog Wildlife Management
Area (WMA) established by the State of Montana in 2010 following the purchase of a large
private holding. In addition to the 1.5 mile herd unit extension into the WMA, another 3,700
acres of newly acquired State land within the Helena NF boundary is also part of the
management area. Most of the old road system in the WMA is off-limits to public vehicle traffic
yearlong and this contributes to the quality of big game security and habitat effectiveness in the
herd unit.
MFWP seasonal range maps identify the eastern quarter of the EHU, the broad grasslands atop
Baldy Ridge and the ridges south of Elliston, as potential winter range [Figure 39]. However,
MFWP aerial surveys (late winter or early spring) over the last 15 years, Helena NF field
observations and relocations of radio collared elk (1983 to 1997) demonstrate that these sites
are being used as spring/fall transitional range and as summer range, but not as wintering areas.
Aside from the presence of a few isolated individuals early and late in the season, there is no
evidence of winter use. Virtually all true winter range associated with this herd unit occurs off
the National Forest on private and State land to the west and north [Figure 21] where winter
foraging habitat is extensive and not limiting (at least under current circumstances) [see the
discussion of elk winter range in the “Environmental Consequences” section].
Most of the Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot herd unit functions as elk summer range. In the west
half of the unit, the best habitat is concentrated around the heads of stream tributaries, which
drain the area in all directions. The east half of the EHU includes much of the headwaters of the
Little Blackfoot River and greater Telegraph Creek, virtually all of it summer range for elk, mule
deer, moose, black bears, lynx, coyotes, mountain lions and others. It is amply forested, most
typically by mature lodgepole pine that originated with stand replacing fires around 1900. Much
of the forest canopy in these stands is now dead from bark beetle infestation, although stands
dominated by smaller diameter trees often manage to resist the beetle [Figure 24]. Productive
wet habitat occupies the headwaters of the unit’s multifarious streams, but large wet meadows
are limited, some of the most conspicuous being located in upper Bison and Ontario Creeks
[Figure 20], around Slate Lake [Figure 54] and at Blackfoot Meadows near the origin of the
Little Blackfoot.
There has been considerable timber harvest around Treasure Mountain and along Ontario and
Telegraph Creeks, as well as in the upper Spotted Dog drainage to the west, all with attendant
road systems. But, because of the extent of the Roadless Area, overall habitat effectiveness is
sufficient (56 percent). Habitat effectiveness in the Roadless Area (including that in the
extensive unroaded country to the immediate south on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge NF) is 100
percent. GIS modeling estimates that 65 percent of the EHU provides hiding cover (Table 89,
Table 91), although this percentage is beginning to decline as beetle-killed lodgepole pine comes
down over thousands of acres. This lost cover will be replaced eventually by natural
regeneration of the pine forests, but it is a process that will take 20 to 30 years to run its course.
Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks biologists recognize the Spotted Dog and upper Little Blackfoot
country on the Helena NF, along with adjacent private and State land to the west (much of it in

WILDLIFE - 315

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

the Spotted Dog Wildlife Management Area), as a fertile area for elk [the northern part of
Hunting District 215]. Winter surveys in the last decade have typically 400 to 500 elk west of the
National Forest in this region (R. Vinkey, personal communication, 2005 to 2008). Surveys from
2010 to 2014 have counted over 1,000 elk in this area (MFWP Elk Surveys in HD 215, 2010 to
2014).
The Spotted Dog – Little Blackfoot EHU affords excellent security for elk through as much of the
hunting season as snow conditions allow. Currently, effective elk security areas occupy 29
percent of fall elk range, the most of any herd unit in the Divide landscape. The combination of
security and intermittent refuge areas comes to 33 percent. The largest block of security is
associated with the Electric Peak Roadless Area in the southern half of the unit [Figure 24].
Most problems with elk security involve lower elevation security habitat that comes into play
after elk have been forced out of higher elevation roadless areas by snow and deteriorating
forage later in the hunting season. Cover and road density is at issue in the Negro Mountain,
Treasure Mountain, lower Telegraph Creek and Spotted Dog Creek areas [see local area
assessments in “Local Effects in Key Areas” toward the end of this report].
In addition to taking advantage of security habitat on the National Forest, many elk, beginning in
September, drop down into the Wildlife Management Area immediately west of the Forest.
Until recently, most of this land (about 27,000 acres) was owned by the Rock Creek Ranch
Corporation and MFWP had identified it as a problem area because of the refuge it provided for
substantial numbers of elk on ground where public hunting was highly restricted [Montana Elk
Management Plan (2004), Deerlodge EMU]. In September 2010, the State was able to purchase
a large portion of the private holdings and establish the Wildlife Management Area. The area is
open to public hunting, but with limitations (the main restraint being that most of the area is
closed to motor vehicles) [see summary in the Helena Independent Record, Oct. 21, 2010; MFWP
website http://fwp.mt.gov/news/article].
I have no harvest data specific to the Wildlife Management Area for the 2010 to 2014 seasons,
but it seems likely that from now on, hunting-generated mortality in this elk herd will be a bit
higher than in the past. Still, the fact that the Wildlife Management Area is mostly nonmotorized allows it to function much like an elk security area on the National Forest.

JERICHO Elk Herd Unit
The Jericho Mountain EHU lies south of U.S. Highway 12, extending westward from Tenmile
Creek over the Continental Divide to Telegraph Creek. It includes private land in the valleys off
its northern edge and encompasses a total of 35,345 acres, 29,364 acres within Helena NF
administrative boundaries. Aside from the valleylands to the north, most private land in the
EHU is on old mining claims, including part of the town of Rimini. Approximately 33 percent of
the EHU is in private ownership. Much of the northern half of the herd unit is occupied by the
9,440-acre Jericho Mountain inventoried Roadless Area, located primarily on the east side of the
Divide in the Tenmile Creek watershed, but lapping westward into the Telegraph Creek drainage
in the vicinity of Mike Renig Gulch in the north and Jericho Mountain in the south. This largely
unroaded habitat block provides most of the fall elk security in the Jericho EHU.
Some of the montane grasslands in the northern end of the unit above Lazyman and Mike Renig
Gulches provide winter habitat for elk in most years. These areas are identified as such on both
the MFWP seasonal range map and the Helena NF “Oil and Gas” winter range map. The rest of
the unit is transitional and summer range, with viable summer habitat concentrated in the
southern half toward the headwaters of Tenmile and Telegraph Creeks and their tributaries.

WILDLIFE - 316

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Most of the herd unit is covered with mature forest (much of it deteriorating from mountain
pine beetle infestation). Upland grasslands occur in the northern end of the unit and at a few
locations along the Divide (as at Bullion Parks). Wet meadows also break the forest continuum
in some areas: those in Flume Gulch, Sure Thing Swamps and Sally Ann Creek are particularly
productive as summer wildlife habitat [Figure 8, Figure 20, Figure 49].
Extensive clearcutting (mostly in the 1970s and 1980s) in the greater Hahn Creek and upper
Telegraph Creek drainages west of the Divide also serves to disrupt the contiguity of the mature
forest. Cutting units are now dominated by regenerating conifer saplings (mostly lodgepole pine
and Douglas-fir), many of which provide hiding cover for big game animals and habitat for
snowshoe hares and the lynx that prey upon them [Figure 51, Figure 52]. Lynx are resident in
this area year-round, as are wolverines. The Tenmile drainage, east of the Divide, serves as part
of the water supply for the City of Helena and as a result, has seen very limited timber harvest
on public land over the past several decades. Forest cover is ubiquitous, but as with other areas
in the Divide landscape that are dominated by pine forests, mountain pine beetle infestation is
taking out a majority of the overstory trees.
Historic logging (dating from the late 19th and early 20th centuries) and mining have generated
far-flung road systems, some still open to vehicle use, others closed. Habitat effectiveness in
summer is now at 70 percent, which is quite good (Table 91). GIS modeling estimates that 73
percent of the EHU provides hiding cover, a percentage that is beginning to decline as pine
beetle mortality escalates. About 12 percent of Helena NF hunting season elk range is currently
in security areas, much of it associated with the Jericho Mountain Roadless Area. When
intermittent refuge areas areas are added in, security rises to around 15 percent. Because the
herd unit is relatively close to the city of Helena and other local population centers, fall hunting
pressure is fairly high.

BLACK MOUNTAIN – BROOKLYN BRIDGE Elk Herd Unit
Less than half of the Black Mountain–Brooklyn Bridge EHU lies within the Divide Travel Plan
Area: The rest is in the Clancy-Unionville Travel Plan Area to the east [Figure 27]. The EHU as a
whole covers 53,840 acres. Roughly 40 percent is in private ownership, much of it along Forest
boundaries in the Little Prickly Pear and Tenmilevalleys to the north and east. There are, in
addition, a couple arrays of interconnected private inholdings in the major gulches running
northward into Helena and in the greater Buffalo Creek drainage further south.
This herd unit supports a variety of summer, winter and transitional ranges. About 85 percent
of the unit is mapped as potential winter range (by both MFWP and the Helena NF), more than
any other EHU in the Divide landscape, but most elk winter use is confined to the northern half
of the unit toward Helena and the Tenmile Valley [and outside the Divide Travel Plan Area]. The
rest of the unit to the south sees most of its elk use from May through November. Most of the
northwest half of the EHU lies within the Lazyman Inventoried Roadless Area, which provides
excellent habitat for elk in spring, summer and fall [see Figure 26]. By contrast, the eastern half
of the unit sits adjacent to the City of Helena and to burgeoning rural settlement in the lower
Tenmile and Prickly Pear valleys. As a consequence, the road and trail systems in this area are
the most heavily used of any in the National Forest. The eastern and western halves of the unit
thus stand in stark contrast to one another in terms of human activity levels.
Given the influence of the Roadless Area, which occupies more than half the National Forest
land in the herd unit, summer range habitat effectiveness in the Black Mountain–Brooklyn
Bridge EHU is the highest in the Divide landscape at 65 percent (Table 91). This has been
WILDLIFE - 317

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

augmented in the east half of the unit by new road/motor trail closures under the ClancyUnionville Travel Management Plan (Helena NF 2003). The area centered on Black Hall
Meadows in the Roadless Area is particularly important as summer habitat. The proportion of
fall range in effective elk security areas is 16 percent in the EHU as a whole (Table 89 and Table
91). The combined contribution of security and intermittent refuge areas is 18 percent. All
security and refuge areas (greather than or equal to 250 acres) are situated in the western half
of the herd unit (within the Divide Travel Plan Area), accounting for nearly 50 percent of that
area. This is important because the area’s proximity to Helena consistently translates to high
hunting pressure each fall. GIS modeling estimates that 57 percent of the EHU provides hiding
cover, although cover levels are on the verge of declining as beetle-killed pine trees continue to
come down.

QUARTZ Elk Herd Unit
The Quartz Creek EHU lies mostly within the Clancy-Unionville Travel Plan Area, but its western
extremities around Red Mountain fall into the Divide Travel Plan Area [Figure 27]. The unit
encompasses the headwaters of several drainages flowing eastward into Prickly Pear Creek:
Corral Gulch, Lump Gulch, the North and South Forks of Quartz Creek, Clancy Creek, Kady Gulch,
Wood Chute Creek and Spring Gulch. The diminutive western segment of the herd unit in the
Divide Plan Area takes in the westward slope down to Tenmile and Banner Creeks, including the
country around Chessman Reservoir and Red Mountain. The EHU includes much private and
BLM land in the Prickly Pear valley to the east: Just over 50 percent of the herd unit is in nonForest ownership. The unit covers 36,733 acres, with 23,036 acres inside Helena NF boundaries,
making it one of the two smallest herd units in the Divide landscape.
Most of the Quartz Creek EHU serves as transitional and summer range for elk. Typically, the
drainage-head basins in the western half of the unit provide the basic summering areas. Some
of this habitat has been disrupted by timber harvest and roading and more significantly, by old
mining operations that have polluted wet meadows and other key summer habitats. These
contaminated sites are gradually being reclaimed, one by one, with mine wastes hauled to offsite repositories and the local habitats returning to a semblance of normalcy. Recent closures of
a number of roads and motor trails under the Clancy-Unionville Travel Management Plan have
improved habitat effectiveness in this area as well. Current summer habitat effectiveness is 75
percent, comfortably above the recommended level of 50 percent. The main contribution of the
Clancy-Unionville restrictions has been the elimination of motor routes into a number of key
wet sites important to elk and other wildlife species.
Because of the fairly even distribution of roads throughout the herd unit, Clancy-Unionville
travel restrictions have been less effective at producing viable elk security areas. Currently,
there are no unroaded blocks large enough to qualify as elk security areas (greater than or equal
to 1,000 acres), but there are two intermittent refuge areas (Little Corral Gulch and Roe Gulch).
Elk survive the hunting season by moving between numerous smaller unroaded habitat enclaves
and taking advantage of private lands east of the EHU where public hunting is barred or limited.
Public lands in this herd unit are readily accessible to nearby population centers in the Helena
and Prickly Pear Valleys and hunting pressure is substantial. GIS modeling estimates that 57
percent of the EHU currently provides hiding cover, although pine beetle-generated mortality
will reduce cover dramatically in the next 10 to 15 years.
MFWP has mapped over 80 percent of the herd unit as potential winter range. The Helena NF
“Oil and Gas” seasonal range maps, on the other hand, show only the northeastern 20 percent

WILDLIFE - 318

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

of Helena NF land within the unit as winter range, which, as it turns out, is where more than 95
percent of the on Forest winter elk use in this herd unit has been observed over the last 25
years. This is the area between Corral Gulch to the north and Quartz Creek to the south. The
majority of the winter elk use occurs in the foothills and valleylands east of the Helena NF
boundary.

Summary of EHU Habitat Parameters

Table 91 summarizes the current status of several key parameters used to assess elk habitat in
elk herd units. Three parameters, percent hiding cover on summer range, percent thermal
cover on winter range and percent of fall range in security areas, are Helena Forest Plan big
game standards. The remaining parameters, hunting season open route density and percent
habitat effectiveness on summer range, are not Forest Plan standards, but they are recognized
as useful indictors of elk habitat status. The measurements in Table 91 are for entire Elk Herd
Units, not just the portions of the units that fall within the Divide Travel Plan Area.

Currently, only one herd unit (Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot) is close to the Hillis
recommendation of 30 percent security for “westside” fall ranges and none approaches the
Blackfoot/Divide goal of 50 percent. All of these EHUs will comply with the new Programmatic
Amendment for big game as long as security is maintained at current levels or increases. Under
current circumstances, these security levels are allowing MFWP to meet its elk population
objectives in areas influenced by Divide elk herd units [see following discussion, “Local Elk
Populations” ]. All five of the EHUs that include winter range are out of compliance with the
HFP thermal cover standard (greater than or equal to 25 percent cover on winter range). All six
herd units comply with the summer range hiding cover standard (greater than or equal to 50
percent cover on summer range), but within the next 10 to 15 years as large numbers of
lodgepole, ponderosa and whitebark pine trees killed in the bark beetle outbreak begin to fall,
all of these units will eventually fail to comply with this standard. Although many standing trees
are now dead, they continue to provide essentially the same level of hiding cover as when they
were alive. Eventually (greater than 25 years), new hiding cover will be provided by
regenerating pine saplings in most beetle-impacted areas. But for now, the situation is in flux.

Local Elk Populations
Elk Management Units

The Divide Travel Plan Area falls within two of the Elk Management Units (EMUs) described in
the Montana Elk Management Plan (2004): the northern half of the Plan Area lies within the
Granite Butte EMU and the southern half within the Deerlodge EMU. Both EMUs straddle the
Continental Divide. The Granite Butte EMU takes in Hunting Districts 293 and 343 north of U.S.
Highway 12 (in addition to others further north); the Deerlodge EMU takes in Hunting Districts
215 and 335 south of Highway 12 (in addition to others southward toward Butte).
The population objective for the Granite Butte EMU is 2,100 elk. In 2004 when the Montana Elk
Management Plan was released, MFWP estimated the population to be just below the objective
(based on aerial winter range surveys). Today, aerial surveys indicate that it is somewhat above
the objective. Bull/cow ratios in the southern part of the EMU that take in the Divide Travel
Plan Area are close to the objective of 10 bulls/100 cows (a bit below the objective in HD 293,
somewhat above it in HD 343).

The population objective for the Deerlodge EMU is 2,100 elk. In 2004, MFWP estimated that
numbers were a bit below this level (at around 1,875 elk). The numbers have risen in the last
seven years. Elk populations are now near or above objectives in the northern half of the EMU
(which includes the Divide Travel Plan Area), but they are still below objectives in the southern
portion of the EMU toward Butte. As well, bull/cow ratios in the northern half of the EMU have
been holding at around 12 to 13 bulls/100 cows in recent years, above the 10 bulls/100 cows
objective.

Coordinating Helena NF and MFWP Elk Management

Helena Forest Plan standards and guidelines for big game are designed to maintain habitat
conditions on the National Forest that help MFWP meet its goals for local elk populations.
MFWP’s primary tool in managing elk is the manipulation of hunting regulations (setting harvest
quotas for different sex/age classes, defining hunting areas, setting seasons, arranging for block
management on private lands and so on). The Forest Service is able to influence the equation
by managing vegetation (cover and forage) and controlling hunter vehicle access on different
parts of the Forest. In spite of this reasonably well-defined division of responsibility, there
remain some knotty problems in coordinating management between agencies.
For one, the quality of aerial survey data on which MFWP bases much of its annual population
estimates can vary widely from year to year and from one hunting district to another. This is a
function of weather conditions, snow cover, variable elk movement patterns and inherent
viewing difficulty imposed by local topography, forest vegetation and artificial obstructions
(most often, powerlines). The survey data (along with harvest statistics) are central to
determining what adjustments the Fish and Game Commission needs to make to hunting
regulations each year. Trends in this data over time also suggest what the Helena NF needs to
consider in terms of cover distribution and vehicle restrictions on its road and trail system.
Changes to these components, particularly forest cover, are difficult, if not impossible to make
on a year-to-year basis in an attempt to follow abrupt yearly shifts in MFWP survey results; but
they certain management changes can adapt to obvious long-term trends .
Another problem stems from the disconnect between the scale of analysis units. MFWP sets its
elk population objectives for elk management units (EMUs) and hunting districts (HDs). In this

WILDLIFE - 320

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

area, EMUs are roughly 700,000 acres in size [Deerlodge EMU ≈ 695,000 acres; Granite Butte
EMU ≈ 712,600 acres]. Both EMUs cover three standard hunting districts, which vary
considerably in size, but average about 235,000 acres. MFWP centers its annual population
estimates and consequent tweaking of hunting regulations on hunting districts.
The Helena NF, on the other hand, focuses its habitat management on elk herd units (EHUs),
which in the Divide landscape may be as small as 35,000 acres, but average a bit less than
60,000 acres [Table 89]. The problem, then, is one of determining how conditions in a given elk
herd unit contribute to the population status of elk on a hunting district three to eight times its
size and to the population objectives for an elk management unit eight to 20 times its size, given
the multifarious conditions in other herd units and private land operations that feed into the
scenario.
In many cases, it is possible to scrutinize the MFWP flight data and divide hunting districts into
distinct segments in terms of how local elk populations fare in each area. In HD 293, for
example, elk herds in the northern half of the district, which is centered on the Big Blackfoot
River Valley, are beset by high rates of natural predation and consequent shifts in population
structure that are not characteristic of elk groups in the southern half of the district. Wherever
it has been possible to partition hunting districts into smaller sub-areas based on elk population
properties, I have done so, in order to provide a better match between MFWP and Helena NF
management units and to potentially tease out some correlations between population dynamics
and habitat status of elk herd units.

Hunting Districts
This section summarizes the status of the four hunting districts in the Granite Butte and
Deerlodge EMUs that cover the Divide Travel Plan area. A map illustrating how these districts
overlap the Divide Travel Plan Area are shown in Figure 27. Key elk population parameters for
each district are summarized in Table 92 and Table 93 following the hunting district narratives.

Most of HDs 335 and 342 are included in this view, but substantial portions of HDs 215 and 293

Hunting District 293
Hunting District 293 lies west of the Continental Divide and north of U.S. Highway 12. It includes
the southwestern half of the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU and the southwestern edge of the
Greenhorn EHU (the portions of those two units on the west side of the Divide). These herd
units account forjust over 15 percent of the hunting district, which extends westward across
private land to the center of the Avon Valley and northward across the Lincoln Ranger District to
State Highway 200 in the Big Blackfoot River valley.

WILDLIFE - 322

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

In the early 1990s, aerial surveys often revealed more than 1,000 elk on HD 293 winter ranges.
MFWP responded in 1994 by increasing antlerless elk hunting permits from 250 to 450. The
antlerless elk harvest spiked dramatically in that year (to about 500) but then began falling: It
averaged 121 antlerless elk between 2000 and 2009 [see Elk Survey and Harvest Data for
Blackfoot Hunting Districts, 1986 to 2010]. After 1996, there was a dramatic drop-off in the
annual winter range population count (from 1,087 elk in 1996 to 387 elk in 1997). And since
then, trends in the elk population have been somewhat difficult to decipher, primarily because
aerial surveys have been erratic, sometimes done in spring, often when visibility was limited by
unfavorable weather or ground conditions, sometimes on only part of the district and
sometimes not at all [see MFWP Elk Surveys, HD 293, 1998-2010; Elk Survey and Harvest Data
for Blackfoot Hunting Districts, 1986-2010]. The average count for HD 293 from 1999 through
2010 (on years when the entire district was surveyed) is 554 elk. The most recent available
count for the district (2013) is 609 elk.
The population objective for HD 293 in the 2004 Elk Management Plan is 750 elk, but the
northwest segment of the district was transferred to HD 298 (a new district) in 2008, so that
now there is a bit of a disconnect between the original population objective and what is possible
under the new configuration. Average ratios of 14 bulls/100 cows from 1999 through 2009
were above hunting district objectives of 10/100. During the same period, calf/cow ratios were
typical of hunting districts in this area, averaging 38 calves/100 cows, comfortably above the
expected norm of around 30 to 35 calves/100 cows.
In the last five years, the number of elk counted during aerial surveys for the hunting district as
a whole (495 to 609 elk) has remained in the same general range as in previous years (back to
1997). But, in the northern half of Hunting District 293 (the Blackfoot River Valley) the number
of animals observed by MFWP biologists on the ground and by local hunters and landowners has
declined noticeably. Likewise, while calf/cow ratios during this same period have remained
relatively stable for the district as a whole (averaging 31 calves/100 cows), calf survival in the
Blackfoot Valley has plummeted. Much of the decline has been attributed to rising predation
from mountain lions, wolves, black bears and grizzly bears, whose populations have all
burgeoned at the same time, due to a variety of circumstances [J. Kolbe, quoted in the Helena
Independent Record, Feb. 26, 2012]. Other factors, including several years of drought, changes
in vegetation patterns from large fires and hunting quotas over the last decade, may be
contributing to the observed shifts in elk (and deer) population size and structure. But
predation appears to be the primary limiting factor in the northern half of HD 293.
Meanwhile, in the south half of the district (the Avon Valley south of the Ogden Mtn–Dalton
Mtn ridge), predation has not been an obvious problem for big game populations. Population
estimates for this part of the district were in the range of 300 to 450 elk from 1998 through
2003. Some recent counts (2004, 2005) have been in the 180 to 190 range. These numbers may
reflect temporary population decline due to over-harvest or the fact that surveys were
conducted after many elk had already migrated off winter ranges (late April). More likely, they
reflect a seasonal shift in elk distribution [see HD 293 Elk Surveys, 2004, 2005]. Biologists have
noted that in some years, elk from HD 293 have moved eastward into HD 343 to escape lateseason hunting pressure (extending into January) and occasionally to move to less severe snow
conditions [see comments accompanying MFWP Elk Surveys, HD 343, 2007]. By 2006, counts for
the southern half of HD 293 were once again over 300 elk. In 2010, 311 elk were counted.
In the end, MFWP objectives for elk populations (herd numbers, bull/cow ratios, calf survival)
continue to be met in the southern half of the HD 293, the area influenced by the Helena NF

WILDLIFE - 323

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

road and trail network in the Divide landscape. Problems in the Blackfoot Valley in the north
half of the district appear to be primarily a consequence of abnormally high rates of predation
and not a result of habitat dysfunction on that part of the National Forest (the Blackfoot
landscape).

Hunting District 215
Hunting District 215 covers a large area west of the Continental Divide and south of U.S.
Highway 12. A majority of the district lies south of the Helena NF on the BeaverheadDeeerlodge NF toward Butte. The northern 45 percent of the district covers the southwest
quadrant of the Divide Travel Plan Area (118 mi²), including the entire Spotted Dog-Little
Blackfoot EHU and the western half of the Jericho Mountain EHU [Figure 27]. It also takes in a
broad region of the private and state lands northeast of Deerlodge (142 mi²). This region of
rolling hills and valley lands provides virtually all of the winter range for elk in this area. MFWP
considers the northern part of HD 215 to be a key area for elk. An average of 67 percent of the
elk in the hunting district have been counted on these northern winter ranges since 2000 and
the population has been increasing steadily since around 2005.
Table 92 and Table 93 summarize some of the data from MFWP aerial surveys of elk winter
range in HD 215 since 1999. Winter range counts are usually conducted sometime between late
January and mid-March (depending on weather conditions and plane availability). Occasionally,
spring surveys have been conducted instead of or in addition to the winter counts. Spring
surveys are typically run in late April and early May and find most of the elk in the open
mountain grasslands on the western and northern edges of the southern Divide landscape on or
near Helena NF ground.
Prior to 2007, MFWP had been counting roughly 800 to 950 elk on HD 215 winter ranges in most
years. This number jumped to 1,365 animals in 2008, to over 1,700 in 2009 and to over 2,000 by
2011. In 2013, nearly 2,500 elk were counted on HD 215 winter ranges. Approximately 67
percent of elk observations have been in the northern half of the district (the portion
encompassed by the Divide Travel Plan Area). These numbers are well above the population
objective of 1,400 elk in this district (the original Elk Plan objective of 1,000 elk having been
raised to 1,400 in 2010).
Observed bull/cow ratios, on the other hand, have been erratic and often low. The average
ratio over the last 15 years has been just over 12 bulls/100 cows (the objective being a minimum
of 10 bulls/100 cows), but in some years the counts have been as low as five or six bulls/100
cows. The 2013 count was right on the 15 year average [Table 92]. The percentage of mature
bulls in the population, however, has decreased in recent years, with bulls older than 1.5 years
accounting for only about two percent of the population in 2012 and 2013. This is an indication
of hunting pressure too heavy for the available security on fall range. Overall bull numbers have
remained adequate only because of a profusion of raghorns and spike bulls [2012, 2013 Elk
Surveys in HD 215; R. Vinkey, personal communication 2014].
Table 92 also shows that calf numbers are down in the last two years, usually an indication of
disruptive weather, poor adult nutrition, or heavy predation. Currently the reason for the dropoff in calf production/survival is unknown, but there has been no sign of an increase in
predation pressure in this area. A number of wolf packs have centered their activity along the
western edge of the Helena NF and in the adjacent ranchlands since 1995, but until 2012,
calf/cow ratios remained in the range of 30 to 40 calves/100 cows year after year (and the
overall population continued to increase). With the removal of wolves from the Endangered

WILDLIFE - 324

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Species List and the advent of the State wolf hunting season in 2010, the ability of wolves to
impact livestock and big game populations in this area has been minimal. Wolves attacking
livestock have been dispatched quickly and there has been no evidence of their having built up
sufficient strength to measurably affect the local elk population. So, something else is at work
here.
Security areas available to elk in the northern part of HD 215 cover a substantial amount of
ground (accounting for 30 percent of the Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot EHU). The largest block of
security (nearly 19,000 acres) is associated with the Electric Peak Roadless Area in the southwest
corner of the Divide landscape. The problem for local elk is that, because of its elevation and
topographic position, much of this area becomes unavailable to them during part of the hunting
season as snow builds up and the forage base shrinks. This is true for most of the other security
areas in this part of the Forest as well. How long elk are able to remain in National Forest
security areas depends on fall weather in any given year, but often they are forced down into
transitional and winter ranges on the edge of the Forest and on private/State lands where
hunting season security can be marginal.
Until recently, elk moving off the Forest to the west had been able to settle in a large block of
private ranchland in the Spotted Dog country, which was been off-limits to public hunting. Elk
began moving to this winter range area as early as the start of the bow season in September.
The move may be a direct response to pressure from bow hunters and motorized recreation on
the Forest, but it may also reflect an established pattern of migration down to secure and
benign valley habitat regardless of other circumstances. MFWP felt that the refuge provided by
this private land suppressed hunting opportunity and allowed the elk population to maintain
itself well in excess of Motana Elk Management Plan objectives (although mature bull numbers
remained low) [MFWP 2004a]. In August 2010, the State was able to purchase most of this land
and convert it to a Wildlife Mangement Area. Public hunting is now allowed, but most of the
area is off-limits to motor vehicles, which tempers the effect.
In spite of the change in ownership and management, elk continue to move to this off Forest
area and recent population trends in HD 215 still hold. In response, the Fish and Game
Commission increased the number of B-licenses for cow elk in this district in from 150 in 2008 to
200 in 2011 and 400 in 2012. Nonetheless the upward population trend continues. At the same
time, mature bull numbers remain very low and in spite of the burgeoning cow population, calf
numbers over the past three years have dropped to half of what had been the norm for over a
decade.

Hunting District 343
Hunting District 343 lies east of the Continental Divide and north of U.S. Highway 12. It takes in
most of the Greenhorn EHU and the northeastern half of the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU
(which is outside the Divide Travel Plan Area). These EHUs account for roughly ⅓ of the hunting
district. The rest of the district extends eastward off the Forest into the Helena and Little Prickly
Pear Valleys and northward to Flescher Pass on the Lincoln Ranger District.
Counts of the elk population in this district were relatively stable between 1999 and 2008,
ranging from 644 to 973 animals (average equals 787); but then they dropped into the 445 to
580 range in 2009 and 2010 [Table 92]. Given the absence of a commensurate increase in
hunter success and natural mortality (although mortality due to wolf kills has increased
somewhat over the last decade), or a drop in calf production and survival, MFWP suspects that
the lower winter counts reflected the switch to a less effective survey method and movement of

WILDLIFE - 325

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

elk off winter range prior to survey flights rather than a large population decline. The 2011
count was back up to 713 elk. This is well within the population objective for HD 343, which is
700 elk (plus or minus 20 percent equals 560 to 840 elk) [see 2011 Post-season Survey of Elk in
HD 343].
Bull/cow ratios have averaged 12.4 bulls/100 cows since 1999 (range equals 8 to 18), which is
considered a “moderate” ratio and is in excess of the hunting district objective of 10 bulls/100
cows [Table 93]. Calf/cow ratios have averaged 30.5 calves/100 cows since 1999, ranging from
16 in 2008 to 49 in 2011. This is typical of calf survival rates throughout the Divide Travel Plan
Area and suggests that natural predation has not been unduly suppressing calf survival in these
populations. Counts for 2013 and 2014 have been below average (around 19 calves/100 cows),
a pattern which has shown up in other local hunting districts as well [Table 93]. MFWP
biologists are uncertain as to what is driving this pattern, but the fact that it has been consistent
over a relatively broad area suggests that it is weather related.
In recent years, HD 343 has sometimes picked up elk from HD 293 to the west later in the year
because of extended hunting seasons in that district. Many elk in HD 343 seek refuge during the
hunting season on large blocks of private land where landowners do not allow public hunting.
Of the large landowners in the district, five allow hunting, five do not. With private lands
accounting for 52 percent of the district, this has a real impact on hunting success, which has
been relatively low (about 40 percent on antlerless permits) in recent years. Statewide success
averages about 50 percent.

Hunting District 335
Hunting District 335 lies east of the Continental Divide and south of U.S. Highway 12. It
encompasses the Quartz EHU, the eastern half of the Jericho EHU and most of the Black
Mountain–Brooklyn Bridge EHU [Figure 27]. These Helena NF herd units make up the western
60 percent of the hunting district, the eastern reaches of which occupy BLM and private land in
the adjacent foothills and Prickly Pear Valley south of Helena.
MFWP winter range surveys showed the elk population increasing in the decade 1999 to 2008:
Population counts that averaged 510 elk earlier in the decade had risen into the 667 to 776
range by 2006 to 2008 [Table 92]. MFWP biologists felt that this was a function of mild winters,
increased travel restrictions in the Clancy-Unionville area of the Helena NF and fewer hunting
permits for antlerless elk (MFWP HD 335 Elk Survey 2005, 2007). In 2009 the number of elk
counted dropped to 450 and then to 388 in 2010. As in some other local districts, MFWP
believes that the lower counts were a function of a less effective survey method and of elk
having moved off winter range by the time surveys were conducted [see Post-season Survey of
Elk in HD 335 for 2010 and 2011]. There was no evidence of a sudden increase in hunter
success, elevated natural mortality, or decreased calf production/survival that might initiate a
downward trend in local elk numbers. In 2011, the elk count was back up to where it had been
prior to 2009: 670 elk were tallied, which is well within the population objective for HD 335
(600 elk plus or minus 20 percent). The most recent counts (2012 to 2014) have ranged from
827 to 1,187 elk, well above the objective.
Bull/cow ratios have been fairly consistent over the last decade, averaging 12.6 bulls/100 cows.
The 2011 count was the highest in the last 25 years at 19 bulls/100 cows. The objective for the
hunting district is a minimum of 10 bulls/100 cows [Table 93]. Brow-tined bulls, however, have
accounted for only about two percent of the count during this period (almost certainly an
underestimate, but lower than biologists would like to see). Calf/cow ratios have been more

WILDLIFE - 326

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

variable over the last 10 years, ranging from 15 calves/100 cows (2008) to 56 calves/100 cows
(2001). The 15-year average is 31.6 calves/100 cows, which is typical of hunting districts in the
Deerlodge and Granite Butte EMUs and indicates a level of calf production and survival
sufficient to maintain current elk populations under a normal regime of hunting and natural
predation. As with the other three local hunting districts discussed here, calf counts have been
below average for the last three years [Table 93].
MFWP feels that elk in HD 335 are being impacted by livestock grazing, partly on the Helena NF,
but more so on privately-owned winter ranges. In addition, MFWP believes that the big
Montana Tunnels mine east of the Forest on Clancy Creek has reduced winter range opportunity
for elk (and more so for mule deer) in the area southwest of Jefferson City east of the Forest
boundary. Native forage is limited, therefore, elk turn to agricultural fields and haystacks
stockpiled for winter livestock feed. This, in turn, has led to ranchers requesting special hunts to
trim elk numbers. Elk numbers have been particularly high over the last four years, in spite of
deficient elk security in the Quartz Creek EHU on the National Forest [Table 88 and Table 89].
As with some other local hunting districts, elk are taking advantage of closed private lands off
the Forest for security, allowing the population to expand.

Elk Population Summary

Key population parameters that MFWP uses to gauge the status of elk populations within
hunting districts and elk management units are summarized for the four local hunting districts
over the the last 15 years in Table 92 and Table 93 below. Most of this information derives
from annual survey flights of winter range. These surveys have provided a stream of data that
has allowed MFWP to estimate total elk numbers, bull/cow ratios and calf/cow ratios over a
period of decades and thus to illuminate population trends and indicate to what degree elk
populations are meeting management objectives. Occasionally, surveys are missing for some
districts (for a variety of technical reasons) and in other years, the accuracy of the counts has
been compromised by unfavorable flying conditions, poor visibility, inopportune flight timing
and so on. But, in most years, the estimates are accurate enough for management purposes
[see State of Montana 2002].
