Effects of Alternative 1 (Existing Condition)
Direct Effects
There are no direct effects on forested habitat or old growth habitat since no new road or trail
construction is a part of this alternative.

Indirect Effects
Indirect effects on general forested habitat and old growth would continue to be generated by
human activity along 450 miles of existing open roads and motor trails. This activity will wax
and wane periodically due to factors unrelated to travel planning.

Effects of Alternative 2
Direct Effects
Alternative 2 would generate no new direct effects on grassland or forest habitat (including oldgrowth) since no new road or trail routes would be constructed. This alternative would retain
five fewer miles of open road and motor trail than the current system, affording the potential
for return of some of these corridors to more natural condition.

Indirect Effects
Indirect effects on forest and grassland habitat would continue to be generated by human
activity along 445 miles of open roads and motor trails. Disturbance levels would decrease in
some areas and increase in others. Motorized activity will vary in time and place due to factors
unrelated to travel planning. Changes in motorized disturbance from the existing condition
would be insufficient to generate measurable differences in survivorship and viability of wildlife
populations. However, differences in local disturbance levels would be noticeable at several
sites in the form of shifts in wildlife behavior and local habitat use patterns.

Effects of Alternative 3
Direct Effects
Alternative 3 would not add to direct effects on forest or grassland habitat since no new roads
or trails are proposed. This alternative retains 71 fewer miles of open road and motor trail than
the current system, affording the opportunity for some of these corridors to return to more
natural condition.

Indirect Effects
Indirect effects on forest and grassland habitat generated by human activity would continue
along 379 miles of existing roads. Redistribution of motorized disturbance to new areas would
be minimal under alternative 3. Decrease in motorized disturbance from the existing condition,
though substantial, would be insufficient to generate measurable improvement in survivorship
and viability of wildlife populations. However, decrease in local disturbance levels would be
noticeable at several sites as shifts in wildlife behavior and local habitat use patterns.

Effects of Alternative 4
Direct Effects

trail routes would be constructed. This alternative retains 57 fewer miles of open road and

Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the detailed matrix in appendix B, which
identifies past, present and reasonably foreseeable projects and activities, in addition to
proposed Travel Management, that may affect general forest, old-growth and grassland habitat.
The scope of the analysis includes the Divide landscape (Helena NF land with non-Forest
inholdings) and immediately surrounding lands (private, State, County, Municipal and BLM).

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Several past and ongoing activities on the National Forest add to the direct effect of the road
system on forest and grassland habitats. These include activities that remove or alter wildlife
habitat such as timber sales, prescribed burning, harvest of dead trees, small mining operations,
noxious weed spraying and cattle grazing. A number of projects designed to deal with the bark
beetle outbreak are underway, some already completed. These include the Cromwell Dixon
campground, Park Lake campground, Kading campground, Moose Creek picnic area,
MacDonald Pass Ski Trails and Forestwide roadside hazard tree removal projects. Also nearing
completion is the Clancy-Unionville vegetation project, an extensive operation originally
designed to thin mature green forest, but now primarily a dead-tree harvest. In addition, the
MacDonald Pass carbaryl spraying project is designed to fend off additional beetle kill at

WILDLIFE - 388

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

developed recreation sites. Road access to upper Tenmile Creek is currently blocked by an
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) operation to deal with toxic mine wastes.

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Vegetation management on private lands, particularly ongoing harvest of beetle-killed trees,
increases fragmentation and edge effects and may result in habitat loss for some species. Large
projects include expansion of developed recreation facilities (Great Divide ski area), expansion
of mining operations (Montana Tunnels), roadside tree cutting along Highway 12 and
reconstructing the Marysville Road.

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Reasonably foreseeable activities that may directly affect forest and grassland habitat include
revision of management plans for several grazing allotments, more projects designed to deal
with the aftermath of the mountain pine beetle epidemic; timber harvest projects (the
Telegraph, Red Mountain Flume and Tenmile south Helena vegetation projects); post and pole
harvest; ongoing firewood cutting; rerouting of some sections of the Continental Divide trail;
and the Rimini Road improvement project. These activities may positively or negatively affect
forest or grassland vegetation structure (including fragmentation and edge effect), some
substantially, others to a minor degree.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Numerous small developments and activities will continue to affect forest and grassland
habitats. Development of private land would continue to diminish wildlife habitat, increase
edge effects and fragment habitat. Removal of beetle-killed trees will continue to modify
habitat adjacent to the Forest.

Summary and Conclusions
All alternatives are in compliance with the Helena Forest Plan and with other appropriate legal
mandates with regard to direct and indirect effects of roads and motor trails on forest and
grassland habitat.

Disturbance
Alternative 1 would retain potential for motorized disturbance of wildlife along 450 miles of
roads and trails. Alternative 2 would decrease motorized disturbance in some areas and
increase it in others, but overall would reduce the motor route system to 445 miles. Under
Alternative 3, redistribution of motorized disturbance to new areas would be minimal and the
system would decrease to 370 miles. Alternative 4 is similar to alternative 3 but with 379 miles
of open routes. Alternative 5 is the most distinctive of the action alternatives in that it retains
substantially less open road (260 miles) while authorizing appreciably more motor trails (64
miles) than other options. Differences in motorized disturbance among alternatives would be
insufficient to generate measurable differences in survivorship and viability of wildlife
populations. Differences in wildlife habitat use patterns would be noticeable in local areas:
alternatives 1 and 2 would generate the most local disturbance, alternative 5 the least.

Habitat Loss
There would be no new road building and thus, no new habitat loss under any of the five
alternatives.

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Edge Effects
Because, in the short-term, edge would remain the same along both open and closed roads,
there would be no differences in edge effects among the five alternatives. Over the long term,
edge will become less distinct along many closed roads as surrounding vegetation moves into
the road corridors. Areawide implications for wildlife are minor.

Riparian Habitats

Riparian Habitat: Common Effects of Travel Management

Riparian zones occupy relatively small areas, but they incur a disproportionate amount of
human activity (Hutto and Young 1999; Thomas 1979). Roads in riparian zones reduce habitat
effectiveness for many wildlife species through vegetation alteration and disturbance associated
with human presence (USFS 1996a). Many riparian zones are paralleled by roads, which often
host dispersed camping sites near the water. While this may enhance recreation opportunity
for camping, angling and wildlife viewing, it decreases habitat effectiveness of the riparian area
for many species. Recreation and firewood retrieval are the main activities facilitated by roads
in and adjacent to riparian areas.
The Divide Travel Plan Area currently supports about 93 miles of roads and motorized trails
within riparian habitat conservation areas (RHCAs), 83 miles of which are open to motorized
use. Table 100 summarizes mileage of motorized routes in riparian habitat conservation areas
under each of the five alternatives. Total open road miles are shown for comparison. Since in
many of these areas recreationists are allowed to drive up to 300 feet off the road to camp, the
zone of influence associated with these routes can be substantial.

Riparian Habitat: Comparison of Alternatives
Effects of Alternative 1
Current direction for off-road use in riparian areas is based on the Off-Highway Vehicle EIS
(2001). This allows for motorized travel up to 300 feet off designated routes to reach dispersed
campsites. Under Alternative 1, current levels of vegetation alteration and disturbance
associated with dispersed camping would continue. The potential for widespread degradation is
unlikely because the off-route use is restricted to dispersed camping. Vehicles are not
permitted in the off-route corridor for activities other than camping (firewood cutting,
picnicking, game retrieval, off-route recreational riding and so on). Periodic displacement of
wildlife and localized degradation of habitat components (vegetation, woody debris) would
continue at current levels. Impacts may be largely eliminated by suspension of the “300 feet
rule” in certain sensitive riparian areas where off-road vehicle is likely to cause environmental
damage.

Alternative 2 would reduce the reach of open roads and motor trails in Riparian Habitat

Alternative 3 would reduce open roads and motor trails in riparian habitat conservation areas by

Alternative 5 would reduce open roads and motor trails in riparian habitat conservation areas by
29 miles, the most of any alternative. About one mile of currently open road in Slate Creek and
upper Tenmile Creek would be converted to motor trail. Overall, this would decrease riparian
impacts discussed previously.

Riparian Habitat: Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the detailed matrix in appendix B, which
identifies past, present and reasonably foreseeable projects and other activities, in addition to
proposed travel management, that may affect riparian habitats. The scope of the analysis
includes the Divide landscape (Helena NF land with non-Forest inholdings) and immediately
surrounding lands.

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Several recent and ongoing activities on the National Forest have implications for riparian
habitat, some positive. These include revision of grazing allotment permits that incorporate
riparian fencing and other means of limiting cattle access to productive wet habitats
(MacDonald Pass, Empire, Clancy); mine reclamation designed to limit seepage of toxic waste
into steams and riparian sites (Charter Oak, Frohner, Rimini); implementation of the Helena NF
Weed EIS, which will improve the functioning of vegetation associations in some in some
riparian sites; relocation of heavily-used recreational trails upslope out of riparian bottoms; and
closure of roads that have degraded riparian habitats. Some activities may reduce riparian
habitat effectiveness. These include scattered small mining operations (under the 1872 Mining
Act), cattle grazing in riparian sites on many allotments and retention of roads in riparian areas
that slowly slough sediment into streams. A number of recently completed and ongoing
vegetation projects have some potential to increase stream sedimentation and thus affect the
quality of the riparian environment, although most potential impacts have been reduced,
eliminated, or mitigated via the standard project NEPA process. Projects include the ClancyUnionville vegetation project; MacDonald Pass CDNST trailhead, Kading campground, Park Lake
campground, Moose Creek picnic area, MacDonald Pass Ski Trails and Cromwell Dixon
campground hazard tree removal.

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Private land development continues to impact productive wet sites in some riparian areas. This
is occurring near the Forest boundary on both sides of the Divide, as well as on private
inholdings within the Forest. Timber harvest on private, State, BLM and Helena City lands may
also have implications for wildlife habitat in riparian areas, some positive, some negative.
Mining operations near the Forest have compromised the integrity of riparian function in the
past and continue to do so in some areas. The recently completed Marysville Road project has
influenced, if only marginally, the functioning of a drainage originating on the National Forest,
though long-term reduction of sediment is a benefit.

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Foreseeable activities that may affect riparian habitats to one degree or another include the
upgrading of the Rimini Road, which closely parallels Tenmile Creek and reauthorization of
grazing in some of the Divide allotments, which inevitably involves riparian area monitoring and
improvement of problem sites. Larger vegetation projects likely to influence some riparian areas
include the Red Mountain Flume-Chessman Reservoir, Telegraph and Tenmile South Helena
projects.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Activity on non-Forest land expected to continue and add to the effects of travel management in
riparian areas includes: settlement and development of private lands (including road building)
that encompass riparian sites; timber harvest and removal of beetle-killed trees in and around
riparian areas; continued mining operations that alter stream courses and add to stream
sedimentation; continued ATV and other motorized activity in riparian areas on private, BLM
and State lands; continued livestock grazing on adjacent private and BLM lands; continued
diversion and impoundment of streams flowing off the National Forest for agricultural purposes
and in Tenmile Creek, for municipal water supply.

Riparian Habitat: Summary and Conclusions
All five alternatives would comply with Helena Forest Plan direction as to the effects of roads on
riparian and wetland wildlife habitat, primarily with regard to summer elk habitat in the
Montana Elk-Logging Study (HFP, Appendix C).
Alternative 1 would retain 96 miles of open roads and motor trails in riparian habitat
conservation areas (RHCAs). Alternative 2 would close roads/ motor trails in some riparian
habitat conservation areas and allow new motorized use in others, reducing overall presence to
90 miles. Alternative 3 would not introduce any new motorized use into currently restricted
riparian habitat conservation areas and would reduce overall road/ motor trail presence to 74
miles in these habitats. Alternative 4 would close nearly as many roads/ motor trails in riparian
habitat conservation areas (78 miles) as Alternative 3, but would sanction ongoing unauthorized
use at two sites (Spotted Dog Creek, Bison/ Ontario Creeks), a total distance of about one mile.
Alternative 5 would retain the fewest riparian habitat conservation areas roads of any
alternative, 67 miles. It would convert about one mile of existing open road in riparian habitat
conservation areas to motor trail.
In most cases, direct impact on riparian wildlife habitats from use of these roads and trails
would be minor (from erosion and sedimentation). Most effects would be indirect: disturbance

WILDLIFE - 392

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

of wildlife in these focal habitats and soil/vegetation damage from off-route riding. These
effects would be local and would not be measurable in terms of areawide population viability.

Connectivity and Fragmentation
Connectivity is important because it allows animals to move between habitats to meet daily and
lifetime needs (Forman et al. 2003). It also allows repopulation of unoccupied areas. Restricted
movement results in habitats where some species are absent, others are present in numbers
well below carrying capacity and diversity is depressed. This increases the risk of isolation,
decreased gene flow and local extinction (Forman et al. 2003; Noss et al. 1996).
Roads vary widely in their role as agents of fragmentation. Some highways act as true barriers
for large numbers of species, substantially altering the way animals are able to move through
the landscape [Figure 16, Figure 17]. Many Forest roads, on the other hand, are so
nondescript and little used that they exert virtually no influence at all on wildlife movement
patterns [Figure 13 to Figure 15, Figure 40, Figure 58].
Roads are not necessarily negative factors and some species are attracted to them (Knight and
Kawashima 1993; Knight et al. 1995). Ravens are more abundant along roadsides than
elsewhere because of food produced by road-kills. Many birds do not perceive roads as any
more of a deterrent to normal activity than natural features of the landscape (St. Clair 2003).
Lynx cross roads at frequencies that do not differ from random expectations (Ruggiero et al.
2000). Deer may be drawn to the forage provided by roadside vegetation, especially in spring.
Carnivores, such as wolves, bears, coyotes and bobcats use roads with low levels of human
activity as travelways, often at night, but sometimes during the day. This use may be greater in
winter when some roads become hard-packed snowmobile routes.

Connectivity: Common Effects of Travel Management

In the following assessment, effects on connectivity are described in terms of the ability of the
landscape to provide dispersal, migration and travel opportunities between suitable habitat
patches. The focus is on regional dispersal of large and mid-sized mammals through the
Continental Divide linkage zone, but the assessment is also applicable to more localized
movement zones. We assume that the primary human-generated complication for these
landscape functions is the density and dispersion of open roads (and in some cases, motorized
trails) and we use this as the basis for two indices to compare alternatives: (1) open road
density and (2) large non-motorized habitat patches.

Paved Roads and Highways
Most of the field studies and literature reviews that have found roads to be “barriers” impeding
wildlife movement and “fragmenting” habitat have dealt with paved roads and highways that
carry a recurrent flow of fast-moving traffic. These roads are hard-surfaced, wide, elevated and
often flanked by cleared corridors, fences and other impediments. They can be formidable
hostile environments, especially for small mammals, amphibians, reptiles and low-flying birds
(Mader 1984; Swihart and Slade 1984). Traffic speed and volume on some of these highways
make crossing them a challenge for humans, to say nothing of foxes, bears, rabbits, squirrels,
grouse, owls and other animals not entirely aware of the hazard they face. Some larger animals
may avoid crossing paved roads and consequently extend and convolute their movement
patterns to compensate (Trombulak and Frissell 2000). For some species, the mere presence of
a highway acts as a barrier. For others, the width of the road, associated clearing and the
presence of roadside barriers (typically fences) may be the deciding factors (Oxley, et al. 1974).
WILDLIFE - 393

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

The only paved highway in the Travel Plan Area is U.S. Highway 12, a well-traveled four-lane
thoroughfare that runs through Helena NF lands for about four miles on its way over MacDonald
Pass, an area where numerous wildlife species are killed by vehicles each year [Figure 16]. The
Highway also runs close enough to the National Forest for another 15 to 16 miles on both sides
of the pass that it influences animals crossing from one part of the National Forest to another
over private, State and BLM lands. No Travel Plan alternative proposes any changes that directly
or indirectly alter the impact of Highway 12.

Forest Roads
With the exception of the Orofino Gulch Road, the Marysville Road and the lower segment of
the Little Blackfoot River Road, all Forest/County roads in or near the Travel Plan Area are
unpaved routes that range from regularly graded, well-traveled gravel roads [Figure 17] to
rough, narrow four-wheel-drive tracks that may see vehicles pass only two or three times a
week [Figure 13, Figure 59]. Most Forest roads fall somewhere in between these extremes
Figure 14, Figure 15, Figure 44, Figure 48]. The implications of this type of road system for
wildlife have been discussed earlier; but, in essence, most of these routes do not physically
impede movement by most animals. Rather, they serve as conduits for human activity that
causes some species to avoid the road corridors or to seek out alternate travelways,
complicating their ability to move through the landscape in an efficient manner. Crossing these
roads can be lethal in that it puts big game animals at risk from hunters in the fall and certain
carnivores at risk from general shooting any time of the year. The roads also provide access for
trappers on snowmobiles in the winter.
Regularly traveled routes, such as the Sweeney Creek, Rimini and Little Blackfoot River roads,
are more formidable barriers to movement than the narrow, lightly traveled roads characteristic
of much of the Plan Area. Vehicle speeds may be high enough on sections of these roads that
animals are hit and killed [Figure 17]. The summary below in Table 101 shows unweighted
densities of open roads and motor trails in the Divide landscape (within Helena NF
administrative boundaries). Overall route densities range from 1.55 mi/mi² at present to 1.20
mi/mi² under alternative 5. Because this computation gives equal weight, in terms of human
disturbance, to primitive, little-used routes and major Forest thoroughfares, it tends to
exaggerate the impact of the travel network. An earlier, but more limited version of this
analysis that weighted roads by estimated use level [Draft Wildlife Background Report, 2013]
produced weighted road densities in the range of 0.71 to 0.84 mi/mi². These estimates were
considerably less precise than those shown in Table 101, but they probably more accurately
portray the general level of impact perceived by animals attempting to navigate the landscape.

patches (compared to now) by lumping unroaded areas between Sweeney and Austin Creeks
and in the Black Mountain–Deadman Creek area. As discussed earlier, an array of larger patches
(even if unconnected) appears to provide greater habitat opportunity than a collection of
numerous small patches connected by narrow corridors.
South of Highway 12, alternative 2 consolidates patches in the Slate Lake–Hat Creek area but
splits an unroaded block in Ontario–Bison Creek with a motor trail. Alternative 3, on the other
hand, combines three separate unroaded patches in the Slate Lake–Hat Creek–Spotted Dog area
and enlarges the Bison Creek–Ontario Creek, Electric Peak block. Alternatives 4 and 5, like
alternative 2, splits the Bison-Ontario Creek block and the Hat Creek-Spotted Dog block with
motorized routes; but the resulting unroaded blocks are larger than in alternative 2. Overall,
alternative 5 provides the most land in large non-motorized patches, increasing such habitat
from 63 percent to 74 percent of the Travel Plan Area. Looking at the landscape as a whole,
average patch size under all alternatives is larger than indicated here, since several of these
habitat blocks connect with other non-motorized areas outside the Plan Area.

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

The benefits of establishing and maintaining corridors between suitable habitat patches versus
enlarging patches in which various species can survive over time has been analyzed by Falcy and
Estades (2007). They conclude that enlarging viable habitat patches is a more productive
strategy than trying to maintain corridor connections between smaller patches. Rosenberg et
al. (1997) reached a similar conclusion. In the case of the Divide landscape, none of the patches
are truly isolated from any other (although Highway 12 does present a formidable barrier for
some species). So, alternatives that consolidate and enlarge effective living space would be the
most beneficial for local wildlife. This pattern of larger unroaded patches would also facilitate
movement through the Divide landscape linkage zone. In this regard, Alternative 2 is somewhat
more effective than the current condition (alternative 1) and alternatives 3, 4 and 5 are
substantially more so.
None of the alternatives would influence the more prominent roads that retard or alter efficient
wildlife movement through the Divide landscape. These include U.S. Highway 12, the Rimini
road (Powell County Road #495), the Little Blackfoot River road (Forest Road #227), the Mullan
Pass–Austin Creek road (Forest Road #1805), the Sweeney Creek–Priest Pass road (Forest Road
#335), the Orofino Gulch road (Lewis & Clark County Road #454) and the Grizzly Gulch road
(County Road #753).

Connectivity: Comparison of Alternatives
Effects of Alternative 1 (Existing Condition)
Alternative 1 would preserve the existing condition, maintaining 20 non-motorized habitat
blocks larger than 1,500 acres in the Travel Plan Area. The nine patches north of U.S. Highway
12 average 3,319 acres in size, the 11 patches south of the highway average 7,403 acres. Patch
size south of the highway is influenced by the three inventoried Roadless Areas in that part of
the Plan Area. Overall patch size averages 5,565 acres. Roughly 63 percent of Helena NF land is
in large non-motorized patches with Alternative 1.

Effects of Alternative 2
Alternative 2 would reduce the number of large non-motorized habitat patches from 20 to 17 by
consolidating unroaded areas between Sweeney and Austin Creeks and in the Black Mountain–
Deadman Creek area. As a result, average size of these habitat blocks north of Highway 12
would increase from 3,319 acres to 4,465 acres. This would benefit a number of resident wildlife
species and would make movement through the linkage zone less problematic. The alternative
would consolidate non-motorized patches in the Slate Lake–Hat Creek area but would split a
non-motorized habitat block in the Ontario–Bison Creek area with a motor trail (on now-closed
Roads #4104-A1 and #4104-A2). The average size of non-motorized blocks south of the highway
would increase from 7,403 acres to 7,732 acres. In the Planning Area as a whole, patch size
would increase from 5,564 acres to 6,391 acres.
While increasing average patch size, Alternative 2 would slightly reduce the total amount of land
in large non-motorized patches compared to the existing condition. In the Slate Lake–Hat Creek
area, for example, the proposal combines two non-motorized patches, but at the same time, it
shaves the size of the Slate Lake portion by designating a new motorized trail in a currently
restricted area. On balance, the improvement in non-motorized patch size would be favorable
to wildlife movement through the area, more than making up for the slight overall loss of nonmotorized acreage.

WILDLIFE - 397

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Effects of Alternative 3
Alternative 3 would reduce the number of large non-motorized habitat blocks from 20 to 15 by
combining unroaded areas north of Highway 12 between Sweeney and Austin Creeks and in the
Black Mountain–Deadman Creek area. It is similar to Alternative 2 in this regard, but by
eliminating additional motorized routes toward the periphery of the consolidated patches, it
would produce larger non-motorized blocks than Alternative 2. Average patch size north of
Highway 12 would increase from 3,319 acres to 4,881 acres.
South of Highway 12, Alternative 3 would merge five separate non-motorized patches north of,
east of and including the Electric Peak Roadless Area into a single non-motorized habitat block
of 48,900 acres. Unlike Alternative 2, it would retain the integrity of the Bison–Ontario Creek
habitat area and would eliminate motor travel in the Baldy ridge area. In sum, Alternative 3
would increase acreage in large non-motorized habitat blocks in the Plan Area from 111,305
acres to 121,705 acres. It would increase the average non-motorized patch size from 5,565
acres to 8,114 acres. Key areas that would see improvement in facilitating wildlife movement
through the area would be (1) Black Mountain–upper Deadman Creek, (2) Austin Creek–
Sweeney Creek–Priest Pass, (3) Bison Creek–Ontario Creek and (3) Slate Lake–Hat Creek–
Spotted Dog Creek.

Effects of Alternative 4
Alternative 4 is similar to Alternative 3, but it provides for three more motorized routes in
strategic locations, resulting in slightly less acreage in large non-motorized patches (120,155
acres in alternative 4 as opposed to 121,705 acres in Alternative 3) and smaller average patch
size (7,510 acres in Alternative 4; 8,114 acres in Alternative 3). The increase in patch size is
achieved by consolidation of adjacent areas, thus reducing the total number of large nonmotorized habitat patches from the current 20 to 16 (one more than Alternative 3, by virtue of
its splitting off the Treasure Mountain and Slate Lake–Hat Creek areas from the central Electric
Peak Roadless Area with motorized routes).
Three routes would fragment or reduce the size of non-motorized patches: (1) a motor trail
north of Meyers Hill (#136-007), (2) a motor trail following Roads #4104-A1 and #4104-A2 along
upper Ontario and Bison Creeks and (3) Road #314 in upper Spotted Dog Creek. Effects would
be felt primarily in the Bison-Ontario and upper Spotted Dog areas as a result of motorized
intrusion into high-country summer ranges. The Meyers Hill route would be less problematic.
Be that as it may, Alternative 4, while somewhat more disruptive of local wildlife than
Alternative 3, would be a substantial improvement over Alternatives 1 and 2 in this regard.

Effects of Alternative 5
Alternative 5 would provide the most non-motorized habitat of any alternative: 130,745 acres,
74 percent of the Travel Plan Area. This represents an increase of 19,440 acres (or 11 percent)
over the existing condition in Alternative 1. The increase is particularly notable in the area north
of Highway 12, where substantial increases in non-motorized habitat would occur around Black
Mountain–Deadman Creek, Esmeralda Hill–Clarks Canyon, Greenhorn Mountain, Sweeney
Creek– Austin Creek and Little Porcupine Creek. In total, large non-motorized habitat patches
would increase from 29,870 acres to 43,765 north of the highway (up 47 percent). This is
substantially more than any other alternative.
South of Highway 12, increases would be considerably less, seven percent over current
conditions. Some non-motorized blocks would decrease in size or would be fragmented into
two smaller patches. This follows from the sanctioning of a number of new motor trails
WILDLIFE - 398

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

throughout the area. In some cases, the new trails would be converted from existing open
roads, but in others, they would be established on currently closed roads, sometimes with newly
built connector routes. Those likely to generate the most problems for wildlife are in the area
between Negro Mountain and upper Telegraph Creek (the #1857-1859 road system), in upper
Ontario Creek (road #4104-A1, as in Alternatives 2 and 4) and particularly, in the Slate Lake area
(the #1871 road system), where illegal ORV use has damaged the wet meadow system in the
past [see the later section on “Local Effects in Key Areas”].

Connectivity: Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the matrix in appendix B, which identifies all
past, present and reasonably foreseeable actions and circumstances, in addition to proposed
Travel Management, that may affect connectivity. The scope of the analysis includes the Divide
landscape (Helena NF land with non-Forest inholdings), adjacent National Forest lands (on the
Lincoln Ranger District and the Beaverhead-Deerlodge NF) and neighboring non-Forest lands
(private, State, County, municipal and BLM). This summary is common to all alternatives.

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Several recent and ongoing activities on the Forest may affect habitat connectivity and the way
animals move through the landscape. Actions that have improved connectivity and habitat
quality in the Divide linkage zone include: implementation of the Statewide OHV Plan (USFS,
USFWS 2001), which prohibits riding off established motor routes; a variety of trail relocation
projects that have removed trails from sensitive wildlife areas likely to serve as local movement
corridors to upslope locations; mine reclamation projects that have improved the functioning of
riparian habitats likely to attract animals moving through a linkage zone; grazing allotment
revisions that have generally reduced cattle numbers and improved habitat condition; and road
and motor trail closures associated with timber harvest projects (Clancy-Unionville, Sound
Wood, Mullan Pass, Lava Mountain, Treasure Mountain).

Activities that have reduced effectiveness of connectivity or had a mixed impact (negative for
some species, positive for others) include: timber harvest that has created large clearcuts (Bison
Creek, Mike Renig-Hahn Creek, Deadman Creek, Slate Creek, Ophir Creek-Cave Gulch, Lump
Gulch, Lava Mountain, Mullan Pass); road permits allowing access across Helena NF land to
private holdings; retention of recreational residences on Helena NF land (as at MacDonald Pass);
small mining operations (under the 1872 Mining Act); construction and maintenance of power
lines and communications sites; Forest road improvement projects that have widened road
corridors; and fencing associated with grazing allotments that can impede movement by some
animals.
Recently, harvest of snags from the mountain pine beetle outbreak have created “clean”
openings in the forest, whereas natural processes eventually would have produced openings full
of large woody debris. Most of these projects have been along roads and at developed
recreation and administrative sites and so have had little impact on unroaded habitat. Most
recently, the Red Mountain Flume-Chessman Reservoir project, on both National Forest and
private land, has been removing dead trees from a broad corridor along the flume and around
the Reservoir in the upper Tenmile drainage. The project has been mostly completed on private
lands, but is ongoing on the Helena NF.

WILDLIFE - 399

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Private land development (esp. rural home building) continues to create sites that make it more
difficult for animals to move through the landscape. Problems also come from new and
upgraded roads, mining operations, ATV-trail bike riding areas, private timber harvest, clearing
of vegetative cover from riparian sites and widening and paving of the Marysville road.

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Reasonably foreseeable activities on Helena NF land that may affect connectivity to one degree
or another include improvement of the Rimini Road and projects designed reduce fuel
accumulations and salvage dead trees created by the on-going bark beetle outbreak, in
particular the Telegraph and Tenmile South Helena projects.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Activity on non-Forest land within the cumulative effects area that is expected to continue in the
future and that may affect connectivity includes: settlement and associated development of
private lands (including road building); timber harvest and removal of beetle-killed dead trees;
continued mining operations that usurp habitat and create disturbance zones (most notably, the
Montana Tunnels mine expansion); continued ATV and other motorized activity.

Connectivity: Summary and Conclusions
All alternatives would comply with mandates and management direction as to the impacts of
roads and motor trails on connectivity and fragmentation. The Helena Forest Plan has no
standards or guidelines that deal directly with the issue, although some of those dealing with big
game and grizzly bear habitat are relevant.
Alternative 1 would retain current unweighted open route density of 1.55 mi/mi². Acreage of
large non-motorized habitat patches would remain unchanged at 111,305 acres (63 percent of
all land in the Plan Area). Under Alternative 2, open route density would decline slightly to 1.52
mi/mi². The area occupied by large non-motorized habitat patches would decrease slightly to
109,970 acres (62 percent of all land ownership). Alternative 3 would lower open route density
to 1.34 mi/mi² and increase the total of large non-motorized habitat blocks to 121,705 acres (68
percent of lands in the Plan Area). Alternative 4 would allow for a slightly higher open route
density than Alternative 3, 1.37 mi/mi², but less than Alternatives 1 and 2. The area covered by
large non-motorized blocks would increase over current acreage to 120,155 acres, a bit less than
Alternative 3, but more than Alternatives 1 and 2. With Alternative 5, open route density would
decrease to 1.20 mi/mi², substantially lower than at present; non-motorized habitat patches
would total 130,745 acres (74 percent of the Plan Area), the most of any alternative.
Dirt/gravel Forest roads and motor trails would not physically “fragment” the environment in
ways meaningful to most wildlife species [exceptions being some small mammals and
amphibians]. Differences between alternatives would arise from the degree to which they
provide refuges free from human activity along open roads and motor trails. In this regard,
Alternatives 1 and 2 would be similar. Alternatives 3, 4 and 5, on the other hand, would provide
a number of new opportunities for wildlife use of non-motorized habitat patches, although each
would provide these patches in different patterns.

Divide Travel Plan

Snags and Woody Debris
Snags and Woody Debris: Common Effects of Travel Management
Direct Effects
Direct effects of Forest roads on snags and coarse woody debris stem from initial clearing of the
road corridor, leading to conversion of suitable habitat to non-habitat for the long-term (Hann
et al. 1997, Reed et al. 1996, Trombulak and Frissell 2000). The same is true for motor trails,
though to a lesser degree since most trail corridors are relatively narrow. As none of the Divide
Travel Plan alternatives propose any new road or trail construction, no direct effects follow.

Indirect Effects
Indirectly, roads negatively impact snags and logs by providing access for firewood retrieval
(Hann et al. 1997; Hamann et al. 1999; Bate and Wisdom 2002a, 2002b). Traditionally, effects
were limited to the distance a person could cut and carry firewood to a vehicle. Now, retrieval
is aided by technology, such as cable systems and by increased access through off-road driving
(Bate and Wisdom 2002a). Most recently, the ability of firewood cutters to drive further offroad than in the past has been facilitated by the mountain pine beetle outbreak, which has
opened up the forest and provided new access routes. Formal studies that quantify the indirect
impacts of roads on snags and logs have been lacking until recent studies in Montana and
Oregon (Bate and Wisdom 2002a, 2002b; Wisdom and Bate 2008).

Standing Dead Trees

Wisdom and Bate (2008) found that on the Flathead NF in Montana, mean snag density was 40
percent lower in forested areas within 50 meters (164 feet) of an open road compared to areas
beyond that distance. This was true of 88 percent of the unharvested forest stands that they
sampled. In the zone 50 to 100 meters (164 to 328 feet) from the road, 48 percent of the stands
showed signs of snag removal; and in the region beyond 100 meters, 22 percent of the stands
were found to have been cut.
Table 104 estimates how much habitat in the Travel Plan Area may be susceptible to roadside
snag removal under different alternatives. I have used data from the marten habitat model to
estimate potential large snag habitat, since this is a summation of most of the mature forest
habitat in the Plan Area (where most of the large snags occur). Estimates of the potential
firewood retrieval area are shown for distances of 70, 150 and 300 feet from the road (140, 300
and 600 foot corridors).

Recently, the average number of large dead trees (greater than seven inch diameter-at-breastheight) in these areas has been a fluid quantity because of the increasing numbers of new snags
made available by the mountain pine beetle infestation between 2006 and 2012. Snag numbers
will be high in mature stands dominated by ponderosa pine and especially, by lodgepole pine
(Figure 18, Figure 47, Figure 48) and usually much lower in stands dominated by other
conifer species. For snag-associated wildlife, loss of standing dead trees means loss of nesting,
roosting and foraging habitat, as well as hiding and thermal cover. [See also the black-backed,
pileated and hairy woodpecker analyses and marten analysis below for additional discussion of
the effects of snag removal on wildlife].
In aAlternatives 2, 3 and 4, the “300-foot rule” would allow off-road vehicle use for dispersed
camping in a 600-foot road corridor. Alternative 5 would reduce the off-road driving distance to
30 feet, with dispersed camping allowed out to 70 feet (a 140-foot off-road corridor). These off-

road driving zones are intended to apply only to dispersed camping, not firewood cutting. It is
likely, however, that many firewood gatherers will continue to drive off-road a certain distance
to load firewood (as is common practice now). Also, under the 300 foot rule, it would be
permissible to cut firewood from an occupied dispersed camp site up to 300 feet off the road.
Firewood cutters will be drawn further into the forest in areas where the Roadside Hazard Tree
Project has already removed dead trees from the first 50 to 150 feet adjacent to the road. The
potential loss of snags to firewood cutting in any given section of road corridor is mediated by
topography natural impediments (steep slopes, streams, rock outcrops).

Coarse Woody Debris
Effects on logs in the road corridor are a direct result of snag attrition and removal for firewood.
Bate and Wisdom (2002b) found that log densities along open roads were significantly lower
than those along closed roads. The areas vulnerable to large log attrition are thus the same as
those for snags. In general, roadside corridors are likely to have more remaining large logs than
snags. Some snags will fall before they are taken for firewood and if not solid, will be left in
place by firewood gatherers. This will be the case most often with the more punky ponderosa
pine logs than with lodgepole pine. Because of the large volume of dead timber now available
and the relatively short time span that beetle-killed trees remain standing, downed trees will be
providing an increasing proportion of the roadside firewood resource over the next few years.
As with standing snags, steep slopes, rough terrain and otherwise difficult ground will limit the
extent of the roadside zone from which logs are taken. On a steep downward slope, for
example, 25 to 50 feet may be all the distance most firewood cutters are willing to venture off
the road to retrieve a fallen snag.
The loss of logs and other coarse woody debris represents a diminution of foraging, denning,
nesting and resting sites, as well as cover and refuge for a variety of wildlife species (Rose et al.
2000). Other indirect effects associated with removal of large logs include influence on basic
ecosystem processes, soil development and productivity, nutrient immobilization and
mineralization and nitrogen fixation (Rose et al. 2000).

Snags and Woody Debris: Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the detailed matrix in appendix B, which
identifies all past, present and reasonably foreseeable projects and other activities, in addition
to proposed Travel Management, that may affect large snags and coarse woody debris habitat.
The scope of the analysis includes the Divide landscape (Helena NF land, non-Forest inholdings)
and immediately surrounding lands (private, State, County, Municipal and BLM).

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Activities that have cumulatively reduced snags or the potential for snag creation include a
number of past timber sales that have created large clearcuts with minimal residual snags or
replacement snags (Bison, Ontario, Upper Telegraph, Mike Renig-Hahn Creek, Slate Creek, Lump
Gulch-Strawberry, Ophir Creek-Cave Gulch, Deadman, Cellar Gulch). Some projects (Mike Renig,
Upper Telegraph, Hope-Snowshoe) were specifically designed to remove dead, dying and
decadent trees. The ongoing Clancy-Unionville project in the upper Lump Gulch and Quartz
Creek drainages, originally designed to harvest green trees, is now focused primarily on
removing dead trees. Also ongoing is the Red Mountain Flume Chessman Resevoir Project,
which is removing snags from 490 acres of beetle-impacted forest in the upper Tenmile Creek
drainage. Recent Carbaryl spraying of campgrounds and other administrative sites (Cromwell
Dixon campground, MacDonald Pass trailhead) has been intended to prevent large trees from
dying in areas of concentrated public use. This enterprise has met with limited success and thus
has not been a major factor in suppressing snag creation.

The ongoing policy of allowing public firewood cutting on the National Forest is the primary
factor driving the removal of most large snags from Forest road corridors. Ongoing efforts by the
Helena NF to limit the potential safety hazard posed by large numbers of dead trees in areas
frequented by the public have accelerated the process of snag loss in road corridors and other
accessible sites. These actions have also reduced the number of snags available to firewood
cutters. Hazard tree removal projects have recently been completed or are going forward at a
number of campgrounds (Cromwell Dixon, Moose Creek, Kading, Park Lake), day-use areas
(Moose Creek, MacDonald Pass), trailheads (MacDonald Pass CDNST), administrative sites
(Moose Creek ranger station, Kading cabin), as well as along the MacDonald Pass Cross-country
ski trails and most conspicuously, along many miles of open Forest roads (an on-going
operation).
Recent and ongoing activities on the National Forest that have improved prospects for snags are
the road closures associated with a number of timber harvest projects (Clancy-Unionville, Sound
Wood, Mullan Pass, Treasure Mountain, Lava Mountain), which limit roadside firewood cutting.
These projects have all adhered to Forest Plan standards for retaining snags and replacement
snags. In some cases, decisions not to pursue potential salvage opportunities (Jericho
Mountain, Snowshoe Creek, MacDonald Pass burn) have resulted in retention of large blocks of
snags.

WILDLIFE - 404

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Numerous dead-tree salvage operations on private land within and adjacent to Forest
boundaries are eliminating many of the snags being created by the current bark beetle
infestation. As well, private land development is slowly eroding snag presence on many local
sites. Many thinning and snag removal projects on private, City and State land have been driven
by the desire to reduce the potential for catastrophic fire and in some cases, to remove hazards
to public safety.

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Reasonably foreseeable activities on Helena NF land that may affect snag density and
distribution on the National Forest include proposals to deal with the effects of the ongoing bark
beetle epidemic: the Telegraph Creek Fuels Reduction and the Tenmile South Helena Projects,
both of which would remove snags and coarse woody debris over extensive areas in the
southern Divide landscape.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Activity on non-Forest land within the cumulative effects area that is expected to continue in the
future and that may affect snags includes the continuation of land development, thinning for
fire prevention and dead tree salvage.

Snags and Woody Debris: Summary and Conclusions
All alternatives would comply with appropriate snag standards and guidelines in the Helena
Forest Plan and with guidance in the Northern Region Snag Management Protocol (USFS 2000)
and Estimates of Snag Densities for Eastside Forests in the Northern Region (Bollenbacher et al.
2008).
Alternative 1 would retain approximately 294 miles of open road corridor available to firewood
cutters in mature forest habitats. Within a 600 foot road corridor, this represents 12 percent of
mature forest in the Travel Plan Area. Under Alternative 2, road corridor open to firewood
cutters would decline to 260 miles in mature forest. Assuming a 600 foot road corridor, this
amounts to 11 percent of mature forest habitat in the Travel Plan Area. Under Alternative 3,
open road corridor available to firewood cutting and snag removal would decline to 233 miles in
mature forest. With a 600 foot road corridor, this amounts to 10 percent of mature forest
habitat in the Travel Plan Area. Alternative 4 is similar to Alternative 3. It would maintain 235
miles of road corridor open to firewood cutting in mature forest. Within a 600 foot road
corridor, this also represents 10 percent of mature forest in the Travel Plan Area. Alternative 5
would put the most roadside snag habitat off-limits to firewood cutting, maintaining 168 miles
of open road in mature habitat and providing a potential 12,220 acres in the 600 foot road
corridor.
Dead trees and increasingly, large logs are prolific on the landscape in the wake of the ongoing
bark beetle infestation. Snags in Forest road corridors susceptible to harvest by firewood
cutters represent a relatively small proportion of the available resource.

Migratory Landbirds and Shorebirds
Management direction for addressing migratory landbirds and shorebirds in project planning
derives from (1) the Forest Service’s Landbird Conservation Strategic Plan (2000), (2) Executive
Order 13186 (2001) [Fed Reg. Vol 66, No. 11, p. 3853-3856] and (3) a memorandum of
WILDLIFE - 405

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

understanding (MOU) between the Forest Service and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (2008).
These documents focus on habitat management and its role in protecting and enhancing bird
populations. The role of road and trail system management comes into play as it relates to (1)
altering, maintaining, or enhancing suitable habitat in the road corridor or (2) funneling human
disturbance into sensitive habitat sites.

Migratory Birds: Common Effects of Travel Management
Direct Effects
Direct effects of Forest roads on migratory bird habitat stem from initial clearing and long-term
maintenance of the road corridors (generally 12 to 20 feet wide), which results in strips of nonhabitat or habitat unsuitable for many species over the long-term (Hann et al. 1997, Reed et al.
1996, Trombulak and Frissell 2000). These corridors also create edge, an effect most evident in
forest and shrub habitats, less so in grasslands [see previous section, “General Habitat: Common
Effects of Travel Management”]. While some bird species have problems with road corridor
habitat and forest edge, others are attracted by these habitat features (Bull and Wales 2001).
Similar effects would be generated by motor trails that follow old roadbeds. Those that have
been established originally as trails subtract little habitat and create little recognizable edge
since in most cases the trail corridors are very narrow and often produce no more recognizable
edge than a well-established game trail.
As none of the Divide Travel Plan alternatives propose new road construction, no direct effects
beyond those already created by the present road/ trail system would follow in any alternative.
Differences between alternatives in terms of the acreage of existing road/road corridor habitat
would be negligible in the short-term since this habitat would remain intact whether roads are
open or closed. Over the long-term, road corridor habitat and edge would decline under
alternatives that close more roads, as obliterated and unmaintained roads would begin to fill
with trees and other vegetation.

Indirect Effects
Birds dependent on dead trees are often unable to find suitable habitat in the vicinity of open
roads (within 200 to 300 feet) because of ongoing snag loss to firewood cutting and hazard tree
removal. An estimate of the acreage potentially affected by these activities under different
alternatives can be found in the previous section, “Snags and Woody Debris” (Table 104). The
overall effect of this snag depletion on local bird populations is relatively small, given the
abundance of unaffected habitat away from roads and the proliferation of dead trees across the
landscape in the wake of the mountain pine beetle epidemic.
Birds that are sensitive to human activity are unlikely to frequent areas near roads that carry a
regular flow of traffic. This is particularly true of nesting raptors and waterfowl, but it applies to
some songbirds as well, particularly specialist species. Whereas most generalist songbird
species will forage and establish nests near Forest roads and trails, a study in Colorado found
that specialist species were less common in a zone within about 250 feet of active trails (Miller
et al. 1998). A number of other studies have defined considerably wider zones of disturbance
around roads; but most of these have been investigating the effects of paved highways, which
carry much more traffic than most Forest roads (Hamann et al. 1999, p. 3.23-3.24). It is likely
that on many roads in theTravel Plan Area, traffic volume is so low that displacement of
songbirds and even raptors, is negligible.

WILDLIFE - 406

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

It should be noted that the Northern Region Landbird Monitoring Program, which employed
Forest roads and trails as transect lines, consistently picked up a wide variety of both specialist
and generalist bird species in its surveys on the Helena NF over a 14-year period [see previous
discussion in “Affected Environment: Migratory Songbirds and Landbirds”].

Migratory Birds: Comparison of Alternatives

Table 105 summarizes potential effects of road management on migratory bird species of
concern for each of the five alternatives. Removal of snags from the 300-foot wide corridors
flanking each side of open roads is a primary influence for snag users. Species listed as “averse
to nesting near open roads” would choose nesting sites in other areas, although in the Divide
Travel Plan Area, few of the nesting components used by these species are available in road
corridors to begin with. Golden eagles and prairie falcons, for example, generally nest in high
cliffs. Great blue herons establish nest colonies in groves of cottonwood trees adjacent to rivers
and lakes.

Each of the four action alternatives would decrease the acreage of roadside habitat open to the
impacts listed in Table 105. Species that make use of habitats or of habitat components little
influenced by the road system are shown as sustaining “no effect”, that is, no effect that
measurably alters their distribution or habitat use patterns within their home ranges.
