As indicated in Table 86[“Affected Environment: Migratory Songbirdes and Landbirds”], Forest
roads have not been determined to be a limiting factor for any of the Species of Concern listed
in that table or in Table 105 above. None of the effects generated by any of the Divide Travel
Plan alternatives would be substantial enough to limit population potential for any of the
migratory bird species considered here.

Effects of Alternative 1 (Existing Condition)
Alternative 1 proposes no new road or trail construction. Consequently, there would be no
direct effect on migratory bird habitat beyond that from past road/trail construction. The
alternative would maintain 450 miles of existing open road and motor trail with varying degrees
of human disturbance and edge effect. It would maintain 294 miles of open road in mature
forest habitat capable of producing snags useful to some of the species listed in Table 105.

WILDLIFE - 408

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Assuming a 300 foot wide firewood removal zone on each side of the road, this would amount
to 21,300 acres, 12 percent of such habitat in the Travel Plan Area. These effects would not be
sufficient to measurably depress populations of any bird species of concern.

Effects of Alternative 2
Alternative 2 would reduce open roads and motor trails slightly to 445 miles, thus subtracting
five route miles subject to motorized disruption. It would maintain 260 miles of open road in
mature forest capable of producing snags useful to some of the species listed in Table 105. This
represents a decline of 34 miles from existing condition. Assuming a 300 foot wide firewood
removal zone on each side of the road, this would amount to 18,900 acres, 11 percent of such
habitat in the Travel Plan Area. These effects would not be sufficient to measurably increase or
decrease populations of any bird species of concern.

Effects of Alternative 3
Alternative 3 would reduce open roads and motor trails to 379 miles, a decline of 61 miles in
routes with motorized disturbance. Alternative 3 would maintain 233 miles of open road in
mature forest habitat capable of producing snags useful to some of the species listed in Table
105. This is a decline of 71 miles from existing condition. Assuming a 300 foot wide firewood
removal zone on each side of the road, this would amount to 16,970 acres, 10 percent of such
habitat in the Travel Plan Area. The net effect would not be sufficient to measurably alter
population potential of any bird species of concern.

Effects of Alternative 4
Alternative 4 would reduce open roads and motor trails to 393 miles, somewhat more than
Alternative 3 but 57 miles less than at present. These closed routes would no longer be subject
to motorized disturbance. Alternative 4 would maintain 235 miles of open road in mature forest
habitat capable of producing snags useful to some of the species listed in Table 105. This is
similar to Alternative 3 and 57 miles less than the existing condition. Assuming a 300 foot wide
firewood removal zone on each side of the road, this would amount to 16,970 acres, 10 percent
of such habitat in the Travel Plan Area. The net effects would not be sufficient to measurably
alter population potential of any bird species of concern.

Effects of Alternative 5
Alternative 5 would reduce open roads and motor trails to 325 miles. This is 126 miles less than
at present and represents the largest decine of any alternative in routes no longer susceptible to
motorized disturbance. Alternative 5 would maintain 168 miles of open road in mature forest
habitat capable of producing snags useful to some of the species listed in Table 105. This
represents a substantial decrease, 126 miles, from existing condition. Assuming a 300-foot wide
firewood removal zone on each side of the road, this would amount to 16,970 acres, only seven
percent of such habitat in the Travel Plan Area. The net effects of these changes would not be
large enough to measurably increase population potential of any bird species of concern.

Migratory Birds: Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the detailed matrix in appendix B, which
identifies all past, present and reasonably foreseeable projects and other activities, in addition
to proposed Travel Management, that may affect large snags and coarse woody debris habitat.
The scope of the analysis includes the Divide landscape (Helena NF land, non-Forest inholdings)
and immediately surrounding lands (private, State, County, Municipal and BLM).

WILDLIFE - 409

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Activities that have cumulatively altered habitat for migratory birds by reducing snags or shifting
the balance between mature and early-seral forest include a number of past timber sales:
Bison, Ontario, Upper Telegraph, Mike Renig-Hahn Creek, Slate Creek, Lump Gulch-Strawberry,
Ophir Creek-Cave Gulch, Deadman and Cellar Gulch. Some projects (Mike Renig, Upper
Telegraph, Hope-Snowshoe) were specifically designed to remove dead, dying and decadent
trees. The recently completed Clancy-Unionville project in the upper Lump Gulch and Quartz
Creek drainages, originally designed to harvest green trees, ended up focusing primarily on
removing dead trees created by the bark beetle outbreak. Prominent among ongoing habitatalterning projects is the the Red Mountain Flume Chessman Resevoir Project, which is removing
snags from 490 acres of beetle-impacted forest in the upper Tenmile Creek drainage. Recent
Carbaryl spraying of campgrounds and other administrative sites (Cromwell Dixon campground,
MacDonald Pass trailhead) has been intended to prevent large trees from dying in areas of
concentrated public use. This enterprise has met with limited success and thus has not been a
major factor in suppressing snag creation.

The policy of allowing public firewood cutting on the National Forest is a primary factor driving
the removal of most large snags from Forest road corridors. Ongoing efforts by the Helena NF
to limit the potential safety hazard posed by large numbers of dead trees in areas frequented by
the public have accelerated the process of snag loss in road corridors and other accessible sites.
These actions have also transformed forest habitat dominated by mature trees to open earlyseral environments. These changes subsantially shift the compositon of local migratory bird
associations. Hazard tree removal projects have recently been completed or are going forward
at a number of campgrounds (Cromwell Dixon, Moose Creek, Kading, Park Lake), day-use areas
(Moose Creek, MacDonald Pass), trailheads (MacDonald Pass CDNST), administrative sites
(Moose Creek ranger station, Kading cabin), as well as along the MacDonald Pass Cross-country
ski trails and most conspicuously, along many miles of open Forest roads (an on-going
operation).
Recent and ongoing activities on the National Forest that have improved prospects for snags
and dependent bird species are the road closures associated with a number of timber harvest
projects (Clancy-Unionville, Sound Wood, Mullan Pass, Treasure Mountain, Lava Mountain),
which limit roadside firewood cutting. These projects have all adhered to Forest Plan standards
for retaining snags and replacement snags. In some cases, decisions not to pursue potential
salvage opportunities (Jericho Mountain, Snowshoe Creek, MacDonald Pass burn) have resulted
in retention of large blocks of snags.

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Numerous dead-tree salvage operations on private land within and adjacent to Forest
boundaries are eliminating many of the snags being created by the current bark beetle
infestation and created wide open early-seral habitat with variable conifer regeneration. Local
bird communities have shifted accordingly. As well, private land development is slowly eroding
snag presence on many local sites. Many thinning and snag removal projects on private, City
and State land have been driven by the desire to reduce the potential for catastrophic fire and in
some cases, to remove hazards to public safety.

WILDLIFE - 410

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Reasonably foreseeable activities on Helena NF land that may affect snag density and
distribution on the National Forest include proposals to deal with the effects of the ongoing bark
beetle epidemic: the Telegraph Creek Fuels Reduction and the Tenmile South Helena Projects,
both of which would remove snags and coarse woody debris over extensive areas in the
southern Divide landscape. Harvested areas with relatively “clean” ground-level environments
would provide different habitat opportunity for birds than sites left with accummulated coarse
woody debris.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Activity on non-Forest land within the cumulative effects area that is expected to continue in the
future and that may affect snags includes the continuation of land development, thinning for
fire prevention and dead tree salvage.

Migratory Birds: Summary and Conclusions
None of the effects generated by project alternatives would be sufficient to measurably depress
populations of any migratory bird species of concern.
Alternative 1 would retain approximately 294 miles of open road corridor available to firewood
cutters in mature forest habitats, a zone with few habitat components for snag dependent bird
species. It would retain 450 miles of open road and motor trail, some of which would unsuitable
for nesting birds sensitive to human activity.
Under Alternative 2, road corridor open to firewood cutters would decline to 260 miles in
mature forest. It would retain 445 miles of open road and motor trail.
Under Alternative 3, open road corridor available to firewood cutting and snag removal would
decline to 233 miles in mature forest. Open road and motor trail would drop to 379miles.
Alternative 4 would maintain 235 miles of road corridor open to firewood cutting in mature
forest and would retain 393 miles of open road and motor trail.
Alternative 5 would put the most roadside snag habitat off-limits to firewood cutting,
maintaining 168 miles of open road in mature habitat. It would reduce open road and motor tail
to 324 miles.

Big Game: Elk
Effects of travel management on elk are discussed in terms of (1) habitat effectiveness (as
measured by open road density) on summer range, (2) human disturbance on winter range and
(3) elk security during the hunting season. Implications for compliance with current Helena
Forest Plan standards are discussed with regard to (1) hiding cover and calving sites on summer
range, (2) thermal cover and human disturbance on winter range and (3) open road density/
hiding cover ratios on fall range. Also discussed are compliance with (1) the proposed
amendment for determining elk security and (2) recommendations of the Montana Cooperative
Elk-Logging Study 1970-1985 (Lyon et al. 1985). Results of management are assessed via elk
population data furnished by Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks.

Elk: Common Effects of Travel Management
Big Game Summer Range

WILDLIFE - 411

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Rationale for Management

Energetic demands of elk, growth, development, lactation, are high during the summer as
animals are simultaneously recovering from weight lost the previous winter, supporting young
of the year through lactation and building fat reserves for the coming winter. Motorized
activities impact elk through direct disturbance and potentially, displacement from high-quality
habitats, resulting in lowered reproductive performance. As well, new road construction and
cross-country ORV use can degrade or eliminate segments of productive summer elk habitat, in
particular, local wet habitats (subirrigated meadows, streamside habitat, drainage-head basins),
thus reducing habitat potential on summer range (Grover and Thompson 1986; Hamilton 1997;
Rowland et al. 2003; Ward and Cupal 1979).

Wisdom et al. (2004) indicate that off-road recreation, motorized and non-motorized, increases
movement rates and flight responses of elk. Elk react more to ATV and mountain bike riding
than to horseback and hiking activities (though mule deer may respond more to hikers). Elk
energy reserves may deteriorate as a cost of fleeing from off-road activity on a regular basis
because of increased movement and displacement from foraging habitat.

Summer Range: Forest Plan Standards

The Helena Forest Plan uses hiding cover as the primary indicator of summer range quality. The
rationale is that “[t]he total amount of hiding cover on summer habitat is an important part of
the overall elk habitat capability” (USFS 1983]. Big game standard 3 specifies that hiding cover is
to be maintained at or above 35 percent (as per the USFS definition) or 50 percent (as per the
MFWP definition) of the elk/deer summer range within each elk herd unit or equivalent analysis
area (HFP, p. II/18). Standard 5 then specifies that in order to be tallied as part of this “Forest
Plan hiding cover” the cover must occur in blocks of 40 acres or more (HFP, p. II/19). In this
analysis, we use the MFWP definition of hiding cover (in which greater than or equal to 40
percent canopy closure is used as a surrogate for actual hiding cover as measured on the
ground) and we thus aim for greater than or equal to 50 percent canopy closure on elk summer
range.

The Divide Travel Plan would have no effect on the status of Forest Plan hiding cover and any
ongoing and future changes in hiding cover generated by other factors (most notably, losses due
to mountain pine beetle infestation) would be the same for all alternatives [see Table 106 and
Table 108 in the following section, “Comparison of Alternatives”]. Application of this Forest Plan
indicator thus leads to the conclusion that summer habitat quality would be identical under all
alternatives, a result that is problematic, given the different road and motor trail configurations
in elk summer range under the different alternatives.

Summer Range: Habitat Effectiveness

Because roads have long been known to influence how elk are able to use summer habitat (see
Lyon 1979, 1982; Lyon et al. 1985), we have employed “habitat effectiveness”, which is based
on open road density, as an additional means of detecting potential differences in how
alternatives impact elk summer range. As it turns out, overall elk habitat effectiveness (HE) for
the Travel Plan Area, as measured by weighted open road density from late spring through early
fall, is roughly the same among the five alternatives (72 percent to 74 percent). The alternatives
vary more, however, in the habitat effectiveness they provide in some individual herd units. All
six herd units are well above the minimum 50 percent level recommended for elk summer range
(Christensen et al. 1993) under each of the five alternatives. The current range of HE values

WILDLIFE - 412

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

runs from 65 percent in the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU to 87 percent in the Black Mountain–
Brooklyn Bridge EHU [see Table 107].
Calf production and survival in local hunting districts, as indicated by cow/calf ratios are in line
with MFWP objectives for this area, 35 to 40 calves/100 cows (MT Elk Management Plan 2004),
which is a good indication of suitable habitat effectiveness on summer range. The status of
summer range in local elk herd units and hunting districts has been discussed in detail in the
“Affected Environment” segment of this report. Specific instances of how different alternatives
may funnel human activity into or away from elk calving areas are provided toward the end of
this report in the section dealing with “Local Effects in Key Areas”. That analysis provides
information relevant to HFP big game standard 4b, which seeks to minimize motorized
disturbance in these key habitat areas (HFP, p. II/18).

Big Game Security during the Hunting Season

Rationale for Management

In the Divide landscape (as on much of the Helena NF), elk security/vulnerability during the
hunting season is a primary determinant of elk abundance and population structure. While the
ability of elk to survive the hunting season is influenced by a number of environmental
circumstances, the status of the local Forest road system is often the key factor. Several studies
have documented the effect of roads on elk security, population structure and hunter success
(Edge and Marcum 1991; Leptich and Zager 1991; Unsworth and Kuck 1991; Gratson and
Whitman 2000). While most studies demonstrate that open roads influence elk distribution
during the hunting season and that road closures can lower the kill rate in a given area, at least
one study indicates that in certain circumstances road closures do not alter hunter success
(Burbridge and Neff 1976 cited in Gratson and Whitman 2000). In an increasing number of
cases, displacement of elk from roaded public land into more remote terrain or to inaccessible
private land early in the fall can depress hunter success rate throughout the remainder of the
season.

Big Game Security: Current Forest Plan Standard

The current Helena Forest Plan (1986) standard for measuring elk vulnerability during the
hunting season is based on an index that combines open road density and hiding cover (HFP, pp.
II/17 – II/18: standard 4a). Hiding cover will change over time, decreasing with losses to fire,
insects and disease, commercial timber harvest, thinning and stand aging. It will increase as
conifer regeneration fills in forest openings and the understories of mature stands. However, in
this case, hiding cover changes will be the same for all five Travel Plan alternatives. Thus, the
variable that separates alternatives is open road density. [See “Affected Environment for Elk”
for a discussion as to how the Helena NF determines compliance with the standard]. Table 108
shows that only three of the six Divide EHUs comply with standard 4a under all five alternatives.
A fourth EHU (Little Prickly Pear–Ophir) comes into compliance with Alternative 5. Although
open road density declines under all action alternatives, sometimes substantially, the only
change in status that the standard recognizes is the shift in the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU in
Alternative 5. Likewise, the standard provides no indication as to how much elk may benefit
from declining open road densities in the three EHUs that are in compliance.

Big Game Security: Amended Forest Plan Standard

The Helena NF is proposing to replace the current Forest Plan big game security index (standard
4a) with a new standard that is less dependent on “open road density” per se than it is on the
pattern of open roads and motor trails on the landscape [see the previous discussion in
WILDLIFE - 413

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

“Affected Environment”]. While recognizing that cover can be an important component of
security, the new standard does not require a specific percentage of hiding cover relative to
open road density. This approach is based in large part on “U.S. Forest Service and Montana
Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks Collaborative Overview and Recommendations for Elk
Habitat Management on the Custer, Gallatin, Helena and Lewis and Clark National Forests”
[FS/MFWP Big Game Working Group (USFS and MFWP 2013)] and is detailed in the Forest Plan
Programmatic Amendment for Big Game Security for the Divide Travel Plan. Application of this
“elk security” approach to the Divide Travel Plan and to future projects in the Travel Plan Area is
summarized as follows:

Definitions.
Elk security is a measure of the degree to which habitat conditions (both natural and humangenerated) enable elk to survive the hunting season. On the Helena NF, this is considered to be
primarily a function of hunter access and in particular, motorized hunter access. Elk security is
expressed as the percentage of hunting season home range within Helena NF administrative
boundaries occupied by effective elk security areas.
Elk security areas capable of holding elk through the hunting season are defined in terms of
parameters developed by Hillis et al. (1991) modified for “eastside” environments: security
areas are non-linear, predominantly forested blocks of habitat at least 1,000 acres in size with all
borders ½ mile from open roads and motor trails.
Intermittent Refuge Areas are unroaded areas 250 to 999 acres in size with all borders ½ mile
from open motor routes. While generally not large enough or diverse enough toserve as “fullservice” security areas, they provide important escape areas for elk during the hunting season
and need to be preserved as such.
Hiding cover (coniferous vegetation capable of hiding 90 percent of a standing elk at 200 feet) is
recognized as an important habitat component to be preserved and developed within security
and refuge areas. There is, however, no specified percentage of a security area that needs to be
maintained as hiding cover under the new standard. Screening cover (forest more open than
hiding cover but capable of blocking clear sightlines) and low-level concealment cover (provided
by deadfall, shrubs, young conifers, boulders, etc.) are also recognized as useful habitat
elements to be nurtured within security and refuge areas.
Herd units are fixed analysis areas that do not shift with variable movement patterns of
individual elk herd groups or from one project to another. Elk security is determined for the
portions of individual elk herd units (or other equivalent elk analysis units) that lie within Helena
NF administrative boundaries (regardless of ownership).
Percent elk security for is based on the combined acreage of full security areas (greater than or
equal to 1,000 acres) within a given herd unit. Intermitent refuge area acres are not added into
the total for purposes of determining compliance with the standard.
The big game hunting season is defined as extending from September 1 through December 1,
thus including both the archery season and the general rifle season.
Amended Standard.
Road management will be implemented to maintain or improve big game security and hunting
opportunity. Road management will also be implemented to maintain or improve big game
intermittent refuge areas. The standard applies only to the National Forest System lands within

WILDLIFE - 414

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

those portions of an elk herd unit that are within the Helena Ranger District, Helena National
Forest administrative boundary.
The standard specifies the minimum security level (the percentage of each elk herd unit
occupied by security areas and intermittent refuge areas) that needs to maintained under each
Divide Travel Plan alternative. These security levels are shown in Table 109, which follows in the
“Comparison of Alternatives” section. The values shown in the table represent baseline security
levels that, at present (Alternative 1), are providing sufficient protection for local elk
populations so as to allow MFWP to meet management goals [Table 92 and Table 93], which
has been the rationale for using them as the baseline. As long as future projects or
circumstances do not depress these percentages, the elk herd units remain in compliance with
the standard. But since all herd units are well below the optimal goal of 50 percent elk security,
it is desireable to increase security area acreage. As can be seen in Table 109, the general trend
under all action alternatives is increasing acreage in elk security areas.
Currently, only 19 percent of the Divide landscape is occupied by bona fide elk security areas
(greater than or equal to 1,000 acres). The total contribution of security areas increases by
about 1,650 acres in Alternative 2, but the overall rounded percentage remains at 19 percent.
The percentage progresses to 23 percent in Alternative 4, 24 percent in Alternative 3 and 27
percent in Alternative 5 [see Table 109].
For individual EHUs at present, only two support security areas occupying more than 20 percent
of the unit: Little Prickly Pear–Ophir (23 percent) and Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot (30 percent).
One herd unit (Quartz) contains no security areas, although it does include two intermittent
refuge areas. Under Alternative 2, two units would increase in security area acreage, one
(Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot) would decrease and three would remain unchanged. Only two
units would be above 20 percent security and none would surpass 30 percent. Under
Alternatives 3, 4 and 5, four herd would increase in percent security and two would remain
unchanged. Under Alternative 5, three herd units would be near or above 30 percent security.
Although security area acreage increases under all action alternatives, particularly alternatives
3, 4 and 5, the overall acreage in intermittent refuge areas remains relatively constant at two to
three percent of the landscape under all alternatives (Table 110). The classification of these
small areas actually changes appreciably between alternatives, as new new refuges are created
and others enlarge into full security areas as road patterns shift [Figure 34 through Figure 38].
Refuge area acreage is not added into the security total for the different herd units, but we felt
that the importance of these areas to elk needed to be recognized and that they should be
delineated as areas not to be compromised by resource management activity.
All herd units in all alternatives would comply with the amended Forest Plan security standard.
Although in a couple cases, security area acreages would decline from current levels, each
alternative is independent of the others in terms of defining the compliance baseline. Once an
alternative is selected and implemented, then the given security levels for that alternative
cannot decline in any herd unit if it is to remain in compliance with the standard.
For the most part, these levels of elk security have been yielding elk populations that exceed
MFWP objectives for total elk numbers in the Granite Butte and Deerlodge Elk Management
Units (EMUs) (Montana Elk Management Plan 2004). Bull/cow ratios in those portions of the
EMUs that overlap the Divide landscape are at or slightly above objectives (currently around 12
to 14 bulls/100 cows). Given the unregulated mature bull hunt allowed in these areas, this ratio
is a good indicator of the adequacy of elk security throughout the Divide landscape.

WILDLIFE - 415

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

The nature of elk security and vulnerability in local hunting districts, elk management units and
elk herd units has been discussed in detail earlier under “Affected Environment”.

Winter Range

Rationale for Management

Winter range can be a key limiting factor for elk (and all ungulates). Wintering areas with little
human activity and adequate forage will help minimize energetic costs associated with overwinter survival. As discussed earlier, much of the elk winter range in the Divide landscape is on
private, State and BLM lands outside the Helena NF boundary and beyond the reach of the
Forest winter road and trail system. In many cases, elk choose to spend much of the winter on
private ranch and agricultural lands, rather than on Forest grasslands in the foothills, even when
they are readily available and stocked with abundant palatable forage.

While winter recreationists on foot (cross-country skiers, snowshoers) can disturb elk on winter
habitat, few local winter ranges see this kind of activity (most of which occurs at higher
elevation). Winter ranges for Helena NF elk are subject primarily to disturbance from
snowmobiles, wheeled vehicles (ATVs, four-wheel-drive rigs, cars and trucks on roads) and a
variety of activities associated with ranching operations and in some cases, subdivisions.
Depending on the intensity, frequency and predictability of the disturbance, elk reactions could
involve an increase in general alertness, slow retreating movement, or outright flight (Canfield
et. al. 1999). A steady stream of disturbance, particularly in severe winters, has potential to
increase mortality on winter and spring ranges and to lower reproductive success (Skovlin et al.
2002).

Helena Forest Plan Winter Range Standards

The Helena Forest Plan aims to limit vehicle use on winter range to established routes that
provide access to other parts of the Forest or to adjacent private lands (big game standard 4c).
These travel restrictions are intended to prevent disturbance and harassment of elk and other
big game animals during a period when physical stress is already high. Most, though not all,
existing routes on winter range meet this standard. Alternatives 2, 3, 4 and 5 propose new
restrictions for motorized recreation on winter range via new snowmobile area closures and
seasonal closure of some motorized recreational trails. None of the Travel Plan alternatives
would allow new motor routes on elk winter range. In a number of cases, the classification of
snowmobile routes would change, not to allow a new use, but to more accurately describe
existing snowmobile routes where no conflicts with wildlife or other resources have arisen. In
cases where a winter range conflict has become apparent (lower Sweeney Creek, Mike Renig
Gulch), action alternatives propose closing existing snowmobile access.

The Forest Plan standard to maintain at least 25 percent of winter range in thermal cover (big
game standard 3) is not now being met on any of the five Divide elk herd units with winter
range. In the Divide landscape, most of the winter range used by elk in all but the mildest of
winters is on private and public land beyond the National Forest boundary. Field observation
across this off-Forest region, along with perusal of aerial photos, reveals that thermal cover is
well below 25 percent on these winter ranges as well. Be that as it may, recent MFWP surveys of
winter ranges in the Divide landscape and adjacent foothills and valley lands suggest that elk
and deer populations are suffering no ill effects from the dearth of classic thermal cover. Both
species make frequent use of mature/pole timber on winter range, although most of these
stands are not dense enough to provide the 70 percent canopy closure required of true thermal
cover.

WILDLIFE - 416

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

In the end, this is a moot point for Divide Travel Plan proposals since no alternative would have
any effect on big game thermal cover: its status would be the same in all herd units under all
alternatives.

Elk: Comparison of Alternatives
Summer Range

Forest Plan Big Game Standard 3: Hiding Cover

Forest Plan big game standard 3 stipulates that 35 percent of summer range in each elk herd
unit should be maintained as Forest Plan hiding cover. When hiding cover is measured indirectly
via crown closure, 50 percent of the range needs to be maintained at 40 percent crown closure
(MDFWP hiding cover). Hiding cover acres in Table 106 are based on pre-beetle-kill crown
closure estimates (from 2011 R1 Vmap satellite imagery). Given that some elk now remain on
low and mid elevation off-Forest lands yearlong, this analysis considers all lands, public and
private, within the elk herd units to be potential summer range. This includes the 1.5 mile
extension of herd unit boundaries onto private and other non-Forest lands.

At present, based on the 2011 data, all six elk herd units are above the MDFWP 50 percent
threshold to one degree or another. No Travel Plan alternative would affect Forest Plan hiding
cover and any changes in cover generated by other factors (most notably, losses to mountain
pine beetle) would be the same for all alternatives. This standard is thus not useful in
differentiating between Travel Plan alternatives in terms of their effects on elk summer range.

Habitat Effectiveness on Summer Range

Habitat effectiveness is not a Forest Plan standard, but because it is based on open road density,
it relates more directly to travel planning proposals than measures based on hiding cover.

Table 107 summarizes open road density and habitat effectiveness (HE) on summer range for
the five alternatives. Habitat effectiveness percentages estimate how much of the potential
summer range is free from motorized disturbance throughout the season. Percentages are
derived from an index developed by Lyon (1983) and employed by Christensen et al. (1993),
who recommended habitat effectiveness levels of at least 50 percent on elk summer range as a
whole and 70 percent in areas of key habitat (productive sites where elk consistently
concentrate). For the sake of consistency, habitat effectiveness is calculated for the same areas
as is Forest Plan hiding cover for big game standard 3: that is, entire elk herd units, including the
1.5 mile off-Forest extension zone. While elk do use low/mid-elevation non-Forest habitat in
some summers, most summer use occurs in higher elevation habitats on the National Forest.

WILDLIFE - 417

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

So the delineation of summer range used in these analyses takes in virtually all areas that elk
may inhabit under a wide range of summer conditions.
As can be seen in Table 107, all elk herd units in the Travel Plan Area are currently above the
recommended 50 percent habitat effectiveness level and all of them would remain above that
level under all action alternatives. This comports with USFS field observations as to summer
habitat availability and condition and with MFWP asessments as to the general health of the elk
population, which lead to the conclusion that summer range in general is not a limiting factor
for elk in the Divide landscape.

While habitat effectiveness in most elk herd units increases over current values under each of
the action alternatives, there are no major shifts. All habitat effectiveness values fall within the
range of 54 percent to 65 percent. The inference is that, in all cases, elk will have access to
enough general summer range free from regular motorized interference to meet their needs.
These values are for broad areas of public and private land that elk may use to one degree or
another, depending on summer conditions. An earlier analysis for the Travel Plan that looked
only at areas within National Forest boundaries and weighted Forest roads according to
estimated use levels (primary roads equal 100 percent of length; lightly used local roads equal
25 percent of length) came up with habitat effectiveness values in the range of 65 percent to 88
percent. Actual habitat effectiveness of summer range most often used by elk probably falls
somewhere between the results of these two analysis approaches.
The above analyses consider the suitability of elk summer habitat in general, but they do not
zero in on the quality and distribution of specific habitat components that elk need regular
access to. Table 107 does not calculate the habitat effectiveness of key areas (esp. wet
meadows, mesic grasslands and riparian sites) where the 70 percent recommendation would
apply. Some of these issues are addressed in the later section, “Local Effects in Key Areas”,
which looks at how individual motorized routes effect habitat sites of particular importance to
elk and other big game animals.

Effects of Alternative 1 (Existing Condition)
Alternative 1 maintains the status quo. Under this scenario, all herd units exceed the
recommended 50 percent habitat effectiveness for overall summer range. Habitat effectiveness
values for five of the herd units are in the 54 to 58 percent range; one unit (Black MountainBrooklyn Bridge) is at 65 percent. Habitat effectiveness of this order suggests that open road
density is not high enough to regularly prevent elk on summer range from foraging successfully
and thus building fat reserves for the upcoming winter. In this case, problems with roads and
motor trails are not a function of overall road density, which is within acceptable limits, but with
WILDLIFE - 418

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

site-specific intrusion of vehicles into habitats of particular importance to elk, typically riparian
areas, wet meadows and other productive sites that focus elk activity. Some of these areas are
discussed in “Local Effects in Key Areas” toward the end of this report.
In the short run, all six herd units would remain in compliance with Forest Plan big game
standard 3 (with crown closure greater than or equal to 50 percent and hiding cover thus
greater than or equal to 35 percent). But within the next 5 to 10 years, all herd units will
probably fall below 35 percent cover due to the loss of standing trees killed by the mountain
pine beetles.

Effects of Alternative 2
Alternative 2 would retain the same overall level of habitat effectiveness as Alternative 1 for the
Travel Plan Area as a whole (56 percent), but shifts would occur within some herd units. Habitat
effectiveness would improve in two units (Little Prickly Pear–Ophir and Greenhorn), decline in
one unit (Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot) and hold steady in three units (Jericho, Quartz, Black
Mtn–Brooklyn Bridge) [see Local Effects in Key Areas for a discussion of what the changes mean
for elk in specific areas]. One area where habitat effectiveness would erode is the Baldy Ridge–
upper Spotted Dog region near the south end of the Plan Area. This area holds elk through the
summer and into the fall. Along the Continental Divide, habitat effectiveness would improve
south of Jericho Mountain and in several sites between Greenhorn Mountain and MacDonald
Pass north of Highway 12. Summer range hiding cover would remain the same as in alternative
1.

Effects of Alternative 3
Alternative 3 would see more of an upswing in habitat effectiveness, to 58 percent overall.
There would be notable improvement (4 to 5 percent) in the Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot and
Greenhorn EHUs and slight improvement (one percent) in the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU. The
Jericho, Quartz and Black Mountain–Brooklyn Bridge EHUs would remain unchanged. All EHUs
would continue to achieve the recommended 50 percent habitat effectiveness level. Summer
range hiding cover would remain the same as in alternative 1.

Effects of Alternative 4
Alternative 4 would provide habitat effectiveness identical to alternative 3 in five herd units. It
would, however, provide only a one percent increase over current conditions in the Spotted
Dog–Little Blackfoot EHU (as opposed to four percent in alternative 3), a function of proposed
vehicle access to elk summer range (1) in upper Ontario and Bison Creeks and (2) along upper
Spotted Creek and adjacent Baldy Ridge. Both areas encompass drainage-head locales with
productive summer habitat that holds elk from late spring through mid-fall. All EHUs would
continue to achieve the recommended 50 percent habitat effectiveness level. Summer range
hiding cover would remain the same as in alternative 1.

Effects of Alternative 5
Alternative 5 would produce the highest habitat effectiveness of any action alternative (60
percent overall). Four EHUs would increase in non-motorized summer range, one of them
(Greenhorn Mountain) by seven percent, the others by two to three percent. Two units (Black
Mountain–Brooklyn Bridge and Quartz) would remain essentially unchanged. All EHUs would
continue to achieve the recommended 50 percent habitat effectiveness level. Summer range
hiding cover (HFP big game standard 3) would remain the same as in alternative 1.

Hiding cover and open road density are the measures of elk vulnerability/security identified in

As can be seen in Table 108, three herd units (Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot, Jericho and Black
Mountain-Brooklyn Bridge) comply with standard 4a under all five alternatives. Substantial
portions of these herd units are taken up by the three Inventoried Roadless Areas located south
of Highway 12, Electric Peak, Jericho Mountain and Lazyman Gulch. Two of the remaining herd
units (Quartz and Greenhorn) show open road densities (in several alternatives) that are similar
to those in the three units that meet the standard; but hiding cover is insufficient to produce
compliance, even when road densities drop in alternative 5. The final herd unit (Little Prickly
Pear-Ophir) does not comply with the standard under alternatives 1, 2, 3 and 4, but does so
under lower road density in alternative 5.
The pattern under standard 4a is that, in spite of shifts in open road density between
alternatives, herd units that currently comply with the standard tend to remain in compliance
and those that do not comply with the standard tend to remain out of compliance. The only
exception is the rise to compliance of the Little Prickly Pear-Ophir EHU under alternative 5, due
to the closure of 52 miles of Forest roads combined with ample hiding cover (60 percent).
On the other hand, in the Greenhorn EHU, road closures of 47 miles in alternative 5 are
insufficient to bring the herd unit into compliance with standard 4a because of hiding cover that
remains at 41 percent. The road density/hiding cover index masks this improvement in fall elk
security, simply indicating that the herd unit remains out of compliance. Likewise, the Spotted
Dog–Little Blackfoot EHU is simply credited with remaining in compliance with the standard, in
spite of 40 miles of road closures in alternative 5. The Black Mountain–Brooklyn Bridge EHU is
also credited with remaining in compliance, although it closes no roads at all. This herd unit is

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

clearly different from the previous two in terms of elk security improvement, but the current
Forest Plan standard recognizes no difference between them. In sum, the standard does not
accurately indicate to what degree the changes in road density improve or degrade the habitat
situation for elk.

Proposed Elk Security Area Standard
The amended Forest Plan standard for gauging the vulnerability of elk to hunting mortality is
based on how much of a given management unit (typically, an elk herd unit) is taken up by elk
security areas. The rationale for using this measure has been discussed in some detail in the
“Affected Environment” section and in the preceding section, “Common Effects of Travel
Management”. In order to comply with the new standard, herd units with more than 50
percent elk security are allowed to lower percent security only if they remain above 50 percent;
those with less than 50 percent security are allowed no further decrease [see the previous
section on “Common Effects of Travel Management” for the exact wording].
Table 109 displays acreage of full-sized elk security areas (greater than or equal to 1,000 acres)
and the percentages of each herd unit that they occupy under different project alternatives.

Hillis et al. have recommended that at least 30 percent of the fall range in each analysis area,
such as a herd unit or larger management area, be maintained as elk security areas if elk
vulnerability is to be effectively tempered during the hunting season. The new HFP elk security
amendment sets the objective for the Divide landscape at 50 percent. This follows from the
objective already in place for the adjacent Blackfoot landscape just to the north. While that
objective is realistically attainable in most of the herd units in that landscape (much of which is
in or near the Scapegoat Wilderness Area), it is highly unlikely to be attainable in all but one or
two herd units in the Divide landscape and then, only with draconian road closures detrimental
to the most basic kind of Forest access. Nonetheless, we have advanced that as the ideal
security area percentage, attainable or not.

Effects of Alternative 1 (Existing Condition)
Alternative 1 is the no-action scenario and it would retain the existing condition. As to the
current big game security index (HFP standard 4a), only three of the six Divide elk herd units
comply with the standard (Table 108). As to the amended security area standard, only one of
the six EHUs (Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot) reaches the 30 percent security level recommended
by Hillis et al. (1991) and none approach the 50 percent level proposed by the amended
standard. One herd unit, the Quartz EHU, supports no full-sized security areas at all, only two
intermittent refuge areas. All herd units, however, meet the amended standard for the time
being because none are declining in percent security.
Currently, MFWP population objectives for elk are being met in three of the hunting districts
that cover the Divide landscape (HD 215, HD 335, HD 343). In the 4th district (HD 293), elk
objectives are being met in the portion of the district associated with the Divide landscape,
while problems in the rest of the district are related to high rates of predation rather than
deficiency in security habitat [see the previous discussion of “Hunting Districts”].

WILDLIFE - 422

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Figure 34 - Elk security and intermittent refuge areas under Alternative 1.

It should be noted that in all EHUs, elk have been able to find refuge on private land beyond the
Helena NF boundary where public hunting is not allowed or to which hunting access is very
difficult because of land ownership patterns. These opportunities are more limited in some
EHUs than others. While private sanctuaries do not qualify as “security areas” under the Hillis
criteria, they do in effect serve much the same purpose. And, as a result, elk are usually more
secure in these EHUs than the security area percentages in Table 110 suggest. Elk compensate

WILDLIFE - 423

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

for the shortage of National Forest security by moving to private-land security zones as the
hunting season progresses.

Effects of Alternative 2
Alternative 2 would produce the same pattern of compliance with Forest Plan big game
standard 4a as alternative 1: three elk herd units would comply, three would not. Two of the
herd units that currently do not comply with the standard would see declines in open road
density, but their compliance status would not change.

Figure 35 - Elk security and intermittent refuge areas under Alternative 2.

WILDLIFE - 424

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Applying the amended elk security area standard, overall security within Helena NF boundaries
would improve north of U.S. Highway 12 (from 19 percent to 21 percent) but decline south of it
(from 19 percent to 18 percent). The decline in the southern sector (a loss of 235 security acres)
would result from a newly sanctioned motor trail in upper Ontario Creek in the Spottted Dog–
Little Blackfoot EHU (Table 109). Nearly 1,750 acres would also be subtracted from intermittent
refuge areas in this herd unit as a result of newly opened roads and motor trails (Table 110;
Figure 35). North of Highway 12, the large security area around Black Mountain (of the north)
would expand with the closure of the Black Mountain Road and the effective closure of the
pioneered motor trail off its west end. The security area around Greenhorn Mountain would
expand as well, increasing from 1,494 to 2,134 acres with the closure of an unauthorized motor
trail and its access road.
The spatial pattern of security and refuge areas in alternative 2 can be seen in Figure 35 above.
Overall percent security in the Divide landscape would remain at 19 percent under alternative 2.

Effects of Alternative 3
Alternative 3 would produce the same pattern of Forest Plan compliance with the current big
game security index (HFP standard 4a) as alternatives 1 and 2: three elk herd units (Spotted
Dog-Little blackfoot, Jericho and Black Mountain-Brooklyn Bridge) would continue to comply
with the standard, the other three would not (Table 108).
Applying the amended security area standard, alternative 3 would provide notably more
security than alternatives 1 and 2, expanding security areas from the current 43,453 acres (19
percent of the landscape) to 55,727 acres (24 percent of the landscape). South of Highway 12,
the Black Mountain-Brooklyn Bridge and Quartz EHUs, which are in large part unaffected by the
Travel Plan, would remain unchanged. Security in the Jericho EHU, however, would rise from 12
percent to 16 percent and in the Spotted Dog–Little Blackfoot EHU it would jump from 29
percent to 39 percent of the herd unit. These changes follow from (1) closure of an OHV route
south of Jericho Mountain and (2) a number of road and motor trail closures on Baldy Ridge and
in the upper Spotted Dog Creek drainage, allowing the big security area centered on the Electric
Peak Roadless Area to expand northward [Figure 36, below]. This latter expansion would be
particularly effective since it is contiguous with security habitat on the adjacent BeaverheadDeerlodge NF, as well as with the Roadless Area. As in all action alternatives, security would
remain unchanged in the Black Mountain–Brooklyn Bridge and Quartz EHUs.
North of Highway 12, security in the Little Prickly Pear–Ophir EHU would expand slightly (from
25 percent to 26 percent); but in the Greenhorn EHU, it would jump from 10 percent to 23
percent of the unit as a result of multiple motor trail closures in lower Sweeney Creek and an
OHV route atop the Continental Divide south of Priest Pass [see Figure 36].
As under current conditions, MFWP objectives for elk populations would continue to be met in
three of the four hunting districts that cover Divide elk herd units (HD 215, HD 335, HD 343).
MFWP elk population objectives are also being met in the southern half of HD 293, which covers
this herd unit. The northern half of HD 293 in the Big Blackfoot Valley (Lincoln Ranger District) is
below population objectives because of predation problems unrelated to security on the
National Forest [see previous discussion of “Hunting Districts”].

Under the amended elk security area standard, security would rise from the current 19 percent
to 27 percent of the Divide landscape, from 43,543 acres to 62,007 acres. These security areas
are mapped in Figure 38.
Alternative 5 would develop the designated motor trail system more than other alternatives
[Table 98]. While this would prove problematic for summer habitat effectiveness in some areas,
it would not erode fall elk security since the trails would be closed to motorized use during the
big game hunting season (September 1 to December 1). New increments in elk security and
refuge areas (compared to alternatives 3 and 4) would occur both north and south of Highway
12. North of the highway, these include increased security in Sweeney Creek, Ophir Creek, the
upper forks of Little Prickly Pear Creek and around Greenhorn Mountain. South of the highway,
the principal gain would come from the transformation of an ittermittent refuge area (651
acres in alternative 3) in the Negro Mountain-Treasure Mountain area into a larger security area
(2,247 acres in alternative 5) [Figure 36 and Figure 38].
Under alternative 5, three herd units (Little Prickly Pear-Ophir, Greenhorn and Spotted DogLittle Blackfoot) are near or above 30 percent security. The Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot herd
unit, with 44 percent of its area in elk security areas, would be the only unit that approaches the
ultimate goal of 50 percent. Since five herd units would see increases in elk security, some of
them substantial and the 6th unit would retain current security levels [Table 109 and Table 110],
all would meet the amended standard for elk security. Current levels of security have proven
compatibile with MFWP population objectives for elk in local hunting districts and the increment
in security proposed in alternative 5 would substantially improve the prospects of continuing to
achieve those objectives.

Application of the Security Area Standard
As can be seen in Table 109 and Table 110 and in the security area maps (Figure 34 through
Figure 38), elk security areas provide a means of gauging elk vulnerability/ security that is
sensitive to changes in open road configuration. This allows a more fine-tuned and realistic
assessment as to potential impacts of travel management proposals in different herd units than
the 1986 Forest Plan standard (the hiding cover/ road density index). The difference between
the two methods results largely from eliminating hiding cover as a primary determinant of elk
security and focusing on the size and distribution of large habitat blocks to which hunter access
is limited. This is particularly appropriate in this case, as Divide Travel Plan alternatives deal
with changes in open road patterns and have no impact on Forest Plan hiding cover. Forest
cover is recognized as an important component of security, but it is not the make-or-break
factor that it has become under the current standard (the road density/hiding cover index).
Compliance with the amended elk security standard hinges on whether or not security area
acreage within a given elk herd unit is increasing, decreasing, or holding steady, regardless of
what the percent security happens to be. While the the ideal situation would be to have 50
percent of each elk herd unit in security areas of 1,000 acres or more, the fact that a given herd
unit is below the 50 percent level does not prevent it from complying with the standard.
The rationale is that current security levels are allowing MFWP population objectives for elk to
be met in local hunting districts or in those portions of the hunting district subject to influence
by Divide herd units. That being the case, the four action alternatives, all of which would
improve upon the overall security level, should do likewise. Figure 27 (in the “Affected
Environment” section) provides a map of the six Divide elk herd units and shows their

WILDLIFE - 429

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

relationship to the four hunting districts that encompass the landscape. Table 92 and Table 93
(also in the “Affected Environment” section) display the status of the four hunting districts with
regard MFWP elk population objectives over the past 15 years.
Table 109 indicates the degree to which security acres and percentages in each herd unit
increase or decrease, or whether they remain steady, under different alternatives. Herd units
that maintain or increase security, regardless of what the percent security is, may be in
compliance with the amended elk security standard. A decrease in security could be an
indication of non-compliance. As can be seen in Table 109, security area acreages in two herd
units (Quartz Creek and Black Mountain-Brooklyn Bridge) neither decrease nor increase under
any alternative (or do so to a trivial degree). So these EHUs initially comply with the standard,
even though the Quartz Creek unit supports no bona fide security areas. This herd unit does
support intermittent security areas [Table 110] and in fact shows an increase in this acreage
under alternative 5; but this does not affect its standing with regard to the standard. Table 109
shows that security area acreages in the remaining four herd units consistently increase over
current conditions under all action alternatives, with one exception. The exception is a slight
decrease in the Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot EHU under alternative 2. This unit thus needs to be
flagged to see if it is in fact out of compliance with the standard.

Winter Range
The Helena Forest Plan measures impacts on elk winter range in terms of (1) the acreage and
dispersion of thermal cover and (2) the location of motorized routes. Thermal cover does not
figure into the current analysis: None of the Travel Plan alternatives would affect it. But,
changes in the classification of snowmobile routes and open roads that can be driven during
winter are of interest. The Forest Plan allows for designated routes through winter range on
Helena NF lands in order to facilitate land management, allow access to private land, or to
provide routes to public recreation opportunities (most often, snowmobiling) in other areas
(HFP, p. II/17-18). The greater the miles of roads, motor trails and snowmobile routes accessible
to vehicles on winter range the greater the potential for disturbance and displacement of elk.
In general, Forest Plan winter range, as mapped during development of the Forest Plan in the
1980s, is quite restrictive, focusing on areas consistently used by most elk in most winters. In
the Divide landscape, relatively little of that winter range falls on Helena NF land so as to be
affected by the Forest road system. A more expansive mapping of winter range was developed
for the Helena NF Oil and Gas Leasing EIS in 1995 (USFS, USFWS 1995). The map was based on
assessments by MFWP and Helena NF biologists as to what sites big game animals might occupy
under a wider variety of winter conditions than contemplated by the Forest Plan. As with Forest
Plan winter range, Oil and Gas winter range is mapped only for areas within Helena NF
boundaries.
More recently, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks (MFWP) [with assistance from the Rocky
Mountain Elk Foundation (RMEF)] has constructed a broadscale (Statewide) planning map of elk
seasonal ranges that has adopted an even more expansive version of potential winter range,
one that incorporates considerably more land on the Helena NF than does the Oil and Gas EIS
map. The “MFWP map” covers both Helena NF and private land and its winter ranges extend
well out into the Helena and Little Blackfoot valleys. The initial version of the map came out in
1999 and a second version (delineating even more winter range) in 2004. A third version,
developed by MFWP between 2008 and 2010, has adopted a new definition of winter range
(“areas where populations....tend to concentrate during the winter season, commonly

WILDLIFE - 430

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

December through April”), eliminated some of the winter range mapped by the previous two
editions and omitted mapping of “crucial winter range”. As with previous versions, the new
maps are “appropriate for general planning purposes or broad landscape review…” The data are
“not intended for planning and/or review of site-specific activities” (MFWP 2011). Because of
these broadscale objectives, winter range boundaries are drawn along section lines rather than
along local topographic or vegetative features and are therefore less precise.
One of the problems with the MFWP map for Forest Plan purposes has been the inclusion of
broad areas into which small numbers of elk occasionally range during mild winters or through
which they pass in late April on their way to summer range. While these sites have been used
by elk in this way over the past 30 years, they do not represent areas where populations “tend
to concentrate during the winter”. The inclusion of these areas of extended winter range is
useful in that it highlights areas where segments of the elk population may be vulnerable to
human interference under mild winter conditions and as they move across transitional range
toward summer range late in the season. But it does not contribute to an accurate delineation
of true winter range, which is the area addressed by HFP standards.
In determining what constitutes elk winter range for purposes of applying HFP standards and
guidelines, I have proceeded as follows:
On a GIS map of the Divide landscape showing both the Helena NF Oil and Gas EIS winter range
(1995) and MFWP extended winter range (2010), I plotted the location of several thousand
“winter” elk locations (December 1 to April 30). Locations were derived both from tracking of
radio collared elk (1983 to 1987) and from annual MFWP aerial winter range surveys (2000 to
2010). I then tallied elk locations within Helena NF boundaries for (1) the Helena NF Oil and Gas
winter range and (2) those found only on MFWP extended winter range beyond the Oil and Gas
range. I confined the comparison to Helena NF lands, since this is the area that would be
affected by Travel Plan alternatives.
Results were as follows:
Total winter elk locations in the sample: 7,856
•
Locations within Helena NF administrative boundaries: 1,149
•
Helena NF locations on Oil and Gas EIS winter range: 1,102 (95.9 percent of NF
locations)
•
Helena NF locations only on MFWP extended winter range: 32 (2.8 percent of NF
locations)
•
Helena NF locations not on winter range: 15 (1.3 percent of NF locations)
Because Helena NF Oil and Gas EIS winter range accounts for nearly 96 percent of the winter elk
locations/ observations and includes all of the sites where elk have been observed to
concentrate for most of the winter, I have concluded that this delineation is appropriate for
assessing potential effects of the Divide Travel Plan on the National Forest. I have, however,
eliminated two areas previously designated as winter range in the Oil and Gas EIS that have
since been determined not to be used by elk in winter: these habitat blocks are located
immediately south of Elliston and in the upper Spotted Dog drainage. Elk use these areas as
transitional and summer range, but not as winter range.
•

Even with the Oil and Gas delineation, a few problem areas remain with regard to Forest Plan
standards. These involve snowmobile routes that have been in place for several decades and
that, until 1995, were not considered to be on big game winter range. The greatly expanded

WILDLIFE - 431

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

delineation of winter range in the Oil and Gas EIS brought portions of these trail systems into
the area covered by HFP standard 4c. This standard states that “all winter range areas will be
closed to vehicles between December 1 and May 15,” with the exception of access routes to
“other lands” (HFP, p. II/18).
For the most part, the Helena NF has allowed snowmobiles to continue using these traditional
trail networks, the assumption being that as long as the snow base in any given area remains
solid enough to support recreational snowmobiling, it will not be suitable for use by grazers,
notably elk. Once the snow deteriorates to the point that elk are able to move through it
without difficulty and get down to ground forage, it will no longer be suitable for snowmobiles.
So, there should be little overlap and minimal conflict between these uses.
Field observation over several decades validates the assumptions as to the temporal separation
of elk and snowmobiles on winter range, with a few exceptions. These have occurred in areas
where newer model snowmobiles, able to deal with shallow, patchy snow, have been used to
access antler hunting grounds in April. These incursions onto occupied winter/transitional
ranges involve extensive off-trail riding and most of the areas where these problems have arisen
are covered by a variety of snowmobile area closures proposed in different alternatives.
