Table 111 tallies acreages of areas closed to snowmobiles under the five Travel Plan
alternatives. Cross-country snowmobiling is not permitted in these areas and the only interior
access is by occasional, longstanding access routes, such as the Rimini and Sweeney Creek/Priest
Pass Roads. Rationale for excluding snowmobiles include minimizing disturbance of big game
animals on winter and spring ranges and deterring the use of snowmobiles for hunting. In
addition, some closures help minimize disturbance of lynx, protect potential wolverine denning
habitat and alleviate conflicts between motorized and non-motorized recreation (primarily
cross-country skiing and snowshoeing).
Some of the additional closures in action alternatives are in new areas separated from the three
existing closure blocks; others represent expansions of those areas. The three consolidated
blocks currently closed to snowmobiles are Baldy Ridge/Electric Peak Roadless Area, Lazyman
WILDLIFE - 432

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Gulch Roadless Area and the MacDonald Pass cross-country ski trail complex. Additional
closures in alternative 2 expand the number of separate closure blocks to six. Consolidation of
some of these blocks in alternatives 3 and 4, reduces the number to five. Alternative 5 reduces
the closure pattern to three large aggregations: Electric Peak/ Bison Creek at the south end of
the Plan Area; Black Mountain/Deadman Creek at the north end; and Lazyman/Jericho/Sweeney
Creek west and southwest of Helena [refer to alternative maps in the FEIS].

Effects of Alternative 1 (Existing Condition)
Of the four current snowmobile area closures (Baldy Ridge, Electric Peak Roadless, Lazyman
Roadless and MacDonald Pass), only the Lazyman Roadless Area block incorporates Helena NF
(Oil and Gas EIS) elk winter range. This latter closure discourages snowmobile-based antler
hunting on late winter and transitional ranges and reduces potential harassment of elk
(particularly bulls) in these areas. In addition, it compliments winter range area closures
recently established in the adjacent Clancy-Unionville Travel Plan area to the south and east.
Snowmobile area closures on big game winter range total about 10,950 acres.
Under alternative 1, 39 miles of regularly-used snowmobile routes impinge on Helena NF winter
range, most of them in the upper reaches of the range where snow conditions are most
conducive to snowmobile use. Few elk and deer venture into these areas in most winters and
no conflicts have been reported on the trail system. Almost 75 percent of winter range
snowmobile routes occur on the east side of the Continental Divide north of U.S. Highway 12,
that is, in the Sweeney Creek, Austin Creek, Greenhorn Creek and Skelly Gulch drainages. Other
areas with trails are along the western Forest boundary in the Threemile-Ophir–Snowshoe Creek
area and south of Highway 12 in Hahn Creek and Mike Renig Gulch. Of the existing snowmobile
routes, 16 miles are specifically designated as snowmobile trails, 20 miles are on roads open
year-round to all vehicles able to navigate them and four miles are on roads technically closed to
all vehicles but on which the Helena NF has allowed snowmobile use for several decades. Some
of these winter ranges are also traversed by roads leading to areas where resource
management, public recreation, or private land require access: vehicle use is thus permitted
under Forest Plan big game standard 4c (HFP, p. II/18).

Effects of Alternative 2
Alternative 2 would appreciably expand snowmobile area closures on winter range. Most
significant is the 6,065 acre area immediately northeast of Sweeney Creek, a key wintering area
for elk, moose and deer [Figure 56]. This area is now open to all vehicles in winter and while it
normally sees little snowmobile use, it is often accessible to ATVs and four-wheel-drive vehicles
because of its low elevation and lesser snow accumulation [Figure 56, Figure 57]. Other new
closures include the fringe of elk winter range along the Helena NF border in the Threemile,
Ophir and Snowshoe Creek drainages; a patch of winter range in upper Mike Renig Gulch and
Hahn Creek; and an extension of the Black Mountain–Mount Helena closure westward across
the Tenmile drainage and northward into Walker Creek. New snowmobile closures would put
an additional 14,315 acres of Helena NF elk winter range off-limits to snowmobiles compared to
current conditions.
Alternative 2 would reduce snowmobile trails on elk winter range from about 40 miles to 24
miles. Most of the reduction would come from closing the Sweeney Creek–Blue Cloud Creek
area, including the trail system, to all vehicles between October 14 and May 16. The closure is
intended to eliminate motorized disturbance on key big game winter range and on late fall and
early spring transitional range, as well as during the hunting season. Of the remaining 24 miles

WILDLIFE - 433

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

of winter range snowmobile routes, nine miles would be specifically designated for
snowmobiles and 15 miles would involve roads open to all vehicles, including snowmobiles
(although, with few exceptions, only snowmobiles are able to negotiate these routes in winter).
Under alternative 2, the current policy of tolerating snowmobiles on certain roads that are
technically closed to them would cease. Alternative 2 would leave open to all vehicles the
current array of “crossing routes” that provide winter access to other parts of the Forest.

Effects of Alternative 3
Alternative 3 would close an additional 3,240 acres to cross-country snowmobile use (compared
to alternative 2) by consolidating closures in the Hahn Creek, Tenmile Creek and Lazyman
Roadless blocks. The new closure would connect areas across the Continental Divide. With
regard to snowmobile closures on winter range, alternatives 2 and 3 are nearly identical.
Alternative 3 is the same as alternative 2 in terms of snowmobile routes on winter range. That
is, nine miles of designated snowmobile trails; 15 miles of roads open to all vehicles able to
negotiate them (in most cases, only snowmobiles); and no sanctioning of snowmobile use on
road systems closed to all vehicles year-round. As with alternative 2, the route and area closure
in the Sweeney Creek–Blue Cloud Creek area represents the most significant removal of
motorized disturbance from actively-used winter range. Other trails remaining open are on
higher elevation ”winter range” in areas not used by big game animals until after snowmobile
use has ceased. “Crossing routes” that allow motor vehicles to pass through winter range to
access other parts of the Forest would be the same as in alternatives 1 and 2.

Effects of Alternative 4
Alternative 4 is identical to alternative 3 in terms of (1) Forest roads and trails open to
snowmobiles on winter range (24 miles) and (2) “crossing roads” open to wheeled vehicles and
snowmobiles on winter range. It also follows alternative 3 in the the acreage of snowmobile
closures on elk winter range.

Effects of Alternative 5
Alternative 5 would consolidate and increase the size of snowmobile area closures considerably
more than other action alternatives. Closure acres would total 71,305 acres, nearly 18,000 acres
more than alternatives 3 and 4. Alternative 5 would (1) create a new closure area in the Black
Mountain/Deadman Creek region at the northern tip of the Travel Plan Area (adjacent to the
Nevada Mountain Roadless Area), (2) merge separate closures (as proposed in alternatives 2, 3
and 4) west and southwest of Helena into one large block and (3) add much of Bison Creek and
part of upper Ontario Creek to the Electric Peak Roadless Area closure. This latter closure would
compliment similar snowmobile restrictions on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge NF immediately to
the south.
Under alternative 5, big game winter ranges would carry the fewest designated snowmobile
routes of any alternative, just over 11 miles. This would be in addition to the standard “crossing
routes” used by wheeled vehicles throughout the winter. These are common to all alternatives
and include sections of the Rimini Road and U.S. Highway 12. Other routes, such as the
Sweeney Creek/Priest Pass Road and the Mullan Pass Road may also be driveable by wheeled
vehicles early in most winters.
Alternative 5 would maintain active snowmobile routes at more-or-less the same level as other
alternatives: 403 miles, which is within the range of the other four alternatives (394 to 418
miles) [Table 99]. This mileage remains relatively constant in spite of the decline in snowmobile

WILDLIFE - 434

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

routes on big game winter range, as these losses are balanced by an increase in designated
routes elsewhere. Overall, this shift is a benefit to elk on winter range. Alternative 5 is the only
alternative that eliminates the category “regularly-used snowmobile routes that the Travel Plan
identifies as ‘closed to motorized use yearlong’ ” [Table 99]. In alternative 5, all snowmobile
routes are specified as “designated snowmobile routes” or as routes on which snowmobile use
is “allowed”. This eliminates the ambiguity of snowmobiles being allowed to use routes that are
technically closed to them (by the Travel Plan) because they pass through areas in which offroute use is allowed.

Elk: Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the detailed matrix in the EIS, which identifies
past, present and reasonably foreseeable actions and circumstances that may affect elk and elk
habitat. The scope of the analysis includes the Divide landscape (Helena NF land with nonForest inholdings), adjacent National Forest lands (the Lincoln Ranger District of the Helena NF
and the Jefferson Ranger District of the Beaverhead-Deerlodge NF) and neighboring non-Forest
lands (private, State, County, municipal and BLM). This summary is common to all alternatives.

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Recent and continuing activities on the Helena NF that have improved prospects for big game
species include: Implementation of the Statewide OHV Plan (USFS, USFWS 2001), which
prohibits riding off established motor routes; a variety of trail relocation projects that have
removed trails from productive riparian areas to upslope locations; mine reclamation projects
that have improved the functioning of riparian habitats likely to attract these animals; grazing
allotment revisions that have generally reduced cattle numbers and improved habitat condition;
road and motor trail closures associated with timber harvest projects (Clancy-Unionville, Sound
Wood, Mullan Pass, Lava Mountain, Treasure Mountain); and ongoing noxious weed
treatments.

Other activities have locally displaced elk, reduced the effectiveness of elk habitat, or have had a
mixed effect. These include: timber harvest, mostly in the 1970s and 1980s, that has created an
abundance of large clearcuts (Bison Creek, Mike Renig-Hahn Creek, Slate Creek, Lump Gulch,
Ophir Creek-Cave Gulch, Deadman); numerous road permits allowing access across Helena NF
land to private holdings; retention of private recreational residences on Helena NF land
(MacDonald Pass, Tenmile Creek); small mining operations (under the 1872 Mining Act);
construction and maintenance of communications sites and power lines; Forest road
improvement projects that have widened road corridors; and widespread fencing associated
with grazing allotments that may complicate movement.
The Forest has also undertaken several vegetation projects unlikely to affect elk because they
are highly localized or situated close to human development. These include hazard tree removal
in developed recreation sites, at administrative sites and along road corridors. The recent
removal of beetle-killed trees in the MacDonald Pass Ski Trail recreation area falls into this
category, as do recently completed tree removal projects in Kading, Park Lake, Cromwell Dixon
and Moose Creek campgrounds.
Other recent vegetation projects have been large enough to have more impact. The ongoing
Forestwide Roadside Hazard Tree Removal Project, which is removing beetle-killed lodgepole
and ponderosa pine from roadside corridors ranging in width from a few feet to as much as 150
feet (each side of the road). Often, these corridors have little effect because they are roadside
WILDLIFE - 435

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

environments seldom used by elk. In other cases, where they are situated in strategic locations,
primarily where elk have traditionally moved along or crossed the road corridors, the more open
habitat structure may be altering elk movement patterns and in some cases, putting them more
at risk from human generated mortality.
The just-completed Clancy-Unionville Project south of Helena has also opened up extensive
areas formerly occupied by closed-canopy forest. Much of the original treatment was proposed
as an array of partial cuts designed to create open-canopied stands more resistent to standreplacing fire. But with the mountain pine beetle outbreak creating entire stands of dead trees,
many of these prescriptions were necessarily changed to regeneration cuts, clearcuts with
reserve trees, seed-tree cuts and widely spaced thinning. This has improved foraging
opportunity for elk but diminished forest cover.
The ongoing Red Mountain Flume-Chesman Reservoir Project is removing dead trees (mostly
lodgepole pine) from 490 acres along the flume corridor and around the reservoir. While
relatively localized and contiguous, these new openings change areas that elk have used
primarily for concealment, escape and resting to those used mostly for foraging.
It should be noted that all of the projects that have removed or are removing dead trees are
merely accellerating the rate of cover loss that would have occurred naturally within another
five to 10 years as dead trees fall. The difference in the end is that treated areas are
characterized by relatively “clean” ground-level environments dominated by grasses, forbs,
shrubs and regenerating conifers; untreated sites are cluttered with an abundance of coarse
woody debris with a matrix of ground vegetation and young conifers dispersed irregularly
throughout. Both of these habitat configurations are useful wildlife environments, although
species mix and use patterns vary.

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Private land development (primarily rural home building) is continuing to create sites that create
problems for animals attempting to move through and occupy the landscape. Other endeavors
with similar effects include mining operations (Drumlummon mine, Bald Butte mine clean-up),
ATV-trail bike riding areas, private timber harvest, clearing vegetative cover from riparian sites
and new and upgraded roads (particularly improvements to the Marysville road).

Recent acquisition by the State of Montana of 27,000 acres of private land centered in the
Spotted Dog Creek drainage immediately west of the Helena NF boundary has implications for
elk security. These holdings were previously off-limits to most public hunting and have, in
recent years, served as a refuge for elk during the hunting season. As of 2010, these lands have
been open to public hunting and to other uses throughout the rest of the year, mostly hiking,
wildlife watching, mountain biking and horseback riding. Motorized access is limited. Other
restrictions will be designed to protect elk on winter range, since these formerly private lands
have served as primary winter habitat for elk for several decades. Public use of these lands may
alter elk movement and use patterns on State, private and adjacent Helena NF lands in the near
future, although limited motorized access is likely to ameliorate elk vulnerability to hunting.

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Reasonably foreseeable activities on Helena NF land that may affect elk to one degree or
another include improvement of the Rimini Road, revision of several grazing allotments
(MacDonald Pass, Austin, Empire and several others) and large vegetation manipulation projects

WILDLIFE - 436

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

(Telegraph salvage and thinning; Tenmile South Helena Vegetation Project). The Telegraph and
Tenmile South Helena Projects are extensive vegetation manipulation projects focused on
removing beetle killed trees in large blocks through a combination of cutting and prescribed
burning. Both would alter habitat opportunity for elk by transforming sites potentially
dominated by stacked, coarse woody debris to uncluttered sites with more continuous ground
vegetation and regeneration. Proposed salvage would accellerate the loss of current
hiding/screening cover by at least five years.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Future activity on non-Forest land that may affect elk and other big game species includes:
settlement and other development of private lands (including road building); continued timber
harvest and removal of beetle-killed dead trees; continued mining operations that usurp habitat
and create disturbance zones (notably, the Montana Tunnels mine expansion); continued ATV
and other motorized activity.

Elk: Summary and Conclusions
No alternative would create circumstances that would measurably shift elk population size or
population structure. The four action alternatives, however, would incrementally alter big game
security and habitat effectiveness in local areas, thus altering elk habitat use patterns and
hunter opportunity.

Elk Summer Range Habitat Effectiveness

Summer range hiding cover, the Forest Plan measure of summer habitat quality, would remain
the same in all alternatives. Habitat effectiveness, however, as a function of open road density,
would vary.

Alternative 1 would retain summer habitat effectiveness (HE) at 56 percent of the Divide
landscape as a whole. Habitat effectiveness would remain above the recommended 50 percent
level in all six elk herd units (EHUs).
Under Alternative 2, habitat effectiveness would increase in two EHUs, decrease in one and
remain steady in three. Habitat effectiveness in the landscape as a whole would remain at 56
percent.
With Alternative 3, habitat effectiveness would increase in three EHUs and remain steady in the
other three. Landscape-wide habitat effectiveness would increase to 58 percent
Habitat effectiveness under Alternative 4 would be identical to that of Alternative 3 in five of the
six EHUs. In one unit, however, (the Spotted Dog – Little Blackfoot EHU) habitat effectiveness
would be three percent lower than in alternative 3 because of routes in upper Spotted Dog
Creek, on Baldy Ridge and in upper Ontario Creek that would be open to wheeled vehicles in
summer. Overall, habitat effectiveness would be 58 percent.
Under Alternative 5, habiatat effectiveness would increase in four herd units and remain
unchanged in the two units that are mostly outside the influence of the Travel Plan Area (Quartz
Creek and Black Mountain-Brooklyn Bridge). Overall habitat effectiveness would be 60 percent.
In sum: Habitat effectiveness would be similar in all five alternatives and the overall availability
of summer habitat would not be a limiting factor for elk under any alternative.

WILDLIFE - 437

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Elk Hunting Season Security

Under Alternative 1, elk security areas (greather than or equal to 1,000 acres) would continue to
occupy 19 percent of elk herd units (EHUs) within Helena NF administrative boundaries across
the Divide landscape as a whole. Intermittent refuge areas would occupy three percent. Only
two EHUs would exceed 20 percent security. If this alternative is chosen, these percentages
would become the baseline security levels that would need to be maintained or improved
within each herd unit. These security levels are, for the time being, allowing MFWP to meet elk
population goals in local hunting districts or in those portions of the districts influenced by
Divide landscape elk herd units.
Under Alternative 2 , elk security areas would occupy 19 percent of the Divide landscape, the
same as alternative 1. Security area configuration would be redistributed, however. Security
would rise in two EHUs, decrease in one and remain steady in three. As with alternative 1, only
two EHU would exceed 20 percent security. If this alternative is chosen, these percentages
would become the baseline security levels that would need to be maintained or increased
within each herd unit.
Under Alternative 3, elk security areas would occupy 24 percent of the landscape. Security
would increase in four EHUs and remain steady in two. Three EHUs would now exceed 20
percent security on fall range. Security in one unit (Spotted Dog-Little Blackfoot) would increase
to 39 percent. Intermittent refuge areas would account for two percent of the landscape. If this
alternative is chosen, these percentages would become the baseline security levels that would
need to be maintained or improved upon within each herd unit.
Under Alternative 4, elk security areas would occupy 23 percent of the landscape, slightly less
than under alternative 3. Overall coverage of intermittent refuge areas would remain in the
same range as other alternatives: two percent in this case. As with alternative 3, security would
increase in four herd units and remain steady in two others. If this alternative is chosen, these
percentages would become the baseline security levels that would need to be maintained within
each herd unit.
Alternative 5 would provide the highest security level of any alternative, 27 percent overall. As
with alternatives 3 and 4, four herd units would see increased security and two would remain
essentially unchanged. Security increases would be more substantial under this alternative,
however, with three herd units near or above the 30 percent level. If this alternative is chosen,
these percentages would become the baseline security levels that would need to be maintained
or improved upon within each herd unit.
Current elk population numbers, bull/cow ratios and calf/cow ratios are at or above MFWP
objectives for three of the four hunting districts that cover the Divide landscape (HDs 215, 335,
343). In the 4th district (HD 293), total elk numbers are below MFWP objectives, but elk
populations in the portion of the district influenced by the Divide Travel Plan Area are at
acceptable levels.

Winter Range

With regard to Forest Plan big game standard 3, no alternative would affect thermal cover on
winter range. With regard to big game standard 4c, all alternatives would continue to allow the
presence of some longstanding snowmobile routes on elk winter range. All four action
alternatives would reduce snowmobile and OHV use on big game winter range, most

WILDLIFE - 438

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

significantly in the Sweeney–Blue Cloud Creek area. Alternative 5, however, would be much
more effective in this regard.
Alternative 1 would retain approximately 10,950 acres of snowmobile area closures on Helena
NF (Oil and Gas EIS) winter range. It would retain 39 miles of active snowmobile trails on winter
range.
Alternative 2 would expand snowmobile area closures to cover approximately 25,490 acres of
elk winter range and would reduce winter range snowmobile trails to 24 miles, most located
toward the upper edge of winter range where elk seldom venture in winter.
Alternative 3 would provide the same snowmobile area closures and the same mileage of
snowmobile trail on elk winter range as alternative 2.
Alternative 4 would provide the same snowmobile area restrictions and the same array of
snowmobile trails on elk winter range as alternatives 2 and 3.
Alternative 5 would reduce snowmobile routes on elk wintr range to about 11 miles.
Snowmobile area closures would increase to approximately 29,500 acres on winter range.

Threatened and Endangered Species
Grizzly Bear
Roads distribute human activity across the National Forest in ways that are known to diminish
utility of otherwise suitable grizzly bear habitat. Travel management obviously has a key role to
play in determining occupancy patterns for grizzlies on the landscape. This section describes
potential effects in terms of road patterns in the Divide Travel Plan Area. Grizzlies are scarce in
the Divide landscape, but they continue to range southward out of solid populations in the
Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem Recovery Zone to the north. The presence of nonmotorized areas with a good dispersion of productive habitat is key to allowing bears to move
through and occupy the landscape, albeit in small numbers.

Common Effects of Travel Management and Alternative Comparison

In this analysis, potential effects of the five alternatives on grizzly bears are gauged in terms of
(1) the size of large non-motorized core area equivalents, (2) road density and (3) motorized use
in key habitat areas. Effective grizzly habitat requires large core areas free from motorized use
during the period when bears are active (April to November) (IGBC 1994). The analysis of large
(greater than 1,500 acres) non-motorized habitat blocks in the previous
“Connectivity/Fragmentation” section provides a basic summary of such areas in the Plan Area.
A modified version more specific to grizzlies is displayed below in Table 112, which shows nonmotorized areas larger than 2,500 acres and 0.3 miles from open motor routes [USFS 2005, p. 7].
This delineation is based on the parameters used to define “core areas” in and around the
Grizzly Bear Recovery Zone in the Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem.

The Travel Plan Area currently supports 20 non-motorized habitat patches larger than 1,500
acres, as measured from the edge of the road/motor trail corridor [see Table 102and Table
103]. However, when the the more stringent parameters for grizzly bear core habitat in the
Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem Recovery Zone are applied to the Divide Travel Plan
Area (177,713 acres), only four of these non-motorized blocks emerge under current conditions.
Secure core area characteristics (blocks of contiguous habitat at least 0.3 mile from motorized
routes and larger than 2,500 acres) are based on recommendations of the Interagency Grizzly
Bear Committee (IGBC 1994) for the Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem Recovery Zone and
have been used in a number of recent analyses in that area (see USFS 2005; Servheen et al.
2001). The core areas provide habitat that is less impacted by human activity and where grizzly
bears are at lower risk of displacement and human-caused mortality (Servheen et al. 2001, p.
167).
In delineating non-motorized habitat blocks for grizzlies in this way, I found that several sizable
blocks of unroaded habitat dropped below the 2,500 acre threshold when the 0.3 mile buffer
was applied. These included non-motorized or lightly roaded areas around Greenhorn
Mountain, Little Porcupine Creek, upper Snowshoe Creek, Sweeney Creek, Priest Pass, Red
Mountain, Lee Mountain, Treasure Mountain, Slate Lake, Hat Creek, upper Spotted Dog Creek,
Jericho Creek and Negro Mountain [see Table 102]. Grizzlies have been reported in some of
these areas over the past 20 years.
Some of the smaller blocks are tenuously connected to the larger core areas (listed in Table 112)
by narrow corridors of unroaded habitat. The Jericho Creek block (currently 3,265 acres in Table
102), for example, is connected over the Divide to the Jericho Mountain Roadless Area by a 0.3
mile-wide corridor of non-motorized habitat. Likewise, the Upper Elliston Creek and Treasure
Mountain patches are both connected to larger core areas to the south by narrow necks of
unroaded habitat.
Two of the potential core areas shown in Table 112 connect with large roadless areas outside
Planning Area boundaries. The Black Mountain – Deadman Creek area abuts the large Nevada
Mountain Roadless Area to the north and reports of grizzly bears have been consistent
throughout this country for several years. Likewise, the extensive Electric Peak Roadless area at
the southern end of the Plan Area is contiguous with roadless country on the BeaverheadWILDLIFE - 440

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Deerlodge NF, a zone within which a majority of grizzly reports from the southern half of the
landscape have occurred over the past 20 years.
Under current road and trail patterns, only a single potential grizzly bear core area (Black
Mountain – Deadman Creek) is present north of Highway 12. As mentioned, this core area is
contiguous with another extensive non-motorized region (roughly 35,000 acres) that abuts the
Travel Plan Area on the north, providing the Distribution Zone in the Travel Plan area with an
effective linkage to established grizzly populations in the Blackfoot landscape on the Lincoln
Ranger District. Under the four action alternatives, a small number of strategic road and motor
trail closures in the area between Sweeney and Austin Creeks allow formation of a second large
non-motorized block north of Highway 12. This area is a peninsula of non-motorized habitat in
an an otherwise settled region of the greater Helena Valley. It does, however, provide a
combination of habitat characteristics (rugged terrain, dense conifer forest, aspen stands,
productive open foraging areas) that the bears may find useful in moving through the Divide
landscape. The Helena NF and MFWP have received rare, but credible, reports of grizzlies in the
upper (western) reaches of this area since 1990.
In the new southern extension of the Distribution Zone, the four action alternatives are more
conducive to grizzly bears than alternative 1 (the existing condition) in terms of the total acreage
within potential core areas and the number of such areas. This is particularly true of alternative
5, which provides a total of six large non-motorized blocks and adds more than 22,000 acres to
this habitat compared to alternative 1. Differences relate primarily to effective motorized trail
and road closures in the Meyers Hill, Sweeney Creek, Treasure Mountain, Baldy Ridge, Es and
areas under alternatives 3 and 4. In alternative 2, core area acreage decreases from current
conditions because of new motor routes in upper Ontario Creek and around Treasure Mountain.
The density and distribution of roads and motor trails, public and private, are important in
determining core areas and understanding the extent of habitat security for grizzly bears. Mace
and Manley (1993) have found that in Montana adult bears use habitat with open road densities
that exceed 1.0 mi/mi2 less than would be expected (if habitat use were random). All sex and
age classes use habitat with total road densities in excess of 2.0 mi/mi2 less than expected.
Table 113 shows the kinds of open road and motor trail densities that grizzly bears would have
to deal with in the Divide landscape under different alternatives. The volume and type of traffic
these routes carry and the resulting impact they have on grizzlies, varies widely within
categories and I have not attempted to apply any weighting factors to the road mileages.

Currently, in the Divide landscape, total road density (including private roads) is about 2.4
mi/mi². Density is around 3.0 mi/mi² in the northern Distribution Zone and 2.1 mi/mi² in the
southern Zone [Table 113]. Total road density is appreciably higher in the northern half of the
Distribution Zone than in the southern half, a consequence of the large Inventoried Roadless
Areas in the region south of Highway 12 outside the zone (Electric Peak, Lazyman Gulch,
Jericho). Route densities in the northern Zone are well in excess of Mace and Manley’s 2.0
mi/mi² total road benchmark; densities in the southern zone are just short of the threshold. In
spite of this, grizzly bears continue to be encountered more frequently in the more heavily
roaded northern Zone than in the area to the south, apparently a function of the Zone’s
proximity to the Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem. Total road densities (open and closed)
are the same for all alternatives, at least in the short-term. These densities could decline where
closed roads are eventually recontoured following action alternatives. Open route densities, on
the other hand, are different for each alternative (Table 113). Mileages and densities include all
routes within the Travel Plan Area open to wheeled vehicles during at least part of the year:
Helena NF roads, motor trails, County roads, State highways and open private roads.
Areawide open route densities would be 1.5 mi/mi² in alternatives 1 and 2, 1.3 mi/mi² in
alternative 3, 1.4 mi/mi² in alternative 4 and 1.2 mi/mi² in alternative 5. All of these exceed the
threshold of 1.0 mi/mi² that Mace and Manley’s research suggests is likely to discourage grizzly
bear use. Table 113 includes motor trails in addition to open roads, but the contribution of the
trails is relatively minor (and in alternative 3, non-existent), so this data is quite comparable to
that of Mace and Manley. Action alternatives reduce open route density only slightly in the
southern half of the Distribution Zone. Current open route density is 1.3 mi/mi²; action
alternatives range from 1.1 to 1.3 mi/mi². In the northern half of the Zone, alternatives 2, 3 and
4 reduce the density from 2.1 mi/mi² to 1.7-1.9 mi/mi². Alternative 5 produces the only notable
decline, down to 1.4 mi/mi².
WILDLIFE - 442

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

The fact that grizzlies continue to move through and occupy parts of the Travel Plan Area may
reflect the rough, primitive condition of many Forest and private roads and the low levels of
vehicle use they receive in summer, to the point that bears may often not perceive them as
functioning roads. Be that as it may, all road densities under all alternatives exceed levels
recommended for and achieved by most Bear Management Subunits in the Northern
Continental Divide Ecosystem Recovery Zone on the Lincoln District to the north, areas in which
the bears thrive [see USFS 2005].
Open roads and motor trails that penetrate key grizzly bear habitats may have an impact well
beyond that indicated by unqualified road density and roadless patch size. Productive grizzly
foraging sites are typically localized and fragmented and they are often a limiting resource in
any given landscape. Motor routes that compromise the functioning of these sites are of
particular concern (see USDI 2006, p. 9, 18-19, 35-38; USDI 1993, p. 146).
A number of local areas that are treated differently under each Travel Plan alternative and that
may be providing habitat for grizzly bears are discussed in some detail in the section on “Local
Effects in Key Areas” (which follows toward the end of this report). Five of these areas are of
particular interest because they support key grizzly bear habitat components and represent
locations in which grizzly bears have been reported in the past five years. One of them, Black
Mountain, is inside the original Grizzly Bear Distribution Zone north of Mullan Pass. The other
four (Baldy Ridge, upper Telegraph Creek, Slate Lake–Slate Creek and upper Ontario Creek–
Bison Creek) are in the new southern extension of the Distribution Zone and south of Highway
12 where grizzly population density is very low.
As to Black Mountain, all four action alternatives eliminate user-made motorized routes into the
otherwise unroaded area of forest habitat through which grizzly bears move between the
Lincoln and Helena Ranger Districts. South of Highway 12, alternative 2 increases motorized
access (over present condition) into all four areas listed above. Alternative 2 increases use into
three of them via motorized trails (Baldy Ridge being the exception). Alternatives 3 and 4
maintain the status quo or decrease motorized access, although alternative 4 is less effective as
it increases motorized access in upper Ontario Creek and maintains some of the current routes
in the upper Spotted Dog–Baldy Ridge area. These areas, while further removed from the
Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem, have seen some grizzly bear activity (sparse though it
may be) in recent years.

Comparison of Alternatives
Effects of Alternative 1
Alternative 1 is the existing condition. As displayed in Table 113, open route densities in the
Travel Plan Area are well beyond the lower limits that research suggests cause grizzly bears to
be reticent about using a particular area (greater than 1.0 mi/mi²). Current open road density
(unweighted by use) is 2.1 mi/mi² in the region north of Highway 12 and 1.3 mi/mi² to the south.
The average size of the 20 non-motorized patches larger than 1,500-acres in the “Connectivity/
Fragmentation” analysis is 5,565 acres [Table 103]. This compares with an average patch size of
7,124 acres for the six potential grizzly bear “core areas“ larger than 2,500 acres and surrounded
by an additional 0.3 mile non-motorized buffer zone [Table 112] 2. This average is considerably
2

Large non-motorized road patches used in the connectivity/fragmentation analysis are delineated from
road’s edge, whereas grizzly bear core areas require a buffer of 0.3 mi between the road and the core area.

WILDLIFE - 443

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

larger than the recommended 2,500 acres for such core areas in the Northern Continental
Divide Ecosystem Recovery Zone to the north [see USFS 2005]; but on the other hand, the core
areas account for only 24 percent of the Divide landscape. By way of comparison, guidelines
applied to Bear Management Units (BMUs) in the Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem
Recovery Zone to the north aim for a minimum of 68 percent of each Subunit in unroaded core
areas. These inherent differences are indicative of why the Divide landscape is classified as a
“distribution zone” and not a “recovery zone”.

Effects of Alternative 2
Alternative 2 would reduce current open route density from 2.1 mi/mi² to 1.9 mi/mi² in the
northern Distribution Zone. In the southern Distribution Zone, the reduction is minimal, with
density remaining at about 1.3 mi/mi² [Table 113].
Alternative 2 would increase the total area in secure core areas from 42,745 acres to 47,055
acres. In the northern distribution Zone, it would enlarge an already secure habitat block in the
Black Mountain-Deadman Creek area and create a new refuge in the and Sweeney-Austin Creek
area [Table 113]. In the southern part of the Zone, two of the three existing core areas would
remain essentially the same but the third (Electric Peak) would lose 250 acres because of newly
opened motor routes in the Baldy Ridge area. Overall, the appreciable expansion of secure
habitat north of Highway 12 would more than compensate for the relatively small loss to the
south. The number of habitat blocks large enough to qualify as potential grizzly bear core areas
would increase from four to five. Secure habitat blocks would come to occupy about 26
percent of the landscape, a bit more than in alternative 1 [Table 112].
In terms of motorized disturbance around key sites, alternative 2 would increase motorized use
in four areas: Baldy Ridge, upper Telegraph Creek, Slate Lake–Slate Creek and upper Ontario
Creek–Bison Creek (all in the southern half of the Distribution Zone). It would eliminate
motorized intrusion in the Black Mountain area (inside the Distribution Zone at the northern
end of the Plan Area).

Effects of Alternative 3
Alternative 3 would reduce open route density in the Distribution Zone from the current 1.5
/mi² to 1.3 mi/mi² [Table 113], somewhat less than alternative 2. This reduction would be more
notable in the northern part of the Distribution Zone, dropping from the current 2.1 mi/mi² to
1.7 mi/mi². In the area south of Highway 12, open route density would drop only from 1.3
mi/mi² to 1.1 mi/mi², but the motorized closures would be more strategic in terms of expanding
secure habitat areas. In the area north of the highway, the Black Mountain-Deadman Creek
area would increase in size and the new Austin-Sweeney block would be larger than the area
produced by alternative 2. In total, secure habitat would increase from the current 10,010 acres
to 16,330 acres [Table 112]. South of the highway, secure habitat acreage would increase from
32,735 acres to 39,450 acres. All three core areas would expand, although the change would be
minimal in the Lazyman Gulch Roadless block. Altogether, secure core area type habitat would
increase from 24 percent to 31 percent of the landscape [Table 113].
Alternative 3 would not increase motorized presence in any of the key areas likely to have been
providing habitat for grizzlies in the last five years. It would decrease potential for such
presence in three of these areas. The resulting parameters, while well below what is required of
a grizzly bear recovery zone, represent a measurable improvement over current conditions.

WILDLIFE - 444

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Effects of Alternative 4
Alternative 4 would produce the same open motor route density in the northern half of the
grizzly bear Distribution Zone as alternative 3 (1.7 mi/mi²). In the southern half of the Zone,
open route density (1.2 mi/mi²) would be slightly more than in alternative 3 (1.1 mi/mi²). These
two alternatives are very similar, with alternative 4 allowing only 13 more open route miles than
alternative 3 [Table 113].
Alternatives 3 and 4 differ somewhat more in terms of the amount of secure core area habitat
produced: 51,075 acres in alternative 4 as opposed to 55,780 acres in alternative 3 [Table 112].
Almost all of this difference occurs in the souther half of the Distribution Zone as a result of
newly opened motor routes in the Jericho Mountain and Electric Peak blocks. Nonetheless,
open route patterns in alternative 4 would allow 29 percent of the landscape to provide secure
grizzly bear habitat blocks as opposed to 24 percent at present (alternative 1) [Table 112].
In terms of motorized presence in key areas likely to have been providing habitat for grizzlies in
recent years, alternative 4 is less intrusive than alternatives 1 and 2 but more so than alternative
3. Like alternative 2, alternative 3 would establish a summertime motor trail on currently closed
road #4104-A1 along upper Ontario and Bison Creeks, an area of excellent potential grizzly
habitat and within two to three miles of sites where grizzlies have been reported in the last five
years. While not as disruptive as an arterial or collector road, the trail would introduce
motorized disturbance into an environment potentially useful to grizzlies. Alternative 4 would
not sanction motorized use in other key grizzly areas and in this regard it is nearly identical to
alternative 3. This includes expansion of non-motorized core areas in the Black Mountain region
along the northern edge of the Plan Area.
As with alternative 3, the resulting conditions, while well below what is required of a grizzly bear
recovery zone, represent a measurable improvement over current conditions.

Effects of Alternative 5
Alternative 5 would produce the lowest open route densities in both the north and south
segments of the Distribution Zone and the lowest overall density of any alternative (1.2 mi/mi²).
Although the miles of motor trails active during the summer would increase, the miles of open
road would decline substantially, both north and south of Highway 12 [Table 113]. Alternative 5
would also generate the largest increase in non-motorized grizzly bear habitat blocks: from
42,745 acres at present to 64,980 acres. A new habitat block (3,405 acres) would appear in the
Treasure Mountain area, increasing the number of these potential core areas from five to six
[Table 112].
On a large scale, alternative 5 would be the most favorable to grizzly bear habitat because of its
lower open road densities and appreciable increment in contiguous unroaded habitat.
However, newly designated motor trails proposed in this alternative would create some sitespecific problems in key habitat areas likely to be used by grizzlies. These include the Slate Lake
area, upper Elliston Creek and upper Ontario/Bison Creeks, all areas where grizzlies have been
reported (though rarely) over the past dozen years. These areas are discussed in some detail
the later section, “Local Effects in Key Areas”.

Cumulative Effects

This summary of cumulative effects is based on the matrix in appendix B, which identifies past,
present and reasonably foreseeable actions and circumstances, in addition to this project, that
may affect grizzly bears and their habitat. The scope of the analysis includes the Divide
WILDLIFE - 445

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

landscape (Helena NF land with non-Forest inholdings), adjacent National Forest lands (on the
Lincoln Ranger District and the Beaverhead-Deerlodge NF) and neighboring non-Forest lands
(private, State, County, municipal and BLM). This summary is common to all alternatives.

Forest Service Past and Ongoing Activities

Recent/ongoing activities on the Forest that have improved prospects for grizzly bears include:
Designation of the Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem Grizzly Bear Distribution Zone north
of Mullan Pass (2002) and its recent expansion southward to cover the entire Divide landscape
(2013); trail relocation projects that have removed trails from riparian areas to upslope locations
(Blackfoot Meadows, CDNST); mine reclamation projects, some of which have improved riparian
habitat function favorable to bears; establishment of the Statewide OHV Plan (2001), which
prohibits riding off established motor routes; grazing allotment revisions that have often
reduced cattle numbers and improved habitat; road and motor trail closures associated with
timber sales (Clancy-Unionville, Sound Wood, Treasure Mountain) that have enlarged nonmotorized habitat blocks.

Activities that have locally reduced the effectiveness of potential grizzly habitat or have had a
mixed effect include: timber harvest in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s that has created large
clearcuts, as opposed to a finer-grained habitat mosaic (Bison Creek, Mike Renig Gulch-Hahn
Creek, Slate Creek, Lump Gulch, Ophir Creek-Cave Gulch, Mullan Pass, Lava Mtn, Deadman);
road permits allowing access across Helena NF land to private holdings; retention of private
recreational residences on Helena NF land (esp. near the Divide at MacDonald Pass); small
mining operations (under the 1872 Mining Act) in areas where grizzlies have been observed;
construction and maintenance of communications sites and power lines; widespread fencing
associated with grazing allotments that complicate movement; efforts to spread out livestock
use on some allotments, which may bring cattle into new areas of potential grizzly habitat;
retention of numerous dispersed camping sites; unrestricted back-country recreational use
(backpackers, day-hikers, horseback riders, hunters). Timber harvest has recently been
completed in the Clancy-Unionville project area, removing blocks of beetle-killed lodgepole pine
in the upper Lump Gulch/ Travis Creek drainages and along the Brooklyn Bridge ridge south of
Helena. The ongoing Red Mountain Flume Chessman Reservoir Project is removing dead
lodgepole pine from 490 acres in the upper Tenmile drainage. Resulting habitat opportunity for
grizzly bears would be mixed.
Some recent hazard tree removal projects are unlikely to impact grizzly bears because of their
association with roads and developed recreation sites (Park Lake and Cromwell Dixon
Campgrounds, MacDonald Pass CDNST Trailhead). Several other projects designed to remove
hazard trees are unlikely to influence grizzly bears because of their association with roads and
developed recreation sites (Kading and Moose Creek campgrounds, Tenmile picnic area,
Roadside Hazard Trees, MacDonald Pass Ski Trails).

Adjacent Private and Other, Past and Ongoing Actions

Private land development (mostly rural home building) continues to create sites that generate
problems for animals striving to move through or occupy the landscape (barriers to movement,
habitat loss, bear attractants, dogs). Other human endeavors with similar effects include mining
operations, ATV-trail bike riding areas, new and upgraded roads (notably, the widening and
paving of the Marysville road), unregulated private timber harvest and clearing of vegetative
cover from riparian sites. Livestock grazing on private lands near the Forest has some potential

WILDLIFE - 446

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

to create conflicts with bears under certain circumstances (sheep being particularly vulnerable).
Recent purchase of 27,600 acres of private ranchland in the Spotted Dog drainage by MFWP will
forestall subdivision and development of those lands immediately west of the Helena NF
boundary and allow them to remain in a condition more amenable to grizzly bear habitation and
passage.

Forest Service Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Reasonably foreseeable activities on Helena NF land that may affect grizzlies to one degree or
another include improvement of the Rimini Road (in a potential wildlife travel zone),
implementation of grazing allotment revision (Clancy, MacDonald Pass, Austin, Empire),
increased recreational use of back-country environments and salvage projects designed to deal
with dead tree and woody debris accumulations resulting from the recent mountain pine beetle
epidemic. Some of these projects would be extensive: (1) the Telegraph Vegetation Project,
affecting a variety of habitats just west of the Continental Divide and (2) the Tenmile-South
Helena Project, which would alter dead-tree environments over a wide area from the
Continental Divide eastward to the outskirts of Helena. Effects on grizzly bear habitat would be
mixed, some beneficial, some problematic. Key ahbitat sites would be protected in all cases.

Adjacent Private and Other, Reasonably Foreseeable Actions

Future activity on non-Forest land in the cumulative effects area that may affect grizzly bears
includes: settlement and associated development of private lands (including road building);
timber harvest and removal of beetle-killed dead trees; continued motorized recreation.

Summary and Conclusions
All alternatives would comply with the Grizzly Bear Recovery Plan, the IGBC Guidelines and with
appropriate standards and guidelines in the Helena Forest Plan.
Alternative 1 would retain four large non-motorized core habitat areas averaging roughly 10,685
acres each (24 percent of the landscape). Unweighted open motor route density would remain
at 1.5 mi/mi².
Alternative 2 would increase the number of large non-motorized core habitat areas to five with
an average size of 9,410 acres (26 percent of the landscape). Unweighted open motor route
density would remain at 1.5 mi/mi².
Alternative 3, like Alternative 2, would support five large non-motorized core habitat areas, but
with an average size of 11,155 acres. They would cover 31 percent of the landscape.
Unweighted open motor route density would decline to 1.3 mi/mi².
Alternative 4 would also support five large non-motorized core habitat areas. These areas
would average 10,215 acres and would cover 29 percent of the landscape, a bit less than
alternative 3. Unweighted open motor route density would be 1.4 mi/mi².
Alternative 5 would increase the number of non-motorized potential core areas to six. These
areas would average 10,830 acres and would cover 37 percent of the landscape. Unweighted
open route density would drop to 1.1 mi/mi².
Under all alternatives, road/ motor trail densities in the Travel Plan Area would remain overly
high by Northern Continental Divide Ecosystem Recovery Zone standards. Given the presence of
a few several large non-motorized habitat areas, they are low enough to support a small local
grizzly bear population and to support linkage zone function. No conflicts with livestock and no
WILDLIFE - 447

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

human-caused grizzly bear mortalities have been recorded in the Divide landscape in several
decades.

Canada Lynx
Effects of travel management on lynx are assessed via standards and guidelines in the Northern
Rockies Lynx Management Direction(NRLMD) (2007b, attachment 1), which is now incorporated
into the Helena Forest Plan. Since none of the alternatives propose new road construction or
specific road improvements that would directly alter vegetation, direct effects on habitat are
essentially non-existent for this particular phase of travel management. Primary effects,
therefore will be those generated by shifts in open road distribution and in snowmobile routes
that provide access for trappers and packed over-snow travel routes into lynx winter habitat for
competing carnivores. There is also some potential for motorized routes disrupting lynx
movement patterns in linkage habitat. Potential effects on critical habitat are further evaluated
in relation to “primary constituent elements” (PCEs) for lynx identified by the USFWS in
documentation designating critical habitat in February 2009 (Federal Register, Vol. 74, No. 36, p.
8638).

Common Effects of Travel Management
General Effects of Open Roads
Useful information on the effects of roads and trails on lynx and their prey is meager (Apps
2000; McKelvey et al. 2000). Much of it is anecdotal and studies that have specifically targeted
road impacts have not produced definitive conclusions.
Construction of roads sometimes removes linear swaths of suitable lynx habitat, which may
have a local impact if habitat is limiting or key sites are affected. Some researchers have noted
that adult females may move kittens to new den sites to avoid nearby vehicle traffic that
escalates as summer comes on (Ruggiero et al. 1999). In some cases, lynx may alter normal
travel and hunting patterns to avoid open roads, but they are also likely to travel along
roadways less than 50 feet wide with good cover along both edges (Koehler and Brittell 1990).
Field research and observation indicate that in normal circumstances most lynx do not
necessarily avoid habitat near roads except for roads with high traffic volume (Aubry et al. 1999;
Ruggiero et al. 1999).
Lynx are particularly vulnerable to exploitation by trapping (Bailey et al. 1986). Although they
can no longer be targeted by trappers in Montana, lynx are at risk from traps set for any midsized furbearer and therefore are affected by roads and snowmobile trails that provide access
for trappers in winter. Research does indicate that lynx are probably more vulnerable to
trapping near open roads (Koehler and Aubry 1994; Bailey et al. 1986).
Denning habitat is usually not a limiting factor for lynx in the northern Rockies (USFS 2007c, p.
173) and the Lynx Management Direction does not present a standard that specifies how much
denning habitat needs to be retained in a given LAU (USFS 2007b, p. 14-17). However, Guideline
VEG G11 states that substantial pockets of large woody debris should be distributed throughout
each LAU and that if denning habitat appears to be deficient, projects should be designed to
retain coarse woody debris (USFS 2007b, Attachment 1, p. 5). The Divide Travel Plan does not
propose to alter existing patterns of woody debris, but it would indirectly provide opportunities
for firewood cutters to remove snags and logs from road corridors, which, in some cases, may
degrade potential lynx denning habitat. Normally, areas within 300 feet of open roads are
unlikely denning sites, but they could serve the purpose in certain circumstances, such as where
WILDLIFE - 448

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

understory regeneration is thick, downfall is abundant, traffic is infrequent and opportunities
are limited elsewhere.

Refuge and Connectivity
While it is not conclusively known what effect roads and motorized trails have on lynx, research
suggests that local unroaded or non-motorized refuges are important for successful lynx
reproduction and for ecological fitness (Ruediger et al. 2000). Such refugia include large areas of
high quality habitat relatively secure from human exploitation, habitat degradation and
disruptive winter access. Landscape connectivity is also an important component of lynx
conservation. Areas of high human use can interrupt habitat connectivity and further fragment
lynx habitat (Ruediger et al. 2000). Previous sections of this report dealing with “Fragmentation
and Connectivity” and with the “Grizzly Bear” present assessments of large blocks of nonmotorized habitat that may be of use to lynx as sanctuaries [see Table 102, Table 103, Table 112
and associated discussion]. These analyses show that the average size of potential lynx refuges
increases substantially under alternative 2 and more so under alternatives 3 and 4.

Snow Compaction
Roads and trails provide unobstructed routes for snowmobiles, cross-country skiing and other
winter uses that create snow compaction. Compacted routes facilitate winter access for
carnivores that would otherwise be unable to negotiate the deep snow characteristic of lynx
winter habitat. Lynx have evolved a competitive advantage in deep, non-compacted snow that
tends to exclude other predators during winter, a time when prey is most limiting (Buskirk et al.
1999; Ruediger et al. 2000). Competing carnivores that might be able to take advantage of solid
over-the-snow routes include coyotes, bobcats, red foxes, mountain lions, wolves and
wolverines (although wolverines are also willing to move through deep loose snow on a regular
basis). Although coyotes and bobcats are most often cited as the primary competing carnivores
taking advantage of compacted snow routes, systematic tracking surveys in the Divide landscape
(Wild Things Unlimited, 2007-2010) found that the most frequently encountered winter
competitors were coyotes and red foxes [see Gehman et al. 2008, 2009].
Research on this issue is new and so far, conclusions have been limited. One study of the effect
of snow compaction on coyotes and lynx in western Montana (Kolbe et al. 2005) found that
while coyotes did use packed snowmobile and ski trails in lynx habitat, most of their travel was
off-trail, often in areas where snow was shallow or naturally compacted. As well, coyotes acted
primarily as scavengers in winter and did not compete significantly with lynx for live prey.
Another recent study in northern Utah (Bunnel 2006, cited in USFS 2007c) found that coyotes
stayed relatively close to snowmobile trails (within 350 meters) when snow was deep and prey
was common in the trail corridor. The sum of recently completed and ongoing research
suggests that lynx and coyote populations often coexist on winter range but that there is no
good evidence that lynx populations are suffering as a result (USFS 2007b, p. 24). A number of
studies have observed also that lynx normally tolerate at least moderate levels of snowmobile
traffic through their winter habitats and that they readily use packed snowmobile routes as
travelways (Aubry et al. 1999).

Effects Assessment: Comparison of Alternatives

Attachment 1 in the Northern Rockies Lynx Management Direction ROD (2007b) displays the
objectives, standards and guidelines designed to promote lynx conservation. Objectives are
descriptions of desired resource conditions for lynx. Standards are management requirements
WILDLIFE - 449

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

designed to meet objectives. Guidelines are management actions that, while not required, are
normally taken to meet objectives (USFS 2007b, p. 7). Standards and guidelines that deal with
the potential effects of travel management on lynx can be found in NRLMD sections addressing
“human use projects” (HU), “linkage areas” (LINK) and management applicable to all actions in
LAUs (ALL).
Guidelines HU G6 and HU G8 deal with road upgrading and maintenance. They will apply to
future road projects emanating from the Divide Travel Plan but not to this phase of the planning
effort. Guidelines HU G7 and HU G9 address the placement, design, closure and reclamation of
new roads. Since no Travel Plan alternative proposes to construct new roads, this guidance does
not apply, although it may be useful in assessing the closure of existing roads. The NRLMD does
not provide standards or guidelines that address the density of open roads, motor trails, foot
trails, or closed roads [see discussion in NRLMD ROD, p. 26-27].
Standard LINK S1 requires identification of potential lynx highway crossings when planning
highway construction or reconstruction in known linkage areas. Likewise, Guideline ALL G1
directs using methods that avoid or reduce effects on lynx when constructing or reconstructing
highways. Since none of the alternatives propose highway construction or reconstruction, this
direction does not apply to the Divide Travel Plan. The problems that two these
standards/guidelines address, however, are relevant in that (1) highway crossings are a problem
on U.S. Highway 12 around MacDonald Pass and (2) one project (by another agency) that may
qualify as “highway reconstruction” (the Rimini road project) lies within the Plan Area. These
circumstances do not influence the Divide Travel Plan’s compliance with the NRLMD, but they
are part of the environmental baseline that needs to accounted for.
This leaves Guidelines HU G11 and HU G12, which deal with over-the-snow routes and the issue
of winter access into lynx habitat. These guidelines are as follows:
HU G11. Designated over-the-snow routes or designated play areas should not expand outside
baseline areas of consistent snow compaction, unless designation serves to consolidate use and
improve lynx habitat. This may be calculated on an LAU basis or for a combination of
immediately adjacent LAUs.
HU G12. Winter access for non-recreation special uses and mineral and energy exploration and
development should be limited to designated routes or designated over-the-snow routes.
A breakdown of snowmobile routes in the Divide Travel Plan Area is shown in Table 99.
Currently, the Plan Area supports 81 miles of roads and trails that have been specifically
designated for snowmobile use under the existing Travel Plan [see HELENA NATIONAL FOREST
Visitor Map, 2006; Divide Travel Plan map for alternative 1]. The Travel Plan also allows
snowmobile use on any Forest or County road open to highway-legal vehicles, whether or not it
is specifically designated as a snowmobile route, as long as the road is (1) unplowed and (2) not
within an area closed to snowmobiles. Snowmobilers currently make use of 239 miles of these
“allowed” routes, most of which have been in use for decades [Helena NF Recreation files;
Helena Snowdrifters Snowmobile Club meetings]. Roughly 48 percent of the non-specified
routes (114 miles) are shown on the map of Snowmobile Routes on the Helena National Forest
(Helena Snowdrifters 2003). Action alternatives would specifically designate many of these
traditional routes as “snowmobile trails”. This represents a shift in status from an allowed use
to a specifically designated use. It does not, however, represent an actual increase in the
identified network of packed over-snow routes.

WILDLIFE - 450

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

In addition to this system of routes on which snowmobile use is specified or allowed by the
Travel Plan, a number of roads that technically are “closed to motorized vehicles yearlong” also
have been serving as snowmobile trails for the past two to three decades. The reasons for the
original route restrictions for snowmobiles [which date from the 1970s and 1980s] are unclear,
particularly since the areas through which the roads travel are open to cross-country
snowmobiling, which means that, in practice, snowmobilers have been permitted to ride next to
or between the roads, but are technically forbidden to ride on the roads. In some cases,
snowmobilers have established trails adjacent to the roadbeds, but in other cases they have
been using the roads themselves.
For the most part, the Helena NF has allowed the unauthorized on-road use to continue in areas
where no problems for wildlife or other recreational activity (notably, cross-country skiing and
snowshoeing) have been evident. Alternatives 2, 3, 4 and 5 would now legitimize the
longstanding snowmobile use on a number of these restricted road systems and allow the nextto-the-road and cross-country use to move onto the roads. The road systems to be thus
designated have been chosen based on historic snowmobile use patterns and the absence of
observed resource problems [supporting data coming from longtime field observations by
Helena NF recreation and wildlife personnel and discussions with the Helena Snowdrifters
Snowmobile Club]. Under all alternatives, wheeled vehicles would continue to be excluded
year-round.
The change in designation would affect 36 miles of currently restricted roads in lynx habitat
under alternative 2, 33 miles under alternatives 3 and 4 and 49 miles under alternative 5.
Combined with new road/trail closures in other areas, the net increase of officially sanctioned
snowmobile routes in lynx habitat would be 32 miles under alternative 2, 28 miles under
alternatives 3 and 4 and 44 miles under alternative 5 [the change in actual usage, apart from
trail designation, is displayed in Table 114 below; LAU maps are in Figure 28, Figure 29 and
Figure 30 in “Affected Environment “].

The Helena NF has not designated off-route “play areas” for snowmobiles in the Divide
landscape; but unless such riding is prohibited by specific area closures, it is allowed and there is
a general understanding as to where these traditional play areas are located. While in most
cases, off-trail riding involves play areas near sanctioned trails, there is potential for pioneering
routes off into new areas, which could extend the reach of competing carnivores. In the Divide
landscape, most of this activity is confined to higher elevation meadows, parks and other breaks
in forest cover where snowmobiles have room to maneuver. As a result, almost none of it is in
mapped lynx habitat (which is forested). No Travel Plan alternative designates specific play
areas or makes changes to existing snowmobile routes that would encourage more off-route
riding. To the contrary, alternatives 2, 3 and 4 propose to expand the number and size of areas
where off-route snowmobile riding is restricted. As a result, all four alternatives comply with
the “play area” aspect of Guideline HU G11.

Alternative 1 would maintain about 34,600 acres of snowmobile area closures, of which roughly
70 percent are in potential lynx habitat. Alternative 2 would expand this to more than 50,100
acres, of which about 77 percent are in lynx habitat. Alternatives 3 and 4 would provide a

close the most acreage to cross-country snowmobiling, roughly 71,300 acres, of which about 78
percent are in lynx habitat. A majority of the area closures in the Travel Plan Area are south of
U.S. Highway 12. This is the part of the Divide landscape that the NRLMD classifies as
“secondary” occupied lynx habitat, but it is the part of the landscape where most of the verified
lynx observations have been made in the last five years. The upshot is that these snowmobile
restrictions are targeted at that portion of the Travel Plan Area where they are most likely to
benefit lynx as currently distributed, regardless of whether or not the area has been classified as
critical lynx habitat.
