Analysis Area
The rights-of-way of travel-ways within the project area were used as the analysis area for direct
effects. The Divide Travel Plan area was used for indirect effects on individual populations.

Sensitive Plant Populations
This assessment addresses the potential for sensitive plant populations to occur in the project
area and within the rights-of-way of travel-ways and the effects of the alternatives on those
populations.

Species Known or Possibly Present
Four sensitive plant species are known to have habitat in the project area, as shown in Table
143: Botrychium paradoxum, Juncus hallii, Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis and Pinus albicaulis.
Additionally the following four species may have habitat in the project area: Botrychium
crenulatum, Cypripedium parviflorum, Polygonum douglasii spp. austiniae and Schoenoplectus
subterminalis.

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 606

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Botrychium crenulatum has not been found to-date on the Helena National Forest. This species
has been found on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest, immediately adjacent in the
Occidental Plateau area. The habitat for this species is moist to wet areas, similar habitat to that
of Juncus hallii. This species is searched for in all wetland and riparian surveys but has not been
found to-date.
Botrychium paradoxum is known from two populations on the Helena National Forest, one
population is known within the Divide Travel Plan project area. The population is near a
motorized trail in the Irish Mine Hill area in an open rough fescue grassland area. This species
has been found in sagebrush/rough fescue shrublands and rough fescue grasslands on the
Helena National Forest.
Cypripedium parviflorum has not been found to-date on the Forest. An unverified record of this
species from the Mount Helena area has been determined to be unfounded (see project file).
Habitat for this species includes fens, moist woods and seepage areas in the lower mountain
areas. Limited habitat exists in the project area due to the low elevation that this species
occupies, along with the moist habitat requirements.
Juncus hallii is known to occur at several locations on the Helena National Forest. In the Divide
project area, Hall’s rush is documented at 18 locations, including sites discovered in 2009 and
2012 during project surveys. The populations are associated with the headwaters of Ontario and
Clemmer gulches, above Sally Anne Creek, in Sure Thing swamps, one location in the
headwaters of Tenmile Creek and a population near Chessman reservoir. This species typically
occurs in moist grasslands and sedge meadows (Poole and Heidel 1993). The Helena populations
are on the edge of more moist riparian or wetland areas, similar to the habitat for Botrychium
crenulatum. Many negative surveys were found during wetland identifications. The populations
tend to be small and isolated; it is likely that many populations could exist, particularly in the
area where other known populations are concentrated. The species has not been found to date
west of the Little Blackfoot River or north of Highway 12 in the project area.
Although widespread across the mountainous portions of southwest and central Montana,
Juncus hallii is rare. Threats and potential negative impacts to most known occurrences appear
to be minimal and the species is likely tolerant of some levels of disturbance (MTNHP 2013). The
Montana Natural Heritage Program has recently removed Hall’s rush from their Species of
Concern list, its status re-determined as low-risk, low priority due to its occurrence in at least 15
subwatersheds.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis has eight known populations within the analysis area. Two large
populations, north and south of the highway on MacDonald pass, one population in the Austin
Creek area, one population near Baldy Ridge, one small population on FS Trail 501 (Kading
cabin); one east of Larabee Gulch road; one between the top of Kading Grade (FS Trail 501) and
the Fred Burr road, 1868; one on either side of FS Road 708-E3 (Snowshoe Creek). Several of
the populations are near motorized travel-ways. The MacDonald Pass site is adjacent to noxious
weeds. The other populations do not currently have noxious weeds immediately adjacent to the
populations. This species could occur in other areas of rough fescue grasslands within the
project area. Negative survey information is available in the project file.
Pinus albicaulis occurs in higher elevations throughout the Helena National Forest. Within the
project area, whitebark pine is present on subalpine fir climax habitat types. This landscape
does not contain the elevations and sites where whitebark pine would be a tree-line dominant.
It is a minor and often understory component in sites dominated by lodgepole pine and/or

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 607

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

subalpine fir and Engelmann spruce. In the Divide Travel Plan Project area, whitebark pine
occurs on at least 1,102 acres. Numerous route segments, ranging from 0 to 0.3 miles and
totaling 18.8 miles intersect whitebark pine stands (see project file).
Whitebark pine is a keystone species because of its various roles in supporting community
diversity and a foundation species for its roles in promoting community development and
stability (Keane et al 2012). Whitebark pine forests are declining across most of their range in
North America because of the combined effects of mountain pine beetle outbreaks, fire
exclusion policies and white pine blister rust. It can be promoted by removing competing
conifers and creating suitable sites for regeneration.
“The decline of whitebark pine comes from a synergism of natural and human-driven
causes. Periodic, massive outbreaks of mountain pine beetle, killing mature whitebark
pines, have been exacerbated by suppression of natural fires. A major reduction in highelevation fires since the early 1900’s has led to successional replacement of whitebark
pine on more productive sites in the part of its range where it otherwise should be
abundant…White pine blister rust is killing whitebark pine trees in the intermountain
region, coastal ranges and Canadian Rocky Mountains and rangewide mortality is
expected within one to several decades.” (Tomback et al 2001, p. 13)
Whitebark pine is dependent on fire to maintain dominance and vigor. It is shade intolerant and
susceptible to mountain pine beetle and the exotic disease white pine blister rust. The success
of mountain pine beetle and white pine blister rust has been exacerbated by drought. See the
Forested Habitats of Special Concern report, in the project record, for more detailed
descriptions of these mortality agents and the ecology of whitebark pine. On the Helena
National Forest, there is whitebark pine mortality from insects and disease and evidence for the
decline of this species is supported by recent Aerial Detection Survey reports and other
whitebark pine monitoring. Again, see the Forested Habitats of Special Concern, in the project
record, report for further details.
Keane and others (2012) published A Range-Wide Restoration Strategy for Whitebark Pine
(Pinus albicaulis), providing a comprehensive strategy for whitebark restoration. The strategy
contains four principles:
1.

2.
3.
4.

Promote rust resistance, by a) supporting selective breeding programs to develop
and deploy blister-rust resistant whitebark; b) facilitating and accelerating natural
selection for rust resistant trees by reducing competition, providing openings for
natural seed dispersal and seedling survival; and c) planting seedlings from trees
known to have some level of resistance.
Conserve genetic diversity, by collecting and archiving seeds and growing and
planting genetically diverse seedlings.
Saving seed sources, by protecting mature seed-producing resistant whitebark pine
trees so that apparent rust-resistant seeds can be harvested in the future; and
Employing restoration treatments, by considering whitebark pine areas that are in
decline for restoration treatments, including limiting the spread of blister rust, using
fire to encourage regeneration, implementing silvicultural cuttings to reduce
competition and increase vigor and reduce likelihood of mountain pine beetle
attacks, planting rust-resistant seedlings to accelerate the effects of selection and
promoting natural regeneration and diverse age-class structures to maintain

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 608

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

ecosystem function and reduce landscape level beetle hazard and to provide large
populations for selection for rust resistance.
Recommended actions relative to these principles include assessments, planning, reducing
disturbance impacts, gathering seeds, growing seedlings, protecting seed sources, implementing
treatments, planting seedlings, monitoring activities and conducting research (Keane et al.
2012).
Polygonum douglasii ssp. austiniae is known from loose talus slopes in the Big Belts Mountains
on the Helena National Forest. There are no known populations within the project area. Other
occurrences are documented by the Montana Natural Heritage Program near the project area.
This species may exist within the project area in talus slopes, other sparsely vegetated areas and
potentially along roads.
Schoenoplectus subterminalis is known from the Indian Meadows Research Natural Area on the
Helena National Forest. There are no known populations within the project area. This species
occurs in very wet sites on the edges of ponds, bogs and open water.
All species on the sensitive species list are searched for in any sensitive plant surveys.
Numerous past vegetation data collection efforts by Forest personnel and Montana Natural
Heritage Program staff have failed to discover any sensitive plant populations in the project
area. Forest Inventory Analysis Intensified Grid data collection that occurred on a grid across the
entire Divide Travel Plan area in 2007 and 2008 did not identify any sensitive plant populations.

Species Unlikely To Be Present
As stated above, all species on the sensitive plant list are searched for during field surveys. The
species discussed below that are followed with * have been found on or very near the Helena
National Forest. Habitats for all species are described in appendix D of the sensitive species
specialist report in the project record.
Astragalus lackschewitzii, Drosera anglica*, Drosera linearis*, Epipactis gigantean, Oxytropis
podocarpa and Veratrum californicum all have specialized habitat that does not occur in the
analysis area. These species will not be included in the effects analysis as the specialized
habitats are not known to occur.
Amerorchis rotundifolia, Aquilegia brevistyla, Cypripedium passerinum, Goodyera repens,
Grindelia howellii, Saxifraga tempestiva and Thalictrum alpinum are unlikely to occur due to
geographic separation from known habitats. These species have not been found on the Helena
National Forest to date. Habitat for these species potentially exists in the analysis area.
These species will not be analyzed further.

Sensitive Plants, Environmental Consequences
Effects Common to All Alternatives

A direct effect of motorized travel would be the constant exposure of weed seeds to the rightsof-way of motorized travel-ways, specifically those areas with a sensitive plant population.
Noxious weeds can out-compete most native plants for nutrients, water and sunlight. The
spread of noxious weeds has a very adverse potential impact on sensitive plant populations
forestwide (Mack 2000; Pauchard et al 2003). If these species are left unchecked it is likely that
noxious weeds would occupy sensitive plant populations, especially those close to motorized
SENSITIVE PLANTS - 609

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

routes in drier habitats. The Helena National Forest requires weed-seed-free feed for stock
users; this limits the exposure of noxious weeds seeds in non-motorized areas. Bicycles can carry
weed seeds, but is much less likely to carry weed seed or plant parts any distance. Animals (both
domestic and wild) can carry noxious weed seeds in their coats (Campbell and Gibson 2001;
Myers et al. 2004). An indirect effect of weed infestations in the rights-of-ways would be that
the entire project area would be exposed to weed introduction and transfer by motorized
vehicles (Trunkle and Fay 1991) and to a lesser extent, bicycles and other non-motorized travel.
The increased weed presence would pose a threat to sensitive plants and their habitat
throughout the travel plan area.
In addition to spreading weeds, vehicles that travel off established routes have the potential to
directly harm sensitive plant populations by driving in or near the populations.
The presence of humans in the forest increases the risk of man-caused wildfire, which would be
an indirect impact. The potential exists for wildfire to have a short term detrimental effect on
sensitive plant habitats, but no long-term effects in most cases. However, there has been a
dramatic increase of severe wildfires in the ponderosa pine type in recent decades where fuels
have built up due to fire suppression (Agee and Skinner 2005). In these habitats there is
potential for long-term damage to sensitive plant habitats (Menges and Dolan 1998;
Pendergrass et al. 1999). Plant response to fire is a result of the interaction between severity of
the fire and the individual plant species’ inherent resistance to injury and ability to recover
(Brown et al. 2000). Mortality of herbaceous species is more dependent on the length of time
plants are exposed to high heat, determined by the amount of duff and woody fuel consumed
by the fire, than flame length and fire intensity (Armour et al. 1984). The effect of wildfire on
sensitive plant habitats therefore would depend on the surface fuel conditions. The longer fuels
build up on the forest floor, the greater the potential damage to sensitive plant habitats.
Wildland fires also risk enhancing non-native plant invasions if severe fires damage the native
vegetation. Canada thistle, bull thistle, knapweeds, Dalmation toadflax and cheatgrass have
been shown to increase following wildfire (Harrod and Reichard 2002). Noxious weeds are a
serious threat to sensitive plant habitats. Wildland fires can also exacerbate non-native plant
invasions if native vegetation is damaged by severe fire. Studies in interior ponderosa pine
forests have shown that Canada thistle, bull thistle, knapweeds, Dalmation toadflax and
cheatgrass increase after fire (Jacobs and Sheley 2003; Keeley 2006).
The spread of noxious weeds can have an adverse impact on sensitive plant populations
whether or not a fire occurs. Noxious weeds dominate plant communities and tend to form
monocultures which negatively impact native biological diversity. This weed competition to
individual plants and plant communities can result in loss of species diversity and sensitive
native plants. If noxious weeds are left unchecked, they can out-compete sensitive plant
populations, especially those close to motorized routes in drier habitats. Herbicide application
would have variable effects on sensitive plant populations. Broadleaf herbicides (i.e. 2,4-D or
Tordon) could adversely impact Botrychium crenulatum, Botrychium paradoxum, Cypripedium
parviflorum, Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensi, Pinus albicaulis and Polygonum douglasii ssp.
austiniae with the exception of herbicides that are specifically designed to harm plant families,
such Asteraceae, the aster family. Grass-like species, Juncus hallii and Schoenoplectus
subterminalis, would not be harmed by herbicides designed to kill broadleaf plants. These
species would, however, be harmed by herbicides that are “non-specific” and kill both broadleaf
and grass-like species. An example of this type of herbicide is Round-up. The Helena National
Forest Weed Treatment Project FEIS provides guidance for proper weed treatment (USDA 2006)

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 610

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

and provides guidance for appropriate herbicides to be used. Herbicide application used to
control noxious weeds would adversely affect sensitive plant populations as described above
unless sensitive plant populations were protected.

Effects Common to All Action Alternatives

The effects common to all alternatives would apply to all action alternatives.

Alternative 1, No Action
Direct and Indirect Effects
There are numerous travel-ways that have known sensitive plant populations. Alternative 1 has
the highest amount of motorized travel-ways of all the alternatives.
Botrychium crenulatum has not been found to date on the Helena National Forest. This species
is associated with wetland habitats. This species was not found to-date in field surveys of the
area nor in FIA grid intensification which conducted in the project area. Wetlands, seeps and
springs would be protected from ground disturbance in the design criteria for this project.
Botrychium paradoxum is known from two populations on the Helena National Forest, of which
one was in the Divide Travel Plan area. The habitat for this species on the Helena National Forest
is open grassland and open grassland/sagebrush. The population is adjacent to the junction of
existing travel-ways as shown in Table 144.
Cypripedium parviflorum has not been found on the Helena National Forest. Its habitat is fens,
which are limited in extent within the project area. The habitat also includes damp mossy
woods, seepage areas and moist forest-meadow ecotones in valleys and lower elevations in the
mountains. These habitats are extremely limited in the project area.
Juncus hallii is known from several locations on the Helena National Forest. In the Divide project
area, Hall’s rush is documented in 18 locations, including sites discovered in 2009 and 2012
during project surveys. Of those, five populations of this species are known to exist within or
very close to road rights-of-way within the Divide Travel Plan area. The roads are shown in Table
145 by alternative.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis is known to occur on eight locations within road rights-of-way in
the project area as shown in Table 146.
Pinus albicaulis occurs in higher elevations throughout the Forest. In the Divide Travel Plan area,
whitebark pine is present on subalpine fir climax habitat types. This landscape does not contain
the elevations and sites where whitebark pine would be dominant. In the project area,
whitebark pine occurs on approximately 1,102 acres, identified from stand exam data,
silvicultural diagnoses and anecdotal evidence. Routes with proposed travel changes bisecting
whitebark pine stands are located in the vicinity of Bison Mountain, Treasure Mountain,
Josephine area, Bullion Parks, Luttrell Peak, upper Banner Creek, Chessman Reservoir and Ward
Gulch.
Polygonum douglasii ssp. austiniae has not been found on the Forest. The species has the
potential to exist in the project area on talus slopes, sparsely vegetated areas or along roads.
Schoenoplectus subterminalis is known only from the Indian Meadows Research Natural Area
and only in true fens. This species is associated with wetland habitats and fens which are limited

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 611

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

on the Forest. This species was not found in field surveys of potential wetlands in the area nor in
FIA grid intensification.

Conclusion
Overall, Alternative 1 has the lowest restriction of any alternative. This would be slightly less
restrictive than alternative 2 and substantially less restrictive than alternatives 3, 4 or 5.
Motorized wheeled vehicles would have the potential to introduce noxious weed seeds and
spread noxious weeds at a higher rate than over-snow vehicles or non-motorized means of
travel (Trunkle and Fay 2001).
Botrychium paradoxum populations: Alternative 1 would have a similar impact as alternative 2,
in that both alternatives leave the routes where Botrychium paradoxum is found open to
motorized use.
Juncus hallii populations: Alternative 1 closes 1859-E1 year-round, but leaves the other roads
open. Overall this alternative has potential for adverse impacts to the populations, although
road 1859-E1 is close to the populations and closing this route would benefit the populations.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis populations: Alternative 1 would have the most potential impact
to Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis by leaving all routes with populations open to wheeled
motorized vehicles.
Pinus albicaulis populations: Alternative 1 closes or limits travel to over-snow vehicles on seven
routes. Overall, this alternative provides some protection to the known populations by closing
three roads yearlong and limiting travel to over-snow on the remaining four routes.
Alternative 1 provides the least restrictions to motorized wheeled vehicles. This alternative
would have the highest direct impact on sensitive plant populations by leaving the above roads
and trails open. This alternative would also have the most potential for indirect impacts on the
populations due to the potential for introduction and spread of noxious weed seeds.
Design criteria would be applied to protect populations from ground disturbance activities
and/or herbicide application by implementing a 100-foot buffer around known or discovered
populations.

Irreversible/Irretrievable Commitments
There are no irreversible/irretrievable commitments that would affect sensitive plants under
this alternative as known populations would be protected from ground disturbance associated
with road maintenance or the use of herbicides.

Cumulative Effects
The cumulative effects analysis area is the Helena National Forest, as effects on plant
populations throughout the Forest are considered in determining potential impacts to the
overall population. Cumulative effects described here for the apply for the all five alternatives.
Cumulative effects from the list of projects noted in the appendix B would be minimal. The
projects that have occurred since 1993 have all had field surveys to determine whether sensitive
plant populations would be impacted by those actions. Where sensitive plant populations were
found, populations were appropriately buffered from treatment. The actions listed in appendix
B could impact individuals or habitat but will not likely contribute to a trend toward Federal
listing or cause a loss of viability to the populations or species.

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 612

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Past activities may have caused minor impacts to sensitive plants or their habitats. The effects of
past activities are reflected in the existing condition of the current sensitive plant populations.
Particularly for those sensitive species related to disturbance (moonworts, whitebark pine, some
habitats for Austin knotweed), these past actions likely resulted in mixed effects (possible
damage or loss of individuals, but improvement of habitat conditions in some affected areas).
Present/ongoing activities that could be contributing to cumulative effects are also described in
appendix B. There are only minor effects to sensitive plant habitats resulting from ongoing
activities, with a low probability of impacting individuals.
Reasonably foreseeable activities that could affect sensitive plants or their habitats are also
addressed in appendix B and the major activities and expected effects are summarized below:
For the reasonably foreseeable future, the following projects have been reviewed; Telegraph
Vegetation Project, Tenmile South Helena Project, Grassy Mountain Vegetation Project,
Stonewall Vegetation Management Project and Blackfoot NonWinter Travel Plan.
Telegraph Vegetation Project. This project would treat approximately 6,300 acres with a
combination of pre-commercial thinning, timber harvest and prescribed fire. Up to six miles of
new temporary road would be built. There are known populations of Pinus albicaulis and Juncus
hallii within the project area. Those populations have been identified and design criteria
appropriate for each species would protect populations.
Tenmile South Helena Project: This project would conduct fuel treatments for the purposes of
maintaining consistent water quantity and quality within Helena's municipal watershed and
improving conditions for public and firefighters safety across the landscape in the event of a
wildfire. There are known populations of Pinus albicaulis and Juncus hallii in the project area.
Surveys will be conducted prior to any ground disturbance. Design criteria would be
implemented as appropriate to protect any sensitive plant populations found.
Grassy Mountain Vegetation Project. This project would treat approximately 3,900 acres with a
combination of prescribed fire and timber harvest. Up to one-half mile of new temporary road
would be built. Intensive vegetation data collection in the project area was completed in 2006.
No sensitive plant populations were found during those surveys or previous surveys. If any
populations are found at any time they will be protected from ground disturbance or herbicide
application.
Stonewall Vegetation Management Project: This project would treat approximately 8,500 acres
with a combination of pre-commercial thinning, timber harvest and prescribed fire. Up to five
miles of new temporary road would be built. Field surveys of the proposed units and temporary
roads were completed in 2009. There are known populations of Pinus albicaulis in the project
area. Design criteria would protect all known sensitive plant populations as appropriate. If
additional sensitive plant populations are found at any time, they would be protected from
ground disturbance or herbicide application.
Blackfoot NonWinter Travel Plan: This decision would be to determine what roads would be
open to motorized traffic. The decision would also include prescriptions for closing routes which
would include ground disturbance. There are known sensitive plant populations of Drosera
anglica, Drosera linearis, Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis, Pinus albicaulis and Schoenoplectus
subterminalis within the project area that could potentially be affected. These populations have
been identified in the sensitive plant analysis and would be protected from ground disturbing

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 613

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

activities and herbicide application. Design criteria and monitoring would protect any sensitive
plant populations found.
Surveys are currently occurring or have been completed for reasonably foreseeable actions. If
populations have been/are found, they will be protected from ground disturbance or herbicide
application. For more information, please see the Cumulative Effects in appendix B to this
report.

Alternative 2
Direct and Indirect Effects
The routes affecting known sensitive plant populations are shown under alternative 1. The
impacts associated with alternative 2 are fewer than the impacts associated with alternative 1.
Overall, alternative 2 would only eliminate wheeled motorized use on approximately 132 miles
of the travel-ways in the Divide Travel plan area. This would be slightly more restrictive than
alternative 1, but substantially less restrictive than alternatives 3, 4 or 5. Motorized wheeled
vehicles would have the potential to introduce noxious weed seeds and spread noxious weeds
at a higher rate than over-snow vehicles or non-motorized means of travel (Trunkle and Fay
2001).

Conclusion
Botrychium paradoxum populations: Alternative 2 would have a similar impact as alternative 1,
in that both alternatives leave the routes where Botrychium paradoxum is found open to
motorized use.
Juncus hallii populations: Alternative 2 would limit road 1863 to over-snow, but would leave the
other roads open. This alternative is likely have the most potential impact to the species, as the
populations are closer to road 1859-E1 than to road 1863.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis populations: Alternative 2 is likely to have the potential for
impact (similar to alternative 1) to Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis by leaving all routes open to
wheeled motorized vehicles.
Pinus albicaulis populations: Alternative 2 provides some protection to populations by closing
three roads yearlong and limiting travel to over-snow on the remaining four routes.
This alternative would have a lower indirect impact on the populations, as compared to
alternative 1, in relation to the potential for introduction and spread of noxious weed seeds
throughout the travel plan area.
Design criteria would be applied to this alternative to protect populations from ground
disturbance or herbicide application within a 100-foot buffer as appropriate.

Irreversible/Irretrievable Commitments
There are no irreversible/irretrievable commitments that would affect sensitive plants under
this alternative as known populations would be protected from ground disturbance associated
with road maintenance or the use of herbicides.

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 614

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Cumulative Effects
Please see the cumulative effects section under alternative 1 for a description of projects. Under
alternative 2, the cumulative effects would likely be minimal as known plant populations would
be protected.
Surveys are currently occurring or have been completed for reasonably foreseeable actions. If
populations have been or are found, they will be protected from ground disturbance and
herbicide application. For more information, please see the Cumulative Effects appendix for the
sensitive species specialist report.

Alternative 3
Direct and Indirect Effects
The routes affecting known sensitive plant populations are shown under alternative 1.
Alternatives 3 and 4 would impose less impact by restricting the use of motorized vehicles more
than alternatives 1 or 2, although alternative 5 is the most restrictive. Alternative 3 would be
most beneficial to Botrychium paradoxum as compared to other alternatives. Alternative 3 and
4 both provide similar benefit to Juncus hallii, only slightly better than alternative 5. Alternative
3 would be slightly less beneficial to Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis as compared to alternatives
4 and 5, but more beneficial than alternatives 1 or 2.
Overall, alternative 3 would restrict motorized use on approximately199 miles of the travel-ways
in the project area. This would be less restrictive then alternative 5, but would provide better
long-term protection of sensitive plants by limiting potential exposure to noxious weed
infestations than alternatives 1 or 2.

Conclusion
Botrychium paradoxum populations: Alternative 3 would provide the most protection to this
species by closing both motorized routes year-round. This is the only alternative that closes
both routes.
Juncus hallii populations: Alternatives 3 and 4 provide the best protection for the plant
populations, by limiting all of the roads, affecting this population, except 1859-B1 to over-snow,
when minimal damage would be done.
Pinus albicaulis: Alternative 3 provides some protection to this species as it limits travel to oversnow vehicles on six routes as does alternative 4.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis populations: Alternative 3 would provide protection for known
populations by closing four of the five routes motorized vehicles either totally, or allows only
over-snow vehicles.
This alternative would have a substantially lower potential for indirect impact on the
populations as compared to alternatives 1 and 2 with regards to the introduction and spread of
noxious weed seeds throughout the travel plan area because motorized vehicle use would be
restricted.
Design criteria would be applied to this alternative to protect populations from ground
disturbance or herbicide application within a 100-foot buffer as appropriate.

There are no irreversible/irretrievable commitments that would affect sensitive plants under

Cumulative Effects
Please see the cumulative effects section under alternative 1 for a description of projects. Under
alternative 3, the cumulative effects would likely be minimal as no known plant populations

Alternative 4
Direct and Indirect Effects
The routes affecting known sensitive plant populations are shown under alternative 1.
Alternatives 3 and 4 would impose less impact by restricting the use of motorized vehicles more
than alternatives 1 or 2, although alternative 5 is the most restrictive. Alternatives 4 and 5 are
the most beneficial to Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis as compared to alternatives 1, 2 and 3.
Alternative 4 is slightly less beneficial to Botrychium paradoxum as compared to Alternative 3.
Overall, alternative 4 would restrict motorized use on approximately 187 miles of the travelways in the project area. This would be slightly less restrictive then alternative 3 but would
provide better long-term protection of sensitive plants by limiting potential exposure to noxious
weed infestations than alternatives 1 or 2.

Conclusion
Botrychium paradoxum populations: Alternative 4 would provide slightly less than alternative 3
protection by closing one of the routes that affect this population to motorized wheeled
vehicles year-round.
Juncus hallii populations: Alternatives 3 and 4 provide the best protection for the plant
populations, by limiting all of the roads with the exception of 1859-B1, which is open to oversnow vehicles, when minimal damage would be done to the plant species.
Pinus albicaulis populations: Alternative 4 provides some protection to this species as it limits
travel to over-snow vehicles on six routes as does Alternative 3.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis populations: Alternative 4 and 5 provide the best protection for
this species as they close all five open routes with populations.
This alternative would have a substantially lower potential for indirect impact on the
populations as compared to alternatives 1 and 2 with the lower potential for introduction and
spread of noxious weed seeds throughout the travel plan area because motorized vehicle use
would be restricted.

with road maintenance or the use of herbicides.

Alternative 5

The routes affecting known sensitive plant populations are shown under alternative 1.
Alternative 5 is the most restrictive alternative, but along with alternatives 3 and 4, impose the
least impact by restricting the use of motorized vehicles more than alternatives 1 and 2.
Alternative 5 is most beneficial to Pinus albicaulis. Alternative 5 provided similar benefit to Phlox
kelseyi var. missoulensis as compared to alternative 4.
Overall, alternative 5 would restrict motorized use on approximately 250 miles of the travelways in the project area. This would be the most restrictive alternative and would provide the
most long-term protection of sensitive plants by limiting potential exposure to noxious weed
infestations.

Conclusion
Botrychium paradoxum populations: Alternative 5 provides limited protection to this species by
limiting travel to vehicles less than 50 inches in width on routes that affect the population.
Juncus hallii populations: Alternatives 3 and 4 provide slightly better protection than alternative
5 for the plant populations, by limiting all of the roads with the exception of 1859-B1, which is
open to over-snow, when minimal damage would be done.
Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis populations: Alternatives 4 and 5 provide the best protection for
this species as it would close all five open routes with known populations.
Pinus albicualis: Alternative 5 provides the best protection for this species by closing or limiting
travel to over-snow on ten routes.
This alternative would have a substantially lower potential for indirect impacts on the
populations as compared to alternatives 1 and 2 with the lower potential for introduction and
spread of noxious weed seeds throughout the travel plan area because motorized vehicle use
would be restricted.
Design criteria would be applied to this alternative to protect populations from ground
disturbance or herbicide application within a 100-foot buffer as appropriate.

Irreversible/Irretrievable Commitments
There are no irreversible/irretrievable commitments that would affect sensitive plants under
this alternative as known populations would be protected from ground disturbance associated
with road maintenance or the use of herbicides.

Please see the cumulative effects section under alternative 1 for a description of projects. Under
alternative 5, the cumulative effects would likely be minimal as no known plant populations
would be

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

Conclusions
Alternative 1, No Action, would have the highest potential impact on sensitive plants by having
the least restriction on motorized wheeled vehicles.
Overall, alternatives 3, 4 and 5 would have the lowest level of potential to affect sensitive plant
populations by restricting motorized wheeled vehicle use, with alternative 4 or 5 providing the
most benefit to Phlox kelseyi var. missoulensis and alternative 3 being more beneficial to
Botrychium paradoxum. Alternatives 3 and 4 both offer similar benefit to Juncus hallii, which is
only slightly better than alternative 5. Alternative 5 would be most beneficial to Pinus albicaulis.
Alternative 2 would have more potential for adverse effects than alternatives 3, 4, or 5, but
somewhat less impact than alternative 1. With the design criteria and proposed mitigation, the
action alternatives may impact individuals, but would not contribute toward a trend for Federal
listing or loss of viability to any of the populations present.
Overall, alternative 5 would eliminate wheeled motorized use on approximately 250 miles of the
travel-ways in the Divide Travel Planning Area and would be the most restrictive alternative.
Alternative 4 would be slightly less restrictive than alternative 3; closing approximately 187
miles to wheeled motorized use compared to approximately 199 miles, but would provide
better long-term protection of sensitive plants by limiting potential exposure to noxious weed
infestations than alternative 1 and 2. Alternative 2 differs very little from alternative 1 in the
respect that it would only eliminate wheeled motorized use on approximately four miles.

Sensitive Plants Biological Evaluation
SPECIES- Botrychium crenulatum
Direct, Indirect and Cumulative Effects of Proposed Actions
This species is known from the Beaverhead-Deerlodge Forest, immediately adjacent to the
Helena National Forest. This species is associated with wetland habitats. This species was not
found in field surveys of the area nor in FIA grid intensification which included the project area.
Wetlands, seeps and springs would be protected from ground disturbance in the design criteria
for this project. Should any populations be found, a buffer would be established around each
plant population as a no-entry zone for equipment associated with road maintenance. This
species would be impacted by broadleaf herbicides. Should any populations be found, a 100foot buffer would be established around any populations and would become a no herbicide
zone. See cumulative effects section under alternative 1 and the cumulative effects appendix to
the sensitive species specialist report.

Determination
The decision may impact individuals but would not contribute toward a trend for Federal
listing or loss of viability because the design criteria described above would protect potential
habitat.

Alternative 3 would provide the best protection for this population as no motorized vehicles

potential impact as both routes would be open to motorized traffic. Alternative 4 would provide
some protection by closing trail 501 year-round.

specialist report.

Determination
The decision may impact individuals but would not contribute toward a trend for Federal
listing or loss of viability. The existing routes have been in place for many years and the
population has not been impacted. As long as the routes do not change location, direct impacts
to the population are unlikely. Indirect impacts due to noxious weeds would be more likely with
alternatives 1, 2 or 4. Alternative 3 would provide the best protection to this population.
Implementation of appropriate design criteria would provide additional protection to the
population from herbicides.

SPECIES- Cypripedium parviflorum:
Direct, Indirect and Cumulative Effects of Proposed Actions
This species has not been found on the Helena National Forest. The habitat is fens, which are
limited in extent on the forest. The habitat also includes damp mossy woods, seepage areas and
moist forest-meadow ecotones in valleys and lower elevations in the mountains. These habitats
would be protected by design criteria that limit ground disturbance in wet habitats.
If any populations are found in the future, a buffer would be established around each plant
population as a no-entry zone for equipment associated with road maintenance. This species

SENSITIVE PLANTS - 619

Divide Travel Plan

would be impacted by broadleaf herbicides. A 100-foot buffer around the known populations
would be a no herbicide zone. See cumulative effects section under alternative 1 and the
cumulative effects appendix to the sensitive species specialist report.

Determination
The decision may impact individuals but would not contribute toward a trend for Federal
listing or loss of viability. Design criteria as described above would protect potential habitat.

Alternatives 3 and 4 provide the best protection for the plant populations, by limiting all of the
roads except 1859-B1 to over-snow, when minimal damage would be done. Alternative 1 closes
1859-E1 year-round, but leaves the other roads open. Overall alternative 1 has potential for
adverse impacts to the populations, although road 1859-E1 is close to the populations and
closing this route would benefit the populations. Alternative 2 would limit road 1863 to oversnow, but would leave the other roads open. Alternative 2 would have the most potential to
impact the species, as the populations are closer to road 1859-E1 than to road 1863.
Ground disturbance would be the most likely direct impact to these populations. Wetlands,
seeps and springs would be protected from ground disturbance in the design criteria for this
project. A buffer would be established around each plant population as a no-entry zone for
equipment associated with road maintenance. This species would not be impacted by broadleaf
herbicides. Non-specific herbicides such as Roundup would damage the population. A 100-foot
buffer around the known populations would be a no herbicide zone if non-specific herbicides
were applied. See cumulative effects section under alternative 1 and the cumulative effects
appendix to the sensitive species specialist report.

Determination
The decision may impact individuals but would not contribute toward a trend for Federal
listing or loss of viability. The populations are all some distance from the road prisms and are
within wet areas. This species would not be impacted by most herbicides. The design criteria
associated with the project would protect the populations from disturbance. Road
maintenance in this area would be designed to protect the populations.

SPECIES- Pinus albicaulis
Direct, Indirect and Cumulative Effects of Proposed Actions
Pinus albicaulis occurs in higher elevations throughout the Helena National Forest. In the Divide
Travel Plan area, whitebark pine is present on subalpine fir climax habitat types. This landscape
does not contain the elevations and sites where whitebark pine would be dominant. In the
Divide Travel Plan area, whitebark pine occurs on approximately 1,102 acres, identified from
stand exam data, silvicultural diagnoses and anecdotal evidence. Routes with proposed travel
changes bisecting whitebark pine stands are located in the vicinity of Bison Mountain, Treasure
Mountain, Josephine area, Bullion Parks, Luttrell Peak, upper Banner Creek, Chessman Reservoir
and Ward Gulch.

Alternative 5 would provide the best protection for this species because it closes a total of 10
routes to motorized vehicles either totally or only allows over-snow vehicles which is more than
the other alternatives. Alternatives 3 and 4 limit travel to over-snow vehicles on six routes.
Alternative 1 closes or limits travel to over-snow vehicles on five routes. Alternative 2 only limits
travel to over-snow vehicles on four routes and therefore would have the most potential impact
to this species.
Live individuals would be retained where they occur and damage to this species or potential
habitat would be limited as no additional tread is proposed in any of the alternatives. The
greatest danger to this species would be from herbicide application or ground disturbance. A
buffer would be established around each plant population as a no-entry zone for equipment
associated with road maintenance. A 100-foot buffer around known populations would be
implemented as a no herbicide zone, unless site-specific exceptions were made by the Forest
Ecologist. See cumulative effects section under alternative 1 and the cumulative effects
appendix to the sensitive species specialist report.

Determination
The decision may impact individuals but would not contribute toward a trend for Federal
listing or loss of viability because the design criteria described above would protect individuals
and potential habitat.

SPECIES- Polygonum douglasii ssp. austiniae
Direct, Indirect and Cumulative Effects of Proposed Actions
This species is known to exist on Bureau of Land Management lands west of Highway 141,
immediately adjacent to the Helena National Forest. This species is known to occur on gravelly,
often shale-derived soil of open slopes and banks in the montane zone. Should any populations
be found, a buffer would be established around each plant population as a no-entry zone for
equipment associated with road maintenance. This species would be impacted by broadleaf
herbicides. Should any populations be found, a 100-foot buffer would be established around any
populations and would then become a no herbicide zone. See cumulative effects section under
alternative 1 and the cumulative effects appendix to the sensitive species specialist report.

Determination
The decision may impact individuals but is not likely to result in a loss of viability, nor cause a
trend toward Federal listing. The design mitigations as described above would protect
individuals and habitat.

SPECIES- Schoenoplectus subterminalis
Direct, Indirect and Cumulative Effects of Proposed Actions
This species is known from the Indian Meadows Research Natural Area in the northern portion
of the Forest in true fens. This species is associated with wetland habitats and fens which are
limited on the Forest. This species was not found in field surveys of potential wetlands in the
area nor in FIA grid intensification conducted within the project area. Wetlands, seeps and
springs would be protected from ground disturbance in the design criteria for this project.
Should any populations be found, a buffer would be established around each plant population
as a no-entry zone for equipment associated with road maintenance. This species would not be
impacted by broadleaf herbicides. Non-specific herbicides such as Roundup would damage the
population. A 100-foot buffer around the known populations would be a no herbicide zone for

Forest Plan Consistency
The Forest Plan direction for sensitive plants (USDA 1986, II/20) refers to the Endangered
Species Act and pertains only to listed species, none of which occur on the Helena National
Forest. Therefore, this direction is not applicable at this time. Subsequent guidance from the
Regional Office provides direction regarding sensitive plants and their habitats with which the
project as proposed is consistent.

NOXIOUS WEEDS
Regulatory Framework
The Plant Protection Act defines a noxious weed as “any plant or plant product that can directly
or indirectly injure or cause damage to crops (including nursery stock or plant products),
livestock, poultry, or other interests of agriculture, irrigation, navigation, the natural resources of
the United States, the public health, or the environment” (7 USC 104 § 7702, 2000). Montana
also has a Weed Control Act (7 Montana Code 22 §§ 2101 et seq., 2003) and while Montana
laws do not apply to federal lands, section 2814 of the Federal Noxious Weed Act of 1974, as
amended (7 USC 61 § 2814, 1990) 9 requires that federal land management agencies “complete
and implement cooperative agreements with state agencies regarding the management of
undesirable plant species on federal lands under the agency’s jurisdiction and establish
integrated management systems to control or contain undesirable plant species targeted under
cooperative agreements.”
The National Forest Management Act of 1976 (PL 94-588) under 36 CFR 219.10(b) states:
Sustaining ecological systems. The overall goal of the ecological element of sustainability is to
provide a framework to contribute to sustain native ecological systems by providing ecological
conditions to support diversity of native plant and animal species in the plan area. This will
satisfy the statutory requirement to provide for diversity of plant and animal communities based
on the suitability and capability of the specific land area in order to meet overall multiple-use
objectives (16 U.S.C. 1604(g)(3)(B)). Procedures developed pursuant to 219.1(c) for sustaining
ecological systems must be consistent with the following:
1. Ecosystem diversity. Ecosystem diversity is the primary means by which a plan
contributes to sustaining ecological systems. Plan components must establish a
framework to provide the characteristics of ecosystem diversity in the plan area.
2. Species diversity. If the Responsible Official determines that provisions in plan
components, in addition to those required by paragraph (b)(1) of this section, are
needed to provide appropriate ecological conditions for specific threatened and
endangered species, species-of-concern and species-of-interest, then the plan must
9 The Plant Protection Act repealed all sections, except section 2814, of the Federal Noxious Weed Act of 1974.

NOXIOUS WEEDS - 627

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

include additional provisions for these species, consistent with the limits of agency
authorities, the capability of the plan area and overall multiple-use objectives.
The Federal Noxious Weed Act of 1974 (7 USC 2801 et seq.; 88 Stat. 2148) provides for the
control and management of non-indigenous weeds that injure or have the potential to injure
the interests of agriculture and commerce, wildlife resources, or the public health. The act
requires that each federal agency develop a management program to control undesirable plants
on federal lands under the agency's jurisdiction; establish and adequately fund the program;
implement cooperative agreements with state agencies to coordinate management of
undesirable plants on federal lands; and establish integrated management systems to control
undesirable plants targeted under cooperative agreements. A federal agency is not required to
carry out management programs on federal lands unless similar programs are being
implemented on state or private lands in the same area.
Executive Order 13112 directs federal agencies to respond to invasive species that threaten
terrestrial and aquatic resources of the National Forest System (NFS) and to collaborate with
Federal, State and local partners to address invasive species that can spread from adjacent
lands.
The Forest Service (forest) adopted new guidelines for invasive species management in 2011 in
the form of a new Forest Service Manual (FSM) 2900. FSM 2900 was issued in order to comply
with EO 13112 and address adverse impacts from invasive species. FSM 2900 is also intended to
ensure, as a matter of policy, that all forest management activities are designed to minimize or
eliminate the possibility of establishment or spread of invasive species on NFS lands, or to
adjacent areas.
FSM 2080 Supplement R1 2000-2001-1 (USDA 2001) provided prevention and control measures
for resource groups. The supplement is no longer in use as result of the new FSM 2900.
However, similar prevention and control measures as those outlined in FSM 2080 (R1 20002001-1) will be carried forward into a new regional supplement to FSM 2900.
The Helena National Forest Weed Treatment Project FEIS (USDA 2006) provides environmental
standards and guidelines for control and management of noxious weeds, specifically the use and
effects of herbicide application.
The Montana Weed Control Act was established in 1948 to protect Montana from destructive
noxious weeds. This act, amended in 1991, established a set of criteria for the control and
management of noxious weeds in Montana. Noxious weeds are defined by this act as being any
exotic plant species that may render land unfit for agriculture, forestry, livestock, wildlife or
other beneficial uses or that may harm native plant communities (Grubb et al 2003). The State
of Montana maintains a Noxious Weed List for the State and individual counties may add
species at the country level as noxious that are not considered noxious at the State level. The
State list, with the appropriate county additions, as of December 2013 was used to identify
noxious species for this analysis. These lists are available in the project file.

Divide Travel Plan

Any soil disturbing activity with mechanized equipment has the potential to increase
noxious weed invasion or spread.
It is anticipated that weeds would continue to spread at a rate of approximately 8 to 12
percent on an annual basis (USDA 1998), without disturbance. The rate of spread could
increase in areas affected by ground disturbing activities.
Herbicide use in accordance with the requirements specified in the Helena National
Forest Weed Treatment Project FEIS (USDA 2006) is appropriate for noxious weed
management on infested lands.
The Forest noxious weed treatment program would continue to treat approximately 30
percent of the weeds within the project area annually, regardless of whether the project
occurs or not.

The paragraphs below define mapped weed acres and weed treatment acres as used in this
report.
Mapped Weed Acres: Mapped acres are reflected by polygons within which there is at least 1
percent noxious weed cover. There are weeds outside those polygons that are too scattered to
map, or are infestations that have not been discovered yet. The mapped acres are taken from
the layer containing invasive plant information, in the Helena National Forest geographical
information systems (GIS) database.
Weed Treatment Acres: Weed treatment acres for the purposes of this report are assumed to
be the total polygon acres described above.

Design Elements
FSM 2900 requires that all forest management activities are designed to minimize or eliminate
the possibility of establishment or spread of invasive species on National Forest System lands, or
to adjacent areas. The following best management practices are intended to satisfy that
requirement and were designed to minimize the spread of existing invasive plants and prevent
the colonization of new invasive plants within the project area.

Roads – Required Objectives and Associated Practices
1. Incorporate weed prevention into road layout, design and alternative evaluation.
Environmental analysis for road construction and reconstruction would include a weed
risk assessment.
2. Remove the seed source that could be picked up by passing vehicles and limit seed
transport in new and reconstruction areas.
a. Remove all mud, dirt and plant parts from all off road equipment before moving
into project area. Cleaning must occur off National Forest lands. This does not
apply to service vehicles that would stay on the roadway, traveling frequently in
and out of the project area.
b. Landings, skid trails and other areas of disturbance resulting from logging
activities would be monitored for weed infestations.
c. Clean all equipment prior to leaving the project site, if operating in areas
infested with new invaders as determined by the forest weed specialist.
Reference Contract Provision C/CT 6.626.

NOXIOUS WEEDS - 629

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

3. Re-establish vegetation on bare ground due to construction and reconstruction activity
to minimize weed spread.
a. Revegetate all disturbed soil, except the travel way on surfaced roads, in a
manner that optimizes plant establishment for that specific site, unless ongoing
disturbance at the site would prevent weed establishment. Use native material
where appropriate and available. Use a seed mix that includes fast, early season
species to provide quick, dense revegetation. To avoid weed contaminated
seed, each lot must be tested by a certified seed laboratory against the State
noxious weed lists and documentation of the seed inspection test needs to be
provided.
b. Use local seeding guidelines for detailed procedures and appropriate mixes. Use
native material where appropriate and available. Revegetation may include
planting, seeding, fertilization and weed-free mulching as indicated by local
prescriptions.
c. Monitor and evaluate success of revegetation in relation to project plan. Repeat
as indicated by local prescriptions.
4. Minimize the movement of existing and new weed species caused by moving infested
gravel and fill material. The borrow pit would not be used if new invaders, defined by
the forest weed specialist, are found on site.
5. Minimize sources of weed seed in areas not yet revegetated. If straw is used for road
stabilization and erosion control, it must be certified weed-free or weed-seed free.
6. Minimize roadside sources of weed seed that could be transported to other areas during
maintenance.
a. Look for priority weed species during road maintenance and report back to
district weed specialist.
b. Do not blade roads or pull ditches where new invaders are found.
c. Maintain desirable roadside vegetation. If desirable vegetation is removed
during blading or other ground disturbing activities, area must be revegetated
according to section (3) (a), (b), (c) above.
d. Straw used for road stabilization and erosion control would be certified weedfree or weed-seed-free.
7. Reduce weed establishment in road obliteration/reclamation projects. Revegetate
according to section (3) (a), (b), (c) above.

Information Used
A geodatabase contains numerous geospatial layers that provide the data used in this analysis.
This geodatabase is available in the project file. The layers include known locations of weed
infestations, watershed and stream information and habitat types. The data was compiled and
utilized to complete an invasive plant risk assessment.

Methodology and Scientific Accuracy
The methodology used in this analysis includes the best available data from the Helena National
Forest weeds database, geographic information system datasets, personal ground

NOXIOUS WEEDS - 630

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

reconnaissance of the project area and experience including vegetation monitoring from past
vegetation treatments on the Helena National Forest. Literature review has been completed of
available information on noxious weed species, habitat and the effects of disturbance on flora.
Various datasets were combined using a geographic information system. The data was then
analyzed and reviewed to assist in understanding the relationships and effects of travel routes
on weeds and other flora as well as influences from physical characteristics across the project
area such as landforms and landtypes.
Data used to generate statistics and information regarding existing condition and affected
environment were provided by the Helena National Forest GIS department in the form of a
geodatabase and based on inventories completed in field in the project area in 2003, 2009,
2010, 2011 and 2012. All raw numbers and calculations can be found in the project file.
Numbers are rounded to the nearest whole number and nearest percent.
The geographic analysis area for this proposal is defined as the project boundary. The
cumulative effects section extends beyond the project boundary. The project area is used as the
spatial boundary for direct and indirect effects. Bounding for the analysis of cumulative effects
of past, present and foreseeable future actions is also the project area. Past actions are
considered as part of the existing condition and future effects are considered for 10 years into
the future, which allows an adequate length of time to record vegetative changes relevant to
the purpose of this project. Effects associated with various actions are based on literature,
known weed infestations and specialist experience.

Noxious Weeds, Affected Environment
Analysis Area
The Divide Travel Plan analysis area was used as the analysis area for this project. A 100-foot
wide buffer was applied to all routes within the project area. This includes 1,751 acres and was
used as the analysis area for direct effects. Natural Resources Conservation Service 6th code
Hydrologic Unit Codes (HUCs) that had roads with noxious weed infestations within the buffer
were used for the affected environment discussion and the pesticide delivery analysis.
Weeds have been expanding on the Helena National Forest for many years. A variety of factors
has contributed to the spread of noxious weeds. According to inventory data compiled in 2011
in support of this analysis, there are over 23,000 acres of mapped noxious weed infestations on
the Helena National Forest and over 5,600 infested acres are in the Divide landscape, which
includes the project area. Noxious weeds are invasive by definition and are able to spread when
there are no natural enemies, pathogens, or ungulate grazing to keep them in check. The spread
of weeds is favored by wildfire and ground disturbance of any kind. More use by the public has
occurred across the Helena National Forest in the past few years due in part to increased OHV
use, recreation displacement from wildfire areas and travel plan closure areas, which place
more pressure on the remaining open areas.
Various methods of weed control are used. Herbicide application is the most common form of
control used in the project area. This analysis tiers to the Helena National Forest Weed
Treatment Project FEIS (USDA 2006) which provides environmental requirements and guidelines
regarding noxious weed treatment and herbicide effects. The Forest treats approximately onethird of the mapped weeds on an annual basis under the normal weed treatment program. The
areas scheduled for treatment in a given year are a combination of: acres associated with
projects with ground disturbing activities; travel and recreation corridors; and re-treatment of
NOXIOUS WEEDS - 631

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

existing infestations. Effectiveness monitoring is used to prioritize the roads and polygons that
need re-treatment.

Forest. There is an ongoing effort to accurately map the extent of weeds as new infestations
start every year and old infestations often expand. The following table reflects the mapped
infestations as of 2011 using the dominant noxious weed species in the infested area. Many

is of less, although increasing, concern in the Blackfoot area. Spotted knapweed is a dominant
weed species across all areas. Roadsides are an area commonly infested with noxious weeds.
Roads have high weed infestations due to several reasons: vehicles carry weed seeds, which are
dispersed along travel ways; roads are disturbed by maintenance activities on a regular basis,
which provides a ready seedbed for weed seeds, both the seeds dispersed by vehicles and those

mapped noxious weed infestations on the Forest. The areas affected by this project are all along
roadsides and as described above, these areas are susceptible to noxious weed infestation.

NOXIOUS WEEDS - 635

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

There are eight State of Montana noxious weed species of primary concern in terms of
level of infestation in the treatment area: spotted knapweed (Centaurea maculosa),
Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense), leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula),), oxeye daisy
(Leucanthemum vulgare), Dalmation toadflax (Linaria dalmatica), common toadflax
(Linaria vulgare), Orange hawkweed (Hieracium aurantiacum) and sulfur cinquefoil
(Potentilla recta). Cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum), although not listed as a noxious weed
in the state of Montana, is considered a “regulated plant” by the State and is a species
of concern on the Helena National Forest.
Many infested areas have more than one weed species present; Table 151 shows the
predominant species in the project area. Other common noxious weeds associated with
the “primary” weeds shown above include butter and eggs (Linaria vulgaris). In addition,
a given infestation may have more than one of the primary weed species present. For
example, spotted knapweed may be the primary mapped species, but Canada thistle is
often present as well. Details on additional species in a given infestation are available in
the GIS layer available in the project file.
Spotted knapweed (Centaurea maculosa) has the largest extent of infestation within
the project area. The species occurs along roadsides and throughout south facing areas
of past harvest, as well as in the natural grasslands. Spotted knapweed thrives in open
areas, with forest canopies of less than 20 percent closure. Spotted knapweed spreads
almost entirely by prolific seed production (Zouhar 2001a). This species has also been
shown to have allelopathic properties, secreting toxins that suppress the growth of
other plants, although resource competition is just as effective in its ability to dominate
areas (Zouhar 2001a).
Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense) has been mapped on a smaller area as compared to
spotted knapweed. This species spreads primarily by adventitious root buds that may
form new adventitious shoots can develop along the root at any location (Zouhar
2001b). Canada thistle is present in much of the project area, generally associated with
roadside disturbance or harvest disturbance. Its habitat is restricted to open areas of
less than 10 percent canopy closure.
Orange hawkweed (Hieracium aurantiacum) is one of the most dangerous weeds in the
project area (Stone 2010), although it is known only at one location. Orange hawkweed
forms a monoculture by establishing a dense mat of plants, lowers biodiversity and
reduces the forage value of grasslands for grazing animals. This plant is a successful
competitor, crowding out native, pasture and range species (Prather et al. 2003).
Hawkweed species are allelopathic (Murphy and Aarssen 1995). It hybridizes freely with
native and non-native hawkweeds (Rinella and Sheley 2002).
Leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula) is found in limited acreage within the project area. Leafy
spurge generally grows in clumps, producing stems up to 3 feet tall from caudices,
rhizomes and roots. It has an extensive underground rhizome and root system. Roots
can penetrate into the soil as far as 15 to 30 feet. Leafy spurge can rapidly invade
disturbed sites by establishing from seed and by sprouting from existing roots and root
crowns. Once established, leafy spurge tends to expand and persist (Simonin 2000;
Gucker 2010).
Sulfur cinquefoil (Potentilla recta) has limited mapped acreage. Populations in North
America are commonly associated with roadsides, vegetation disturbance, abandoned
agricultural fields and "waste areas." Sulfur cinquefoil can also invade native plant
NOXIOUS WEEDS - 635

Environmental Impact Statement

Divide Travel Plan

communities that are far from any apparent human disturbance and is now common in
natural grasslands and shrubby areas (Zouhar 2003c).
Oxeye daisy (Leucanthemum vulgare also known as Chrysanthemum leucanthemum) is
found along numerous roads and trails in the Divide landscape, although its mapped
acreage is limited. Besides reproducing vegetatively along a rhizome, oxeye daisy is a
prolific seed (achene) producer (Olson and Wallander 1999). Oxeye daisy reduces plant
species diversity in infested areas. Grazing by cattle in infested areas intensifies its
spread because they avoid the plant. Consequently, it forms dense populations. Oxeye
daisy has the potential of increasing soil erosion because bare soil is more prominent in
areas where high densities occur. Cultivation destroys oxeye daisy’s shallow root system
without difficulty (Mitich 2000). This plant can become noxious and is capable of taking
over and modifying natural areas, pasture and rangeland and may increase soil erosion
compared to native plant communities (Olson and Wallander 1999).
Dalmation toadflax (Linaria dalmatica) has a limited mapped acreage in the project
area. Toadflax has been shown to readily establish on open and disturbed sites where
competition from other plants is reduced (Zouhar 2003b). Dalmatian toadflax seeds may
be dispersed by cattle, deer and other browsing animals and the seeds can remain
viable after passing through the gastrointestinal tracts of cattle and possibly deer. This
species can also expand vegetatively by the formation of adventitious shoots from both
the tap and lateral roots (Zouhar 2003b). There is serious risk of infestation from
Dalmation toadflax, even though current infestation levels are thought to be very low.
Weeds are expected to increase in level of infestation and acres infested overall in the
project area in spite of the efforts of herbicide application for control. Weed seeds are
stored in the upper soil layers and will germinate over several years. This species is
difficult to control.
Common yellow toadflax, or butter and eggs, (Linaria vulgaris) infestations may be
included in the Dalmation toadflax mapped acreage for this project area. The two
species have similar characteristics. Butter and eggs has been shown to readily establish
on open and disturbed sites where competition from other plants is reduced (Zouhar
2003b). The seeds may be dispersed by water, ants, birds and rodents, but existing
infestations of butter and eggs appear to expand mainly by vegetative reproduction
rather than by seed (Pauchard et al. 2003; Zouhar 2003b). There is serious risk of
infestation from yellow toadflax even though current infestation levels are thought to
be very low.
Cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum) is a serious weed that competes with native vegetation
and fuels wildfires (Young et al 1987). Cheatgrass is listed as a regulated species on the
Montana State Noxious Weed list and has not been mapped on the Helena National
Forest. It is established along numerous roadsides and other areas of disturbance in
Montana. Cheatgrass spread rapidly through sagebrush ranges following World War II
and has been expanding its range ever since. Disturbance by spring grazing or even
rodent activity is sufficient to perpetuate cheatgrass reproduction (Zouhar 2003a).
Cheatgrass is highly adaptable and has increased on lands around the Helena National
Forest over the past 30 years.

Effects Common to All Alternatives

The Forest treats approximately one-third of its mapped weeds on an annual basis
under its normal weed treatment program; therefore, one-third, or 525 of the 1,751
acres of weeds along travel routes, would be treated annually. Herbicide treatment of
these acres would have an average cost of about $51 per acre for easily accessible sites
(≤200 feet of a road and on slopes <40 percent) and $65 per acre for areas with more
difficult terrain (>200 feet from a road and on slopes >40 percent). The cost of biocontrol is included in these prices. An average cost of $58/acre is used to calculate costs.
Appendix A of the noxious weed specialist report outlines the weed control costs by
method of treatment and can be found in the project file.

area. This table does not include the cost of monitoring. This cost is not included in
further analysis of the alternatives as it is assumed to be a baseline, independent of
management actions and common to all alternatives.
